New York City schools will have roughly 5 percent, or $405 million, of their overall budget trimmed for the 2009-10 school year. Schools that had spent less than what they were budgeted for this year will be able to roll over their savings to next year to help cushion their cuts.

A checklist of requirements for renters last Sunday with an article about new residents in New York City misstated one element of the formulas for tenants’ and guarantors’ annual income. Tenants should have annual income that is at least 40 times the monthly rent, not the annual rent, and guarantors’ annual income should be at least 70 times the monthly rent, not the annual rent.

A review on May 10 about the BMW 335d and X5 xDrive 35d attributed a distinction erroneously to their twin turbocharged diesel engine. This type of engine was previously offered in the United States in the Volkswagen Touareg V-10 TDI and in some heavy-duty trucks; the 335d and X5 35d were not “the nation’s first” with such engines.

To the Editor: Your article “Europe on Two Borrowed Wheels” (May 3), on bicycling in Europe, evoked fond memories of our trip to Italy last year. Hotel Verona in the city of Verona provided free bicycles for my wife and me. Cycling around that lovely city on a Sunday was a highlight of our entire trip. We rent bicycles on all our overseas trips. Not only is cycling a healthy activity, it is a great way to see a city or the countryside. Bicycles can also be rented in many Asian cities. We were pleasantly surprised to find excellent bicycles for rent in Vietnam and Laos for a couple of dollars for an entire day. One word of advice: watch how bicycle-riding locals make left-hand turns at crowded intersections.

To the Editor: Your recent article by Somini Sengupta, “A Walk in Calcutta” (May 3), was an engrossing one. Her coverage of the historical, social, political and gastronomical facets of Kolkata brought a nostalgic flavor to me. However, I do not know why she missed mentioning two historic figures of the city: Swami Vivekananda and Ramakrishna Paramahansa. The fundamental changes in the socio-religious outlook of Bengal and consequently in India were brought about by these personalities. The Ramakrishna Mission Institute of Culture at Belur Math should have had some place in Somini Sengupta’s otherwise highly readable travelogue.

The White House announced on Saturday the nomination of Charles F. Bolden Jr., a former space shuttle astronaut and Marine general, to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A White House official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the decision, said the announcement was timed to take advantage of the attention paid to the current mission of the space shuttle Atlantis; its astronauts made repairs to the Hubble Space Telescope in recent days. The shuttle had been scheduled to return to Earth first on Friday and then on Saturday. With bad weather at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, NASA delayed the landing to Sunday.

CHILDREN OF MEN A Blu-ray upgrade for Alfonso Cuarón's dystopian science-fiction film of 2006, set in a near future when humans have lost the ability to reproduce. It's up to Clive Owen to rescue the world's last expectant mother (Clare-Hope Ashitey). With Michael Caine and Julianne Moore. The movie ''may be something of a bummer,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times in 2006, ''but it's the kind of glorious bummer that lifts you to the rafters, transporting you with the greatness of its filmmaking.'' (Universal, $29.98, R) FALLING DOWNJoel Schumacher's 1993 film, about a Los Angeles engineer (Michael Douglas) who goes on a rampage after being fired, gets a remastered rerelease. ''There are movies that honestly hit a raw nerve and others that cynically push your buttons, and 'Falling Down' is a push-your-buttons film,'' Caryn James wrote in The Times in 1993. (Warners, Blu-ray $34.99, two-disc standard definition $19.98, R)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending May 9, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Texas has always been a team that has had more power than it knew what to do with but not enough pitching to compete. That has made it seem as if the Ballpark at Arlington is merely a training ground for hitters who go on to success with other teams, like Mark Teixeira of the Yankees and Carlos Pena of the Tampa Bay Rays. But this season, the Rangers' pitching has finally been good enough to give their hitters a chance. It has been a new world for a staff ranked in the middle of the pack in the American League with a 4.52 earned run average through Saturday. Last season, the Rangers had a 5.37 E.R.A., the worst in the major leagues.

PHOTOGRAPHING AN OASIS IN THE DUNES NEAR ZAAFRANE, TUNISIA Karin Sherman, 60, a homemaker from Larchmont, N.Y., Oct. 31, 2008. ''Five of us were traveling -- we're all photographers and we all like to go to unusual places. We would never go to Rome, that's just too boring. This was our first trip that we organized by ourselves without a guide, truly based on five people's wants and desires. Seeing a desert was one of our big goals, and we all felt the desert in one area did not resemble the desert in another area, which was really surprising. The sand was different, the horizons even looked different. The oases that we visited were such pleasurable stops. You could see why caravans really looked out for these things, because there's nothing else around. You wonder how palm trees could possibly be in this location because there doesn't seem to be any source of water, but there is. The other thing was: you really do see mirages. I mean, that sparkling water in the distance, you swear it's there and you'll walk and you'll walk and after a half a mile, you'll realize, maybe it's really not there.'' As told to Seth Kugel

To the Editor: ''It's No Time to Stop This Train'' (Economic View, May 17), which argued that the Obama administration needs to avoid a mistake made by the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1936: reversing the stimulus program too soon over a fear of inflation. Although there are some similarities between the economic crises of the 1930s and today -- both were systemic failures rather than mere cyclical downturns -- there are also huge differences. One of the biggest is in the monstrous and rapidly growing government debt. If the next crisis is precipitated by the Chinese declining to purchase United States government debt, some people will argue that we should have seen it coming and will criticize government for not cutting deficits sooner. I think that no one knows the correct course of action, and that the best we can hope for is that government doesn't make the situation worse, as it did in the 1930s. I'm not optimistic.

Men, once limited to an unyielding style of dress, began to stretch their wings in the peacock revolution of the hippie era. These days the traditional co-exists with the far-fetched, like an oversize T-shirt with a ruffled hem. Highlights of spring include: business suits bicycling to work, a revival of the sports jacket, cuffed 1950's jeans, brown shoes without socks, and for a daring few, gold shoes, even gold sneakers with Mercury wings. A few very young men enjoy futuristic fabrics and tailoring. And one celebrated the arrival of fine weather with a philodendron-pattern suit and a matching shirt with a real leaf in the buttonhole.

The stock market edged up slightly for the week, despite concern in the bond and currency markets about rising United States government debt. The difficulties of the dollar and the 10-year Treasury note were exacerbated by a warning directed at Britain. Standard & Poor's said that the pristine rating of Britain's sovereign debt might be downgraded if economic conditions deteriorated further and the British debt load continued to grow. The situation of the United States bears some similarities to Britain's, although there are significant differences -- among them, the dollar's global status as a reserve currency.

THE NEWS In a speech at the National Archives, President Obama defended his plans to close the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to move some detainees to United States prisons, and to prosecute some of them in civilian courts and others in military tribunals. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Obama sought to rebut criticism from all sides -- from fellow Democrats in Congress, who blocked money for closing the center and want detainees kept out of the United States; from rights advocates, who want an end to indefinite detention and military trials; and from former Vice President Dick Cheney, who called Mr. Obama's policies ''recklessness clothed in righteousness.''

Inspired painter and poet, raconteur, world traveler, Hawkeye, craftsman, opera lover and dapper dresser, Thor taught us how to savor life; as devoted husband to our dearest Jane, he taught us how to love. Donations may be sent to The Thor Rinden Fund, Cape Regional Medical Center Foundation, 2 Stone Harbor Blvd. Cape May Court House, New Jersey.

The rookie right-hander Ricky Romero was a big reason that what figured to be a mess of a Toronto rotation at the start of the season quickly turned into a strength. Romero, left, won two of his three starts, with a 1.71 earned run average, before straining an oblique muscle and going on the disabled list. Even though three minor league rehab starts were less than scintillating, the Jays will look to Romero to help settle things down after the rookies Brett Cecil and Robert Ray were exposed by the Red Sox. The Mets' John Maine took a step back in his loss to the Dodgers last week, but he has a chance to get healthy again with two starts at Citi Field. Maine has allowed four hits in his last 12 innings at home, and he draws the Nationals and Marlins this week.

TOLK--Sylvia Coe, 82, died peacefully at home on January 4th. Sylvia had an adventurous and indomitable spirit. Born and raised in New York, after graduating from Vassar College she worked in TV production, in its early days. She moved to Zermatt, Switzerland, to work in a hotel, skiing in the winter and climbing in the summer. She was the first woman to climb all four faces of the Matterhorn, a record she was pleased to say "could never be beaten". A distinguished commercial and fine artist, her other passions included trekking, sailing, tennis, dancing, studying languages, her sheepdog Pandora, San Francisco MOMA, Elkhorn Ranch and travel of all kinds. And she was a lifelong devotee of live theater, staffing the library at ACT (American Conservatory Theatre) on Fridays as a volunteer for many years. Sylvia moved to San Francisco in 1965, with her husband, the late Bernard Tolk. She is survived by her sister Rosalie Coe Weir, and by the children and grandchildren of her cherished late brother Henry (Tony) Coe. A memorial will be held on Friday, June 5th at 10:30am at her beloved ACT (American Conservatory Theatre) at 415 Geary Street (between Mason and Taylor), San Francisco.

ROLLS-ROYCE, which enjoyed a 20 percent sales increase in 2008, is bracing for another strong year in 2009. In fact, the luxury automaker announced this week that it would be increasing its manufacturing work force by 50 percent. The company said in a news release that it was looking for craftsmen to work in its paint, leather and woodworking shops. Although the company laid off several dozen temporary workers late last year and idled its factory for a few weeks as orders slowed slightly around the holidays, a rush of orders has been received for its new, smaller Ghost model. The concept was unveiled last month at the Shanghai auto show, and the production version should be ready to make its official debut at the Frankfurt Motor Show in September.

MORRIS--Wayne J.,passed away suddenly on November 27, 2008. Born May 24, 1954 to John and Edith. Wayne is survived by his beloved wife Tracy, brothers: John, Ray and Ronnie, sisters-in-law: Denise, Rita and Deborah, mother-in-law, Martha, four nieces, one nephew as well as other extended family members and many, many wonderful friends. We remain shocked and profoundly saddened by this devastating loss. Wayne was such a special person; he loved traveling, reading, gardening, carpentry, music and history. He loved nothing more than to spend vacations in France. Wayne brought a special light and presence everywhere he went. He truly made this world a better place and is missed dearly by all who had the good fortune to know him. His family appreciates the many expressions of love, respect and kindness received as they mourn their loss. My husband, my best friend, my beloved-always, Dublavey and Poupette.

OUTPOSTS On a day not long after Californians showed they may be ready to pull the plug on the bankrupt citizen-democracy they have created, it's worth going back a few years to a moment when this divorce could have been predicted. The prison guards' union, having swelled its well-paid ranks after voter mandates helped to produce a system where 750,000 Californians are either locked up, on parole or on probation, was upset at Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger for balking at their demands. The union trolled a billboard around town of a nearly naked and decidedly unbuff Governator in a thong. That'll show him who's the girly man.

FARBER--Rhonda, 58, of Fort Lee, NJ died peacefully on May 21, 2009 leaving behind beloved husband, Robert, adoring son, Jonathan, loving mother, Phyllis, and caring sister, Cheryl.

McNAMARA--Brooks, died on May 8, in Doylestown, PA. He was 72. Mr. McNamara held a bachelor's degree from Knox College, a master's degree from the University of Iowa, and a Ph.D. in theater history from Tulane University. Mr. McNamara was a professor emeritus in the Department of Performance Studies, Tisch School of the Arts, New York University, and founding director of the archives of the Shubert Organization. He held a Fulbright Senior Research Fellowship and a Guggenheim Fellowship. His was a Fellow of the American Theater, and served on the boards of the Theater Library Association, the American Society for Theater Reseach, and the Doylestwon Historical Society. A scholar of American theater history and popular entertainment, he was author or editor of more than a dozen books, including Step Right Up: The American Meidicne Show; The New York Concert Saloon; The Devil's Own Nights; and The Merry Muldoons and the Brighteyes Affair, for children. He is survived by wife, Nan, his daughter and son-in-law Jane McNamara and John Oddy, his son and daughter-in-law Whitney and Mona McNamara and his grandchildren, James Brooks Oddy, Gwendolyn Claire McNamara, George Jansen Oddy and Thomas Carlin McNamara. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Scott McNamara and Carol Wittels, his sister-in-law Sally Kuder and his mother-in-law Nan Jansen. Services will be held on Saturday May 30 at 3pm in Saint Paul's Lutheran Church, North Main and Spruce Streets, Doylestown, PA.

KAPELL--Elise W.,died peacefully in Daytona Beach, FL on May 10th at the age of 94. She is survived by family members in New York City, Miami, Argentina and Israel. Preceded in death by her parents, William and Celia Witzling, her sisters Helen Glazer and Claire Strauss, and her beloved husband of almost 50 years, Bernard Kapell. Elise was born in New York City, a graduate from Hunter College, and indeed a remarkable woman, first in business with Bernard and then as a member of the National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section, where she became a staunch supporter of multiple just causes. For over 30 years she was at the United Nations representing the International Council of Jewish Women of which she was a life member of its Board of Directors. Her fluency in Spanish contributed to her success in international affairs, particularly those related to the aging population, appearing as invited speaker at the World Assembly on Aging in Vienna (1982) and Madrid (2002). Her social skills attracted numerous prominent people in diplomacy and politics whom she entertained both at the United Nations and at her home in New York. Her last four years were spent in Daytona Beach, where she was splendidly attended by her caregivers. Her philanthropy and voluntary work reached several institutions in music and the arts. She leaves a cohort of cherished friends whose lives were touched by her wisdom and love. A Memorial Service was conducted at Temple Beth-El in Daytona. Interment will be at the Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield Gardens, NY on May 28 at 11am. Donations in her memory may be made to the Elise Kapell High Holidays Memorial Fund at Temple Beth-El, 595 North Nova Road, Ormond Beach, FL 32174.

LANG--Paula Prager, passed peacefully at 11am Saturday, May 16 from complications of aortic stenosis. She was 98 years old and is survived by her son, Fred Prager, daughter-in-law Eileen Prager, grandsons Ian and AJ Prager and nephew Alan Kafton. Born Paula Sherzer in Brooklyn, New York on March 23, 1911, she began working in the coal business in the 1930s. She started the Susquehanna and Chesapeake Coal Companies in the late 30s and as the first woman owner of a coal company, she disarmingly signed her name "Paul Sherzer." After the war, Paula moved to Los Angles, California where she spent most of her life, never losing her Brooklyn accent or New York sense of humor. She was a life force and the center of action for a large group of friends and family. Her zest for life was total and Paula got great joy from any child within reach, making a point of squeezing every tusch, cheek or body part close by. An incredibly positive attitude was her hallmark and she never waivered in her acceptance and love of everybody she encountered. Affectionately known as Grandma Paula or "GP," she will be missed but never forgotten.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

THE buzz around the collector-car world for quite some time has been the possible emergence of early Japanese cars as collectibles. Few have hit the radar as mainstream collectibles. The ultra-rare Toyota 2000GT, the Datsun Fairlady Roadster and the Datsun 240Z are the only Japanese cars that show up regularly at collector-car auctions. Until last weekend, there have been few if any large collections of Japanese cars sold en masse in the United States. The Jack Safro Estate Collection, which was auctioned last weekend at the Mecum Original Spring Classic Auction in Indianapolis, may have been the first such collection to sell publicly.

KASARSKY--Leon. In loving memory of a sweet, good man, loyal and true to his family, friends and country. Beloved by his late siblings, Gladys and Sidney. Remembered with much love by his brother Irving and sister-in-law Lynne.

RINDEN--Thor, 72, of Brooklyn and Stone Harbor, NJ, died May 19. Born in Marshalltown, IA in 1937, he graduated from the University of Iowa. After serving in the Army in Southeast Asia and Alaska, he moved to New York and received an M.A. in Art from Hunter College. His eloquently-crafted paintings are in many private and university collections. A book of his poetry and drawings is being published this month. His wife Jane survives him.

LEFFERTS--Cynthia, of New York and St. Huberts, NY, died peacefully in her Manhattan home on May 8. She was 80. Cynthia had been ill for some years with primary progressive aphasia. She was valiant at every turn. Cynthia leaves many loving friends and family members, including two nieces and two nephews: Susan Lefferts of Salem, OR; Sarah Lefferts of Portland, ME; Thomas Lefferts of South China, ME; and Nicholas Lefferts of Denver, CO. Independent in mind and spirit, Cynthia had a keen interest in politics and in the life of the nation. Her working life was marked by high ideals. She began her career in 1951 as an administrative assistant at the Ford Foundation; she went on to serve as executive secretary of the New York State Commission on Government Operations of the City of New York and later of the New York State Moreland Commission on Welfare. She was a special assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller from 1963 to 1966, and then worked devotedly for Common Cause, serving in the 1970s as executive director of its New York office. Cynthia was born in Santa Barbara, CA, in 1928, while her parents, Halleck Lefferts and Sarah Barney Lefferts, were on the faculty of the Thacher School in nearby Ojai. Her brothers Barney and Charlie died before her, in 1976 and 1995. Cynthia was educated at Concord Academy and the Winsor School, and graduated from Vassar College in 1951. From an early age, Cynthia loved the mountains, lakes, and streams of the Adirondacks, where she had a second home. When the effects of polio kept her off the highest peaks, she continued to walk, hike, and swim with vigor, and she took up tennis with a gracious tenacity. She was a longtime member of the Ausable Club in St. Huberts and a trustee of the related Adirondack Mountain Reserve. In 2007 Cynthia was given the Harold Weston Award for "personal dedication to the unique spirit and qualities" of the AMR. She also served on the board of managers of the Havens Relief Fund Society in New York. She was especially proud to be a trustee of the Pomfret School in Pomfret, CT, where her father had been headmaster. Cynthia's grace and courage were inspiration and example to her friends and family. She had steel in her sinews, but she was never hard. She was kind and fair-minded, and naturally elegant. A memorial service will be held this summer in Keene Valley, NY, in the Adirondacks.

FRASER--Liza, 41, on May 21, 2009 after sudden illness. Born London. Adoring mother of Harrison. Dedicated daughter of Ann and Jimmy. Beloved wife of Ron. Dear sister of Krister and Justin and radiant friend to so many. Missed by all. In lieu of flowers, please support Harrison Fraser's Education Fund.

HEALY--Nicholas J.,of Glengarriff, Ireland, formerly of Garden City, NY, died at age 99 on May 20, 2009, at his home in Ireland, of natural causes. He was the founding partner of the distinguished maritime law firm of Healy & Baillie, LLC He is survived by his loving children: Nicholas Jr. of Naples, FL, Margaret Parker of Glen Rock, NJ, Rosemary Bell of Naples, FL, Mary Louise White of Garden City, NY; Donall of New York City, Kathleen Hamon of Harrisville, NH, 21 grandchildren, 21 great-grandchildren and his sister Marjorie Borden of King of Prussia, PA. His beloved wife of 66 years, Margaret Ferry, died in 2003. A wake will be held at Perazzo's Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York, NY, 2 - 5:00pm and 7 - 9:00pm Monday, May 25. Funeral Mass at 10:00am on Tuesday, May 26, St. Joseph's Church, 371 Sixth Ave., New York, NY, Contributions may be made to the Nicholas J. Healy Lecture on Admiralty Law, Development Office, NYU, 161 Sixth Ave., NYC, NY 10013.

CRESHKOFF--Lawrence, died on May 21 at his home in New York of pancreatic cancer. Born in Philadelphia in 1924, he graduated cum laude from Harvard in 1947, having served in the Navy during the war. He worked in radio broadcasting at what was to become WGBH, where he met Nancy Freeman; they married in 1953 and spent a year in Paris on a Fulbright fellowship. He worked as an editor in educational radio and TV, gave time to education and fair-housing causes and cared for Nancy during the last decade of her life. He enjoyed intelligent conversation and planting trees at the family farm in Maryland. He is survived by stepchildren Mary Harper of Oakland, CA, and Frederick Harper of New York; daughters Maggie of Port Deposit, MD, and Rebekah of New York; two granddaughters; and two great-grandchildren. A gathering will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please consider a memorial gift to VNSNY Hospice Care.

HERR--Alva Susan Mendels July 15, 1940 - May 8, 2009 Daughter of the late David ("Dudley") Nathaniel Mendels and Sarah Rachel Mendelsohn Mendels, both of Montreal; Alva is survived by her sister Louisa Margaret Mendels of Montreal and New York; her husband Robert C. Herr, of Berkeley, CA, and her son David C. Herr, of El Cerrito, CA; her brother- and sister-in-law Richard and Eugenia Herr of Navarro, CA; her nephew John Herr of San Anselmo, CA, and grandnieces Jackie and Shannon; and her niece Serena Herr, of San Anselmo, CA, and grandnephew Ryan and grandniece Anika. Great friend to Irene Davis, of Vallejo, CA, and Mrs. Davis' daughter Sonja Nelson of Oakland, CA; Carlos Privat and his entire family, of Oakland and San Francisco, CA; Barbara Kernan of Maryland; and the late Earline Aitkens, of New Orleans and Berkeley. Alva was raised in Montreal, Canada, and obtained her Bachelor of Arts from Smith College in Massachusetts and her Master's degree of Library Science from the School of Librarianship at UC Berkeley, where she met her husband. A resident of Berkeley, CA, for over 40 years, she loved opera, ballet, music (especially Elton John), the arts, her wonderful garden, and the cats and rabbits taken in by her son and his girlfriend, Rachel Post. A self-taught expert on finance, she foresaw the current economic meltdown years ago. She was devoted to her family, and they to her. At Alva's request there will be no services. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may send contributions in her memory to: Disabled American Veterans, Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH 45250; or the Canadian National Institute for the Blind, 1929 Bayview Ave., Toronto, ON M4G 3E8, Canada.

When I first left, people would stop me after one sentence and they'd be like, 'Where is your accent from? Where do you come from?' Not very far: from Brooklyn. Life was very small. Everything was within a few blocks from the house -- the outside world didn't really exist. You live in New York, but you're not really in New York. There's a purpose to every day, everything has a meaning, everything you're doing is for a reason.

BROWNSTONE--Nathan. 1912-2008. Fondly remembered by sons, Mark and Robert, brother, Charles, grandchildren, Ari and Liza and by friends and family everywhere. Poet, musician, scholar and educator, Nathan made the world a better place.

ROCHMAN--Morton, in his 76th year, on May 21. Adored and devoted husband for 54 years of his high school sweetheart Barbara. His children, Diane (Rich), Larry (Leslie) and David (Diane) will miss his unconditional love, guidance and energetic support. His beloved grandchildren Paul, Zoe, Laura, Max, James and Noah will always remember Poppy's optimism, wisdom, fairness, curiosity, zest for life and endless love. To his sister Toby (Michael), he was the best traveling companion. To his brother-in-law Neil (Susan), a terrific guy who enjoyed a great scotch and a laugh. A graduate of Cornell (class of '54), he served in the air force and enjoyed a long career at Northrop Grumman. He leaves a huge circle of friends. Morty, Mr. Fixit, was a Mensch. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Cornell Engineering School, Ithaca, NY.

Recently, the Consults blog took questions from readers about autopsy, "Should You Have an Autopsy Done?" Stephen A. Geller, M.D., wrote in:In late 1968, when I was chief resident in the Department of Pathology at the The Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, the senior surgical pathologist, my teacher, who had many medical problems, rolled up his shirt sleeve and brought my finger to a firm tumor under his forearm skin, telling me his diagnosis. "When you do my autopsy," he said, "don't forget this." A native of Japan who had studied in Germany, he had been at Mount Sinai for almost 40 years and was regarded, by those who knew him or of him, as one of the greatest surgical pathologists. I had the great privilege to perform the autopsy a few months later. His diagnosis, of course, was correct.

The 10th film from Pixar, ''Up,'' pictured above, opens on Friday. The movie stars Edward Asner as Carl, a crusty old man who sets off on a balloon adventure with Russell, a young stowaway, and Dug, a dog they find in South America. ''Up'' opened the Cannes Film Festival this year, the first animated film to do so. Pixar's films have mostly been critical and commercial successes. ''Ratatouille,'' released in 2007, and ''Wall-E,'' from 2008, were the studio's two worst performers but each film still took in more than $200 million.

MERJAN--Florence L.,born May 14, 1929 in Hyde Park, MA, beloved wife, mother, and grandmother. She passed peacefully on May 23, 2009 in the presence of her family. She was a graduate of Pembroke College and worked as a clinical psychologist for the US Department of the Navy and Community Services of Nassau County. She is survived by Stanley, her loving and devoted husband of 55 years; his sister, Sue Allen; her children Barbara, David, and Alice; and grandchildren, Jake, Julia, Alexandra and Olivia. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday May 26th at 12:30 at Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Heart Fund of St. Francis Hospital, Manhasset, NY.

MARIA DE BARROS ''Morabeza'' (Sheer Sound) Born in Senegal, chiefly raised in Mauritania and wholly devoted to the culture of Cape Verde, Maria de Barros practices an open-minded approach to tradition. Like the august Cesária Évora, her godmother and beacon, she often sings the serene, plaintive folk music known as morna, applying her richly rounded alto to songs of reflection and longing. But on each of her three albums, now including ''Morabeza,'' she has also mixed in other styles, including a high-gloss hybrid best described as global pop.
LUBALIN--Herb. 1918-1981. Lovingly remembered always Rhoda Sparber Lubalin

ENRICH--Esther Prager, 88, died peacefully after a full life and a long illness on May 23. She is survived by her devoted children, Katherine Sacks, Peter Enrich, and Deborah Enrich, and by her five loving grandchildren. Services will be at graveside at Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Sawmill River Rd. (Rte. 9A), Hastings-on-Hudson, at 1pm on Tuesday, May 26, with a gathering for remembrances at her home immediately following.

When it comes to technology innovation and investment, Waltham, Mass., and Route 128 were once compared with Menlo Park, Calif., and Sand Hill Road. But is the Boston region losing its entrepreneurial edge? The latest evidence that it may be: Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm that was founded in Massachusetts in 1965, is moving its headquarters to Silicon Valley.

KRAININ--Dr. Ralph, dentist and longtime resident of Rye Brook, NY, passed away on May 23rd in New York City. Dedicated to supporting communities in need, he played an active role on many boards and committees throughout New York, and was Past President of Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel. Funeral services will be held Tuesday 1pm at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions should be made to the N.Y. Theological Seminary Sing Sing Program.

Survived by daughters Robin and Sandy, sons-in-law Peter and Steve, grandchildren Laura, Elisa, and Holly. Donations to National Parkinson's Foundation in memory of Evelyn Cohen.

ZAP MAMA ''ReCreation'' (Heads Up International/Concord) ''Vibrations,'' a dizzying song from the new Zap Mama album, doesn't have profound lyrics. They're along the lines of ''Everything in our universe consists of vibrations.'' Its joy lies in its music, with two alternating beats (one muffled, one crisp) below swampy electronics, distorted guitar, sputtering hand drums and vocal sounds appearing from every direction. Groups of women harmonize, ''Stay positive!'' and hoot quiet syllables in the background, alongside male grunts and percussive breaths. Marie Daulne's lead vocal darts above them all, singing long lines in Bjork-like leaps, whimsical and surefooted.

KAPELL--Elise W.,died peacefully in Daytona Beach, FL on May 10th at the age of 94. She is survived by family members in New York City, Miami, Argentina and Israel. Preceded in death by her parents, William and Celia Witzling, her sisters Helen Glazer and Claire Strauss, and her beloved husband of almost 50 years, Bernard Kapell. Elise was born in New York City, a graduate from Hunter College, and indeed a remarkable woman, first in business with Bernard and then as a member of the National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section, where she became a staunch supporter of multiple just causes. For over 30 years she was at the United Nations representing the International Council of Jewish Women of which she was a life member of its Board of Directors. Her fluency in Spanish contributed to her success in international affairs, particularly those related to the aging population, appearing as invited speaker at the World Assembly on Aging in Vienna (1982) and Madrid (2002). Her social skills attracted numerous prominent people in diplomacy and politics whom she entertained both at the United Nations and at her home in New York. Her last four years were spent in Daytona Beach, where she was splendidly attended by her caregivers. Her philanthropy and voluntary work reached several institutions in music and the arts. She leaves a cohort of cherished friends whose lives were touched by her wisdom and love. A Memorial Service was conducted at Temple Beth-El in Daytona. Interment will be at the Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield Gardens, NY on May 28 at 11am. Donations in her memory may be made to the Elise Kapell High Holidays Memorial Fund at Temple Beth-El, 595 North Nova Road, Ormond Beach, FL 32174.

FENNELL--George W.,of Quogue, NY born in Manhattan passed away May 20, 2009 at the age of 95. Surviving are his wife Vicky, his children George III (Nancy), Gene (Bill), Christine (Ralph), John and Larry (Maria Luisa), nine grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. He was President of George Fennell and Co., a furniture business.

VIEUX FARKA TOURé ''Fondo'' (Six Degrees) The second album by the Malian singer and guitarist Vieux Farka Touré distinguishes itself right away. In ''Fafa,'' we hear the reverb and slight overdrive of his electric guitar in a graceful, unaccompanied flourish and statement of melody. The low notes rustle, and the high notes are clean and silvery; a second, superimposed guitar, playing midrange lines, sounds watery.

WEINTRAUB--Alfred, died May 23, 2009. Beloved husband of Ruth (Benkow). Devoted father of Robert (Marilyn) and Donald (Marsha) Weintraub, and grandfather of Lauren, Aaron, Jenny and Daniel; and stepfather of Robert (Debra) and Lawrence Miller, and step-grandfather of Carly and Samantha. Treasured brother of Roslyn Besdine, Moses (Marian) Weintraub and the late Esther (Howard) Miller. Loved by nieces, nephews, cousins, and a wide circle of friends. Esteemed by his legal colleagues. Fought Parkinson's as he had lived before, with dignity, humor and spirit. Services Tuesday, May 26 2pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 91 and Amsterdam Avenue.

This is the 25th anniversary of John McEnroe's meltdown against Ivan Lendl in the 1984 final, and the 20th anniversary of Michael Chang's underhanded victory for all little guys in 1989 against Lendl in the fourth round.

RINDEN--Thor, 72, of Brooklyn and Stone Harbor, NJ, died May 19. Born in Marshalltown, IA in 1937, he graduated from the University of Iowa. Reading through the flood of traffic on Twitter during and after the Season 5 premiere of “Jon & Kate Plus 8″ on TLC Monday night, it was hard to avoid the curmudgeonly and not very interesting response of: Who cares? Why watch, let alone think about, a show in which an off-putting couple has turned their children into performing seals if it’s going to be this dull?

As recent weeks have demonstrated, you can have a “Terminator” franchise with a minimal Arnold Schwarzenegger presence and “Star Trek” without William Shatner (though perhaps not without Leonard Nimoy). But can you have “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” without the series’ creator, Joss Whedon? A filmmaker is exploring the possibility, The Hollywood Reporter said. The director Fran Rubel Kuzui’s production company, Kuzui Enterprises, has owned the rights to the franchise since producing the original 1992 feature film (which was written by Mr. Whedon and directed by Ms. Kuzui). Ms. Kuzui, who was also an executive producer on the “Buffy” television series, told The Hollywood Reporter that she was looking into a new film that would continue the idea of a guardian who protects the world from undead villains, but would not use the existing characters from the “Buffy” movie or television shows. Ms. Kuzui said the possibility of involving Mr. Whedon (the creator of the television shows “Firefly” and “Dollhouse”) had not been ruled out, and that the project had not yet been discussed with him. A possible release date for the film was not announced.

Hold on to your flying buttresses: the Milan Cathedral, the 600-year-old Italian Gothic structure, will host its first-ever concerts on the building’s roof, Reuters reported. The Veneranda Fabbrica del Duomo di Milano, the group that oversees the building, said that it would hold five concerts from June 10 to July 15, featuring the music of Verdi as performed by a 60-piece orchestra and choir playing more than 160 feet above the ground. The organization said that it would offer 500 free tickets for the June 10 concert in an online drawing. Gianni Baratta, the artistic director of the concerts, said that it was “absolutely the first time in more than six centuries” that musicians had performed on the cathedral’s roof, according to Reuters.

Updated | 11:32 a.m. How do you create a television show when you’re a Web-based communication tool that allows you to send messages of no more than 140 characters? (We already hit that limit before we finished this sentence.) Presumably that content restriction will be relaxed for a planned series being developed by Twitter, the popular online network that allows users to communicate and broadcast through microscopically short text messages. Variety reported that the network’s parent company, Twitter Inc., would be working with the production companies Reveille (which also produces “The Biggest Loser” and the American edition of “The Office”) and Brillstein Entertainment to develop a reality series. In a statement the companies said the show would put “ordinary people on the trail of celebrities in a revolutionary competitive format.” A premiere date has not been announced.

A Turkish author on trial after being charged with inciting religious hatred in a novel based on the birth of Islam said that his book was a work of fiction but the result of extensive research and consultation with religious leaders, and therefore could not be called blasphemous. An Istanbul court on Tuesday adjourned the trial of the author, Nedim Gursel, until June 25. He faces up to a year in jail if convicted.

Janet Evanovich, the best-selling author behind the series of books about the New Jersey-based bounty hunter Stephanie Plum, is entering the world of comic books. She, along with her daughter Alex, will be working on a graphic novel for Dark Horse Comics, based on the author’s “Metro Girl” and “Motor Mouth” books about a racecar driver named Sam Hooker and a Nascar mechanic named Alexandra Barnaby. “We’re comic book fans; we’re huge Nascar fans,” Ms. Evanovich said in a telephone interview. “It allows me to feed my Nascar addiction and comic book addiction all at the same time.” The book is expected to come out next year. Another writer who made the jump from novels to comics, Brad Meltzer, will be moving into nonfiction with “Heroes for My Son,” a collection of stories about the Wright Brothers, Jim Henson and others. The book, to be published by HarperStudio, is currently scheduled for release in June 2010, in time for Father’s Day.

Now that President Obama has announced Judge Sonia Sotomayor as his nominee for the Supreme Court, the residents and observers of our nation’s capital can turn their attention to another equally pressing matter: who will Bravo cast in its reality series “The Real Housewives of D.C.”? On Tuesday, the cable channel announced that it was working on a new entry in its “Real Housewives” franchise (which already includes editions set in New York, New Jersey, Atlanta and Orange County, Calif.), to take place in Washington. In a news release, Frances Berwick, the executive vice president and general manager of Bravo Media, said that producers were scouting the city for “influential players, cultural connoisseurs, fashion sophisticates and philanthropic leaders — the people who rub elbows with the most prominent people in the country and easily move in the city’s diverse political and social circles.” A premiere date was not announced.

As befits a filmmaker who broke through as a director of music videos, Michel Gondry (“Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind”) has found a distributor for his latest film with a hip-hop pedigree. Mr. Gondry’s “The Thorn in the Heart” (“L’Epine dans le Coeur”), a documentary that had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, will be released by Oscilloscope Laboratories, the film company founded by Adam Yauch (better known as the rapper MCA from the Beastie Boys). In a news release, Oscilloscope Laboratories said it would handle theatrical and digital distribution of the film, about Mr. Gondry’s aunt Suzette, who worked as a school teacher in rural France, and her son, Jean-Yves. A release date was not given. Separately, the Beastie Boys announced that their new studio album, “Hot Sauce Committee,” would be released this fall.

A Tony Awards voter who is involved with the Broadway play “reasons to be pretty” passes along the following e-mail, which is being sent to Tony voters who attend the production. The play — which has been struggling at the box office — has been nominated for three Tonys, including Best Play; its author, Neil LaBute, is competing against Yasmina Reza’s hit play “God of Carnage,” among others. Ms. Reza happens to be French; Mr. LaBute is indeed American, as the e-mail message from the play’s producers Bob LuPone and Bernie Telsey pointedly note. The Tonys are on June 7. The Public Theater’s 2009-10 season will include “Othello,” starring John Ortiz in the title role and Philip Seymour Hoffman as Iago, as well as the world premiere of “Snake” by the Pulitzer Prize winner Suzan-Lori Parks (“Topdog/Underdog”), the theater announced on Tuesday. “Othello,” directed by Peter Sellars, will run for 23 performances beginning Sept. 12; given the potential audience interest, the production will run in a larger space than the Public can offer: the 860-seat Skirball Center at New York University. In October the Public will present the world premiere of “Idiot Savant,” written and directed by Richard Foreman and starring Willem Dafoe. Also in the fall, a trilogy of plays by Tarell Alvin McCraney (“Wig Out!”) will run in two separate productions; the work is collectively titled “The Brother/Sister Plays Part 1 & Part 2″ (Part 2 consists of two plays). The monologist Mike Daisey will perform his piece “The Last Cargo Cult” in December, and Ms. Parks’s new play will open in March. A new play by John Guare, “Free Man of Color,” which was to have been directed this season by George C. Wolfe, was postponed and is not a part of the 2009-10 calendar; a Public spokeswoman said the theater still wants to do the piece.

Broadway musicals and plays grossed approximately $943.3 million during the 2008-9 theater season, a slight increase over the previous season and enough to set a new record for total grosses, according to data released this evening by the Broadway League.

That lesson was taught to me by SEWA in India, Kashf in Pakistan and Grameen in Bangladesh. A call for favorite food festivals.

Every summer, New York hosts dozens of food fairs and festivals with an international flavor. This week the Dining section previews five of the best. The following months feature events that are just as tasty, including the boisterous Brazilian Day Festival and West Indian Day Parade, both on Labor Day weekend; East Harlem's celebration of Mexican Independence, in mid-September; the Czech Independence Day street festival and Chusok, the Korean harvest festival, in October; the Royal Kathin celebration at Wat Buddha Thai, in early November; and various Scandinavian festivals for the Christmas season.

Eugenia Bone, above, a food writer in New York, learned the basics of preserving from her father, Italian-American cookbook author Edward Giobbi. As a buyer of seasonal and local foods, she often found herself in the kitchen with bounteous produce -- and old-fashioned canning recipes that didn't reflect her taste. To write "Well-Preserved'' (Clarkson-Potter), her new book of master recipes, she studied the craft and science of preserving in order to include recipes for her own modern kitchen staples -- like marinated artichokes, fresh herb pestos, pickled asparagus, and cherries in wine.

Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn and The Valerie Fund in Maplewood have received grants from The Horizon Foundation for New Jersey during its first round of grants in 2009, the foundation announced today. The foundation, which is based in Newark and affiliated with Horizon Blue Cross/Blue Shield, awarded Paper Mill $10,000 to support its Adopt-A-School Project, allowing students and teachers from Phillipsburg High School to attend Paper Mill productions, participate in intensive theater arts workshops and receive customized classroom study. The Valerie Fund in Maplewood received a grant of $20,000 to support its Child Life Program, providing education and counseling for children diagnosed with cancer. The program also provides support for parents, siblings as well as extended family members.

More than 1,000 employees at nine H&M stores in Manhattan will receive wage increases and other benefits in their first-ever union contract. The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, which represents the workers, announced on Tuesday that the contract was ratified last Friday. The union organized clerks, cashiers and other workers at the Manhattan outlets of the Swedish clothing retailer in November 2007.

Once she locks up her bike each morning at work, Andrea Cortes-Comerer faces a series of potentially awkward moments. She climbs into a crowded elevator, still sweaty, her hair matted down from her helmet, hoping to avoid eye contact. She rushes into the bathroom, where she changes clothes, combs her hair (which she has shampooed and tied into a ponytail before leaving her apartment), washes her face and applies deodorant. Then she heads to her desk, where she has arranged some cardboard boxes at her feet where she can hang her clothing to dry, out of sight.

Now that cocktails have been successfully exported to the City of Light, the French capital has fully embraced its next trend from across the pond: dimanche brunch. With a legendary café culture and firmly ingrained tradition of lingering over a Sunday meal, this was hardly a stretch for Parisians. But lately the Sunday ritual has been given an American-style makeover, and it's attracting locals every bit as much as Anglophone transplants.The early trendsetter was Connecticut-bred Craig Carlson, who back in 2003 opened the roadside diner Breakfast in America near the Sorbonne. Crowds have been clogging the sidewalks every Sunday since for sucré-salé (sweet-salty) feasts of cheese Western omelets and dense blueberry pancakes.

Mike Coolbaugh and Tino Sanchez toiled in the minor leagues for a combined 28 years. They were baseball lifers, devoted to a game that gave them only fleeting chances to play at the pinnacle of their sport. On July 22, 2007, in North Little Rock, Ark., Sanchez, playing for the Class AA Tulsa Drillers, sharply hit a foul ball that struck Coolbaugh, who was coaching at first base, in the back of the neck. The ball crushed an artery, cutting off blood to Coolbaugh's brain and killing him almost instantly.

Formula One: Jenson Button became the first British driver to win the prestigious Monaco Grand Prix from pole since Jackie Stewart did it in 1973. The win was Button's fifth in six races this season, and his Brawn GP team is quickly pulling away in the championship. The Monaco Grand Prix, raced under idyllic conditions, encapsulated the fortunes of the team. Button and his teammate, Rubens Barrichello, dominated the race, from wire to wire, with a Ferrari driver, Kimi Raikkonen, finishing third for the team's first podium of the season. Ross Brawn, the owner and team principal of Brawn GP, was the technical director at Ferrari during its glory years with Michael Schumacher, and this season is reminiscent of those Ferrari days. Brawn has even begun comparing Button to Schumacher, reports the BBC. "Rubens has had his occasions when he beat Michael and he was a pretty strong reference," Brawn said. "The fact Jenson's won these races with Rubens in the team sets the standard." High praise, indeed.

The Nobel Prize-winning chemist Dorothy Hodgkin once compared her discovery, piecing together the anatomy of insulin, to "trying to work out the structure of a tree from seeing only its shadow." Forty years later, the British artist Conrad Shawcross takes Hodgkin's description as the inspiration for a series of kinetic sculptures. "Slow Arc III," now on view at Location One, where the artist is having his first solo exhibition in New York, consists of a single penlight-size halogen bulb that travels a system of tracks within a metal cage.Installed in a darkened room, the light source (whose computer-controlled movements are generated at random) casts a grid of shadows over every surface. Shawcross's illusive vanishing point effectuates an unstable space.

AMSTERDAM | The rule of thumb for most moviegoers is to find a seat in the middle of the theater. If you have to, sit a little farther back. You never want to sit at the front, forced to crane your neck to see the image. That' not a problem at The Movies (www.themovies.nl), the independent movie theater on the Haarlemmerdijk. Chagrined when the only seats left at a recent weekend's screening of "Slumdog Millionaire" were on the front row, my movie-going companions and I realized as soon as we took our seats that we had scored. The screen, in keeping with its ornate, intimate surroundings, is much smaller than what we've grown accustomed to at the megaplexes, giving the front row the best seats in the house.

MERJAN--Florence L.,born May 14, 1929 in Hyde Park, MA, beloved wife, mother, and grandmother. She passed peacefully on May 23, 2009 in the presence of her family. She is survived by Stanley, her loving and devoted husband of 55 years; her sister, Sue Allen; her children Barbara, David, and Alice; and grandchildren, Jake, Julia, Alexandra and Olivia. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday May 26th at 12:30 at Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Heart Fund or St. Francis Hospital, Manhasset, NY.

The opposition Democratic Party claimed victory on Monday in the presidential election, and the incumbent quickly conceded to prevent a repeat of the violence that followed last year's disputed election results. Both candidates favored the government's taking a greater share of the nation's mineral wealth. The winner, Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj, left, had also promised to reform the judiciary and rout out corruption. ''This is a victory for fairness and honesty,'' said Galsan Ishdondov, 54, a party flag draped over his shoulders. ''Finally we will have the change we need and the justice we deserve.''

Survived by brother Barry Kasdan (Deborah); sons Jonathan Goldman (Monica Lasky), and Adam Goldman (Mara); grandchildren Cassidy, Max, Chelsea, Samuel.

President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea faced double crises on Monday as a North Korean nuclear test caught his government off-guard and he struggled to soothe political rancor over the suicide of his predecessor, Roh Moo-hyun. In one of the biggest outpourings of national grief in years, the central and provincial governments and religious and civic groups opened 300 mourning centers across the country on Monday. Long lines of Cabinet ministers and ordinary citizens streamed into the centers to pay respects to Mr. Roh. About 180,000 mourners have journeyed to Mr. Roh's rural home village of Bongha on the south coast alone.

9 P.M. (Science) SCIENCE OF THE MOVIES Nar Williams, the self-described geek in chief of AchieveNerdvana.com, analyzes famous film scenes to reveal the science behind the silver screen. In this premiere episode Mr. Williams, above, interviews John Dykstra, the Academy Award-winning special-effects pioneer for ''Star Wars'' and ''Spider-Man 2'' who invented the Dykstraflex, a motion-control rig used to film the explosion of the Death Star in ''Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope.'' Mr. Williams also demonstrates the Milo, a motion-control system that captures precise shots to create a fluid moment in films like ''Spider-Man''; visits Hydraulx, the company that created visual effects for ''Terminator 3'' and ''Aliens vs. Predator 2: Requiem''; and talks with Gary Thieltges about his inventory of camera mounts, including the body mount and the sparrow head, each of which won an Oscar for technical achievement. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Adam Lambert, the ''American Idol'' runner-up, shows off his chops.

SALKIN--Goldie, of Boca Raton, Florida originally of Brooklyn, NY died on May 25th, 2009. After struggling with numerous ailments, she passed serenely and peacefully at Hospice by the Sea surrounded by her loving family. Goldie was our matriarch, and is survived by her adoring husband of 62 years Ben, her children Bruce, Ellen, Ellyn, Bob, Susan and her grandchildren who loved her without end, Adam, Brian, and Rachel. She will be with us all, forever. Donations may be made to the National Psoriasis Foundation (www.psoriasis.org). Services Wednesday May 27, 2009 at 10:00am at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.
HORNIG--Judith. You are a wonderful and loving family. We are so sorry for your loss. The Sobel Family

POWERS--John Austin. On May 23rd, Jack, 82, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his beloved family, having fought a tenacious four year battle with Myeloma. Throughout his illness Jack never lost the dignity, gallant courage, or determination that so marked his life. He is deeply mourned by his loving wife of 47 years, Eileen, and by their children, Cecilia Owen and Jennifer Powers. From his previous marriage, he is survived by John Powers, Jr. and Maribeth Moody. Born in New York, Jack served his country in WW II and later graduated from St. Peter's College. During his career in advertising, Jack served as President of McCann-Erickson in Europe and America, ultimately leaving that post to become the Chairman and COO of Heublein, Inc., now Diageo. He served on various boards and dedicated himself to charitable interests, particularly in education and medicine. Devoted to family and friends, Jack's life was shaped by perseverance. We will remember his integrity, his business acumen and his enchantment with his family and grandchildren. Jack was a memorable presence, with limitless vitality and a keen intellect, who sought challenges in every aspect of life. Friends knew him to be engaging, loyal, and unflagging in his support. Jack possessed just enough knowledge about power tools to be dangerous, and his legendary repair projects are the stuff of family lore. He will not be forgotten. A memorial service will be held in New York on Wednesday, June 10th at 4pm at St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue. In his memory, donations may be made to Jack's endowment to Pain and Palliative Care Service (Attn: Dr. Kathleen M. Foley) at MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

PRUZANSKY--Leon, on May 24, 2009 at age 90. Loving father of Paul, Bruce (Amy), Mark (Sheila). Cherished grandfather of Julie and Jason. Beloved brother of Ruth. Services Tuesday 9am at L.I. National Cemetery Pinelawn, New York.

KRAININ--Dr. Ralph, dentist and longtime resident of Rye Brook, NY, passed away on May 23rd in New York City. He is survived by his wife Ruth, children Sylvia, Deborah and Andrew, brother Harold and grandchildren Dara and Jeremy. Funeral services will be held Tuesday 1pm at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions should be made to the N.Y. Theological Seminary Sing Sing Program.

McGINN--Audrey, died of cancer on Friday, May 8, 2009 in New York. Born on May 4, 1943 in Jersey City, NJ, Audrey graduated from Cabrini College and received Masters Degrees from Lehigh University and the City College of New York. She taught in East Harlem for several years, then fashioned a distinguished career at Scarsdale High School from 1976-2005. Audrey was a devoted daughter to her parents Leo J. McGinn and Casimer (Devlin) McGinn; sister to her brother Jim and his wife Gretchen; and aunt to their children, Alexandra, Ben and Catherine. Family and friends will miss Audrey's love, guidance, support, and friendship, as well as her iconic red clogs. A memorial service will held at Scarsdale High School on June 12th, 2009 from 3-5pm.

For Klaus Franz, the top union official at General Motors' Opel unit here, the difference between how the United States and Europe confront the auto industry's global overcapacity problem is simple. ''In the U.S., you get money to close down factories,'' said Mr. Franz, referring to the tens of thousands of Chrysler and G.M. workers who will lose their jobs as part of the White House's plan to restructure the American auto industry. ''In Europe, you get money to keep them open and safeguard jobs.''

DUNN Charles Wesley Jr.,born July 11, 1931 died May 23rd from pancreatic cancer. He was the son of the late Alice Hafner and Charles Wesley Dunn, founder of the Food and Drug Law Institute. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, the former Olivia Endicott Hutchins; two sons, Charles Wesley III and John Endicott; his sister, Anne Foster and her three children. Wes attended the North County School in Lake Placid, NY and was a member of their board for many years. He graduated from the Putney School in Vermont where his life long love of skiing and woodworking was born and in 1953 from Middlebury College. After working briefly for two shipping companies, he joined Kidder Peabody & Co. in 1960. There, he become a Managing Director, a member of their Board of Directors and managed their Corporate Pension Fund. In 1994 Wes went to work for Paine Webber as a Senior Vice President of Financial Services and continued as such until it was acquired by UBS. While living with his family in Darien, he became a member of the House Committee at the Tokeneke Club and was elected President of the Tokeneke Association. In Fairfield/Southport where they have lived since 1983, he held the position of Chairman of the House Committee at both the Country Club of Fairfield and the Pequot Yacht Club and was a member of their Board. He was also a member of the Board of Trustees at the Pequot Library. His other clubs included the New York Yacht Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York and was the proud President of the Amateur Ski Club of New York, the second oldest ski club in America. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 5th at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the North Country School, P.O. Box 187, Lake Placid, NY, 12946 or to the Pequot Library 720 Pequot Ave., Southport, CT 06890 would be gratefully received.

When North Korea suddenly announced Monday that it had conducted a second nuclear test, the initial view across the region was that this had been yet another defiant gambit by the North to extract more concessions from Washington. That has been the oft-repeated pattern in the past, and is likely to be one motivation now as well, say North Korea watchers. But this time around, North Korea's succession crisis is the primary impetus, many experts believe, suggesting that the audience for the test is its own population as much as the United States.

Initial seismic readings from the underground blast in North Korea were consistent with a relatively small nuclear test, but it will be days or weeks before the United States and international organizations can determine whether it was a nuclear detonation and how successful it might have been, experts said Monday. Scientists can judge the size of an underground nuclear blast by how violently it shakes the earth, although this method is not foolproof because conventional explosives can mimic the rumble. Experts can confirm the atomic origin by detecting the signature of radioactive gases and particles that a nuclear blast emits.

KAPLAN--Terri Lev Koller. Beloved daughter of Sina Lev and adored mother of Ross, Edward, Evelyn and Daniel and grandchildren Benjamin, Eli, Emily and Michael. Sinai Medical Center, NYC Attention: Jane McDonald.

ROTHZEID--Bernard, a leading New York architect, died of leukemia on May 25. He was 83 and lived in Park Slope, Brooklyn. As an architect, he was known for his skill in the adaptive reuse of existing structures, and was a longtime architect for the landmark City Center Theater in Manhattan. His expertise in health-care facility planning and design included major additions to New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. Bernard Rothzeid was born in Brooklyn in 1925. After Army service in the Philippines in WW II, he graduated from Cooper Union in 1949 and MIT in 1954. He was a Fulbright Scholar in Rome. Back in New York he became a project architect in the firm of I.M. Pei and Partners. In 1963 he founded his own architectural firm. In 1981 the firm became Rothzeid Kaiserman Thomson & Bee. Mr. Rothzeid was elected a Fellow of the AIA in 1979, and in 1986 he received the Augustus Saint Gaudens Award from Cooper Union. He served on the boards of Cooper Union, New York Methodist Hospital, and the Citizen's Housing and Planning Council. He taught at Cooper Union and at the School of Architecture at CCNY. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Madge, his daughter Mitzie and his son Alexander. Contributions in his memory may be made to Cooper Union, 30 Cooper Square, New York NY, 10003. Funeral services at 2pm on Wednesday May 27 at Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn. A memorial will be announced at a later date.
ROSE--Frances Bailen. Memorial on Wednesday, May 27, 4pm, New York University Medical School Faculty Dining Room.

FOXEN William Jr.,on May 23, 2009. Bill passed away at home, surrounded by his family, after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Denise Bouchard Foxen. Loving and cherished father of Ashley, William "Alex" and Lindsay. Devoted son of Eleanor Amy Foxen and the late William Foxen Sr. Treasured by his siblings Kathy Jessup, Nancy Foxen, Betsy Dunn, Bebe Foxen Mascolo, Peter Foxen, Anne Cote and their families. Denise was immeasurable aided in helping care for Bill by her sister Kim Bouchard, who Bill often referred to as his "second wife". Bill was an unforgettable character who lived life to the fullest. After growing up in Laurel Hollow, L.I., he attended Mount St. Mary's College in Emmitsburgh, MD, graduating in 1969, After college he returned to the neighborhood where he grew up and never left. Bill started as a lifeguard at Jones Beach when he was sixteen years old, and finally retired from the beach two decades later. Bill was an avid athlete. He started the lacrosse team in college, won awards for open-ocean rowing, sailed competitively, was a ferocious biker and played men's league ice hockey until shortly before his death. Bill pursued a career in insurance, and in 1992 established The Foxen Agency, which he built over seventeen years with the help of his dear friend and colleague Terry Grosso. Of all the things at which Bill excelled, he was the best at being a husband, father, son, brother, uncle and friend. His huge, gregarious personality made him hard to resist, and the number of friends he had, from all walks and spectrums of life, is a testament to that. For his family and friends, Bill will always be with us. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home of Syosset 79 Berry Hill Road. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 Tuesday. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:45am St. Patrick's Church, 400 West Main Street, Huntington. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Gastrointestinal Oncology Service, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065.

Former member of the Palm Beach Bath and Tennis Club, the New York Colony Club, and the Paris Cercle de L'Union Interalliee, she was forever engaging and passionate, a generous donor to her Church, and a brilliant storyteller to her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral service to be held on Wednesday, May 27th, at the Church of St. Genevieve, Gouvieux, France 60270.

She will be missed by the many who loved her and took pleasure in her company. Charitable donations in her memory may be made to the Mount Sinai Medical Center Department of Liver Transplant.

The Canadian author Alice Munro, whose short story collections run from her 1968 debut “Dance of the Happy Shades” to 2006’s “The View from Castle Rock,” has won the Man Booker International Prize, The Guardian reported. The prize, a lifetime achievement honor, has been given out every other year since 2005; its previous recipients are the Albanian novelist Ismail Kadare and the Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe. Ms. Munro was selected by a jury from a shortlist of finalists that also included E. L. Doctorow, V. S. Naipaul, Joyce Carol Oates and Mario Vargas Llosa. The prize, which includes an award of about $95,800, will be presented to Ms. Munro in a ceremony at Trinity College in Dublin on June 25. In announcing that Ms. Munro had won the prize, the juror Jane Smiley told The Guardian, “Any writer has to gawk when reading her because her work is very subtle and precise. Her thoughtfulness about every subject is so concentrated.”

At a meeting in Mumbai, the makers of the film “Slumdog Millionaire” said they were trying to find new homes for its young actors and their families, but the father of one actor said the filmmakers were not doing enough, The Associated Press reported. On Wednesday, the director Danny Boyle and Christian Colson, a producer of the Academy Award-winning film, met with the parents of Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9, and Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, the actors who play the young incarnations of the characters Latika and Salim. Their families’ homes were demolished earlier this month by local authorities who were ordered to clear illegally built shanties before the region’s monsoon season.

Eminem, has been absent from the pop scene for almost five years, but the strong sales last week for his comeback album, “Relapse” (Interscope), prove that he is still a star. “Relapse” is Eminem’s fifth consecutive release to open at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, with 608,000 copies sold. That is also the best opening-week sales of any album this year, beating the 484,000 that U2 racked up for “No Line on the Horizon” in March. Last week’s top seller, Green Day’s “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise), dropped to No. 2 in its second week out, with 166,000 in sales. New releases take up the next three spots on the Top 10: Kenny Chesney’s “Greatest Hits II” (BNA) reached No. 3 with 89,000 in sales; Dane Cook’s comedy album “Isolated Incident” (Comedy Central) was No. 4 with 61,000; and Busta Rhymes’s new “Back on My B.S.” (Universal Motown) was No. 5 with 59,000.

The coming productions of Neil Simon‘s “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound” have found their Eugene — or rather, Eugenes. The plays will be performed in repertory on Broadway this fall, and will feature Noah Robbins as Eugene Jerome, Mr. Simon’s alter ego, in “Brighton Beach Memoirs,” and Josh Grisetti as that character in “Broadway Bound,” the show’s producers Emanuel Azenberg and Ira Pittelman announced Wednesday. Mr. Grisetti, a star of “Enter Laughing,” will be making his Broadway debut, as will Mr. Robbins, a senior at Georgetown Day School in Washington, whose credits include Max Bialystock in his high school’s production of “The Producers.” The plays, to be directed by David Cromer (“Our Town”) will also feature Dennis Boutsikaris as Jack Jerome, Santino Fontana as Stanley Jerome and Jessica Hecht as Blanche. Allan Miller will play Ben in “Broadway Bound” and Alexandra Socha will play Nora in “Brighton Beach Memoirs.” Laurie Metcalf was previously announced to play Kate Jerome. “Brighton Beach Memoirs” begins previews on Oct. 2 and “Broadway Bound” begins previews on Nov. 18; a theater has not been announced.

The latest chapter of the best-selling video game Grand Theft Auto IV should preserve the franchise’s reputation for pushing buttons, in every sense of the phrase. The Web site Cnet.com reported that the next downloadable installment of the game, set in a crime-ridden metropolis called Liberty City, would be called The Ballad of Gay Tony, and would be released for the Xbox Live network in the fall. On the Web site of Rockstar Games, which publishes the Grand Theft Auto series, the company said the new installment would cast players as Luis Lopez, “part-time hoodlum and full-time assistant to legendary nightclub impresario Tony Prince (aka ‘Gay Tony’).” Cnet.com said the new chapter would be sold as a download for $19.95 or on a disc with a previous chapter, The Lost and Damned, for $39.95.

Updated | 3:11 p.m. Continuing our coverage of news that is tangentially related to Matthew Broderick: a suburban Chicago home that was prominently featured in his 1986 comedy “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” is up for sale. The building, a cantilevered, 5,300-square-foot house at 370 Beech Street in Highland Park, Ill., was once owned by the textile designer Ben Rose. But it is perhaps better known as the home of Cameron Frye (played by Alan Ruck), his authoritarian dad and his dad’s beloved Ferrari 250 GT, which makes the movie’s mischief possible.

A two-day auction of items belonging to the mime Marcel Marceau yielded almost $700,000 in sales, despite the vocal protests of some of his fans, The Associated Press reported. The sale, held by in Paris the auction house Néret-Minet Tessier, featured many items that have become synonymous with mime performance, including Marceau’s top hat (which sold for about $4,500) and a white sailor suit with a striped shirt and a too-small jacket (which fetched about $8,000). A Paris court had ordered the sale, which was expected to raise about $420,000, to pay for debts left by Marceau when he died in 2007. His admirers had hoped that his belongings would be displayed in a museum and were trying to raise money via a Web site, unmuseepourbip.com, before the sale started on Tuesday.

--In today's Guardian, Ian Sample describes a new trend in biology that rave-scene habitués will especially appreciate: glow-in-the-dark marmosets. The Central Institute for Experimental Animals in Kawasaki, Japan has engineered the bioluminescence so that the animals would pass the trait on. Next they will program in genetic anomalies similar to Parkinson's and other neural motor diseases; the green skin was the first, allegedly harmless step. Color us perplexed.

New York City has agreed to pay $2 million to the family of a woman who died on the floor of the psychiatric ward at Kings County Hospital Center in June 2008 after waiting more than 24 hours to be treated. On a recent visit to Ohio University, I talked with journalism and science students about communication and the environment. We discussed the merits and limits of blogging, which can be a great two-way pipeline for ideas and observations, but mostly serves a pre-sorted audience. We did the same for print and television coverage, which can expose general audiences to issues and ideas they might never otherwise consider, but sometimes convey more definitiveness than exists. And of course we talked about the challenges confronting media in a world of free information sources and dispersing, declining advertising income. I gave my sense of where we're headed (more on that here), then turned the tables on students of Professor Bernhard Debatin and asked the following:What is your vision of how the public will track environmental issues and developments in five years?

Some comments to yesterday's post on mass layoffs deny that corporations (or owners and managers) have any ethical duties -- No. 23 because such an idea is "socialist," No. 25 because ethics has no place in a "business argument." But we denounce child labor not just as a legal but also a moral offense. We condemn racist and sexist hiring policies both legally and ethically. We regard a chemical company as having an ethical as well as a legal duty not to poison a town's drinking water. Mass layoffs are another sort of harm a company inflicts on individual employees, their families and their communities -- and hence similarly susceptible to ethical consideration.

I was told, just the other day, that Prince Edward Island mussels were "the best." They're not. They're consistent, they're the most widely available, they're not bad, and they're not outrageously priced. "The best" mussels are the ones you harvest yourself, from a nice dock or outcropping of rocks in a cold tidal inlet. The second best are the ones someone else harvests from a like place, then sells to you. The third best are covered with mud or seaweed or whatever, and are difficult to clean, but are also wild and tasty. After these, the farm-raised ones from P.E.I. are kind of bland.

Apparently proving that real-life marital discord is a bigger draw than a sitcom or even real-life crime, the cable reality show “Jon & Kate Plus 8” on TLC drew more viewers than any broadcast network show on Monday night — 9.8 million, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That topped a rerun of “Two and a Half Men” on CBS (9.2 million) and a two-hour installment of “Dateline” on NBC (an average of 7.2 million). NBC still averaged the most viewers for the night, leaving CBS in second place. ABC finished in third with a two-hour edition of “The Bachelorette” (6 million) followed by the season premiere of “Here Come the Newlyweds” (5 million). Fox was fourth with reruns of “House” (4.7 million) and “Bones” (5.5 million).

The Public Theater’s 2009-10 season will include “Othello,” starring John Ortiz in the title role and Philip Seymour Hoffman (above, left, with Mr. Ortiz) as Iago, as well as the world premiere of “Snake” by the Pulitzer Prize winner Suzan-Lori Parks (“Topdog/Underdog”), left, the theater announced on Tuesday. “Othello,” directed by Peter Sellars, will run for 23 performances beginning on Sept. 12; given the potential audience interest, the production will run in a larger space than the Public can offer: the 860-seat Skirball Center at New York University. In October the Public will present the world premiere of “Idiot Savant,” written and directed by Richard Foreman and starring Willem Dafoe. Also in the fall, a trilogy y Tarell Alvin McCraney (“Wig Out!”) will run in two separate productions; the work is collectively titled “The Brother/Sister Plays Part 1 & Part 2.” (Part 2 consists of two plays.) The monologist Mike Daisey will perform his piece “The Last Cargo Cult” in December, and Ms. Parks’s new play will open in March. A new play by John Guare, “Free Man of Color,” to be directed this season by George C. Wolfe, was postponed and is not a part of the 2009-10 calendar; a Public spokeswoman said the theater still wants to do that piece.

Diana Salvatore, most recently editor in chief of Ladies’ Home Journal, has been named publisher of Broadway Books, an imprint of the Crown Publishing Group of Random House. Ms. Salvatore, 48, who edited Ladies’ Home Journal for six years and left in a shakeup in July, fills a post vacated last month when Stacy Creamer joined the Touchstone Fireside imprint of Simon & Schuster as publisher. Broadway publishes mostly commercial nonfiction. Ms. Salvatore, who will oversee six editors, said she had focused throughout her 28-year magazine career on long-form narrative. But with the magazine industry undergoing significant tumult and retrenchment, she said, books were now the refuge of such stories.
