A Turkish author on trial after being charged with inciting religious hatred in a novel based on the birth of Islam said that his book was fiction, but the result of extensive research and consultation with religious leaders, and therefore could not be called blasphemous. An Istanbul court on Tuesday adjourned the trial of the author, Nedim Gursel, right, until June 25. He faces up to a year in jail if convicted. His novel “The Daughters of Allah,” published last year, questioned the ideas of belief and violence in Islam, but had no intention of humiliating religious values, he told the NTV network. The case was filed after a citizen complained that Mr. Gursel had used inappropriate language against the Prophet Muhammad, his wives and the Koran. In a public letter to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in April, Mr. Gursel noted the damage such trials could cause Turkey’s efforts to join the European Union.

Janet Evanovich, the best-selling author behind the series of books about the New Jersey bounty hunter Stephanie Plum, is entering the world of comic books. She, along with her daughter Alex, will be working on a graphic novel for Dark Horse Comics, based on Ms. Evanovich’s “Metro Girl” and “Motor Mouth” books about a racecar driver named Sam Hooker and a Nascar mechanic named Alexandra Barnaby. “We’re comic book fans; we’re huge Nascar fans,” Ms. Evanovich said in a telephone interview. “It allows me to feed my Nascar addiction and comic book addiction all at the same time.” The book is expected to come out next year. Another writer who made the jump from novels to comics, Brad Meltzer, will be moving into nonfiction with “Heroes for My Son,” a collection of stories about the Wright Brothers, Jim Henson and others. The book, to be published by HarperStudio, is scheduled for release in June 2010, in time for Father’s Day.

As befits a filmmaker who broke through as a director of music videos, Michel Gondry (“Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind”) has found a distributor with a hip-hop pedigree for his latest film. Mr. Gondry’s “Thorn in the Heart” (“L’Epine Dans le Coeur”), a documentary that had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, will be released by Oscilloscope Laboratories, the film company founded by Adam Yauch (better known as the rapper MCA of the Beastie Boys). In a news release Oscilloscope said it would handle theatrical and digital distribution of the film, about Mr. Gondry’s Aunt Suzette, who worked as a schoolteacher in rural France, and her son, Jean-Yves. A release date was not given. Separately, the Beastie Boys announced that their new studio album, “Hot Sauce Committee,” would be released this fall.

As recent weeks have demonstrated, you can have a “Terminator” franchise with a minimal Arnold Schwarzenegger presence and a “Star Trek” without William Shatner (though perhaps not without Leonard Nimoy). But can you have “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” without the series’ creator, Joss Whedon? A filmmaker is exploring the possibility, The Hollywood Reporter said. The director Fran Rubel Kuzui’s production company, Kuzui Enterprises, has owned the rights to the franchise since producing the original 1992 feature film (written by Mr. Whedon and directed by Ms. Kuzui). Ms. Kuzui, who was also an executive producer on the “Buffy” television series (starring Sarah Michelle Gellar, below left, with David Boreanaz), told The Hollywood Reporter that she was looking into a new film that would continue the idea of a guardian who protects the world from undead villains, but would not use the existing characters from the “Buffy” movie or television shows. Ms. Kuzui said the possibility of involving Mr. Whedon (creator of the television shows “Firefly” and “Dollhouse”) had not been ruled out, and that the project had not been discussed with him. A possible release date for the film was not announced.

PATRICK--Julian. American baritone Julian Patrick died peacefully Thursday, May 7, 2009. A versatile singer, Patrick had a prolific fifty-year career singing concerts, musicals, cabaret, and opera, and towards the end of his life teaching. Born in Meridian, Mississippi, in 1927, Patrick came to music early in his childhood. After high school, he joined the Navy and served as a singer with Special Services. At 23, in 1951, he made his operatic debut in Mobile, Alabama, in La traviata. Shortly thereafter Patrick was drafted into the Army and was stationed in New York where he sang with the first Army Band. When he completed his service, he sang in night clubs and began auditioning for Broadway, where he made his debut in 1954 in Jerome Moross's The Golden Apple. Patrick was in the original companies of Once Upon a Mattress, Ziegfeld Follies, Bells are Ringing, and Fiorello. He revisited the musical stage often in his career for roles in works like 1776, Sweeney Todd, The Most Happy Fella, and South Pacific. In the mid-1960s, Patrick returned to opera as a principal of the Metropolitan Opera National Company (Figaro in The Barber of Seville and the Count in The Marriage of Figaro, among others) and toured the nation for two years; after it's demise, in 1967, he joined New York City Opera, making his debut in Douglas Moore's Carrie Nation the next year. Patrick sang in world premieres at City Opera of The Tempest by Lee Hoiby, Nine Rivers From Jordan by Hugo Weisgall, and Leonard Bernstein's Trouble in Tahiti. He worked with Dominick Argento on two world-premieres, singing the lead in Cassanova's Homecoming and a role specifically written for him in The Dream of Valentino. Mr. Patrick's most prominent work in contemporary American opera was with Carlisle Floyd in Of Mice and Men. Patrick sang the role of George in the world premiere of Of Mice and Men in 1970 at Seattle Opera. Patrick sang performed eighteen roles in nearly thirty productions with Seattle Opera, including Alberich in The Ring of the Nibelung in five different series of cycles over an eleven year period, as well as such comic roles as Dr. Dulcamara in The Elixir of Love. He also sang Alberich at the Metropolitan Opera on several occasions. Patrick sang at many other major U.S. opera houses, including San Francisco Opera, Houston Grand Opera, Washington National Opera, and Lyric Opera of Chicago. Overseas he was heard in many theaters, including the Netherlands Opera, Grand Theatre de Geneve, and the Vienna Volksoper. Mr. Patrick served as a professor of voice at the University of Washington from 1990 until 2005. He served as head of the vocal department from 1996 until 2005. He continued to teach and coach young singers until his passing. Mr. Patrick's work was recorded for RCA, Columbia, Desto, and various other labels. Mr. Patrick is survived by his partner of fifty-six years, Donn Talenti. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials and tributes be made to Seattle Opera. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on June 27 at the Nesholm Lecture Hall of McCaw Hall at Seattle Center.

HART--Edward J.,Jr., of Chappaqua, NY died peacefully on May 19, 2009; he was 80 years old. Born November 15, 1928 to Ann Wooley Hart and Edward Joseph Hart in Trenton NJ; Edward married Joan Irene Mckee, October 21, 1950. Ed was predeceased by the love of his life, his much beloved wife, Joan Hart. Ed demonstrated his leadership qualities from an early age as president of his High School class and Captain of a New Jersey State Championship Football team. He served our Country during the Korean War, rising to First Lieutenant. His work took him to Dover, Delaware where he served as the head of the Department of Science for the State of Delaware before taking on the position of Assistant Principal at Dover High School. Ed, and his then young family, moved to Chappaqua, where he served as Assistant Principal for two years at Horace Greeley High School before becoming Greeley's Principal. For his 26 years in that post, Ed gained great joy from his love of students, faculty and the community. Ed's devotion to education and service before, during and after his tenure at Greeley, was recognized by his peers and communities with numerous awards. Most recently, he worked with single mothers and their children on a literacy program he initiated in the Bronx. Ed is survived by his Sister, Valerie Hart Babecki Kuznerik; his children and their spouses: Roxanne (Philip Casnoff) Hart of Los Angeles, CA; Timothy (Catherine Gallagher) Hart of Somers, NY; Nancy (James) Sherrard of Bladenboro, NC; Christopher (Margaret) Hart of Wolfeboro, NH and Barbara (Joseph Slakas) Hart of Croton on Hudson, NY. Ed is also survived by his ten grandchildren: Shannon, Daniel, Catherine, Marly, Alex, Mollie, Macklin, Sam, Ian and Bridget. Visiting Hours: Friday, May 29th 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville. Mass Saturday, 10am, Upper Church, St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua. Donations to HGHS Scholarship Fund; Lewy Body Foundation.

PRESERVING is no more technical or challenging than baking. But because the risks are greater -- a fallen cake will not send anyone to the hospital, but a contaminated jar of salsa just might -- cooks must do it attentively. Basic equipment like a dishwasher, new jars and a roll of paper towels can eliminate many possible hazards.

While most people may believe Sonia Sotomayor is poised to become the first Hispanic justice on the Supreme Court, there has been a rich under-the-radar debate for years as to whether the court had already had a Hispanic justice. Several people have suggested that Justice Benjamin Cardozo might properly hold the title of the court's first Hispanic justice. Prof. Andrew Kaufman of the Harvard Law School, who is the author of a 1998 biography of Cardozo, said the debate was esoteric, complicated and, perhaps above all, amusing.

President Obama announced Tuesday that he would nominate Sonia Sotomayor, a federal appeals judge in New York, to the Supreme Court, choosing a daughter of Puerto Rican parents who was raised in a Bronx public housing project to become the nation's first Hispanic justice. In making his first pick for the court, Mr. Obama emphasized Judge Sotomayor's ''extraordinary journey'' from modest beginnings to the Ivy League and now the pinnacle of the judicial system. Casting her as the embodiment of the American dream, he touched off a confirmation battle that he hopes to wage over biography more than ideology.

The lunch crowd at El Palacio de Los Jugos on Tuesday could not agree on the appropriate level of excitement. Cubans, Colombians, Dominicans -- they all said they were pleased to hear Judge Sonia Sotomayor accept her selection for the United States Supreme Court with a speech that included the rolling ''r's'' of her Puerto Rican roots. But do not assume that Judge Sotomayor's identity will define her, said Luis Home, 35, a Colombian-American technology recruiter. ''It's like saying if you're Hispanic, you're going to be a superhero for Hispanics. That's not true.''

A former Guantánamo detainee, an Algerian given a new home in France, is contending that he was interrogated at the Cuban detention center for 16 straight nights in 2003 -- from midnight until 5 a.m., at least -- and that he was force-fed through a nasal tube for more than two years when he went on a hunger strike. The Algerian, Lakhdar Boumediene, 43, is the only Guantánamo detainee that President Nicolas Sarkozy of France has agreed to accept so far to help the Obama administration close the detention center.

In dealing with North Korea, American officials are reduced to studying two-month-old photographs of its reclusive leader, Kim Jong-il, to calculate how long he is likely to live. The new administration's North Korea team includes a special emissary who works part time as an academic dean and a State Department official who has yet to be confirmed by Congress. And as President Obama tries to find a way to punish North Korea for its latest nuclear test and missile launchings, his senior aides acknowledge that every policy option employed by previous presidents over the past dozen years -- whether hard or soft, political or economic -- has been fruitless in stopping North Korea from building a nuclear weapon.

Sonia Sotomayor, who would be the Supreme Court's first Hispanic justice, brings to the confirmation experience the kind of rich personal story that has always been deeply gratifying to Americans, the journey from humble beginnings to a respected position of great influence. As she was presented by President Obama at the White House on Tuesday morning, she referred to herself as ''a kid from the Bronx.'' But it was Mr. Obama who provided many details of her history as a child of a city housing project who lost her father at an early age and saw her mother work two jobs to put her and her brother through professional schools.

Representative Anthony D. Weiner, the one-time front-runner in the campaign for mayor who became a frustrated sideline player, has made it official: he is staying out of the race. His decision all but ensures that the city's comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., will not face a serious challenger in the Democratic primary. Mr. Weiner is expected to announce his plans at a news conference outside his parents' home in Brooklyn on Wednesday, according to a person briefed on the matter.

LUBY--Robert Maurice, of Cheshire, CT, formerly of Meriden, passed away on Friday evening, May 22, after a long and glorious life one week before his 95th birthday. Mr. Luby lived at Elim Park, Cheshire, CT. Mr. Luby is survived by his wife of 65 years, Ruth McGee Luby. Mr. Luby was born in Meriden, CT on May 29, 1914, and was the son of the late William J. Luby and Ellen O'Donnell Luby. He resided in Meriden for nearly 90 years. Mr. Luby attended St. Joseph School, and was graduated from Meriden High School in 1932. He graduated from Yale College in 1936 and Yale Law School in 1939. He then opened his practice of law in Meriden. He was a veteran of World War II. He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1942, and served in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, 3rd Engineer Special Brigade, 32nd Division. He spent most of his service in the South Pacific Theatre as an Amphibious Engineer and Shore Battalion Commander, participating in the military campaigns of the Bismarck Archipelago, Luzon, Southern Philippines, and New Guinea. He also served as Combat Liaison Officer on the staff of General Ogden. Following the Japanese surrender, he served in the first Provisional Government for the Island of Hokkaido. He was awarded a Bronze Star for bravery, and was honorably discharged in 1945 with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. Mr. Luby returned to the practice of law in Meriden after the war, and was the founding partner of Luby Olson, P.C. He held many leadership positions in the community during his lifetime, including President of the Meriden Boys Club, the Meriden Wallingford Hospital, and the Home Club. He served as Chairman and Director of the Home Bank and Trust Company, and Director of the Bradley Home, the H. Wales Lines Co., the C.N. Flagg Company, and the Meriden Gravure Co. He was a founding member of the Meriden Industrial Development Corp., a small group of private citizens who sought to preserve space for industrial growth to increase employment in the Meriden and Wallingford area, and which is now known as Research Parkway. He also played a key role in the formation and development of the Cuno Foundation. Mr. Luby and his wife Ruth shared a love of travel, history and reading. They traveled to Ireland, England, France, Spain, Italy, Egypt, New Guinea, China, Thailand, India, Panama, Peru, and throughout the United States and Canada. He never missed a birthday, first communion or a graduation. He was a frequent spectator at his grandchildren's softball, basketball, and horse riding competitions. He loved his family, lunch at Fischer's with his law partners, history, the novels of Louis L'Amour, Yale, and Sunday afternoon naps. Despite his sustained efforts over many years, his golf game was an object of sympathy. In addition to his wife, Mr. Luby is survived by three children and their spouses, Deborah Luby Rie and her husband John Rie of Westbrook, CT, Robert M. Luby Jr. and his wife Karen Grava of Wallingford, CT, and Attorney Thomas S. Luby and his wife Paula of Old Saybrook, CT; by four grandchildren, Jessica Ruth Hammatt and her husband James Adam Wrubleski of Westbrook, Caroline Ruth Luby and Katherine Mary Luby of Old Saybrook, CT, and Elizabeth Theresa Luby of New York City; by four nieces, Jane Luby, Mary Luby Larsen, and Ann Luby Adamczyk, all of Meriden, and Ellen Luby Larsen of Middlefield; by his sister-in-law Agnes Stazewski Luby of Meriden and formerly of Kensington; by three step- grandchildren, Johanna Wolfe of Rockville, MD, Jacob Williams of Woodbury, CT and Colby Williams of Secaucus, NJ; and by two great grandchildren, Hannah Elizabeth Wrubleski and Cooper James Wrubleski. Mr. Luby was predeceased by his brothers William J. Luby Jr. and James F. Luby. The family of Mr. Luby wishes to express its appreciation to the staff of Elim Park for the attention, quality care and respect shown to Mr. Luby during the final chapter of his life. The funeral will be held on Thursday, May 28, 2009 at 10am at the Saint Rose of Lima Church, 35 Center Street, Meriden. Burial will be at Sacred Heart Cemetery, 250 Gypsy Lane, Meriden. Friends and relatives are invited to call at the John J. Ferry Funeral Home, 88 East Main St., Meriden, CT 06450, on Wednesday, May 27, from 4pm to 7pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Elim Park Resident Benevolence Fund, 150 Cook Hill Rd., Cheshire, CT 06410. www.jferryfh.com

BLUE--Richard, September 18, 1946 - May 16, 2009. Beloved husband to Amanda and wonderful father to Kathleen, Rich was a remarkable human being, loved by all. A great contributor to the music world, Rich had early success as a member of the Association (as Ted Bluechel Jr.) and progressed to write many great songs. In later years he entered the world of finance and joined the Corporate Bank at Chase Manhattan, where he met Amanda. After their marriage in 1981, they moved to Burlingame and established their home. In the mid 1990s, Rich retired from the business world and devoted himself to raising his daughter, Katie, a role which he considered the greatest achievement of his life. In 1998, Rich and his family moved to London, England, where they spent ten interesting years before returning home to Burlingame in 2008. He will be greatly missed by his wide circle of friends and family.

FOR Eugenia Bone, opening the kitchen cupboard in her SoHo apartment is like dipping into a favorite TV show. ''The jars are like characters, with story lines that I remember,'' she said recently, scrabbling around in search of a jar of yellowfin tuna preserved in olive oil and salt. ''Seeing them brings back the farm where I bought that case of artichokes, or the day we picked all those cherries.'' When the tuna came to light, the date on the label was discouraging: 2006. ''The Feds wouldn't like it,'' she said, referring to Department of Agriculture recommendations that home-preserved food be eaten within a year. ''But it's still going to make a great lunch.''

The band Depeche Mode has canceled additional concerts after announcing that its lead singer, Dave Gahan, had had surgery to remove a malignant tumor from his bladder, Agence France-Presse reported. Earlier this month, the group canceled a scheduled concert in Athens, Greece, hours before showtime as Mr. Gahan was taken to a hospital. The singer was initially given a diagnosis of severe gastroenteritis and the band postponed further appearances in Europe while he recovered. But in a statement Thursday, the band said that while Mr. Gahan was hospitalized, “further medical tests revealed a low-grade malignant tumor in Dave’s bladder, which has since been successfully removed.” Depeche Mode has rescheduled or canceled further performances in Britain, Germany and the Netherlands, and is presently slated to resume its tour in Leipzig on June 8.

Four decades after Barbra Streisand told you she could get it for you wholesale, the entertainment multi-hyphenate will soon offer design advice to readers. On Thursday, the Viking imprint of Penguin Group said that it had acquired a book by Ms. Streisand, titled “A Passion for Design,” that would detail the architecture and construction of her Malibu, Calif., house, which took more than five years to build. In a news release, Viking said the book would also contain photographs of the house’s decoration, furniture and art (as well as the flowers and vegetables Ms. Streisand grows in her gardens), and chronicle the previous homes she has owned in New York and California. The book is expected to be released in the fall of 2010. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Updated | 4:23 p.m. The attorney general of New Jersey has filed charges against three ticket resellers, saying that the companies were offering to sell tickets to coming Bruce Springsteen shows that had not yet gone on sale, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported. The attorney general, Anne Milgram, filed lawsuits on Wednesday in Essex County Superior Court against Select-A-Ticket, Orbitz Worldwide Inc. and TicketNetwork. The companies were selling tickets at several hundred dollars above face value to Mr. Springsteen’s concerts on Sept. 30, Oct. 2 and Oct. 3 at Giants Stadium. Those tickets are scheduled to go on sale on Monday. Additionally, Orbitz was charged with selling tickets to sections of Giants Stadium that do not exist. In a statement, TicketNetwork said that it is not selling any tickets to these concerts and is only providing a platform where buyers and sellers can exchange goods.

Jonathan Groff, replenish your collection of bug sprays: one year after performing the role of Claude in the Public Theater‘s open-air production of “Hair,” Mr. Groff will return to Central Park’s Delacorte Theater in a coming revival of “The Bacchae.” In a news release, the Public said that Mr. Groff (of “Spring Awakening” and “The Singing Forest”) would play Dionysus. He’ll be joined by Andre De Shields (“Impressionism,” “The Fully Monty”) as Teiresias, and George Bartenieff as Cadmus. The cast also includes Karen Kandel, Joan Macintosh, Steven Rishard and Rocco Sisto. The production, to be directed by JoAnne Akalaitis with original music by Philip Glass, is scheduled to begin performances on Aug. 11 with an official opening of Aug. 24. Its limited run concludes on Aug. 30.

In February, we noted an eBay auction for a Tony Award won by the costume designer Florence Klotz for her work on the 1985 musical “Grind.” Now another Broadway veteran is putting her Tony on the auction block — along with much, much more.

The Amato Opera bids farewell to this world on Sunday after 60 years of presenting low-cost, homey productions on the Bowery. Its founder, Anthony Amato, 88, has decided the run has come to a close. But a group of Amato veterans — singers, administrators, a few board members — are trying to fill the void. On Wednesday, they held a meeting and formed a board, appointed officers and established a budget of $50,000.

You may not know the name of Nolan Gerard Funk if you’re over the age of 15, but the young actor (who starred earlier this year in the Nickelodeon movie “Spectacular!”) will soon be visible on Broadway. Mr. Funk has been cast as Conrad Birdie, the Elvis Presley analogue in Roundabout Theater Company‘s revival of “Bye Bye Birdie,” the company announced Thursday. In a news release, Roundabout said it had also cast Allie Trimm (of the musical “13”) as Kim MacAfee and Matt Doyle (“Spring Awakening”) as Hugo Peabody, as well as Dee Hoty, Molly Ephraim and Jake Evan Schwencke. They join the show’s previously announced stars John Stamos, Gina Gershon, Bill Irwin and Jayne Houdyshell. Previews for “Bye Bye Birdie,” which will be directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, are scheduled to begin on Sept. 10 with an opening of Oct. 15 at the new Henry Miller’s Theater.

By now, most HDTV set owners are likely to be familiar with the HDMI cable. When HDTVs were first introduced, three component cables, plus separate audio cables, were needed to get the best picture. One of the great things about HDMI is that it cuts the clutter by combining audio and video into one cable. And unlike early cables used to connect, for example, PCs and printers, the HDMI cable has a small, elegant plug that easily attaches to a TV or cable box.

Collette Blanchard Gallery in New York is now showing "Bois" by the photographer Sarah Baley. The images explore lesbian sexuality -- specifically those who reject the notion that gender is a simple male-female binary. Baley, a graduate of Art Center College of Design in California, has been following the close-knit community of bois (pronounced "boys" just like womyn is pronounced "women") since 2005. Photographing her subjects in boxing uniforms and western wear, posing in bars and in the Brooklyn Naval Yard, Baley offers a real glimpse into the scene of this subculture. If you miss her highly cinematic works at the gallery, Baley will be showing more images at the Brooklyn Museum starting in August.

On the topic of the Bugatti Veyron, Pierre Henri-Raphanel, Bugatti's test driver, told me that there would never be another car like it. He was speaking of overall engineering rather than outright horsepower, but his feeling that the Veyron represents a high-water mark for automobiles is inextricably tied to its four-digit horsepower number. LONDON | Tucked away behind an unimposing shop front in London's Bloomsbury quarter is the headquarters of an institution with ambitious ideals. The School of Life, the brainchild of various writers and intellectuals including the philosopher, Alain de Botton, was established last year to offer people innovative ways of approaching life. Through a variety of short breaks, courses, meals in some of London's interesting restaurants and more, the school claims it is the place "to step back and think intelligently" about the concerns and stresses of modern-day life.

The Bruins owner Jeremy Jacobs plans to ring in the new year by rooting for his team at Fenway Park. Robby Gordon was docked 50 points by Nascar on Wednesday for failing an inspection after his best finish in almost four years. Gordon used strategy in the rain-shortened Coca-Cola to finish third, his best finish in a Sprint Cup Series race since he was second at Watkins Glen in 2005.

Eminem, above, has been absent from the pop scene for almost five years, but the strong sales last week for his comeback album, “Relapse” (Interscope), prove that he is still a star. “Relapse” is Eminem’s fifth consecutive release to open at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, with 608,000 copies sold. That is also the best opening-week sales of any album this year, beating the 484,000 that U2 racked up for “No Line on the Horizon” in March. Last week’s top seller, Green Day’s “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise), dropped to No. 2 in its second week out, with 166,000 in sales. New releases take up the next three spots on the Top 10: Kenny Chesney’s “Greatest Hits II” (BNA) reached No. 3 with 89,000 in sales; Dane Cook’s comedy album “Isolated Incident” (Comedy Central) was No. 4 with 61,000; and Busta Rhymes’s new “Back on My B.S.” (Universal Motown) was No. 5 with 59,000.

The coming productions of Neil Simon’s “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound” have found their Eugene — or rather, Eugenes. The plays will be performed in repertory on Broadway this fall and will feature Noah Robbins as Eugene Jerome, Mr. Simon’s alter ego, in “Brighton Beach Memoirs,” and Josh Grisetti as that character in “Broadway Bound,” the producers Emanuel Azenberg and Ira Pittelman announced on Wednesday. Mr. Grisetti, a star of “Enter Laughing,” will be making his Broadway debut, as will Mr. Robbins, a senior at Georgetown Day School in Washington, whose credits include Max Bialystock in his high school’s production of “The Producers.” The plays, to be directed by David Cromer (“Our Town”), will also feature Dennis Boutsikaris as Jack Jerome, Santino Fontana as Stanley Jerome and Jessica Hecht as Blanche. (Laurie Metcalf was previously announced to play Kate Jerome.) “Brighton Beach Memoirs” begins previews on Oct. 2, and “Broadway Bound” begins previews on Nov. 18; a theater has not been announced.

A federal district judge in Manhattan said Tuesday that a class-action lawsuit charging fraud and other misconduct could proceed against the Andy Warhol Foundation and the board that authenticates Warhol’s work. The suit was filed by a filmmaker, Joe Simon-Whelan, who bought a Warhol painting, above, in 1989 only to see it later declared inauthentic on two occasions by the board, even though, he contends, Warhol’s estate determined earlier that it was real. Mr. Simon-Whelan maintains that beyond his case the foundation and board have conducted a 20-year conspiracy to inflate the prices for Warhol works — and thus the value of the foundation’s holdings — by denying the authenticity of a certain number as a way to create artificial scarcity. The board and foundation have denied the accusations and sought to have the suit dismissed. Judge Laura Taylor Swain ruled that Mr. Simon-Whelan had asserted his allegations “plausibly” enough for the case to continue to the discovery phase on many of its claims.

The latest chapter of the best-selling video game Grand Theft Auto IV should preserve the franchise’s reputation for pushing buttons, in every sense of the phrase. The Web site cnet.com reported that the next downloadable installment of the game, set in a crime-ridden metropolis called Liberty City, would be called “The Ballad of Gay Tony” and would be released for the Xbox Live network in the fall. On the Web site of Rockstar Games, rockstargames.com, which publishes the Grand Theft Auto series, the company said the installment would cast players as Luis Lopez, “part-time hoodlum and full-time assistant to legendary nightclub impresario Tony Prince (a k a ‘Gay Tony’).” Cnet.com said the new chapter would be sold as a download for $19.95 or on a disc with a previous chapter, “The Lost and Damned,” for $39.95.

At a meeting in Mumbai, the makers of the film “Slumdog Millionaire” said they were trying to find new homes for its young actors, but the father of one actor said the filmmakers were not doing enough, The Associated Press reported. On Wednesday the director Danny Boyle and Christian Colson, a producer of the Academy Award-winning film, met with the parents of the actors Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9, and Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10. Their families’ shanty homes were demolished by authorities ahead of the monsoon season. Reuters reported that Mr. Boyle said the filmmakers had purchased a new home for Azharuddin and would soon buy one for Rubina. But Rafiq Qureshi, Rubina’s father, said their efforts fell short. “Everything is available in Mumbai if you have the money,” Mr. Qureshi said, according to The A.P. “If you really want to get us a house, you can get us a house in two days.”.

The White House moved aggressively on Wednesday to begin selling the Senate and the public on President Obama's choice of Judge Sonia Sotomayor for the Supreme Court, as the battle lines surrounding her confirmation hearings began to harden into shape. One day after President Obama introduced her to the nation, Judge Sotomayor was at the White House, plotting strategy with Mr. Obama's aides and continuing a round of calls to senators.

LYONS--Natalie B. - The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Natalie B. Lyons of Coral Gables, FL, whose decades of loving service to our organization and to its Women's Division, and staunch support of the Technion, have been a source of inspiration. Ms. Lyons served two terms as the ATS national Women's Division president, and president of its Miami/Coral Gables Chapter. She was a life trustee of the ATS Board of Regents, as well as an Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors, and a regular participant on ATS missions. Her advocacy for the advancement of women in academia was characterized by her generosity to Women's Division projects, particularly the Zara E. and George Trinin General Chemistry Laboratory and the Hortense and Lawrence Fairberg Analytical Chemistry Laboratory. A Cuban native, Ms. Lyons was a bilingual journalist and book reviewer, and was active in many philanthropic and educational endeavors. Along with her late husband, Arthur, Ms. Lyons was a Technion Guardian, achieving the highest level of commitment. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children, Ann Fisher and Sara Burns, to her stepson, Scott Lyons, and to the entire Lyons family. American Society for Technion- Israel Institute of Technology Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman of the Board Ilse Blumenfeld, President, Women's Division Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Gloria Neimark, Director of Women's Leadership

Yahoo has added its voice-enabled search program to its iPhone application. Although the new capability will eventually arrive on an iPhone through an update, the impatient can go into the iTunes app store and download the free Yahoo feature to get the update right away.

CHORNEY--Irving. The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the untimely passing of Irving Chorney. Irving Chorney leaves a grieving family and many friends. We mourn his passing as we celebrate his life and extend our heartfelt condolences, at this difficult time, to his loving wife, Anita, children, Gail and Alan and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Chairman, and the members of the Faculty

Tennis, like all sports at the elite level, is a game of hellos and farewells, or, more precisely at Roland Garros, des saluts and des adieux. On Wednesday, with the world's greatest clay-court tournament gathering momentum, it was time to say adieu to Marat Safin and Fabrice Santoro, who played and lost what they insisted were their final French Open singles matches. It was time to say salut to the 16-year-old Michelle Larcher de Brito, a Portuguese whirlwind who upset No. 15 seed Zheng Jie, 6-4, 6-3, in her first Grand Slam event.

O'HARE--Douglas Kennard, an educator for over 40 years, died Friday after a courageous battle with cancer. He was 63. He leaves a legacy of 25 years of inspiring students at the Stephen Gaynor School with a love for learning. Over the years he touched so many, and changed the lives of so many more. For each and every one of his students, he opened the door to the enchantment of literature, history, poetry, reading and writing. Prior to Doug's move to New York City in 1983, he resided in Washington, DC where he was a Coordinator at the St. Maurice Day School in Potomac, MD. Doug has no immediate family members surviving him. He is predeceased by his parents, Mary Ann O'Hare and Winston L. O'Hare, and two brothers, Steven Bradford O'Hare and John O'Hare. A 1969 graduate of the University of Maryland in English, he earned his master's degree in Education from Catholic University in Washington, DC in 1976. Doug's presence will be greatly missed at the Stephen Gaynor School where he touched the lives and left a lasting mark on so many of his colleagues. Services: A memorial service will be held at the Stephen Gaynor School 148 West 90th Street - on Wednesday, June 3, 2009 at 5:00pm. Prior to Doug's passing, in lieu of flowers, he requested expressions of sympathy be made to the Doug O'Hare Scholarship at the Stephen Gaynor School. Contributions should be made to the Stephen Gaynor School, c/o Development Office, 148 West 90th Street, New York, NY 10024.

MINTER--Dr. Thomas. Riverdale Mental Health Assn. mourns the loss of our dear friend and former Board member. He will be long remembered for his wisdom and kindness. Sandra Lerner, RMHA Board President Robert Brewster, Executive Director

The Nike+ iPod Sport Kit for runners talks to you during your workout, a feature that serves as both a reminder of how much farther you need to run and a little pick-me-up if you feel like you're ready to give up. The $29 kit includes the Nike Sensor, a little pod that is inserted into a slot in a Nike+ ready running shoe (or in a pod holder if you prefer another brand of sneaker). The sensor beams information about your run to Apple iPod Nano or Touch (but not to an iPhone). It collects data like running pace, distance, duration and calories burned.

ELENKO Stuart S.,died peacefully on May 25, 2009. Beloved husband of Carole for 50 years. Loving father of David and Robin and father-in-law of Beth and Gary. Adoring grandfather of Lucy, Harry and Alexis. For many years, he was a dedicated, revered and inspiring teacher and mentor at the Bronx High School of Science where he had a profound impact on shaping the character and life path of his students. He also founded the nation's first high school Holocaust Studies Center in 1978. He was awarded the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Hebrew College in Brookline, MA for his work in Holocaust education. Throughout his life, he was always compelled to speak out against injustice and indifference. His generosity, wisdom, kindness, honesty and sense of humor will be missed by all who knew him. The family would appreciate that any donations be made to the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity; 555 Madison Ave-20th Floor; NY, NY 10022.

Pentax will be selling a new midlevel digital single-lens reflex camera that captures high-definition video and offers some intriguing new features for faster focusing and more accurate light metering. The 14.6-megapixel K-7 ($1,300, body only) will replace Pentax's K20D when it ships in July. It's currently priced at about $100 more than its nearest competitors, the Canon EOS 50D and the Olympus E-30.

GROAT--William B. III, on May 26, 2009. He was born in Queens Village, NY. His life included more than 50 years of service to humanitarian causes and civic welfare. He served on numerous hospital boards and committees and worked with many organizations to promote the welfare of youth. He was a board member of the National Conference of Christians and Jews which presented him with the highest award for leadership and distinguished service in the field of human relations. He is survived by his wife Estelle, his daughter Janet and two grandchildren; he was pre-deceased by his parents the Hon. William B. Groat Jr. and Viola Groat and his brother John S. Groat. Reposing at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., New York City. Funeral Mass Friday, 10am at St. Joseph's Church. Interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery and Memorial Park. Visitation Thursday, 5-7pm.

SULZBERGER--Maye. May 28, 1909 - November 26, 2005 We remember her nutty laugh, the little knit suits with the perfectly matched pocketbooks and shoes, a liberal application of Revlon's "Love That Red, " but most of all how deeply and powerfully Maye loved us. If she were still physically with us, we'd celebrate her 100th birthday tonight with Chinese food, iced tea (no ice), and a lot of chocolate. Happy Birthday dear Mazie, happy birthday to you! Susan, Mickey, Jody and Penny

ALGEO--Warren Howley was born August 4, 1923 and grew up in Hastings, NY. His father, Joseph, owned Algeo Pharmacy on Main Street. He worked for Diamond Alkali for twenty years in their International Division and in 1981; Warren took early retirement to run a livestock import business in the Dominican Republic. In 2005, he retired to Albuquerque. He died peacefully at his home in Albuquerque on April 24, 2009. His son Edmund A. Algeo of Cleveland, Ohio survives him. His daughter, Beatriz Gronert and ex-wife, Lolita Algeo, also survive him. Family contact address is: P.O. Box 25446, Albuquerque, NM 87125.

BOURNE--George Allen, of Lyme, CT and formerly of Oyster Bay, NY died suddenly May 24, at age 64. Survived by his children John and Katie, sisters Rosemary Bourne and Elizabeth Roche (William), brother William, nieces Elizabeth and Laura, nephew George, and ex-wife Anne Bourne. A graduate of Kent School, University of Connecticut and Columbia School of Business, he also attended University of Pennsylvania. After serving in the United States Marine Corps he had a long career on Wall St, with many years spent at Lehman Bros. George loved life to the end; he was an adoring father, compassionate friend, raconteur, fisherman, hunter, boater, lover of dogs and stray cats. Funeral service will take place at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Old Lyme, CT, Saturday, May 30, 11am. Graveside service at St. John's Cemetery, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, Friday, June 5, 12pm, with Luncheon to follow at Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. In lieu of flowers, donations to Kent School, Kent, CT or Camp Dudley, Westport, NY would be appreciated.

DELAYED START AVERTED The Stanley Cup finals could have begun as late as June 5 if the Blackhawks had won Game 5. Because of the N.H.L.'s television commitments with NBC, a Chicago victory would have most likely pushed the opener to Friday of next week -- a week and a half after Pittsburgh completed its sweep of Carolina.

At their meeting last week, it became clear that N.F.L. owners were prepared to go straight to an 18-game regular season, skipping right past 17 games and the comparatively fewer injuries and dollars they would provide. Do not look to the injury study that the N.F.L. conducted for owners and executives to provide much of an answer.

When Amazon.com introduced its Kindle e-book device over a year ago, it waived its fee of 10 cents a megabyte for letting customers e-mail their own text and PDF documents to Amazon, which would, in turn, relay them wirelessly to the Kindle. But that came to an end on May 4, and the fee has increased to 15 cents a megabyte. Kindle owners can avoid the fee altogether by uploading documents to the Kindle via the oft-neglected U.S.B. cable that comes with the device. Two free stand-alone programs, Calibre and Stanza, can convert most document types to a format that the Kindle can display. The free Mobipocket eBook Creator from Mobipocket works too, but it's for Windows only.

FEW accessories can detract so thoroughly from the success of a well-dressed man as the standard sports bag. In most instances, the conventional gym duffel -- awkward, garish and usually overwrought with excess mesh and polyester -- is better left off the shoulders of an elegant shirt or suit, unless, of course, the man inside the ensemble cares little for his aggregate appearance. Yet the presence of an accessory so essential to sport and play doesn't necessarily have to spoil even the most dapper suit. This spring's new line of simpler, more refined gym totes allows the tasteful athlete to retain his sense of style while transporting necessities to and from workouts and away on weekend outings.

Ron Lieber, the “Your Money” columnist — known to readers of The Choice for his April Q&A on saving for college — read our colleague Jonathan D. Glater’s article on imperiled loan-forgiveness programs earlier this week and came away with an idea. Along with Mr. Glater and several other colleagues, he decided to build a scorecard of sorts in which lenders, states and employers that have offered such incentives — often as a means to lure prospective teachers or nurses — would be asked to guarantee that they will make good on previous commitments to pay off student loans.

The Tony-nominated actress Hallie Foote will take on several major roles in “The Orphans’ Home Cycle,” a three-part nine-play work by her father, Horton Foote, that Hartford Stage and Signature Theater Company are mounting for the 2009-10 theater season, the theaters announced on Friday.

The Pennsylvania Department of Labor said that it was investigating a complaint about the hit reality show “Jon & Kate Plus 8″ to make sure that it was complying with the state’s child labor laws, The Associated Press reported. On Friday, Justin Fleming, a spokesman for the Labor Department, said that it was investigating the TLC series, about the parents Jon and Kate Gosselin, who reside in Wernersville, Pa., and their eight children: a set of twins, age 8, and a set of sextuplets, age 5. The Gosselins’ marriage has lately drawn intense scrutiny from celebrity magazines, and the season premiere of “Jon & Kate Plus 8″ broadcast on Monday evening was watched by 9.8 million people, making it the most watched television show of the night.

The venerable heavy metal musician Ozzy Osbourne acknowledged in a statement that he is suing Tony Iommi, his longtime band mate in the group Black Sabbath. On Friday, The New York Post reported that Mr. Osbourne had filed a claim with the US Patent and Trademark Office, saying that Mr. Iommi had illegally taken sole possession of the band’s name, and that he is suing Mr. Iommi in a Manhattan federal court for a 50 percent interest in the Black Sabbath trademark and a portion of Mr. Iommi’s profits from use of the name.

New on the hardcover list in the No. 2 slot is Superman: New Krypton. After Pa Kent died last year, Superman’s grief was slightly offset by the discovery of the bottled city of Kandor, which the villainous Brainiac had shrunken and inadvertently saved from the destruction of Krypton. In the new storyline, the citizens of Kandor are returned to normal size. They each have the power of Superman, but unfortunately for the Man of Steel, they do not necessarily share his values. The second volume of the story hits comic stores on Sept. 2.

The chief minister of Maharashtra State in India said that two child stars of “Slumdog Millionaire” would be been given new apartments after their shanty homes were torn down, Reuters reported. In recent days, municipal workers in Mumbai have demolished the homes of Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, and Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9, who played the young incarnations of the film’s characters Salim and Latika. Illegal shanties are routinely destroyed in advance of India’s monsoon season. On Wednesday, the “Slumdog Millionaire” director Danny Boyle and Christian Colson, a producer of the film, met with the children’s families and said that they would find new homes for them. On Friday, Ashok Chavan, the chief minister, said that the Congress party had purchased new apartments, at a cost of about $8,500 each, for both families in suburban Mumbai, and that they could move in soon.

Alex Clark, the editor of the British literary magazine Granta, is resigning after less than a year in the job, Publishers Weekly reported. When Ms. Clark became editor in September, she was the first woman to hold that post in the history of the publication, which dates to 1889. She was promoted from deputy editor to succeed Jason Cowley, who left after a seven-month stint to become editor of The New Statesman. Before joining Granta, Ms. Clark worked as a reporter, columnist and editor for several British newspapers including The Observer and The Daily Telegraph, and had served as a judge for the 2008 Man Booker prize. She will be the third editor in 18 months to have left Granta, which has a circulation of about 50,000. John Freeman, the publication’s American editor, will serve as acting editor.

I'm pretty rough on Bill Ackman, the hedge fund manager who mounting a proxy fight aimed at Target, in this week's column. I feel a little badly about that because Bill is a smart guy whose work I have often admired (see my column about him taking on MBIA here). But the more I looked into it, the more I felt that Mr. Ackman was using the rhetoric of corporate governance to disguise his annoyance at having Target turn down his ideas. I'm sure he'll give me an earful about this next week, but that's a whole other story. I'll blog about it if he does.

The last six months have made it clear how out of control Americans' shopping habits have gotten. The Chicago-based photographer Brian Ulrich has been aware of it for much longer. His 2001 "Copia" project tracked what happened when Americans were urged to shop as a patriotic act. His two most recent series, "Thrift" and "Dark Stores," which opened Thursday at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea, follow consumption to its haunting end (from big box to white cube?). In "Frank Lloyd Wright: From Within Outward," an exhibition currently on view at the Guggenheim Museum, the models of Wright's designs are attracting as much attention as the exhibition itself. Perhaps the most notable model is that of Wright's Herbert Jacobs House #1 of 1936-37, the first of the architect's pioneering open-plan, energy-efficient Usonian houses. The basswood model takes the house's components - from its window frames to its innovative copper-piped radiant-heating system - and explodes them, so that they seem to hang in midair.This and five other models in the exhibition were designed and made by Situ Studio, a four-year-old Brooklyn multidisciplinary firm known for its cutting-edge approach to digital design and fabrication technologies. It's current projects include fabricating a bamboo and birch lobby for One Jackson Square, a soon-to-be-completed building by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates. The Guggenheim curators chose Situ because they were determined not to go the usual architectural-model route and they even put a clause in Situ's contract forbidding the use of those fuzzy little hobby-shop trees.

It sounds like pulp fiction. Connie Converse, singer-songwriter, disappeared from Ann Arbor, Michigan, in 1974, leaving behind a baffled circle of family and friends, a filing cabinet of carefully cataloged music and tapes of over fifty original songs, recorded between 1952 and 1958. "What makes her music so mysterious is that no one can pinpoint where it came from," says Daniel Dzula, a sound engineer and co-founder of Lau derette Recordings, who released her music commercially for the first time this year. Self taught, Converse wasn't part of the '50s folk revival that many of her peers flocked to, though her songs are superficially similar: literate and introspective, they actually sound more likely to have come from the late '60s, if not from today. In the meticulously drafted goodbye letters she sent to intimates before her disappearance, she comes across as a woman bursting at her era's seams.

"Cy Twombly: The Natural World, Selected Works 2000-2007" is the inaugural exhibition for the new Renzo Piano-designed Modern Wing at the Art Institute of Chicago (both opened earlier this month). On display through Sept. 13, it includes 31 works by the octogenarian artist: paintings, wood and plaster sculptures, photographs and works on paper like "Untitled" (2001), pictured right. Adult admission is $18 but is free on Thursdays and Fridays after 5 p.m. through Labor Day (www.artinstituteofchicago.org).

It has been almost three weeks since the Derby, and every time I watch the replay, all I can do is smile. Never in a graded stakes have I witnessed such a race. Such a resounding victory from such an unlikely source: fantastic. Never have I lost and laughed so much at the same time. I tip my cap to the connections of Mine that Bird. This will be the Derby I'll remember, always. The overhead camera shot of Calvin Borel was as magnificent as the ride itself. Thank you Mr. Woolley and Mr. Allen for validating my parents' mantra "do your best, try your hardest and good things will happen". Not for "us", but they will happen.

With so much gloom in the air, it was refreshing to see the work of so many bright young things at the recent Milan fair. T spotlights six of the brightest, with cheeky photographs and illustrations by Todd Selby. There's also something playful going on at home, as our portfolio of new furniture and accessories shows. For the guerrilla design gallerist Libby Sellers, a Paris pied-à-terre doubles as a playfully personalized showroom. And for the prolific (and famously playful) Philippe Starck, entertaining at home means casual excess, down to an understated yet over-the-top meal cooked by the equally prolific chef José Andrés. Online, you'll find additional playthings, from a guide to the summer's brightest (and cheapest) wine to tips on budget entertaining that won't depress you. So brighten up: summer's almost here.

Barcelona finally met its match on the streets of its home city as up to a million fans flocked to welcome the team home from its European Champions League triumph. Barcelona, which won the Spanish League, the King’s Cup and the Champions League, struggled to get through the crowds. Having beaten Manchester United, 2-0, in Rome on Wednesday, Coach Pep Guardiola and captain Carles Puyol carried the European Cup down the steps from the plane on Thursday. The team boarded an open-top bus with the trophies propped up inside the front windshield for a journey that took more than three hours.

Karczeby, a mixture of Polish and Belarussian, is a dialect still spoken in the east of Poland. Karczeb is a vernacular word for people strongly attached to the land they cultivate. A Karczeb is also called a stump with roots still stuck in the earth after the tree has been cut down - allegorical for the problems the various aggressive authorities have had with these people, trying to eradicate or dislocate them. They still stand tall on their land. And when a Karczeb farmer's life comes to an end, he is buried in his soil, later on tilled by his children or grandchildren.

An art review last Friday about the renovated galleries in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art misspelled the surname of the museum’s curator of American decorative arts. She is Alice Cooney Frelinghuysen, not Frelinghauser.

A report in the Antiques column last Friday about an exhibition of illustrations by the artist Georg Ehret at the New York Botanical Garden misstated the year of his death. It was 1770, not 1780. The report also misidentified the work by Ehret that was published by the Swedish naturalist Linnaeus without crediting Ehret. It was a single illustration of Linnaeus’s system of plant classification, not 20 images. Those images were in fact credited to Ehret in a book by Linnaeus; the uncredited illustration was in a different book.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on May 2 about prime-time television ratings for April 30 misidentified the show on CBS at 10 p.m. that drew an estimated 10.3 million viewers. (In Nielsen’s final ratings the number of viewers was 10.2 million.) It was a rerun of “Criminal Minds” — not “Harper’s Island,” which had appeared in that time slot but was moved to Saturday nights.

An article on Thursday about a campaign by an advocacy group to embarrass movie studios that show people smoking in films aimed at young people misstated the group’s relationship to the American Medical Association. The group, the American Medical Association Alliance, is a volunteer arm of the American Medical Association that focuses on physician, child and family issues. It is not “the advocacy arm” of the A.M.A., which aims its own advocacy efforts at reform of the health-care system.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: SEAN CONNERY This tribute ends with a little fudged history in ''The Wind and the Lion'' (1975), starring Mr. Connery as the leader of Berber insurrectionists who kidnap an American woman (Candice Bergen) and her two children in Morocco, inciting President Theodore Roosevelt to undertake a rescue mission. (The real kidnap victims were a middle-age man and his stepson.) In ''The Great Train Robbery'' (1979), above, at 10:15, a couple of crooks (Mr. Connery and Donald Sutherland) plot to steal a fortune in gold from the safe of a moving train. And in ''Robin and Marian'' (1976), at 12:15 a.m., an aging Robin Hood (Mr. Connery) returns to Sherwood Forest to pick up where he left off with Maid Marian (Audrey Hepburn) and the Sheriff of Nottingham (Robert Shaw). Richard Harris does a regal turn as King Richard. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Segments look at the future for Jay Leno, overweight teenagers, waterskiing and women's issues. Taylor Swift performs; P. Allen Smith gardens; and some viewers are ambushed and given makeovers.

NOT long after dawn on my second day in Boulder City, Nev., I was on a rented bicycle heading for Hemenway Park, where I was told I might spy bighorn sheep grazing near the playground. I didn't find the sheep, but I did run headlong into herds of much bigger game that Boulder City is hoping to catch. My route sent me to an exit for a bypass that lets those heading for Hoover Dam, six miles away, avoid Boulder City's business district, and as I waited at a light I watched no fewer than five packed buses from Las Vegas drive by.

In the 1980s, the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund sued the New York City Police Department, claiming that its promotion exams discriminated against Latinos and African-Americans. The fund, one of the advocacy groups pressing similar cases across the country, also helped redraw voting districts in the city that increased the number of Hispanic elected officials. The defense fund even sued a former Reagan administration official for defamation after he claimed that virtually all Puerto Ricans in New York received food stamps.

People have a deep desire to communicate with animals, as is evident from the way they converse with their dogs, enjoy myths about talking animals or devote lifetimes to teaching chimpanzees how to speak. A delicate, if tiny, step has now been taken toward the real thing: the creation of a mouse with a human gene for language. The gene, FOXP2, was identified in 1998 as the cause of a subtle speech defect in a large London family, half of whose members have difficulties with articulation and grammar. All those affected inherited a disrupted version of the gene from one parent. FOXP2 quickly attracted the attention of evolutionary biologists because other animals also possess the gene, and the human version differs significantly in its DNA sequence from those of mice and chimpanzees, just as might be expected for a gene sculpted by natural selection to play an important role in language.

CHANCHALGUDA, INDIA -- Behind the hulking, metal-studded front door of Hyderabad's Central Prison live more than 900 men being held in connection with crimes ranging from pick- pocketing to murder. And then there are the two accountants. Four months after the revelation of a massive fraud at Satyam Computer Services threw corporate India into turmoil, markets here have practically declared the incident over. Satyam's top managers gave detailed confessions of their crimes and were jailed; the board was fired; and the giant outsourcing company was sold. Foreign investors are even flocking back to Indian stocks.

FRIEDMAN--Morris R.,died at 91 on May 23rd. A graduate of the New York City public schools and City College, Morris served in WWII in the European Theater as an officer in Patton's 3rd army. He attended NYU Law School on the GI Bill, which brought him an education and a life he'd never dreamed of. Morris taught taxation at NYU Law where he received an LLM, and for 50 years practiced tax law in New York. In June 1949 he married the beautiful Norma Luloff, later a fashion writer at Vogue, with whom he lived for 58 years. Morris was absolutely devoted to his wife and two children. He had a lifelong passion for Beethoven, Mozart and Brahms, 19th century literature, old film, amateur singing, proper grammar, and progressive politics. He was predeceased by his wife Norma and son Philip, both of whom he tended with loving care. Morris is survived by his adoring daughter Ruth, his loving niece Lorna Peterson and her family, Dale, Zach and Seth, and by his faithful caregivers and friends. Morris Friedman was a generous, honorable, and humble man. His memory can be honored by donations to the Equal Justice Initiative, 122 Commerce Street, Montgomery, Alabama. A memorial celebration of his life will be held in the coming months.
HELEN LEVITT Laurence Miller

TOSTESON--Daniel. The officers of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences acknowledge with sadness the passing of former Academy President, distinguished medical scientist, and renowned academic administrator Daniel C. Tosteson. Elected a Fellow of the Academy in 1979, he served as President from 1997 to 2000 and oversaw a strategic planning initiative that helped set the national research agenda of the modern Academy. He served as Dean of Harvard Medical School for two decades, where he modernized the structure of the school and pioneered innovations in problem-based learning, while maintaining scholarly research in the field of membrane biophysics. He was a frequent advisor to government on matters of national health policy and had a lifelong passion for research, scholarship, and higher education. We extend our condolences to his wife Magdalena and his children. Emilio Bizzi, President Leslie Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer Louis W. Cabot, Chair of the Trust and Vice President John S. Reed, Treasurer Jerrold Meinwald, Secretary

Two Michigan auto parts suppliers, Visteon and Metaldyne, filed for bankruptcy protection on Thursday, becoming the latest to falter in the industry slump. Visteon is the largest supplier to the Ford Motor Company, which spun off the parts maker in 2000. Metaldyne's biggest customer is Chrysler, which filed for Chapter 11 protection last month.

People have a deep desire to communicate with animals, as is evident from the way they converse with their dogs, enjoy myths about talking animals or devote lifetimes to teaching chimpanzees how to speak. A delicate, if tiny, step has now been taken toward the real thing -- the creation of a mouse with a human gene for language. The gene, known as FOXP2, was identified in 1998 as the cause of a subtle speech defect in a large London family, half of whose members have difficulties with articulation and grammar. All those affected have inherited a disrupted version of the gene from one parent. FOXP2 quickly attracted the attention of evolutionary biologists because other animals also possess the gene, and the human version differs significantly in its DNA sequence from those of mice and chimpanzees, just as might be expected for a gene sculpted by natural selection to play an important role in language.

FINKELSTEIN--Nat. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Nat Finkelstein. We extend our deepest sympathy to Sheila Schouela and their families. Richard G. Hunegs, President Mervyn Manning, Secretary.

PLATT--Mervyn John, (Merv). October 17, 1917-May 24, 2009 in Florida. Lifelong resident in Trenton. Known for his charitable, civic, and interfaith work. Survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Betty (Eckert) Platt of Palm Beach, formerly of Trenton; his children Julia Platt Herzberg (Horacio) of Manhattan; Marc Platt of Palm Beach, Lawrence Platt (Carrie Cook Platt) of Providence; five grandchildren, Gabriela and David Herzberg (Elizabeth Feld Herzberg) of Manhattan; Nicholas and Charlotte Platt of Providence; Michael Platt of Vienna (his mother Eva Janelle); great-grandson James Herzberg; brother Allan Plapinger. Attended University of Alabama and St. John's University; announcer at Radio Station WAIR, Winston Salem; drafted in the Army Air Corp (1942); graduated Officer's Candidate School (1943); served in the China Burma India Theater (CBI) (1943). Administrative officer in the first B-29 bomber raid on Japan from China; stationed in Okinawa as commanding officer in the 346th Station Complement Squadron IE SHIMA Asiatic Pacific Theater. Recalled to active duty during the Korean War. Retired as Lt. Colonel from the Air Force Reserves in 1966; received 16 decorations and awards. In the 1950s formed Platt and Plapinger Insurance; awarded life membership to the Million Dollar Round Table. Co-founder, charter member, and regional vice-president of the Association for Advanced Life Underwriting. In 1961 Platt and his brother, Wallace, developed their first shopping center, leading to many in New Jersey and Florida under Eastern States Properties. Retired as vice-chairman in 1999. Fund raising was a serious endeavor; chaired drives for Har Sinai Temple (served as Treasurer), Jewish Federation of Trenton, Boys Scouts of America, Hamilton Hospital, and The Hamilton Foundation. The Mervyn J. Platt Orthopaedic Wing at Hamilton Hospital is named in his honor. Passion for skiing; curiosity for people and travel had few parallels. Services Sunday, May 31, 11am, Har Sinai Temple, 2421 Pennington Rd, Pennington, NJ. Donations to Har Sinai Temple or Alzheimer's Foundation.

MOORE--William H.,died of lung cancer in his sleep at home on May 6th. He is survived by his three children; Pamela Olyphant of Bozeman, Montana, William H. Moore III of Greenwich, Connecticut and Timothy Moore of Delray Beach, Florida, eleven Grandchildren and seventeen Great-Grandchildren. His wife of 69 years Edith McKnight predeceased him. He was 94. He was born in 1914 in Convent, New Jersey, the third of four children. He graduated St. Paul's School and then Yale University in 1937. During World War II he served in the United States Navy and was awarded the Bronze Star for bravery when a German submarine crew boarded his destroyer. He was Chairman of Bankers Trust Company for 17 years, retiring in 1975. He served on the Boards of American Can Co., Nabisco, Republic Aviation, M.A. Hanna, Lockheed, IBM, Royal Globe Insurance Group and the Lackawanna Railroad. He was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. Paul's School and on the boards of The Peck School, the Greater New York Fund, Morristown Memorial Hospital Roosevelt Hospital and Mystic Seaport. He headed the United Way of New York. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to The Jupiter Medical Center. The service is private.

AMID the farmland just north of the Ohio River, thickets of sumac and maple trees hem the edge of a one-lane road, just as they might have lined the way to freedom two centuries ago. Back then, before concrete paving and electricity transformed the countryside, it was along roads like these that runaway slaves were silently escorted through the shadows by kindly strangers. The sound of dogs barking often punctured the silence, signaling that their furious owners had crossed the river from Kentucky to recapture them. If they were lucky, they would find shelter in a safe house to the north by the time dawn's light crept over the tobacco fields.

After a five-game trip, Sky Blue (1-4-2, 5 points) will play its first match at Yurcak Field at Rutgers University. The club named Gerry Marrone as Sawyers's replacement.

President Obama's choice for the United States Supreme Court did not vote in the last two statewide elections in New York, according to voting records. The selection, Sonia Sotomayor, currently a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and a resident of Manhattan, did not cast a ballot in the 2002 election, when the Democratic ticket in New York was led by H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and a candidate for governor. Nor did she vote in the 2006 elections, which gave Democrats control of the United States Senate, where the fate of her nomination to the nation's highest court will be decided.

In the economics of baseball, one of the most common themes is control. For the first six years of a player's career, the team that brought him up controls his rights. But after a player's third year of service, he gains back some of the control in the form of arbitration, where he can request a much higher salary and his team must make a counteroffer.

In 1968, the Detroit Tigers' Denny McLain won 31 games and the St. Louis Cardinals' Bob Gibson set a modern mark with an earned run average of 1.12. Sudanese planes are said to have crossed the border and dropped seven bombs on the Oure Cassoni camp for Darfuris in Chad. UN and humanitarian movements suspended, and two people reportedly killed. Sudan's willingness to bomb a refugee camp on the sovereign soil of a neighboring country underscores the degree to which it feels unconcerned about foreign pressure of any kind.

The International Space Station crew doubled in size with the arrival of a Russian Soyuz capsule carrying three people. The station, with a full complement of solar panels, ample room and a working water-recycling system, is ready to be a full-time home to six people after a decade of construction. The Soyuz was launched Wednesday from Kazakhstan. With a crew of six, the amount of time spent on scientific experiments will grow to more than 70 hours a week from 20.

SAWITSKY--Arthur, M.D.,93, of Roslyn and East Hampton, NY passed away peacefully at his home on May 28, 2009 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Barbara, father of Kitt (Heather) and Edith (Michael Keane). Loving grandfather of Aaron, Luke and Karin and great-grandfather of Anna and Herman. Graduate of NYU and NYU School of Medicine (1940), Major US Army and WWII combat veteran (Europe). Pioneering hematologist-oncologist on Long Island. Professor of Medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Chief of the Division of Hematology-Oncology at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY until his retirement. Teacher, mentor and role model for three generations of young physicians who went on to make important contributions in their fields. Donations can be made to Israel Cancer Research Fund, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 550 New York, NY 10104 or Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd, Woodbury, NY 11797. Services: Sunday, May 31, 2pm Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. Friends are invited to the home in Roslyn on Sunday and Monday evenings.

The annual inflation rate for the euro area was unchanged over the year to May, compared with a 0.6 percent increase over the year to April, the European Union statistics agency said Friday in a preliminary report. A breakdown of the data was not available, but analysts said the decline was largely because of lower energy and food price inflation, while core inflation, which excludes those prices, probably also fell.

SCHOEN--Andrew J.,died Thursday, May 28. He is survived by his two loving children, Douglas E. Schoen of New York, NY and Sarah A. Schoen of Denver, CO, his son-in-law, Ken Rothstein and his devoted grandson, Joshua Evan. He is also survived by his second wife, Ginger Strauss and his first wife Carol Schoen. He was a graduate of Harvard College, class of 1947 and Harvard Law School, class of 1950, where he was an editor of the Law Review. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 31, 12pm at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street.

PEARLMAN--Amalia ("Mali") Cecile Rapaport, internationally acclaimed artist, died peacefully at home in Oakland, CA on May 27, 2009. Born October 10, 1918, in Czechoslovakia, the youngest of four sisters, she was raised in Brooklyn, NY, where her father, Charles David Rapaport, helped found a shul. A graduate of Brooklyn College, Mali married engineer/inventor Lester Pearlman in 1939 and later earned a Ph.D. in Fine Arts from NYU. The Pearlmans lived in Bethel, CT, Ramat Aviv, Israel and Sunnyvale, CA. In 1992 when Lester died, Mali moved to San Francisco and set up an art studio. She was a member of the Rocky Neck Artists Association in Gloucester, MA, where she often spent summers. Pencil or brush always in hand, Mali saw the world through artist's eyes. Mali's watercolors won prizes and acclaim from the New York Times and other critics for "unliteral lyricism," "lightness and sparkle" and "elusive washes of pure jeweled color." She proclaimed: "My goal is to express the inexpressible the universe within me because I must." Mali was a founding member of the National Museum of Women in the Arts in DC. A print of her sketch of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is featured in the Justice's private collection. Mali survived two of her five children, Austin and Jared. Her quick wit, flawless style and bright smile will be missed by her daughters Leslie and Lise, her son Justin, ten grandchildren, ten great-grandchildren, other family and friends.

R.H. Donnelley Corporation, the publisher of 600 directories including telephone yellow pages, sought bankruptcy protection from creditors to reduce debt by about $6.4 billion amid mounting losses. The company, based in Cary, N.C., had assets of $11.9 billion and debt of $12.4 billion as of Dec. 31, according to Chapter 11 documents filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. Nineteen affiliates also sought court protection. The company attributed the filing partly to ''a significant decline in advertising sales due to the recent economic downturn and increased competition in the local business advertising industry,'' court papers said.

She is survived by her two sons and their families: Gerry and Kris Lesk of New York, NY, and Dr. Steven Lesk, his wife Eileen and their daughter Phoebe of Marine-on St.Croix, MN.

PEARLMAN--Amalia ("Mali") Cecile Rapaport, internationally acclaimed artist, died peacefully at home on May 27, 2009, at the age of 90. Mali was born October 10, 1918, in Zborov in what would become Czechoslovakia. The youngest of four sisters, she moved to Brooklyn, NY with her family in 1920, where her father, scholar Charles David Rapaport ("Pop"), helped found a shul and she became an avid Dodgers fan. She graduated from Brooklyn College and later earned a Ph.D in Fine Arts from NYU. In a match of opposites, she married engineer and inventor Lester Pearlman in 1939; they would complement each other for over 50 years. In 1949, the Pearlmans moved to Bethel, CT where they spent 20 years raising their five children. They next lived in Israel before moving to Sunnyvale, CA. In 1992 after Lester died, Mali moved to San Francisco, where she rooted for the Giants against the traitor Los Angeles Dodgers and established an art studio. Pencil or brush always in hand, Mali saw the world through artist's eyes. Known best for her authoritative watercolors and calligraphy, Mali exhibited in shows throughout New England as well as in Paris, Palm Beach, Jerusalem, San Francisco and New York. Her work won her numerous prizes and acclaim from the New York Times and other art critics for its "unliteral lyricis[m]," "lightness and sparkle" and "elusive washes of pure jeweled color." She proclaimed: "My goal is to express the inexpressible the universe within me because I must." The Norwalk Hour noted "Dr. Pearlman has a rare gift in arriving at the essence of the matter in a most poetic fashion." Mali is a founding member of the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, D.C. An extraordinary caricaturist, among her courtroom sketches is one of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg; the Justice called it a "gem" and proudly features a print of it in her private collection. Mali was also a member of the Rocky Neck Artists Association, the oldest artist colony in the country, in Gloucester, MA, where she often spent summers with her elder daughter, Leslie, painting and showing her work. Mali taught her children contour drawing, poker, how to make an adventure of a misadventure. A natural wordsmith, she enjoyed Scrabble and solving acrostic puzzles, once discovering her father was quoted in the solution. Her creativity was contagious. She wrote and directed family silent films of Shakespeare. She also loved chess, baseball, tennis, her family, and anything beautiful. She was a unique Mom and Bubba and a world class inimitable artist with an unpresumptuous presence. She survived her husband Lester and two of her five children, Austin and Jared. Her unfailing honesty, quick wit, flawless style and bright smile will be missed by her daughters Leslie and Lise, her son Justin; her grandchildren Aram, Naomi, Rebecca, Jessica, Anna, Jamie, Amalia, David, David and Laura; her great-grandchildren Ben, Tim, Zack, Allison, Mian, Abe, Gary, Maggie, Avila and Safara, and many other family and friends. Funeral services will be held at noon on Sunday, May 31 at the Children of Israel cemetery, Miry Brook Road, Danbury, CT. A memorial exhibit is planned for later this year in San Francisco, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the National Museum of Women in the Arts. Sinai Memorial Chapel (925) 962-3636

In 1924, just as in 2009, a filly won the Preakness. In 1924, just as in 2009, the winner of the Kentucky Oaks defeated the colts. That's where the similarities end. For in 2009, there was one filly, Rachel Alexandra who won both the Oaks and the Preakness. In 1924, there were two different fillies who won the Preakness and the Oaks, and the winner of the Preakness was far less accomplished than the winner of the Oaks.

BookExpo America, the publishing industry's annual convention, is, at its core, the event where publishers promote their fall lineup of books. In past years, publishers competed to build enough buzz to have the so-called book of the fair, and novels like "Cold Mountain" and "The Lovely Bones" got their starts there.
