Niall Ferguson claims “that crises are more often caused by bad regulation than by deregulation” (May 17). Our current credit problems have been caused by both. Only a few commentators remember that it was Henry Paulson, who then was chief executive at Goldman Sachs, who led the 2004 request for the S.E.C. to exempt investment banks’ brokerage units from the old net-capital rules that limited their debt leverage. Furthermore, William H. Donaldson, who was the S.E.C. chairman, and his staff decided to rely on the investment firms’ own computer models to measure investment risk. A recipe for disaster was in place. One can hope that Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, and Timothy Geithner, the Treasury secretary, as well as Mary Shapiro, the current S.E.C. chairwoman, will reinstate some effective form of the old net-capital rules. The “haircuts” required worked well for many years. They can and must do so again.james zucker.

The idea of relocating an entire island population is radical and may at some point become unavoidable (Nicholas Schmidle, May 10). The Maldives are a unique place of beauty and serenity, however, and giving them (and a couple of dozen other island states) up to global warming and rising sea levels must be a last resort and not a first best option. We have caused global warming, and we should take responsibility for it now and come up with a lot more ideas, efforts and resources to contain its negative effects. Many ideas have been floated by more or less qualified individuals and organizations. We can try to seed algae growth in the South Pacific with iron powder to extract carbon from the atmosphere. We might pump large amounts of seawater into the Saharan desert to create a huge salt lake, which would potentially feed underground aquifers and natural rainfall in Northeast Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Or we could cover vulnerable glaciers in Greenland with reflective tin foil during the summer months. These are just a few ideas that might help and would not cost billions. Is there an international discussion forum for scientists from different disciplinary and national backgrounds to exchange their views on the feasibility and side effects of existing and new ideas? Have we even started to seriously dedicate our minds to the matter? Or are we still stuck in the Bush administration attitude that global warming is either not happening or not as bad as it sounds or at least not going to strike in our lifetime?.

Myron Scholes, the Nobel Prize-winning economist and arguably the inventor of credit-default swaps, refers self-assuredly and guiltlessly in his interview with Deborah Solomon (Questions for Myron Scholes, May 17) to the Black-Scholes equation used to measure risk and transfer risk and to banks that need models to measure risk. This past year illustrates the irony of even a trace of confidence in such models. The influential British statistician (and chemist) George Box — a pioneer in the areas of quality control, time series analysis, design of experiments and Bayesian inference — is noted also for his warning about models: all models are wrong, but some are useful. That caveat should be a warning plastered across every forecast on risk, public or private.

Regarding William Safire’s On Language column (May 10): Necessity, which John Milton aptly called “the tyrant’s plea,” is a word beloved of political leaders who seek to evade responsibility for their acts. When our Great Decider chose to invade Iraq without clear proof that it threatened either us or its neighbors, he called it “a war of necessity . . . we had no choice.” But in October 1962, when surveillance photographs clearly showed that Soviet missiles deployed in Cuba threatened the American mainland, President John F. Kennedy overruled all those — and there were many — who thought war was necessary. Choosing instead to blockade Cuba until the Soviets withdrew their missiles, he showed what can be freely done by a commander in chief bent on avoiding war until it becomes absolutely necessary.

While I can sympathize somewhat with Edmund L. Andrews and what he went through (May 17), his comment that “I took a certain pride that I outlasted two of my three mortgage lenders” actually left me angered. I am not a fan of these mortgage companies, but a big reason they failed was that borrowers like Andrews felt that it was O.K. to live beyond their means and not do everything they could to honor contracts they signed.

Susan Dominus’s profile of Suze Orman (May 17) showed some of the self-contradictions that fans of the financial guru prefer to ignore. She preaches the importance of honesty about money while creating two different personal mythologies: one in which she has risen above her cash-strapped childhood to enjoy personal comfort and the ability to give charitably, the other in which money is so essential that it is the only thing worth thinking about.

When the design superstar Philippe Starck and his wife, Jasmine, unplug, entertaining is never on the half shell.

Keeping up with the Starcks is nearly impossible: not at work, and certainly not at play. Even when the design superstar Philippe and his wife, Jasmine, unplug, as they do every July at their house near Cap Ferret, France (June is spent on the Venetian island of Burano; August is Formentera), the tiny cabanas surrounding their modest home are filled with friends and family, who gather at the seaside table for an ad hoc lunch that lasts until well after the lights strung in the fig trees have been switched on.

FRIEDMAN--Morris R.,died at 91 on May 23rd. A graduate of the New York City public schools and City College, Morris served in WWII in the European Theater as an officer in Patton's 3rd army. He attended NYU Law School on the GI Bill, which brought him an education and a life he'd never dreamed of. Morris taught taxation at NYU Law where he received an LLM, and for 50 years practiced tax law in New York. In June 1949 he married the beautiful Norma Luloff, later a fashion writer at Vogue, with whom he lived for 58 years. Morris was absolutely devoted to his wife and two children. He had a lifelong passion for Beethoven, Mozart and Brahms, 19th century literature, old film, amateur singing, proper grammar, and progressive politics. He was predeceased by his wife Norma and son Philip, both of whom he tended with loving care. Morris is survived by his adoring daughter Ruth, his loving niece Lorna Peterson and her family, Dale, Zach and Seth, and by his faithful caregivers and friends. Morris Friedman was a generous, honorable, and humble man. His memory can be honored by donations to the Equal Justice Initiative, 122 Commerce Street, Montgomery, Alabama. A memorial celebration of his life will be held in the coming months.
Film Mike Hale

The 1974 adventure series about three companions trapped in a prehistoric world (whose working titles included ''Lost'') spawned a 1991 remake that ran for two seasons on ABC's Saturday morning schedule. In the mid-1990s the Kroffts struck a deal with the Walt Disney Company for a film adaptation of the show; two different scripts were prepared by two different writers, but the Kroffts were disappointed with both. ''Everybody wanted to do another episode, and that just really didn't work,'' Sid Krofft said. ''It needed something special.'' The brothers moved the property to Sony's family division, which the studio shut down on the day a new ''Land of the Lost'' script was delivered. Finally they joined up with Mosaic Entertainment Group, the powerhouse management company, whose clients Jim Carrey and Will Ferrell were considered for the lead role. (Mr. Ferrell, a ''Land of the Lost'' fan since childhood, got the job.) The project landed at Universal, where Mr. Ferrell's longtime collaborator Adam McKay (the director of ''Anchorman'' and ''Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby'') considered directing, as did Robert Rodriguez (''Sin City''), before Brad Silberling (''Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events'') was signed. The film cost an estimated $100 million, or as Marty Krofft said, ''more, probably, than the whole career we did.''
Theater Jason Zinoman

HYUNDAI has been good at generating marketing buzz during the economic downturn, and now the company is at it again. In January, it announced the Hyundai Assurance program, which allows consumers to return their new cars without hurting their credit if they lose their jobs. Then there was Assurance Plus, a one-time payment to the lender that is equal to 90 days of a loan or lease payment. Now a new commercial tells consumers that if they buy a vehicle between now and June 30, Hyundai will send them money for six months.

BELL--Marion Virginia, June 18, 1929 - May 4 2009, died in New York City after a confining illness. Daughter of William Wallace and Alberta Graham Bell, She grew up in Rosslyn Farms, PA, later graduating from the Madeira School and Barnard College. Her career included teaching first grade in a Pittsburgh private school and a stint in California as the librarian for the San Francisco Chronicle, before returning to New York to work in the children's book department at Scribner and Sons and ,after its demise, at the Corner Book Store. Marion was know on the upper east side for the annual cocktail parties she organized for dogs and their owners at the bookstore. She loved animals, books, music, tennis and good food, but had little interest in other worldly goods, leading a spartan life in a studio apartment with two orphaned cats. She walked dogs, volunteered in a cancer clinic for cats and in the gardens of Central Park. She was a flaming liberal who hated any form of injustice and befriended the downtrodden, human or animal. Marion is survived by her sister, Betsy Bell Martin of Pittsburgh, PA, her bother Bill Bell of Brookline, MA. seven neices and nephews, 14 grandneices and nephews and many caring friends. She would have favored memorial donation to the Animal Haven or Amnesty International.

Promoting Trouble In the economics of baseball, one of the most common themes is control. For the first six years of a player's career, the team that brought him up controls his rights. But after a player's third year of service, he gains back some of the control in the form of arbitration, where he can request a much higher salary and his team must make a counteroffer.

IN THE IAO VALLEY, MAUI, HAWAII Barbara Hand Clow, left, 66, an author and teacher, with her husband, Gerry Clow, 60, a polarity and craniosacral therapist, Feb. 26, 2009. ''I had been wanting to go to Maui for about 30 years because my husband comes from a very famous Hawaiian family, the Charles Brewer family. They were originally whalers; his great-great-grandfather arrived in Hawaii on a clipper ship in the 1840s, and the next generation had plantations and ran C. Brewer & Company. So I wanted to explore that and see if I could find remnants. I've got 12 books in print including the ''Mind Chronicles'' trilogy, an exploration of my own past lives. I did 100 sessions under hypnosis, and this is where it gets interesting: I discovered that I was my husband's grandmother. The deepest reason I went to Maui was to see if it was one of those places that felt like I'd been there before. And it was. Now that I dragged him there we're going to go back every two years; it's just exquisite.'' As told to Seth Kugel

BOURNE--George Allen, of Lyme, CT and formerly of Oyster Bay, NY died suddenly May 24, at age 64. Survived by his children John and Katie, sisters Rosemary Bourne and Elizabeth Roche (William), brother William, nieces Elizabeth and Laura, nephew George, and ex-wife Anne Bourne. A graduate of Kent School, University of Connecticut and Columbia School of Business, he also attended University of Pennsylvania. After serving in the United States Marine Corps he had a long career on Wall St, with many years spent at Lehman Bros. George loved life to the end; he was an adoring father, compassionate friend, raconteur, fisherman, hunter, boater, lover of dogs and stray cats. Funeral service will take place at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Old Lyme, CT, Saturday, May 30, 11am. Graveside service at St. John's Cemetery, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, Friday, June 5, 12pm, with Luncheon to follow at Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. In lieu of flowers, donations to Kent School, Kent, CT or Camp Dudley, Westport, NY would be appreciated.

When I started planning my family's trip to Alaska I knew I wanted to spend part of our stay somewhere truly remote, unreachable by road and far from other people. Backpacking into the wilderness seemed daunting (I had read ''Into the Wild,'' Jon Krakauer's account of Christopher McCandless's death in the Alaskan wilderness), but using a cabin as a base seemed to provide the right mixture of getting away from it all and relative comfort. It was relative, though: While cabins are a step up from tents, they generally have no electricity, indoor plumbing or heat other than a wood or oil stove. They do have bunks, but no mattresses, cooking stoves or utensils. Plan on bringing sleeping bags, pads, a cookstove and cooking gear, and all necessary food and drinking water (or a water purifier). Firewood is usually available, but not guaranteed.

IT was fewer than 100 blocks from their shared apartment in Harlem to the Dyckman Houses in Inwood, but for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and his mother and father, who made the move in 1950, it ''was really considered a step up,'' he recalled in an interview last week. ''We had two bedrooms -- for us. We didn't have to share the kitchen or the bathroom.'' Mr. Abdul-Jabbar, 62, then known as Lew Alcindor, spent his childhood in Building 3 on the fifth floor, leaving the complex only after the University of California lured him west. Home reverberated with the round-the-clock clatter of the El and the sounds of his father, a transit officer who had gone to Juilliard, playing trombone and piano. From their windows, the family could see the Cloisters rising in the distance.

STRAND--Ivar Sr. Beloved father, grandfather, father-in-law, uncle and friend, Ivar Strand Sr. passed away in Stange, Norway on April 30, 2009. Ivar was born on August 22, 1919 in Haugesund, Norway, and as a youth, traveled the world with his father, Sea Captain Ivar Strand. He immigrated to New York City in the early 1950s and received his MBA at New York University. He married Gerd Abelvik from Aalesund, Norway in 1957 and together they had two sons who grew up in Brooklyn, NY. He later became a ship broker for States Marine Company and Peraco Chartering Corporation. For the past 15 years, he has split his time between New York and Norway, where his two sons reside respectively. Ivar will always be remembered for his positive outlook on life, his penchant for telling a good story, his love of golf, gardening, Long Island and Norway. He is survived by his two sons: Eric, an American and European Board Certified Specialist in Veterinary Surgery at the Norwegian School of Veterinary Medicine; and Ivar, an Assistant Vice President in the Administration of the State University of New York at Stony Brook. There will be a memorial service at the Norwegians Seamens Church in NYC on June 6th, 2009 at noon.

ROSHKOW--Howard M.,died May 28 after a longstanding battle with prostate cancer. He finally succumbed, but never gave in, displaying the bravery and supreme class that were his calling cards his entire life. Born in the Bronx in 1924, he enlisted in the Air Force at the tender age of 17, eventually being awarded the rank of second lieutenant and becoming the youngest commissioned officer in the Air Force at that time. The military remained the formative, defining experience of his life, endowing him with the maturity and direction he craved as a young man and helped point him to a long, successful career in advertising and corporate communications that would one day take the form of his own agency, Howard-Matthews, Inc. He remained to his dying day the epitome of the selfless husband and doting father and grandfather and served as the unofficial but clearly recognized patriarch of a loving and appreciative extended family. Like his father before him, a man has walked among us. He is survived by his adoring wife of 56 years, Sylvia, his daughter, Julia, his son Matthew, his grandchildren, Rachel, Jacob and Luke, his daughter-in-law Helaine, and son-in-law Steve, as well as his grandcats, Elsa and Grizzabella. Contributions should be made to the New York ASPCA, 520 8th Avenue, 7th Floor, New York, NY, 10018, Attn: Linda Tiramani.

STEFANO PILATI of Yves Saint Laurent is the latest designer to go green. On June 8, he will introduce New Vintage, a capsule line of classic Saint Laurent pieces (the bustier dress, the tailored jacket, the trench coat) cut from the unused cloth of past collections. This season, it is cotton drill, a utilitarian fabric, reinvigorated through embroidery and plasticizing. ''It doesn't have to be organic to be environmentally conscious,'' said Julie Gilhart, the fashion director of Barneys, who has coaxed many designers, including Mr. Pilati, to think more responsibly. ''Stefano made use of something that was already made -- it's sustainable fashion.''

WHEN Sonia Sotomayor first set foot in the Bronxdale Houses along Bruckner Boulevard in 1957, they encapsulated New York's promise. The towers beckoned to the working class as a coveted antidote to some of the city's unlivable residential spaces and, later on, its unfathomable rents. These were not the projects of idle, stinky elevators, of gang-controlled stairwells where drug deals go down. In the 1940s, '50s and '60s, when most of the city's public housing was built, a sense of pride and community permeated well-kept corridors, apartments and grounds. Far from dangerous, the projects were viewed as nurturing. There are more than 400,000 residents in the New York City Housing Authority's 2,611 buildings at any given time. Judge Sotomayor, President Obama's nominee for the United States Supreme Court, is just one of more than 100 marquee names on a city list of alumni.

HOFFMANN--Catharine Baldwin died peacefully at age 93 on May 27th in Basking Ridge, NJ. She was predeceased by her husband of 59 years, William L. Hoffmann. She lived in East Orange and New Vernon, NJ, retiring to Bridgehampton, NY, before returning to Fellowship Village in Basking Ridge. Catharine was a graduate of Hood College, Frederick, MD, and served on its Board of Trustees. A gifted writer, her stories and poems delighted generations of readers. Catharine was a volunteer for many organizations including Morristown Memorial Hospital where she was on the Board of Trustees and President of the Women's Association. She was also President of The Women's Club of Orange. She is survived by four children: John (and Nancy) of Spring Island, SC and NY, Anne Moore (and Richard) of Mendham, NJ, James (and Martha) of Cambridge MA, and Ellen Wallop (and Michael) of NY; seven grandchildren and three Great- Grandchildren. She is also survived by her brother Robert H. B. Baldwin, of Hobe Sound, FL, Princeton, NJ and Bridgehampton. Funeral services will be Monday June 1st at St. Mark's Church, Mendham, at 11 am. Visiting hours will be 4-7pm at Bailey Funeral Home, Mendham on Sunday May 31. There will be a service at St. Ann's Church, Bridgehampton on June 15th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Catharine B. Hoffmann Jane Swift Moore Memorial Fund for children's literature at Mendham Borough Library, Mendham NJ 07945.

ROSS--Michael "Mickey". President Gregory H. Williams and the faculty, students, staff and alumni of The City College of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Michael "Mickey" Ross, CCNY Class of 1939. A dedicated son of City College, Mr. Ross created the Michael and Irene Ross Program in Jewish Studies at his alma mater early last year. "Mr. Ross' generosity and vision in coupling his love for his alma mater with his love for Judaism and Yiddish culture has enabled City College's thriving Jewish Studies program, which gives students from diverse backgrounds new insights into their own experiences, to become even stronger," President Williams said. The Michael and Irene Ross Program in Jewish Studies includes new offices, conference space and a library, and supports scholarships, publication of a newsletter, and a wide range of activities, including conferences, lectures, visiting professorships and student and faculty trips to places of significance in Judaism and Jewish culture. Close to 100 majors and 500 other students are taking coursework in the area. In addition to endowing the Program in Jewish Studies, the gift from Mr. Ross establishes the Michael and Irene Ross Chair in Hebrew and Yiddish. The College will conduct a national search for a prominent scholar to fill this position. A graduate of Seward Park High School, Isadore Rovinsky, as he was known then, majored in social science at City College. He also participated in intramural swimming and was vice president of Theatron. Early in his career, he formed a comedy partnership with a CCNY classmate, Bernard West, Class of 1939. Together, they created and produced some of the most famous shows in television, including the breakout sitcom "All in the Family," which explored prejudice and the social mores of the 1970s, and earned Mr. Ross and Mr. West an Emmy for Outstanding Writing Achievement in Comedy in 1973. Other shows Mr. Ross worked on include "The Jeffersons" and "Three's Company." Michael Ross' legacy will live on at City College, ensuring that future generations of CCNY students will have the opportunity to study and benefit from his generosity and to honor his name.

THE British fashion photographer Miles Aldridge is known for his decadent color-drenched images depicting women in erotic dreamlike settings. Some stem from personal experience (a fashion feature portraying a woman being seduced in a Rolls recalls an adolescent romp with his girlfriend); others are simply the product of an overactive imagination. All of them begin as rather crude sketches. In his new book, ''Miles Aldridge: Pictures for Photographs'' (Editions 7L/Steidl, $125), he has set these doodles, which serve as a kind of a storyboard, against the actualized photos, offering insight into the way he works. ''Certainly, I'm not the first man to draw naked pictures of women and wonder how to make them come to life,'' he noted drolly.

OH, it's not too hilly, said the woman at Syncline Wine Cellars when I called for directions from the Lewis and Clark Highway, somewhere southeast of Bingen, Wash. Just bike east to the Klickitat River, she said, turn left, and you'll be there in no time. I was skeptical. To my right was the Columbia River, wide and as steely as the clouds above. To my left, a sheer rock face, behind which rose yet more hills -- the hills that led to my ultimate goal, three promising wineries in the Columbia River Gorge. Back in Oregon, the wines, particularly down in the Willamette Valley but also along the Columbia, were well-known, easier to reach and, thanks to a decade-plus of buzz, not exactly affordable.

INSPIRED by Paris in the 1920s, and its fascination with African culture, Bal d'Afrique, the latest unisex scent from the fashionable Swedish fragrance brand Byredo, has proved to be quite captivating. Based on a mix of vetiver and tonka (a vanilla substitute), with notes of amber and lemon, the warm, citrusy fragrance has sold out twice since hitting Barneys last month. Ben Gorham, an art school graduate who founded Byredo in 2006, isn't all that surprised. ''It has a power and character,'' he said. ''People have just fallen for it.'' Come the end of June, Byredo will introduce its next fragrance, Blanche, a soft clean scent based on the idea of innocence -- loosely translated.

The 1969 television series, about a boy (Jack Wild of ''Oliver!'') in a magical realm run by a dragon mayor, established the trippy bona fides of the Kroffts, who say they were inspired by the era's colorful counterculture but never indulged in it. It gave birth to a 1970 feature film whose cast included Cass Elliot of the Mamas and the Papas. Sony attempted a big-budget remake around 2001, with Julian Fellowes (''Gosford Park'') attached to write the script, but dropped the project. (The lesson learned: ''Don't have anybody around who didn't grow up with the shows,'' Marty Krofft said.) The studio is now looking to revive ''Pufnstuf,'' with Dennis McNicholas (a screenwriter of ''Land of the Lost'') writing and Conrad Vernon (''Shrek 2,'' ''Monsters Vs. Aliens'') directing. The Kroffts hope Johnny Depp plays the villainous sorceress Witchiepoo, though they emphasize that Mr. Depp is not attached to the film.

MAYBE 2009 has had its challenges, but once again we've made it to summer, the season to hit the road on the weekend and wander, teasing the senses with the view over the next hill, the squish of sand on an unfamiliar beach, and the chef's spiciest barbecue in a faraway locale. Between now and Labor Day, this summer is serving up 14 weekends. To go with them, here are 14 weekend destinations, offering simple and exotic pleasures. Scale a mountain, dance to folk music, nibble some fudge, groove to classic rock, float down a river, fly a kite, pedal around an island and, please, for your sanity, get hot sauce on your chin. SMITH--David Joseph, of Upper Nyack, NY a distinguished and beloved academic, biochemist and dentist, died on May 24, 2009 at age 87. Born in Brooklyn, NY on August 8, 1921, and educated at Brooklyn Boys High and New York University, he graduated from Columbia University Dental School in 1944. He served in the US Army during WWII and as the prison dentist at the International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg, supervising the dental treatment of the accused, including Hermann Goering and Albert Speer. After the War, he practiced dentistry in Manhattan for seven years, then worked in Albany for the State Health Dept, principally with the well-known Kingston-Newburgh fluoridation studies. In 1963 he was appointed Associate Professor of Biochemistry at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, and later served as Acting Assistant Dean of Columbia School of Dental and Oral Surgery. In 1974 he became Professor of Biochemistry and Chairman of the Department of Human Biochemistry at Fairleigh Dickinson School of Dentistry, retiring in 1985. In retirement he traveled widely, and served from 1997-2005 as an Upper Nyack Village Trustee. Devoted husband to Sylvia, his wife of 64 years; loving father to his three daughters, Judith (Brian) Dobbs, of London, England; Lois (Charles) Goldsmith of Croton-on-Hudson, NY and Diane Smith of Manhattan; and grandfather extraordinaire to David, Charlotte, Michael and Jonathon. A memorial service will be held Thursday, June 11, 2009, at 6pm at the Valley Cottage Public Library, 110 Route 303, Valley Cottage, NY 10989. Donations may be made to the Valley Cottage Public Library.

When marshals have to make a federal courthouse safe (maybe Bernie Madoff is on the docket), they check that they have their body armor, their tear gas, their handcuffs, weapons -- and a copy of Form 531B. Developed in March 2003, the red, white and blue card contains pertinent questions to ask if a bomb threat is phoned in, along with suggestions for how to pick up other potential clues about the pending danger. There was no such warning on Monday, when a Starbucks on the Upper East Side was damaged by a bomb, or May 20, when the authorities accused four men with planting what they took to be explosives near two synagogues in the Bronx.

HEISEY--W. Lawrence. It is with great sadness that his family announces the death of W. Lawrence Heisey on Thursday, May 28, 2009, as a result of complications from an eight year confrontation with Parkinsons disease. He lived an active, full and happy life enjoying 35 years of laughter and companionship with his second wife Barclay Ann (Smith) of Hamilton, who predeceased him in March of 2007. He was also predeceased by his parents, Karl Brooks Heisey of Markham and Alice Isabel (Smith) of Unionville, his younger brother Karl Brooks, his first wife Donna Bell (Marshall), mother of his two natural children, Janet Elizabeth, and Mark Alexander. He will be missed by his grandchildren Adam, Philip and Claudia Winterton, son-in-law Brock Winterton and step-daughter Brenda Baldocchi and her son Peter Dixon, his surviving brother Alan and wife Barbara and nephews Alan Milliken, Peter, Robin and David Heisey and niece Kate McFarland. He will be missed by friends and business associates from his years at Proctor and Gamble, Standard Broadcasting and Harlequin Enterprises. He served on a number of corporate and charitable boards and was celebrated by being named an Officer of the Order of Canada for his community involvements. His charitable involvements included early days at The Toronto French School, The Canadian Film Centre, York University, The Banff Centre, The Art Gallery of Ontario and his great passion, the National Ballet of Canada. He joined Harlequin as President in 1971 and spent the next years in a whirlwind of exciting growth and acquisition. He later became chairman and finally Chairman Emeritus. Many thanks to Mrs. Jocelyne Desrochers, Ms. Swavka Moryl and Dr. David Smith for their years of caring. There will be a small, private family funeral. Please send flowers to someone you love.

REGARDED, for the most part, as a fall wardrobe staple, leopard print is changing its spots. This season it is popping up all over the place, in a slew of bright summery hues: bubblegum pink and turquoise at Lanvin (pictured here on the Teen Vogue editor Amy Astley, inset); lavender and acid yellow at Just Cavalli; electric blue at Temperley. For her latest Topshop collection, which arrived in the New York store on May 25, Kate Moss did a swingy cocktail dress in a baby blue variation. ''There must be something in the air,'' said Ulrika Lundgren, the stylist turned designer behind the Swedish label Rika. Her spring collection includes easy cotton pieces punched up in a hot pink leopard print. ''I wanted to do it, but not in a classic way. I wanted to give it a modern twist -- something a little rock 'n' roll.'' Compared with, say, Roberto Cavalli, and his clash of wild prints, Ms. Lundgren prefers to keep the rest of the outfit simple: denim shorts and a pair of high heels. ''I'm Swedish,'' she explained.

MEADES--Gertrude Webb, the wife of the late Harry Meades, military hero who served as a Royal Air Force Officer and was decorated four times and held five Combat Medals. She was the granddaughter of former Mayor William J. Gaynor of New York City, NY. Gertrude passed away peacefully Saturday, May 9, 2009 at her home in Naples, Florida. She was raised in Manhasset, New York and known to her family and friends as "Punchie." Gertrude Webb Meades was born February 28, 1925 the fourth child of five children whose parents were William Seward Webb, Jr. and Gertrude Gaynor Webb. Her father was the founder of Webb and Knapp, real estate agent, and son of the late William Seward Webb, railroad builder and his mother was the late Mrs. Eliza Osgood Webb, a daughter of William H. Vanderbilt. Mrs. Meades mother was the late Gertrude Gaynor Webb, daughter of William J. Gaynor and Elizabeth Handwright. Her parents fortunes enabled the Webb's and Vanderbilt's to be among the earliest to enjoy summers in Shelburne, Vermont and go on to create the world renowned "Shelburne Museum". (The Shelburne Museum was founded by Electra Havemayer Webb and her husband J. Watson Webb whose parents were Dr. William Seward Webb and Lila Vanderbilt Webb. Their 19th century lakeside estate would become Shelburne Farms.) Gertrude (Punchie) Webb Meades, longtime character of life, regaled in living life to the fullest with long freighter trips to exotic ports of call, the love of animal husbandry, she had a passion for reading and enjoyed the solitude of needlepoint. She spent many productive years as a volunteer with the Naples Community Hospital Blood Bank. There was no one else like this woman, lovingly known as Punchie. She will be remembered for her love of family, her dear friends, her zest for life, and her elegantly gentle kind outlook on life, graceful manners, wit and warmth. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by Emma II, her "Pug", her two sons, Michael Harry Meades of Apopka, Florida and Jamie Seward Meades of Sarasota, Florida, three granddaughters, Heather Portanova, Meredith Magennis and Mindy Meades and great-grandchildren, Caitlin Magennis, Caleb Portanova and Kayli Portanova. In addition, she is survived by her sister Frederica Webb Gamble of Westwood, MA, her nieces, Frederique Gamble, Susan Webb Porter and nephew W. Seward Webb. Memorial service was conducted Saturday, May 16, 2009 at the St. John's Episcopal Church, Naples, Florida. In lieu of flowers, family and friends may make contributions in Punchie's name to Vitas Innovative Hospice Care: Naples, Florida, Animal Refuge Center of Fort Myers: North Fort Myers, Florida or the Naples Community Hospital Blood Center: Naples, Florida.

ISAACSON--Katy. The partners and staff of Joel Isaacson & Co. are deeply saddened by the passing of Katy. We were blessed to have known her. May 26: The Museum of Modern Art held its annual Party in the Garden, an occasion that signals the end of the spring benefit season. For the first time: no black tie; informality was the mood. The 550 dinner guests served themselves, and many sat on sofas, plates in laps. For others, there were glass tables, no tablecloths. After dinner, 1,000 guests came by for a party and a concert by Estelle. The event raised over $1.8 million. 1. DAVID ROCKEFELLER, center, with some of his relatives.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''From Preps to the Pinnacle of the N.B.A.,'' May 28: There is no reason to think that high school players will become better through four years of college ball (with lesser coaches and teammates, competing demands and restrictions on practice time) than by prepping on an N.B.A. team (with superior coaches and teammates and a focused, open-ended commitment).

SCHOEN--Andrew J.,died Thursday, May 28. He is survived by his two loving children, Douglas E. Schoen of New York, NY and Sarah A. Schoen of Denver, CO, his son-in-law, Ken Rothstein and his devoted grandson, Joshua Evan. He is also survived by his second wife, Ginger Strauss and his first wife Carol Schoen. He was a graduate of Harvard College, class of 1947 and Harvard Law School, class of 1950, where he was an editor of the Law Review. He served for more than 50 years as an esteemed partner of the firm of Rosenman, Colin and Freund and its successor firm. Known and respected by all who knew him and worked with him, he was passionately committed to the law and social justice. He was a longtime member and officer of Sunningdale Country Club, and served in the 1970s and 1980s as president of the board of trustees of Columbia Grammar School. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 31, 12pm at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street.

WACHTEL--Allan, died peacefully at Englewood Hospital, New Jersey, on Thursday, May 28 after a long illness. There will be a funeral service in New York City, Monday, June 1, 2009 at 11am at the Plaza Community Center (212-769-4400), 630 Amsterdam Avenue at West 91st Street, followed by burial at the Stockbridge Cemetery in Massachusetts. Please call the funeral parlor for New Jersey Shiva information. Although he graduated from Newport News High School in Virginia during a brief family business venture, he was mostly a native New Yorker until moving to New Jersey with his wife Marilyn Umlas Wachtel just in time for Op-Sail. He was a consummate businessman forming his own corporation, Wachtel Mechanical Services. He also was President of the Chock Full of Nuts Franchise Owners Association which he helped set up. Among other business ventures, he expanded into the areas of fire protection services and with his wife owns Action Sprinkler Systems and Goldman Fire Prevention. Allan liked to travel, discuss world affairs and read mysteries and adventure novels and loved to "tune-out" by watching violent movies. Allan had a heart of gold and a soft underbelly, lending money to friends or getting them jobs and helping them stay out of trouble, while maintaining a slightly porcupine exterior. All who know him understood they could count on him whenever he gave his word. He is survived by his wife, Marilyn and the in-laws on that side, Robert and Judy Umlas and their children Jared, Stefanie and her fiance Shaun. He is also survived by his sister Dorothy and her husband Irwin Fingerit, dear friends and many loving cousins. In lieu of flowers, please donate to your favorite charity in his name and advise. Or send a contribution to the United Fire Fighters Association for Widows and Children at 204 East 23rd St., 5th floor, New York, NY or your local Ambulance Corp.
KELMAN--Charles. It has been 5 years, not a day goes by... We love you. Lesley, David, Noah, Adam and Claire

In lieu of flowers, donations to UJA-Federation of NY, Donor Center, 130 East 59th Street, New York, NY 10022, would be gratefully appreciated.

SAWITSKY--Arthur, M.D.,93, of Roslyn and East Hampton, NY passed away peacefully at his home on May 28, 2009 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Barbara, father of Kitt (Heather) and Edith (Michael Keane), brother of Claire. Loving grandfather of Aaron, Luke and Karin and great-grandfather of Anna and Herman. Graduate of NYU and NYU School of Medicine (1940), Major US Army and WWII combat veteran (Europe). Pioneering hematologist-oncologist on Long Island. Professor of Medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Chief of the Division of Hematology-Oncology at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY until his retirement. Teacher, mentor and role model for three generations of young physicians who went on to make important contributions in their fields. PATRICK--Julian. American baritone Julian Patrick died peacefully Thursday, May 7, 2009. A versatile singer, Patrick had a prolific fifty-year career singing concerts, musicals, cabaret, and opera, and towards the end of his life teaching. Born in Meridian, Mississippi, in 1927, Patrick came to music early in his childhood. After high school, he joined the Navy and served as a singer with Special Services. At 23, in 1951, he made his operatic debut in Mobile, Alabama, in La traviata. Shortly thereafter Patrick was drafted into the Army and was stationed in New York where he sang with the first Army Band. When he completed his service, he sang in night clubs and began auditioning for Broadway, where he made his debut in 1954 in Jerome Moross's The Golden Apple. Patrick was in the original companies of Once Upon a Mattress, Ziegfeld Follies, Bells are Ringing, and Fiorello. He revisited the musical stage often in his career for roles in works like 1776, Sweeney Todd, The Most Happy Fella, and South Pacific. In the mid-1960s, Patrick returned to opera as a principal of the Metropolitan Opera National Company (Figaro in The Barber of Seville and the Count in The Marriage of Figaro, among others) and toured the nation for two years; after it's demise, in 1967, he joined New York City Opera, making his debut in Douglas Moore's Carrie Nation the next year. Patrick sang in world premieres at City Opera of The Tempest by Lee Hoiby, Nine Rivers From Jordan by Hugo Weisgall, and Leonard Bernstein's Trouble in Tahiti. He worked with Dominick Argento on two world-premieres, singing the lead in Cassanova's Homecoming and a role specifically written for him in The Dream of Valentino. Mr. Patrick's most prominent work in contemporary American opera was with Carlisle Floyd in Of Mice and Men. Patrick sang the role of George in the world premiere of Of Mice and Men in 1970 at Seattle Opera. Patrick sang performed eighteen roles in nearly thirty productions with Seattle Opera, including Alberich in The Ring of the Nibelung in five different series of cycles over an eleven year period, as well as such comic roles as Dr. Dulcamara in The Elixir of Love. He also sang Alberich at the Metropolitan Opera on several occasions. Patrick sang at many other major U.S. opera houses, including San Francisco Opera, Houston Grand Opera, Washington National Opera, and Lyric Opera of Chicago. Overseas he was heard in many theaters, including the Netherlands Opera, Grand Theatre de Geneve, and the Vienna Volksoper. Mr. Patrick served as a professor of voice at the University of Washington from 1990 until 2005. He served as head of the vocal department from 1996 until 2005. He continued to teach and coach young singers until his passing. Mr. Patrick's work was recorded for RCA, Columbia, Desto, and various other labels. Mr. Patrick is survived by his partner of fifty-six years, Donn Talenti. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials and tributes be made to Seattle Opera. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on June 27 at the Nesholm Lecture Hall of McCaw Hall at Seattle Center.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''If Vick Is Sincere, Give Him a Chance to Prove It,'' May 25: I remind Harvey Araton and other apologists that Michael Vick is a convicted felon and that Alex Rodriguez has yet to be charged with a crime. The situations are different.

Last weekend, weddings and Sweet 16 parties added glamour to the city's parks and the new traffic-free Times Square. The most stunning dress I saw, right, was home-sewn and represented to my eye a shift away from the old Cinderella gown toward Grecian draping. The bride's mother had gathered a swath of organza at the hip with a feathered flower. The train fell to the side. The dress had the spirit of the silent movie era and recalled an autumn bride, top right, with a band of heirloom lace covering her forehead. I saw many bridesmaids in black, some carrying black calla lilies, and young men in rakish fedoras. But some things never change: after the posed photos, it's off with the elegant shoes, and on with the flip-flops.

TALK SHOW I wish I had daily access to Jonathan Miller's thoughts on significant current events. On one taping with him on my old PBS show, the news had just broken of the attempt to ban the teaching of ''the theory of evolution'' in schools. I archly asked him if he would submit his own children to the ''poisonous teachings of Charles Darwin.'' He said he would as readily as he would expose them to ''the poisonous teachings of Isaac Newton.'' He stated his ''respect for people's religious beliefs'' but not for ''this particular bit of nonsense.'' Jonathan observed that referring to the ''theory'' of evolution is like saying the ''theory'' of gravity. Jonathan spouts original insights and observations on just about anything. Once, as we waited backstage to go on together at the 92nd St. Y, I pointed disapprovingly at his lit cigarette, causing him to talk entertainingly about some of the ironic rationales of the smoker who's aware he's doing wrong: ''I know these will kill me. I'm just not convinced that this particular one will kill me.''

O'HARE--Douglas Kennard, an educator for over 40 years, died Friday after a courageous battle with cancer. He was 63. He leaves a legacy of 25 years of inspiring students at the Stephen Gaynor School with a love for learning. Over the years he touched so many, and changed the lives of so many more. For each and every one of his students, he opened the door to the enchantment of literature, history, poetry, reading and writing. Prior to Doug's move to New York City in 1983, he resided in Washington, DC where he was a Coordinator at the St. Maurice Day School in Potomac, MD. Doug has no immediate family members surviving him. He is predeceased by his parents, Mary Ann O'Hare and Winston L. O'Hare, and two brothers, Steven Bradford O'Hare and John O'Hare. A 1969 graduate of the University of Maryland in English, he earned his master's degree in Education from Catholic University in Washington, DC in 1976. Doug's presence will be greatly missed at the Stephen Gaynor School where he touched the lives and left a lasting mark on so many of his colleagues. Services: A memorial service will be held at the Stephen Gaynor School 148 West 90th Street - on Wednesday, June 3, 2009 at 5:00pm. Prior to Doug's passing, in lieu of flowers, he requested expressions of sympathy be made to the Doug O'Hare Scholarship at the Stephen Gaynor School. Contributions should be made to the Stephen Gaynor School, c/o Development Office, 148 West 90th Street, New York, NY 10024.

9 P.M. (HBO) INTO THE STORM (2009) The charismatic leadership and soaring rhetoric of Winston Churchill played a vital role in the defeat of the Nazis in World War II. Yet his political prowess ultimately undermined his career and threatened his marriage. In this drama from the director Thaddeus O'Sullivan and the writer Hugh Whitemore, Churchill and his wife, Clemmie (Brendan Gleeson and Janet McTeer, right), go on holiday in France. As Britain heads to the polls to choose a postwar prime minister, the couple look back at the war years while pondering Churchill's fate. Len Cariou plays President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, discuss the nomination of Federal Judge Sonia Sotomayor to the United States Supreme Court. The debate continues with Senator Arlen Specter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace'' at 10 on Fox; Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, on ''Meet the Press'' at 10:30 on NBC; and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, on ''Face the Nation'' at 10:30 on CBS.

STABILE--Vincent Joseph, an executive with JetBlue Airways, died on May 23rd at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Columbia University Medical Center, following a profound stroke suffered at his home in Mamaroneck, NY. He was 55 years old. Mr. Stabile, a senior vice president in charge of Human Resources for the "People" department as it is called by the airline, was part of the team that fostered the company's culture and oversaw the growth of JetBlue from 1,600-11,500 crewmembers during his eight year tenure. Recently he assumed a senior advisory role with the corporation. Known for his interpersonal skills, Vinny, as everyone called him, began his career as an Executive Trainer and Employment Manager with Macy's New York and then continued in the retail world with Saks Fifth Avenue from 1981 forward in various Human Resource positions both at the flagship store and in the corporate offices before moving to Ziff Davis Publishing in 1996 as the Director of Human Resources. When Ziff Davis was divided and sold, Mr. Stabile was promoted and became Vice President of Human Resources for the newly formed Ziff Davis Media in April of 2000. Finally, on September 11, 2001, he joined JetBlue as "Vice President of People." Vinny Stabile was passionate about music and a gifted, self-taught guitarist and singer. He played solo and in numerous bands during his life, joining a Mamaroneck- based group called "The Circuit Riders" in 1995. This band performed for over twelve years at charitable events in the tri-state area as well as venues such as the New York City Marathon, The Bitter End, corporate retreats, private parties and numerous other community events. When the Circuit Riders ended their run in 2007, Vinny joined Free Lunch Rock Band also based in Mamaroneck. Vinny's priorities in life were always clear to anyone he met: his love for his family, his positive, down to earth attitude, extraordinary work ethic and his playfulness. Vinny was a devoted husband and father, a special friend, trusted colleague, mentor and advisor who touched the lives of so many. Vincent J. Stabile was born in the Bronx, graduated from Regis High School in Manhattan in 1971 and received a BS from Fordham University in 1975. He earned his Masters degree in Psychology from the New School for Social Research in 1977. Stabile is survived by his wife of 29 years, Allison Stone Stabile and his sons Christopher and Joshua, as well as his mother Carmela Stabile and his sister Claudia Stabile, both of Pelham Manor, NY. In addition, Vinny leaves behind myriad loving aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces, nephews, and in-laws. Information regarding his memorial service and donation information will be released shortly.

FRAME--Clara (nee Horicht), artist, translator, generous soul, lost too soon at 47, in Los Angeles, on April 6. Safely at rest on the Frame family farm in Delaware Co., NY. Missed by David and his family in America, her family in Europe, and friends. "Come to me, and I will give you rest."

POWERS--John Austin. On May 23rd, Jack, 82, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his beloved family, having fought a tenacious four year battle with Myeloma. Throughout his illness Jack never lost the dignity, gallant courage, or determination that so marked his life. He is deeply mourned by his loving wife of 47 years, Eileen, and by their children, Cecilia Owen and Jennifer Powers. From his previous marriage, he is survived by John Powers, Jr. and Maribeth Moody. Born in New York, Jack served his country in WW II and later graduated from St. Peter's College. During his career in advertising, Jack served as President of McCann-Erickson in Europe and America, ultimately leaving that post to become the Chairman and COO of Heublein, Inc., now Diageo. He served on various boards and dedicated himself to charitable interests, particularly in education and medicine. Devoted to family and friends, Jack's life was shaped by perseverance. We will remember his integrity, his business acumen and his enchantment with his family and grandchildren. Jack was a memorable presence, with limitless vitality and a keen intellect, who sought challenges in every aspect of life. Friends knew him to be engaging, loyal, and unflagging in his support. Jack possessed just enough knowledge about power tools to be dangerous, and his legendary repair projects are the stuff of family lore. He will not be forgotten. A memorial service will be held in New York on Wednesday, June 10th at 4pm at St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue. In his memory, donations may be made to Jack's endowment to Pain and Palliative Care Service (Attn: Dr. Kathleen M. Foley) at MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

PEEBLER--Charles D.,Jr. There will be a Memorial Mass for Chuck Peebler on Tuesday, June 2nd at 2pm in New York City at St. Patrick's Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to The Peebler PSP Research Foundation, 74-923 Highway 111-PMB 226, Indian Wells, CA 92210.

It's not that I didn't think my family was complete with my three boys; it was just I knew that we had room for one more. We said, 'You know what? We don't care where we get our fourth child from. We basically want to go where there's a need.' Then I was like, 'Listen, I have one request: I have three boys; can I ask for a girl?' And that was it. That was the start of our journey. You know, she didn't really have a big adjustment period. She just, like, O.K. I'm here. She saw pink, she saw her room -- we didn't even have to tell her. And that was it. She wanted to do everything her older brothers did. Everything. Whatever they said, she mimicked.

KERN--Kenneth Roland, 87, died Monday, May 11, 2009 at Stonebridge in Skillman, NJ. He was born in Cleveland, Ohio June 15, 1921 and was a graduate of Case Western Reserve 1947 in Chemical Engineering. In 1982, he established the Lester Kern '39 Computational Laboratory at Case Western in memory of his brother. As an Army veteran of WWII, he served in Europe earning the Purple Heart. Later he became a captain in the reserve. In 1955 he married Nancy Lee Huber of Baltimore, MD and moved to Princeton, in 1956, where he established a publishing firm that produced Chemical and Pharmaceutical directories. His offices were located first in Upper Pyne and later in Lower Pyne in Princeton. In 1970-71, he was featured in Who's Who in Finance and Industry. He and his wife became involved with the Humane Society of the United States and the Princeton deer problem. Swareflex were donated and installed on The Great Road and special high deer accident signs were created and installed throughout Princeton Township. With the HSUS, they introduced and pioneered the contraception program that is now in operation. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Nancy Lee Kern. Funeral services and burial were private. Services are under the direction of The Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton.
EDELMAN--Hilda W.,Our diva, then and now. With us always. Diana and Alex

The stock market rallied again last week and commodity prices surged to their biggest monthly gains since 1974, while Treasury yields bounced up and down. For the month of May, the MSCI World index rose 8.7 percent, its best monthly performance in more than 30 years, according to Bloomberg. The futures price of a barrel of crude oil in New York settled at $66.31 a barrel on Friday, up from $61.67 the previous week, and its highest close since November.

The gender-bending 1976 gloss on Batman, about a pair of female crime fighters, was revisited for a 2001 WB pilot starring Markie Post (''Night Court'') as a washed-up Electra Woman, whose husband had left her for Dyna Girl. (The cynical approach didn't get far with the network.) At present there are no feature plans for the property, though the Kroffts would love to see it made into a movie starring Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, or possibly Diablo Cody, whom Marty Krofft met on the ''Land of the Lost'' set. ''I said, 'How do you make a regular living?' '' he recalled asking Ms. Cody, the writer of ''Juno.'' ''She said, 'I write screenplays.' I said: 'Really? Have you ever gotten any success?' ''

THE Terrafugia Transition, a flying-car concept that achieved a brief but successful maiden flight in March, will make what is being called its first major public appearance at the Greenwich Concours d'Élégance on June 6 and 7. Alas, the Transition won't be flying in Greenwich, Conn., that weekend. But it will be on display, along with some 300 cars and motorcycles dating from 1900 to the present. A collection of classic yachts will be shown, while special exhibits will honor Morgan's 100th anniversary and Mini's 50th.

The Kroffts' attempt to grapple with the British music invasion of the 1960s, about a young British pop band whose members were insect-human hybrids who lived in a world of talking plants, had a one-season run in 1970. Jersey Films, the production company then run by Danny DeVito, Stacey Sher and Michael Shamberg, started development on a film for Universal in the mid-'90s, but nothing came of it. (''The writer never put pencil to paper,'' Marty Krofft said.) Today the Kroffts would like to revive the show for younger viewers, though the project is still in the larval stage. ''We're not sure whether it's preschool, 6 to 12, or prime time,'' Marty Krofft said. ''We're not even there yet.''

SHIFF-Doris. Beloved wife of the late Ben Barnett Shiff. Loving mother of Joel and mother-in-law of Jane. Loving grandmother of Adam and Deena, Jonathan and Laurie and Gabriel and Ranit. Loving great-grandmother of Benjamin, Sammy, Emily and Charlie. For service information, call Boulevard-Riverside Chapels 516-295-3100.

When he began his career as a senior analyst at General Motors in 1984, Fritz Henderson probably never dreamed that 25 years later, his name would be on the top of a court document describing how the giant automaker landed in bankruptcy protection.
And the honor of handling General Motors‘ bankruptcy filing goes to — Robert E. Gerber.

It is a company that helped lift hundreds of thousands of American workers into the middle class. It transformed Detroit into the Silicon Valley of its day, a symbol of America’s talent for innovation. It built celebrated cars, like Cadillacs, that became synonymous with luxury.
General Motors filed for bankruptcy protection in federal court in Manhattan on Monday, a humbling fate for the longtime titan of American industry.
Chevrolet-Saturn of Harlem became the first affiliate of General Motors to seek Chapter 11 protection as the carmaker prepares for a massive government-sponsored restructuring.

Ford Motor stands alone among Detroit’s Big Three in dodging a shareholder-crushing government bailout. If automobile sales continue to slide, that may be a short-lived accolade. If not, it is a testament to the carmaker’s hard work, smart financial planning and competent management, Breakingviews says.

President Obama will push General Motors into bankruptcy protection on Monday, making a risky bet that by temporarily nationalizing the onetime icon of American capitalism, he can save at least a diminished automaker that is competitive.

With General Motors about to follow Chrysler into bankruptcy, the ability of the United States to bounce back from the steep recession is being hobbled, The New York Times’s Louis Uchitelle writes.
It is not every 31-year-old who, in a first government job, finds himself dismantling General Motors and rewriting the rules of American capitalism.

Schwartz of The New York Times reports from Paris.

As General Motors formally filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday, many eyes on Wall Street turned to GMAC, which said it would not follow G.M. into Chapter 11. But credit rating agencies are still skeptical of the financing company’s ability to hold on.
President Obama said Monday that the bankruptcy of General Motors marked “the end of an old General Motors and the beginning of a new General Motors.”
As General Motors went bankruptcy protection on Monday, Delphi, a former unit of the giant automaker, unveiled a new plan to leave it.

General Motors followed Chrysler into bankruptcy on Monday in a case that will be one of the largest and most complex in history. It hopes to follow the same path Chrysler has taken through court, but there will be some differences between the two cases. Micheline Maynard of The New York Times takes a look at some basics of the G.M. bankruptcy.

Measured by the size of its assets, General Motors‘s Chapter 11 case isn’t the largest the nation has ever seen. That dubious honor belongs to the investment bank Lehman Brothers, which reported about $691 billion in assets when it collapsed into bankruptcy protection in mid-September.

To train for my first marathon, I’m using the “run-walk” method, popularized by the distance coach Jeff Galloway, a member of the 1972 Olympic team.When I mentioned this to a colleague who runs, she snickered — a common reaction among purists.

The back wall of the Ara Pacis Museum in Rome was splattered with paint in an attack by vandals, Roman police said on Monday, according to The Associated Press. The museum, designed by the American architect Richard Meier, has been a source of controversy since its 2006 opening. At that time, it was the first major civic building completed in the city’s historic center in more than a half-century, but critics said that its angular modern design clashed with the classical architecture surrounding it. The vandals pelted the museum’s white wall with balloons filled with red and green paint. They also left a porcelain toilet and two packs of toilet paper nearby. The museum houses a carved sacrificial altar that was built in 9 B.C. for the emperor Augustus as a symbol of Roman peace and restored in the 1930s by Mussolini.

When you next crack open a retirement card only to hear Roy Scheider telling you that you’re going to need a bigger boat, or tear into a birthday greeting and are met with the sound of Steve Carell screaming “Kelly Clarkson!” as his hair is ripped from his skin, now you’ll know why. Variety reported that NBC Universal had made a deal with Hallmark Cards to create a line of greeting cards that use content from the studio’s film, television and music libraries. Among the products planned are greeting cards that use sound clips from movies including “Jaws” and “The 40-Year-Old Virgin” and television shows including “The Office,” “30 Rock” and “Battlestar Galactica,” as well as audio from the NBC News archives. The deal also calls for a line of cards planned around the studio’s first 3D computer animated feature, “Despicable Me,” which will be released next year.

“Defiance” will be released on DVD on Tuesday and we have a look at the first five minutes of the film. Edward Zwick directed this tale of Jewish resistance to the Nazis in Belarus, starring Daniel Craig, Liev Schreiber and Jamie Bell. In his original review of the film, A. O. Scott wrote, “‘Defiance’ celebrates strong men (who in real life sought no such glory) at the expense of those whose weakness — whose inability to fight back, or to stay alive — was not a moral failure but a fact of history.”

The Shubert Foundation, a prominent grant-maker to nonprofit theaters and dance companies in the United States, announced Monday that it had provided about $17.5 million in grants for 2009, including an increase of 6.8 percent to theater companies compared to 2008.

The media mogul Barry Diller and the fashion designer Diane Von Furstenberg have made a $10 million challenge grant to the High Line, the former elevated railway along the Hudson River that is being converted into a landscaped walkway. “I fell in love with the project, with the place,” Ms. Von Furstenberg said in a telephone interview. “It’s a beautiful green ribbon that will travel from Gansevoort to the Javits Center.”

When word spread that President Obama and his wife, Michelle, had chosen “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone” for their Broadway date night on Saturday, questions quickly followed about the impact of a presidential endorsement: Would it help “Joe Turner” at the box office? Or among Tony Award voters, who are now judging the play in its six nominated categories?

The Broadway production “Shrek the Musical” announced a major ticket discount offer Monday afternoon in hopes of assuring that performances through September draw in families on summer vacation — a crucial demographic for “Shrek” and other Broadway shows that market themselves to children.

When it wasn’t doubling as a two-hour infomercial for the “Twilight” movies and books, the MTV Movie Awards (whose own host, Andy Samberg, referred to the show as “the big commercial”) were actually pretty entertaining. Some of the best moments were the results of offbeat celebrity pairings: LeAnn Rimes and Chris Isaak’s lewd duet of Lonely Island songs (with a guest appearance from Forest Whitaker); Kiefer Sutherland’s weepy tribute to Ben Stiller; Hayden Panettiere presenting an award with a fictional rapper who exists only in chewing gum commercials; Mr. Samberg’s “Saturday Night Live” co-star Amy Poehler referring to him as “Adam Sandwich.”

Apparently, the latest monster to emerge from Mattel‘s toy-creation laboratories is so terrifying that the company will not give its name or say when it is hitting shelves — yet the beast is also so appealing that it has already been signed up for its own movie musical. Variety reported that Universal Pictures, the home of vintage movie monsters like Dracula, Frankenstein, the Mummy and the Wolf Man as well as the summer singalong hit “Mamma Mia!”, had struck a deal with Mattel to create a live-action musical film about the new creature. The movie is to be produced by Craig Zadan and Neil Meron (whose previous credits include the “Hairspray” film musical) and will reteam them with the “Hairspray” composer Marc Shaiman and lyricist Scott Wittman. Mattel gave no details about its coming monster toy, except that it “aspires to add a fresh twist to monster lore,” according to Variety.

One doesn't pop in to make a quick purchase at the Forum Shops at Caesars. Once inside this pseudo-palatial labyrinth, your path is blocked, er, directed by faux-marble benches, enormous planters and ill-placed concierge desks. You may see the store you need to get to in your line of sight, but access to it is, fittingly for Las Vegas, a mirage. There are no short cuts allowed, no direct paths. Your leisurely stroll is in fact carefully choreographed, and ensures that you will come into contact, however briefly, with every single store in the mall.

Anyone lucky enough to share a life with young children knows how determined they are to randomize your day. They'll empty your purse or wallet, reprogram your cellphone and figure out how to speed-dial 9-1-1. The highest value items are those with the most potential for trouble -- your car horn, the panic button on your car keys, the lens on your digital camera or that fascinating slot on your laptop. "I wonder where the disk goes?"

The New York Times was not particularly sympathetic to the emergence in the 1960s of a visible and active gay community. But its photo files turn out to contain some treasures for those who care about that transformative time. Larry Morris, a staff photographer for The Times, recorded the final night of the six-night Stonewall uprising in Greenwich Village, which history has judged to be a linchpin in the gay civil rights movement. Our colleague Sewell Chan on the City Room blog tells the tale of how the pictures came light.

Online networks can provide benefits similar to those of real-world groups of friends, but often are easier to assemble and maintain, experts say.

Jerry Rosenberg, who was spared the death penalty for the 1962 murders of two New York City police detectives, and who became a pioneering jailhouse lawyer and a legal adviser for the leaders of the Attica prison uprising in 1971, died on Monday at the Wende Correctional Facility in Alden, N.Y. He was 72, and the state's longest-serving inmate at the time of his death.

A Newark man was arrested Saturday and charged with the fatal shooting of Altariq Collins, 25, of East Orange, whose body was found along the side of a home on South Stanley Road in South Orange on Dec. 4. The Essex County Prosecutor's Office said today that the suspect, Taiwan Blunt, 22, was charged with conspiracy to commit murder, murder and possession of a handgun for an unlawful purpose. Witnesses had been able to give a partial description of the vehicle leaving the scene, and detectives developed information that they said led them to the suspect. Mr. Blunt is being held in Essex County Jail on $250,000 bail.

Many of us focused on the fate of the Air France jetliner that disappeared with 228 people on its way from Rio de Janeiro to Paris and were riveted by images of grief-stricken relatives. But there were reminders that grief need not be fresh to be keenly felt. Damir Sagolj of Reuters captured a Bosnian woman weeping for her two sons at a funeral for Muslim victims of the 1992-95 war, whose remains were found in mass graves. It is not the human element alone that distinguishes the picture. So does its strong geometry.

Congratulations to the Millburn High School PhysicsBowl first-year physics students team, which led the nation with a score of 165. Amy Chen and Evan Leichter had higher scores than anyone else in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and Amy scored second in the nation overall. Scores by Timothy Matchen and Benjamin Lieber were also counted in the team total in the competition, a timed exam of 40 multiple-choice questions. Millburn's team of students with two or more years of physics placed third in the region. Congratulations to their teacher, Robert Barkovitz.

Long-distance hiking is rarely something that you would file under the category of luxury travel - not when accommodations usually mean staying in a leaky tent, a drafty cabin, or maybe even just a sleeping bag unfurled by the side of the trail. But a different kind of experience can apparently be found in New Zealand, according to a story in the Washington Post Travel section this past Sunday, in which the author wrote about trekking the Queen Charlotte Track. The Queen Charlotte Track, located on the South Island, is sometimes compared to the Appalachian Trail, but as Angus Phillip wrote, "The Queen Charlotte Track is to the Appalachian Trail what the Ritz-Carlton is to a homeless shelter." Among its calling cards: easy access to overnight lodgings like the No Road Inn, in which for about the equivalent of $240 a night, you get a spacious room with a flat-screen TV, terrycloth robes and "a steaming hot tub made from an old wine barrel," as well as superbly prepared meals, including a boxed lunch to take with you when you head off toward your next refueling (and pampering) spot. Mr. Phillip does point out that there are less expensive lodging options for hikers who insist on roughing it, but that he prefers "walking in the finest way, with full stomachs, no heavy packs on our backs, soft beds and crisp sheets waiting. It sure beats the Appalachian Trail."

Richard Ford recently told Newsweek what his five "most essential" books were: Emerson's "Essays," "The Moviegoer," Dante's "Inferno," Cheever's "Collected Stories" and the Snopes trilogy. One book to which he always returns is Eudora Welty's "Collected Stories." Asked to mention a classic that he "revisited with disappointment," he chose "Ulysses": "Way too long, and unduly obscure. Should have stuck to short stories." Which is a bit like saying Samuel Beckett should have stuck to novels, or Richard Ford should have stuck to sportswriting.

Just like on Friday, commuters to New York had to "detrain" and go to Hoboken. Or did they? As soon as half the passengers from one train got out to take the long way in, the train sped away direct to Penn Station. The 9:08 from South Orange got in to Penn Station 40 minutes late. Was it a train stuck in the tunnel, as Clever Commute said, or overhead wire and signal problems, as New Jersey Transit said, or both? One conductor was blaming Amtrak, another, at 10:03, was telling folks there was still no Midtown Direct service. Sounds like a good day to stay home!

Grey Gardens, the East Hampton manse that provided the backdrop for David and Albert Maysles's 1975 documentary about that madcap mother and daughter duo, Edie and Edie Beale, could have generously been described as a glorious, cat-infested, crumbling wreck. But that was nothing compared to the recent state of Maysles's own archives. Over the course of making the film and several years afterward, the brothers accumulated untold mounds of photographs, film stills, letters and production notes, not to mention some 150 hours of aptly called "wild sound" or extra audio footage.

MotoGP: Casey Stoner of Ducati became the first rider not named Valentino Rossi to win at Mugello Circuit in Italy since 2001. Starting second on the grid, Stoner shot off the line into the lead. The track was still damp when the race started, but as it dried, several riders cycled to the front, including Rossi. By the middle of the race, Stoner pushed his way back into the lead and began pulling away. It was only in the later stages of the race that Rossi and his Yamaha teammate, Jorge Lorenzo, returned to podium positions, with Lorenzo finishing second and Rossi third. Afterward, Stoner said he had problems with his clutch, and thought the faulty clutch might end his race. "I just tried adjusting it as much as I could, and we got to a point where it started to grab again and go," Stoner told Autosport. "Then we started having the bike lock up coming into corners because we'd adjusted the clutch too far in. It was really, really difficult to ride." Meanwhile Rossi blamed tire choice (and his team) for his third-place finish, Agence France-Presse reported: "In the dry we made a mistake in going with the hard tires. The choice of hards was made even though I wanted the soft ones."

The headline technology winners in the government's economic stimulus package have been electronic health records and smart grids, where computing is front and center. Many billions have been pledged to these obviously high-tech fields. Yet a far larger flow of money into information technology may eventually come from local governments as part of a vast array of stimulus-package investment projects, according to Joaquin Gonzalez, director of research for CivicUS, which advises state and local governments.

Jens and Lars Rasmussen, the brothers who created what has become Google Maps, have spent the last couple of years holed up in Google's offices in Sydney, Australia, dreaming up a new tool for communicating over the Web. On Thursday, at a Google conference for developers in San Francisco, they showcased the result: Google Wave. Google Wave is an application running in a Web browser that creates a shared online desktop where two or more users can interact easily. They can exchange messages as they would in e-mail or instant messaging conversation. They can share and edit documents that include text, images and graphics. They can also drag and drop simple applications called widgets into a Wave to, for example, play a game together.

TAKING BACK SUNDAY ''New Again'' (Warner Brothers) Punkiness doesn't last forever. Taking Back Sunday, a band from Long Island that formed in 1999, helped shape the self-doubting punk-pop that would soon be called emo. A decade later, after multiple changes of lineup -- past members of the band formed Straylight Run -- Taking Back Sunday has embraced the persuasiveness of a long-lined tune, a sustained vocal and a harmony chorus.

Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said on Monday that the global financial crisis seemed to be easing, but that the United States and China would have to work together to rebalance the world economy. In a speech at Peking University, Mr. Geithner encouraged China to diversify its economy away from a heavy reliance on exports while offering Beijing assurances that Washington intended to tackle its deficit and protect the value of China's huge investments in United States government debt.

STRAND--Ivar Sr. Beloved father, grandfather, father-in-law, uncle and friend, Ivar Strand Sr. passed away in Stange, Norway on April 30, 2009. Ivar was born on August 22, 1919 in Haugesund, Norway, and as a youth, traveled the world with his father, Sea Captain Ivar Strand. He immigrated to New York City in the early 1950s and received his MBA at New York University. He married Gerd Abelvik from Aalesund, Norway in 1957 and together they had two sons who grew up in Brooklyn, NY. He later became a ship broker for States Marine Company and Peraco Chartering Corporation. For the past 15 years, he has split his time between New York and Norway, where his two sons reside respectively. Ivar will always be remembered for his positive outlook on life, his penchant for telling a good story, his love of golf, gardening, Long Island and Norway. He is survived by his two sons: Eric, an American and European Board Certified Specialist in Veterinary Surgery at the Norwegian School of Veterinary Medicine; and Ivar, an Assistant Vice President in the Administration of the State University of New York at Stony Brook. There will be a memorial service at the Norwegians Seamens Church in NYC on June 6th, 2009 at noon.

BANKRUPTCY FOR G.M.General Motors will file for bankruptcy protection before the financial markets open Monday, and the filing will be made in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Rarely has a company fallen so far and so fast as General Motors. The ink is hardly dry on the deal to salvage the German automaker Opel, and already the political recriminations are echoing across Europe. IMMERMAN--Benjamin J.,born 1924 in The Bronx and raised in Yonkers and a resident of Great Barrington, MA and Longboat Key, FL, passed away on May 27, 2009 of complications from bronchiectasis. He was a decorated World War II Air Force veteran who flew dozens of missions over Germany as bombardier in the legendary B-17 "Flying Fortress". Dr. Immerman graduated from Columbia University and SUNY Downstate Medical Center in New York, and became an eminent obstetrician and gynecologist who practiced for nearly 40 years in Forest Hills, New York. Dr. Immerman believed that we were placed on this planet to help others and he dedicated his life to doing just that. He leaves behind his wife of 18 years, Agnes of Stockbridge MA and Longboat Key, FL, his son Bruce of Corte Madera, California, his step-daughter Jennifer of Palm Harbor, FL, his brother David of Reading, MA and eight nieces and nephews. POMERANTZ--Rabbi Aaron. The family of the East Midwood Jewish Center mourns the passing of its distinguished and beloved Associate Rabbi. RANCID ''Let the Dominoes Fall'' (Hellcat/Epitaph) ''Civilian Ways,'' from Rancid's new album, ''Let the Dominoes Fall,'' is inspired by the return of a soldier -- the brother of the frontman Tim Armstrong -- from combat in Iraq. Slow and lean, it's a delicate tour of a confused mind -- ''I'm shaking hands with everyone that I meet/And I watch everyone and wondering what they see/Civilian ways are now what's foreign to me'' -- with echoes of the Beatles and Tom Waits. It's a song so intense and thoughtful that it raises the question: Why should Green Day get to stoke all the good fires?

SAM YAHEL ''Hometown'' (Posi-Tone) Sam Yahel has been playing jazz in New York since the early 1990s, almost always as a Hammond organist. (He was a fixture in the early days of Smalls, on West 10th Street, along with the pianist Brad Mehldau and the guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel; these days he leads his own trio.) But he hasn't hid behind the bullying power of the Hammond, its ability to give you shivers with shifting drawbars or a loud crescendo: he has put himself in places where pianists go, playing volatile music with curiosity and hunger in his improvising.

Last week, new guidelines urged women to be more vigilant about weight gain during pregnancy.
