Fresh from Pearl Jam’s (slightly cavernous) performance as the first musical guest on Conan O’Brien’s “Tonight” show, the band is making further news: its next album will be released in the U.S. without the support of a major label, the Web site Billboard.biz reported. In an interview on the site, Pearl Jam’s manager, Kelly Curtis, said that the album, called “Backspacer” and scheduled for release in the fall, would be sold at Target stores as an exclusive “big box” retail partner. Mr. Curtis said the band was pursuing deals with online and independent music stores and that the album would be sold through Pearl Jam’s fan club, Ten Club. The band previously released its albums in the U.S. through Sony Music, and will release its new album internationally with Universal Music Group.

In “The Catcher in the Rye,” the narrator Holden Caulfield warns his readers to beware of phonies, and his creator, J. D. Salinger, evidently still believes in that caution. On Monday, Mr. Salinger, the reclusive author, filed suit against the writer and the publisher of a planned book that claims to be a sequel to “The Catcher in the Rye,” Reuters reported. In an interview in The Telegraph, the author John David California said that his coming novel, called “60 Years Later: Coming Through the Rye,” would feature a 76-year-old character called Mr. C, who wanders the streets of New York after he escapes his nursing home, in a manner similar to Holden Caulfield’s escape from an elite prep school. In The Telegraph, Mr. California said that Mr. Salinger was “a great writer who influenced the entire world with the words he made up” and said that his novel was “a tribute the way Holden would have said it.” In the suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, lawyers for Mr. Salinger said, “The sequel is not a parody and it does not comment upon or criticize the original. It is a rip-off pure and simple,” according to Reuters.

If Comedy Central can stop Demetri Martin from being cast in so many movie roles, the network would like to offer the comedian another season of his hit television series “Important Things with Demetri Martin.” In a release, Comedy Central said that it had renewed the show for a second season, which it plans to start showing in early 2010. When it was first broadcast in February, “Important Things” was the cable channel’s most-watched premiere since “Chappelle’s Show,” in 2003, and built a strong following of young male viewers in its seven-episode run. Mr. Martin is also starring in the coming film “Taking Woodstock,” directed by Ang Lee, and has been cast in an adaptation of “Moneyball,” the Michael Lewis book, to be directed by Steven Soderbergh.

Surprising few people who watched the MTV Movie Awards, a writer for the show said that an incident in which the comedian Sacha Baron Cohen appeared to be accidentally deposited in the lap of Eminem was done with both performers’ knowledge and participation. On the awards show, broadcast on Sunday night, Mr. Cohen was dressed, minimally, as his gay character Bruno, and was descending by wire from the ceiling of the Gibson Ampitheater when he landed upside down on Eminem. The rapper then stormed out of the ceremony. In a post on his blog, Scott Aukerman, a writer for the event, said: “Yes, the Bruno/Eminem incident was staged. That’s all anyone wants to talk about, so let’s get it out of the way. They rehearsed it at dress and yes, it went as far as it did on the live show then.” The post on Mr. Aukerman’s blog was later taken down.

Exene Cervenka, a founder and vocalist of the Los Angeles punk and rockabilly band X, said in a statement released Tuesday that she has multiple sclerosis. Ms. Cervenka, 53, said in the statement that she had not been feeling well for several months and that she probably had the condition for some time. She added that the diagnosis would not affect plans for an X tour or a solo record scheduled for the fall, and directed fans to Sweet Relief, a charity for uninsured musicians founded by Victoria Williams, who has also been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis.

VENICE — The 53rd Venice Biennale is not yet officially underway here but signs of it are everywhere, bubbling up out of the canals, blaring from loudspeakers, flapping from the sides of palazzi. Probably the most thematically appropriate — given the shaken state of the art market and the art world as a whole — is the schoolchild’s maxim on a huge sign dangling from a sun-bleached facade near St. Mark’s Square: “I will not make any more boring art.” John Baldessari, whose influence over many of the artists showing this year makes him one of the event’s presiding deities, first made the statement in prints almost 40 years ago. But it is wise, wickedly funny advice at a time when the money tide has ebbed and bad art is much more easily spotted.

William Grimes is the author of "Straight Up or On the Rocks, The Story of the American Cocktail," (North Point Press, 2001). In the course of researching America's most distinctive contribution to drink culture, he delved into the newspaper accounts, memoirs, and cocktail recipe books that describe this strange interlude in American history, as well as searching the archives of Joseph Urban, the Ziegfeld Follies designer who created some of New York's lavish speakeasies, and savored the gin-soaked fiction of writers like John O'Hara ("Butterfield 8"), Elmer Davis ("Friends of Mr. Sweeney"), and Dashiell Hammett ("The Thin Man'') to get the full flavor of the period. He has come to the firm conclusion that Americans looking for a good cocktail should zero in on 1909 or 2009 as their best bet, and write off the Roaring 20s. Great jazz, bad booze. If you'd like to ask Mr. Grimes a question about Prohibition or speakeasies submit it as a comment below and he'll respond in a later post.

Artists are seldom prudish, but the "orgasm shows" currently taking place at the gallery Envoy Enterprises, set a new standard for easy. Officially called "One Day at a Time," Envoy's 24-hour art shows were started this February by the gallery's owner Jimi Dams as a response to the recession, and his increasing dismay with the way larger New York galleries were playing it safe by exhibiting work of established, bankable artists. His shows, on the other hand, are "short and forceful," he says. "Our objective was never to make money, but to have lesser-known artists feel good about exhibiting their work."

On a recent trip to Los Angeles, I found a pair of shops that offer a welcome reprieve from the showy, label-worshiping shrines like Kitson and Fred Segal. The shop Lost and Found (Yucca Street; 323-856-5872) is actually five small storefronts that span a nondescript block of Yucca Street in Hollywood. It's been around for almost a decade, but the owner Jamie Rosenthal, an ex-stylist who forages the globe for fashion, jewelry, textiles, housewares and accessories, has a laid-back attitude about courting press, or celebrities for that matter. Instead of House of Harlow maxidresses (when's this trend going away?) courtesy of Nicole Richie, you'll find all you need for that true Laurel Canyon (or Ibiza, or Marrakesh) boho lifestyle here - gauzy caftans, Baja shirts (made in Italy, no less), African trading beads, oversize scarves and stripey beach totes from France. And that's just in the women's shop. There's kids, mens, housewares and even a quasi-garden and craft outlet.

Update: June 2, 2009, 1:10 p.m. Keith Bradsher and Nick Bunkley are reporting that a machinery company in western China is being identified as the buyer for Hummer. The report cites a person familiar with the Chinese government approval process, who identified the company as the Sichuan Tengzhong Heavy Industrial Machinery Company Ltd., based in Chengdu. G.M. has also confirmed that Sichuan is the buyer. Sichuan is known for making a wide range of road equipment, from bridge piers to highway construction and maintenance machinery, but has been moving more into heavy-duty trucks, including tow trucks and oil tankers.

Like many other hotel reward arrangements, the Starwood Preferred Guest program earns a number of discounts and incentives. In a new offer, the freebie has little to do with an actual hotel stay. In partnership with Live Nation, the company is offering a free general admission concert lawn ticket with stays through Aug. 31. Concert choices range from Incubus to Jay Z, Rascal Flatts to New Kids on the Block, Def Leppard to Tom Jones. Just register your member number, and once you book an eligible stay, Starwood will send you a concert ticket redemption code. Tickets are redeemable until Oct. 31, or while supplies last. From Seattle, the birthplace of Starbucks, comes a cooler coffee company. Caffé Vita - one of the farm-direct, we-roast-our-own-organic-beans places to emerge from the Pacific Northwest in the last five years - has stayed true to the city's indie spirit. First came a collaboration with One Pot, the food provocateur Michael Hebberoy's roving, site-specific culture project, resulting in some interesting dinners in Seattle and meals made with farmers on coffee-sourcing trips in, say, Sumatra or Guatemala. Next came a T-shirt series, with images of the life of a coffee seed designed by the local artist Robert Mercer, who has created album graphics for his brother's band, the Shins. (Vita's five cafes also host regular concerts, like Mates of State and Black Kids.)

Phil Mickelson plans a brief return to the PGA Tour in time to play in the United States Open. Mickelson intends to return next week at the St. Jude Championship in Memphis, then play the next week in the United States Open at Bethpage Black. The news was first reported by Golf Digest.

He represents Mr. Brown — not the pop star Rihanna, who prosecutors say was attacked by Mr. Brown. (Rihanna’s lawyer is Donald Etra.).

A “Slap Shots” note on Saturday with an article about the Stanley Cup finals rematch between the Detroit Red Wings and the Pittsburgh Penguins referred incorrectly to the history of such rematches since 1927. There have been 10 others — not nine — and the reigning champions have compiled a 7-3 record, not 7-2. (In addition to the 1933 Rangers and the 1984 Edmonton Oilers, the 1956 Montreal Canadiens also defeated the team that had won the year before.).

The Times should not have stated the assertion as fact without attribution.

MUNNO--Gladys E.,on June 1, 2009. Beloved wife of Dominick, loving mother of Thomas, M. William and Andrea Munno-Weiden, loving mother-in-law of Deborah, cherished grandmother of Gregory, Carolyn, Michael, David, Steven, Jessica and Julia. Great-grandmother of Jamison, Zachary, Ethan and Jay. Fond sister of William. Memorial service Wednesday, June 3 at Gutterman's Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Road. Rockville Centre, NY.

KERN--Ralph W. of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully at his home, in the arms of his devoted wife of 53 years, Leona. He was a faithful son to Morris and Anna Kern, caring brother to Morton Kern, loving father of Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, and the proud grandfather of Seth, Allison, Melanie and Adam. Born in The Bronx in 1934, son of a furniture manufacturer, he worked full time to put himself through NYU. Early in his career, he established himself as a builder, entrepreneur, and visionary New York City developer. He was also adventurous, traveling and sailing extensively throughout the world. His passions were his family, opera, ballet, tennis, and sailing. We all looked to him for courage, direction, and understanding. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, June 3, 2009, 11:15am, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Ave, Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made in his name to Trustees of Columbia University, Division of Cardiology, Att: Dr. Allan Schwartz or Julie Fisher, 622 West 168th St, NY, NY 10032.

JACKMAN--Barbara. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Always glamorous, sophisticated, and proud. Sharp as a tack. A TRUE survivor. Your courageous and fiery spirit will endure in us forever. Nanny, we love you. Robby, Heidi, Valerie, Jason, Haley, Benjamin and Cassidy

LYNN--Judith (nee Judith Roslyn Edelman), 68, died peacefully May 28, 2009, after a brief illness. She was the adored and beloved wife of Norman, devoted and loving mother of daughters Amy and Elizabeth, fond mother-in-law of Dennis Heon and David Block, active grandmother of Gregory, Jennifer and Emma, and caring sister-in-law of Helen and Richard Lynn. She will be deeply missed by family and friends and always remembered for her wisdom, humor, and generosity of time and spirit. Donations in her memory may be made to Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York.

WEISS--Dorothy Passed away at home in Piedmont, California, on May 30th, 2009. She was the beloved wife of Fred Weiss, mother of Ron, Toby and John Weiss and mother-in-law of Jocelyn and Teri Weiss and Alison Stone. Dorothy was adored by her four grandchildren; Meredith Levy, Jennifer Weiss, Rebecca Weiss, and Michael Weiss, and by her two great-grandchildren, Andrew and Jane Levy. Dorothy was a dear and loving sister to Pauline Sinow and husband Dr. Garland Sinow, of Long Beach, California, and aunt to their children, Dr. Jordan Sinow and Elisabeth Hutchinson, as well as to Fred's niece, Linda Spencer, of Philadelphia. Dorothy was born on October 2nd, 1920 in St. Paul, Minnesota. Her family moved to Los Angeles where she met and married Fred Weiss in 1940. They lived in Cambridge, MA and St. Louis and eventually settled in Piedmont, California in 1946. While in Piedmont raising their three boys, Dorothy worked for the Women's League of Voters and began what would become her long relationship with the Oakland Museum. She established its Gallery Shop in 1959 and in 1961 initiated the Museum's docent program. In 1977 she joined her two dear friends Virginia Breier and Sue Meyer to create the Meyer, Breier, Weiss Gallery on Fillmore Street in San Francisco, which later moved to Fort Mason. When the gallery was established, Dorothy and Fred were living in Houston as part of Fred's long career with Shell Oil, but they moved back to Piedmont permanently in 1980. The Dorothy Weiss Gallery opened in 1984 at 256 Sutter Street and focused on contemporary ceramic and glass sculpture with an emphasis on non-functional, sculptural work. The Gallery closed in 2000 but Dorothy took great pleasure in maintaining her relationships with her many artists, collectors, and longtime supporters. In 2001 Dorothy received a Visionary! award from the Museum of Craft and Folk Art (now called The Museum of Art and Design) in New York for her contribution of "exciting exhibitions of some of the best contemporary work in clay and glass in the United States at her gallery which was a mecca for art collectors and artists from all over the country." Dorothy was adored by her entire family and by her many friends and will be indescribably missed by all who knew her. Services will be held on Wednesday June 3rd at 1:00pm, at Temple Sinai, 2823 Webster Street, (at 28th St.) Oakland, 94609. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Oakland Museum or the Judah L. Magnes Museum in Berkeley.

ISAACSON--Katy. The Board of Directors, members, staff and participants of AHRC New York City sadly note the passing of their good friend Katy Isaacson. We convey our condolences to her husband, Leonard, long time Board Member of the Association, and to her children Laurence (a member of AHRC Board), Joel and Deborah. Katy was, for many years, an enthusiastic support of the Association's activities, including the establishment of the "Katy Isaacson Gym" at the Esther Ashkenas Central Park Early Learning Center, in Manhattan. Katy was always present, warm, supportive and encouraging,. We will miss her deeply. Arlene Pedone, President Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director

KATZIR--Ephraim. The leadership, staff, and supporters of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of a most esteemed and dear member of our family, Professor Ephraim Katzir. Professor Katzir was the fourth President of Israel and one of the Weizmann Institute of Science's founding faculty members. He founded and headed the Department of Biophysics, and in doing so, laid the foundation for enzyme engineering today a critical component of the food and pharmaceutical industries. In addition to his scientific research, Professor Katzir was a pioneer in the social and educational aspects of science. His attention to these issues did not wane when he was elected President of Israel, in 1973; nor did his curious spirit rest when his term ended, in 1978. Rather, he returned to his work at the Weizmann Institute and was given the prestigious title of Institute Professor. Professor Katzir was fundamentally dedicated to the mission of bettering humanity; he enacted this commitment through his impressive achievements in science, culture, education, and politics; he embodied and pursued what he called the "universal human values that emphasize the kinship of the human race," among them freedom, peace, honesty, respect, and love. Professor Ephraim Katzir engendered these qualities. He succeeded in benefiting the human race. We send heartfelt condolences to the entire Katzir family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. & CEO American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

LEEDS--Mark. We mourn the passing of Mark Leeds of New York City on May 29, 2009. He will always be loved and remembered by his beloved wife, Marlene, step-son Adam, brother-in-law Steven, father-in-law Bill, mother-in-law Pauline, son Marshall, daughter Meredith, granddaughters Emily and Julie. A gathering will be held at the home of Bill Saferstein at 800 West End Avenue, on Wednesday, June 3rd at 11am.

KERN--Ralph. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus Jill Abramson, Cantor

SNYDER--Norman, 72, of Manhattan, died May 28th. He was a graphic designer and a photographer. In the 1980s he returned to the piano after a long hiatus, eventually becoming a piano technician. He was active in the New York Piano Technicians Guild, serving at times as president. He leaves many loving friends, his wife, Sally Fisher, his daughter Lisa and her husband, Edward Antonik and their son, Jason; his daughter Michelle and her husband, James Silverman, and their son Jaden, his stepson Adam Fisher and his wife, Martha, and their son, Samuel; his stepson Jacob Fisher. He was known for his spirit, curiosity, and singular sense of humor. A memorial gathering will be held in September.
SHIFF--Doris. Congregation Beth Sholom records with sorrow the passing of its esteemed member. May her memory be for a blessing.

SCHUSTER--Eugene, 90. Beloved husband of Lillian, adored father of Andrea (Richard) Traubner, Paul (Sandy) Schuster, Hope (David) LaPlante, and cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Leaves a host of loving relatives and friends. Harvard Law graduate, Lt. in World War II and Korean War, and Village Justice, Great Neck Estates. Service: Wednesday, June 3 at 12 noon, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

SERLING--Clarice B.,long time resident of Larchmont, died on June 1, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Maurice E. Serling. Loving mother of Joseph Serling (Merril Wasserman), Louise Sagor (Bryan), Susan Serling (David Kessler), and Deborah Serling (Terry Barr). Adoring grandmother of Jonathan Polk and Joshua Townsend and four great-grandchildren. Active in numerous national and local organizations. Funeral service Wednesday 10am at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. Interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers to Planned Parenthood or WNET (Channel 13).

LOENGARD--Richard O.,Jr. The partners and staff of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson LLP mourn the passing of retired partner and former Chair of the New York Tax Department, Richard O. Loengard, Jr. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, friends and those whose lives he touched.

ADAMS--Mary (nee Hardiman), 81, of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ on May 29, 2009. Wife of Henry. Sister of James E. Hardiman. Cousin to Ann Hardiman. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, June 3, 2009 at 9:45am from Costello-Greiner Funeral Home (www.costello-greiner.com), 44 Green Street, Woodbridge, NJ. A Funeral Liturgy will follow at 10:30am at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Perth Amboy. Visitation will be on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Funeral Home.

Prosecutors filed court papers Monday asking a federal appeals court to allow them to use several pieces of evidence that they say tie Barry Bonds to the use of performance-enhancing drugs. The papers said that United States District Court Judge Susan Illston, who is overseeing Bonds's perjury case, incorrectly excluded the evidence, which included positive drug tests for steroids from 2000 and 2001.

HINES--Laura M. Died May 29 at age 86. Psychologist, Therapist, Professor Emerita Yeshiva Univ. Survived by husband Dom Balducci, brother Irving, sister Jessie, step-daughter Donna and granddaughter Amanda. She will be missed by all who know her.

8 P.M. (ABC) ACCORDING TO JIM After eight seasons, it's adios to Jim. In the first of the last two episodes, Jim (Jim Belushi, right, with Courtney Thorne-Smith) decides to buy Cheryl (Ms. Thorne-Smith) a diamond necklace for her birthday and goes to an unusual source to save a few bucks. But then he is haunted by the necklace's previous owner. In the series finale, at 8:30, Jim dies after choking on a shrimp puff and arrives at heaven's gate, where he is put on trial to prove his selflessness on earth. Andy (Larry Joe Campbell) is summoned to heaven to defend him before God (Lee Majors); Jim's sister-in-law, Dana (Kimberly Williams-Paisley), represents the Devil (Erik Estrada) and argues that Jim should go to hell. Dan Aykroyd also guest stars. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEWEdie Falco talks about her new Showtime series, ''Nurse Jackie''; Nia Vardalos promotes her new movie, ''My Life in Ruins,'' opening on Friday. The Broadway cast of ''West Side Story'' performs.

BELL--Marion Virginia, June 18, 1929 - May 4 2009, died in New York City after a confining illness. Daughter of William Wallace and Alberta Graham Bell, She grew up in Rosslyn Farms, PA, later graduating from the Madeira School and Barnard College. Her career included teaching first grade in a Pittsburgh private school and a stint in California as the librarian for the San Francisco Chronicle, before returning to New York to work in the children's book department at Scribner and Sons and ,after its demise, at the Corner Book Store. Marion was know on the upper east side for the annual cocktail parties she organized for dogs and their owners at the bookstore. She loved animals, books, music, tennis and good food, but had little interest in other worldly goods, leading a spartan life in a studio apartment with two orphaned cats. She walked dogs, volunteered in a cancer clinic for cats and in the gardens of Central Park. She was a flaming liberal who hated any form of injustice and befriended the downtrodden, human or animal. Marion is survived by her sister, Betsy Bell Martin of Pittsburgh, PA, her bother Bill Bell of Brookline, MA. seven neices and nephews, 14 grandneices and nephews and many caring friends. She would have favored memorial donation to the Animal Haven or Amnesty International.

JACKMAN--Barbara Solomon Died May 31, 2009, after a long and productive life. Survived by her beloved daughter, Patricia Gutman and son-in-law Edward. Adored grandmother of Heidi and Jason Rosenfarb and Robert and Valarie Gutman; loving great-grandmother of Haley, Benjamin and Cassidy. Barbara pursued active and successful careers as the first female radio disc jockey (known as Barbara Day) in the 1950s and later as a life insurance agent. Barbara's keen intelligence and feisty spirit made her a force to be reckoned with. Always elegant and with boundless energy, Barbara spoke with honesty and directness, softened by her deep caressing voice. Funeral services will be private. The family will receive visitors at her daughter's home, Wednesday, June 3, 6-8pm and Thursday, June 4, 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

POMERANTZ--Rabbi Aaron. The family of the East Midwood Jewish Center mourns the passing of its distinguished and beloved Associate Rabbi. Israel Zangwill wrote of a "scholar unafraid to follow thought to any sea or back to any fount." Such was the erudition and acuity of our master teacher and exemplar of piety. He inspired us all for three decades through his love of Torah and the Jewish people. Though his physical presence will be sorely missed, his lessons will sanctify our lives for all time to come. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife Roz, his children Suri and Nissim, his granddaughter Bailey, and his entire family. Dr. Alvin Kass, Rabbi Sam Levine, Cantor Larry Isaacson & Michael Sucher, Presidents

ORENSTEIN--Clara, 1914-2009, died peacefully at home May 28. Wife of the late Albert. Survived by sister, Mildred Saltzer; nieces, Sandra Saltzer Duzak (James) and Susan Saltzer Drucker (Daniel); grandnephew, Joshua Drucker (Kirstin Martin); grandniece Matana Drucker (Michael Bloor); great-grandnephews, Matthew Bloor and Benjamin Drucker. Family graveside service held Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Queens, NY May 31.

LOENGARD--Richard O.,Jr. of Bernardsville, New Jersey, died in New York-Presbyterian hospital on May 31, 2009. He was born in New York City on January 28, 1932 and was a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. He began his legal career in 1956 with the law firm now known as Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver and Jacobson, retiring as a partner in 1997 but remaining of counsel until his death. He interrupted the practice of law between 1964 and 1967 to become Deputy Legislative Tax Counsel and Special Assistant for International Tax Affairs to the U.S. Treasury Department. He was Chair of the New York State Bar Association Section of Taxation in 1997-98 and continued to serve on its executive committee thereafter, and was a consultant to the Federal Income Tax Treaties Project of the American Law Institute from 1988 to 1991. Apart from law and his family and friends, he particularly enjoyed sports statistics, history, and Harvard. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Janet Senderowitz Loengard; two daughters, Maranda Loengard St. John Nicolle of Blewbury, Oxfordshire, England, and Philippa Loengard Almond of Manhattan; a grandson, Edward Almond; and a brother, John Loengard, of Manhattan, nieces and a nephew. Funeral services will be held on Friday, June 5 at 2pm at the Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue, Manhattan. Donations may be made to the Harvard University Library or to New York-Presbyterian Medical/Surgical Oncology Center.
LICHTENBERG-- Harold. Happy Birthday, We miss you every day. Jeffrey, Jessica, Jordan, Peter, Jamie, Ryan, Brett, Susan, Todd, Nicky, Katy, Jenny and Maxine.

SAMELSON--Sylvia. Wife of late Harold, pre-deceased by son Joseph, survived by daughters Elise of Israel and Marian Wade of Manhattan. A loving and generous trouper, she was as fiercely loyal as she was independent in spirit. She will be deeply missed. Donations in her memory may be made to "SMS music program," EKCC, 129 W. 67th St., NY, NY 10023.

The chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson, vowed to Congress on Wednesday that as long as the American taxpayer was its largest investor, “it’s our obligation to be open and transparent in all we do to reinvent G.M.”

A co-head of Magna International, Siegfried Wolf, addressed an employees’ meeting at Opel for the first time on Wednesday, Handelsblatt reported. He said he expected to take over the German automaker by the end of September, according to Reuters.

General Motors, which reached a preliminary agreement Tuesday to sell its Hummer brand, said it had no plans to put its Asian automaking operations on the block, nor would it sell off operations in Latin America, Africa or the Middle East.

The American premiere of a dance collaboration between the actress Juliette Binoche and the choreographer Akram Khan will open the 2009 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which runs Sept. 15 through Dec. 19, the organization said in a release. The dance collaboration, “In-I,” will run Sept. 15 through 26 at the Harvey Theater in Brooklyn. Other festival highlights include the premiere of “Lipsynch,” a new theater production created by Ex Machina and Théâtre Sans Frontières, and directed by Robert Lepage; and a concert staging of “Kepler,” a new opera with music by Philip Glass, libretto by Martina Winkel and conducted by Dennis Russell Davies. More details can be found at bam.org.

Cher has filed suit against Universal Music Group on behalf of herself and the heirs of her ex-husband Sonny Bono, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the suit, filed Tuesday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Cher said that executives at the label had “engaged in wrongful tactics” that prevented her and Mr. Bono’s heirs from receiving revenues they are owed from compilation albums. Under the terms of her recording contracts with two labels that were absorbed by Universal, Cher said that she is supposed to receive up to 50 percent of net royalties from the label; Mr. Bono was also entitled to a share of royalties under one of the deals. The suit says that Universal funneled profits on a 1999 album, “Cher The Greatest Hits,” through its international division to avoid paying these royalties. A Universal spokesman told The Hollywood Reporter that the claims were “meritless.”

The University of Alberta in Canada said that Derek Walcott‘s withdrawal as a candidate to be Oxford University‘s professor of poetry would have no effect on his appointment as a distinguished scholar in residence at the Canadian school, The Globe and Mail reported. In May, Mr. Walcott, a Nobel laureate, withdrew from an election for the Oxford position after hundreds of faculty members and alumni were anonymously sent photocopied pages from a book that recounted a sexual harassment claim made by a Harvard student against Mr. Walcott, who taught at Harvard in the 1980s. Information about another sexual harassment accusation, from a Boston University student, was also included. (The poet Ruth Padel, who won the election, quickly resigned when it was learned she had sent e-mail messages to two reporters alerting them to the allegations.) Carl Amrhein, the provost of the University of Alberta, told The Globe and Mail that Mr. Walcott had been put through a “typical” appointments process. He added: “We did our background checks and we were very impressed. Nothing was brought to our attention.” Mr. Walcott is to teach a master class in poetry there starting in the fall.

Is it possible to hold a reality competition anymore that doesn’t end in allegations of a tainted voting process? The Daily Mail reported that the “Britain’s Got Talent” contestant Susan Boyle may have been denied the votes of television viewers, based on YouTube clips that showed incorrect telephone numbers displayed during Ms. Boyle’s final performance on the show. In a stunning upset on Saturday, Ms. Boyle, the church volunteer and amateur singer, placed second to the dance troupe Diversity. The Daily Mail said that on the YouTube clips, the phone numbers for fans who wanted to vote for Diversity were mistakenly displayed as phone numbers indicating votes for Ms. Boyle. A spokesman for ITV, which broadcasts “Britain’s Got Talent,” told The Daily Mail: “We are satisfied viewers had ample opportunity to know which voting numbers to call.”

Start practicing your teenage shrieks and squeals of delight: Paul McCartney will be the first musical artist to hold concerts at Citi Field in Flushing, N.Y., the concert promoter AEG Live announced Wednesday. In a news release, the company said that Mr. McCartney would perform at the stadium on July 17 and 18, and that tickets for the shows would go on sale June 15. Mr. McCartney, you may recall, was among the first musicians to play at Shea Stadium, the previous home of the New York Mets, when he performed there with the Beatles in 1965. (This was the group Mr. McCartney played in before forming Wings.) He also made a guest appearance during a 2008 performance by Billy Joel, who was the last musician to hold a concert there.

Eminem’s comeback record, “Relapse” (Interscope), lost 65 percent of its sales in its second week out but remains No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. “Relapse” sold 211,000 copies last week, bringing its total to 820,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (That may sound like a lot, but Eminem’s last studio album, “Encore,” sold almost twice as many in its first two weeks, in late 2004.) Also this week, Green Day’s “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise) holds at No. 2 with 76,000 in its third week at stores, and the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) is in third place with 52,000. Marilyn Manson’s “High End of Low” (Interscope) opens at No. 4 with 49,000 sales, and other new arrivals to the Top 10 include “La Revolución” (Machete) by Wisin & Yandel, a reggaetón duo from Puerto Rico, at No. 7 with 36,000 sales; and “Veckatimest” (Warp) by the Brooklyn band Grizzly Bear, at No. 8 with 33,000.

In introducing Armando Iannucci‘s coming political satire “In the Loop” at a screening on Tuesday, the “Daily Show” star John Oliver (who freely admitted he had nothing do with the film) told the audience: “The British invented swearing and this movie is the apex of swearing.”
President Obama announced on Wednesday that he plans to nominate Jim Leach, the former Republican congressman, as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

VENICE — There’s a very funny video “news clip” online produced by the folks at The Onion, called “Prague’s Kafka International Named Most Alienating Airport”. In the report, travelers describe an airport where corridors lead nowhere, shuttle trains deposit people back where they started and gate B2 can be found in the F terminal. This is a little what trying to get your press pass feels like at the Venice Biennale.

The novelist Marilynne Robinson won the Orange Prize for Fiction for her novel “Home.” The British award, given annually for the best novel written by a woman in English, was presented to Ms. Robinson at a ceremony on Wednesday night at the Royal Festival Hall. The novel, a follow-up to her Pulitzer Prize-winning 2004 work, “Gilead,” won out over other finalists that included Ellen Feldman’s “Scottsboro,” Samantha Hunt’s “The Invention of Everything Else,” and Kamila Shamsie’s “Burnt Shadows.” Ms. Robinson received a prize of about $49,000 and a bronze figurine called the Bessie. At the ceremony, the author Francesca Kay was given the Orange Award for New Writers for her novel “An Equal Stillness.” It comes with a prize of about $16,000.

The documentary filmmaker Megan Mylan has much to smile about. Her 39-minute film “Smile Pinki,” about a group of children in a rural Indian village with cleft lips who get a life-changing operation through the charity organization Smile Train, won the Oscar in February for best documentary short. After playing at various film festivals, the inspirational film found a home at HBO, where it premieres today.

Whoopi Goldberg drew a standing ovation Tuesday night at the London premiere of “Sister Act,” the musical adapted from her 1992 comedy about a woman who masquerades as a nun while hiding from vengeful mobsters, BBC News reported. The show, which stars Patina Miller in the role that Ms. Goldberg played on film, and features music by Alan Menken (of “Little Shop of Horrors” and “The Little Mermaid”), was tried out in 2006 at the Pasadena Playhouse in California before its West End debut at the London Palladium (where another musical involving nuns, “The Sound of Music,” recently closed.) And it clearly has the support of Ms. Goldberg, who’s a producer of the show. But how is it fairing with British critics?
After a Monday-night debut that drew a wide range of responses for mostly playing it safe, Conan O’Brien added a modicum of edge on Tuesday evening‘s “Tonight Show.”

No longer content to lurk in the background, some Taiwanese manufacturers are developing reputations as tech leaders.

PITTSBURGH - Once again, the Pittsburgh Pirates have traded their best and most recognizable player. This time, it was the All-Star center fielder Nate McLouth, who was shipped to the Atlanta Braves on Wednesday for a package of three prospects.

WASHINGTON - For more than three hours, fans here at Nationals (Water) Park stayed underneath the cover, hoping the same hopes as Randy Johnson and the San Francisco Giants. They were here for history, for Johnson's first attempt at career victory No. 300.

The Giants' Randy Johnson has to wait another day to try for his 300th victory, with his outing at Washington postponed on Wednesday. Johnson will be the last pitcher to reach the milestone for the next few years, but I doubt he'll be the last, period.

Some 2.96 million viewers watched the Penguins beat the Red Wings in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Tuesday night -- the most-watched show of any kind shown by Versus.

The San Francisco company, which lets people vote on the news stories that interest them, has tried at various times running ads from Google, the ad network Federated Media and Microsoft, and it recently began to reach out to advertisers directly.

Malia and Sasha Obama will fly with the first lady to France on Friday to join President Obama for a family weekend in Paris, a White House official said on Wednesday. It will be the girls' first foreign trip since they moved into the White House in January.

A Greek diner that closed over the weekend after serving as a late-night refuge for patients and staff at Bellevue Hospital Center since 1984 will be able to reopen, and will not be supplanted by an Au Bon Pain, as some had feared.

In the last few days, Vizio has ratcheted up its campaign to reduce the patent royalty payments it owes Funai, a Japanese company that holds key digital TV patents and manufactures Philips-branded TVs, among others. Vizio says it is part of a "shakedown" and has created a new Web site to get consumers to join its side. The implicit payoff: even lower prices from the company known for low-priced TVs.

While each of these photos has a degree of ambiguity to it, this may be the least easy to interpret at first. Jaime Saldarriaga's photo for Reuters is a different way of depicting a drug seizure; in this case, more than two tons of marijuana by the authorities in Cali, Colombia.

Yesterday The Blood-Horse reported on Tuesday that the Jockey Club papers of Mine that Bird were stolen out of trainer Chip Woolley's truck. The papers have been replaced and this little hiccup will not slow down Mine That Bird as he prepares for the final leg of the Triple Crown.

Executives at General Motors and Chrysler defended the methods they used to whittle down dealerships at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, calling it a painful but necessary part of creating leaner, more competitive companies, The New York Times's Bernie Becker reports.

PARIS - When the curtain goes up on the women's semifinals, Samantha Stosur of Australia will be facing the toughest challenge and biggest opportunity of her career. It's her first time in the semifinal round at one of the four major international championships.

ALBANY -- Gov. David A. Paterson said Wednesday that he vetoed legislation that would have allowed new police officers and firefighters across the state to enroll for a category of pension benefits that was phased out for other public employees in the 1970s.

Carlos Beltran is back with the team and, more importantly, back in the lineup after a nasty case of food poisoning or a stomach virus (he doesn't know which) caused him to feel as bad as he ever has, he said.

When Brooke Astor made changes to her will between 2000 and 2003, she knew exactly what she was doing -- and what the consequences would be -- even though she was sometimes signing her name reluctantly, her former lawyer said Wednesday.

This week's guest blogger, Francesco Bonami, was born in Florence and lives in New York. In 2003, he directed the Venice Biennale; next year, he'll curate the Whitney's. With Alison Gingeras, he staged the current show in Venice of the Pinault Collection. Bonami is also the artistic director of Fondazione Sandretto in Turin and of Fondazione Pitti Immagine Discovery in Florence.

In speeches at a ceremony to unveil a statue of Ronald Reagan in the United States Capitol, Republican admirers of the 40th president repeatedly invoked Reagan's insistence that America's brightest days lay ahead and that the focus should always be on the future not the past.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is known for his practiced soft-spoken brevity, but he startled quite a few people on Tuesday -- and not just Republican critics -- when he responded to a question about particular rulings of Judge Sonia Sotomayor: "I understand that during her career, she's written hundreds and hundreds of opinions. I haven't read a single one of them. And if I'm fortunate before we end this, I won't have to read one of them."

Shareholders of the luxury chain Saks voted to put directors up for election annually, eliminating a staggered board with three-year terms, in a move to make the board of the struggling retailer more accountable.

A cherry pick of pristine Pucci is reason enough to elevate our blood pressure. But Federico Marchetti, the founder of yoox.com, plans to kick it up a notch by allowing users to purchase the vintage collection from the convenience of their iPhone. (For those without an iPhone, the items are also available on any olde-worlde computer.) The sale, which kicks off tomorrow, features high-ticket items spanning Emilio Pucci's 40-year career. Highlights include a 1960s strapless couture babydoll dress and a one-of-a-kind Slave Bracelet made for Pucci by Coppola e Toppo.

An elusive quality hovers over this Stanley Cup finals series through the first three games. The team that outshoots the opponent has lost all three. A team that dominates play for long stretches is not guaranteed victory. Two teams known for high-octane offense have not come close to filling the net.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia - President Obama's speech to the Muslim world will not only be delivered at Cairo University. It also will be texted and tweeted, as well as highlighted on Facebook, Myspace and a host of other social networking sites. The speech will also be Webcast as it happens on the White House Live section of Whitehouse.gov and streamed by the State Department as part of a live Web chat.

Lots of fashion labels have been enjoying a new wave of appreciation thanks to fashion's current 1980s revival. Yet little mention has been made of Jean Paul Gaultier, arguably the most influential designer of that decade. Gaultier, of course, is still very much in action - though sadly, he hasn't indulged recently in non-design adventures, like his television stints of the '90s and his brief fling with a musical career. His 1989 single "Aow Tou Dou Zat" (also known as "How to Do That") didn't exactly burn up the Billboard charts, but the video is still pretty incredible. There are cameos by demi-stars like the model Cameron; Gaultier's amazing sketches are brought to life with animation; we get glimpses of memorable pieces like his cone-breasted bustiers; and he rocks a set with crazy furniture reminiscent of Garouste & Bonetti. My favorite touch is the giant dancing scissors.

Charles Leerhsen, a former executive editor of Sports Illustrated who has written about sports and culture for such publications as Newsweek, Rolling Stone, Esquire and People, is the author of "Crazy Good: The True Story of Dan Patch, the Most Famous Horse in America," which was released in paperback Tuesday. "Crazy Good" is "not a harness racing book -- that would be the road to poverty and bankruptcy," he said. Instead it's a history lesson of sorts, recounting a time when horses were part of everyday life and how one world-record-setting horse in particular captured the attention of the nation. Leerhsen's two and a half years of painstaking "detective work," as he calls it, contributes to the vividness of the story of a racing hero from the early 1900s and the colorful characters associated with him. Many lessons and themes from "the age of endurance" resonate today: think the beginnings of the steroids era and the concept of marketing athletes as brands. Leerhsen will be reading from "Crazy Good" at 7 p.m. Thursday at BookCourt in Brooklyn.

Filmmaker, coffee manufacturer, weather reporter and champion of Transcendental Meditation are just of a few of the many hats David Lynch wears. So it is not surprising that he is also an accomplished photographer. Lynch is currently collaborating with the music producer and artist Danger Mouse on the installation "Dark Night of the Soul," which is on view at the Michael Kohn Gallery in Los Angeles through July 11.Fifty of Lynch's photographs, some straightforward (a pair of dice sitting on a green shag carpet) and some quite bizarre (a giant man's head being served on a platter in what appears to be a '70s family dining room), are mounted in this two-room installation. The works create a visual narrative for the album "Dark Night of the Soul," by Danger Mouse and the recording artist Mark Linkous (a k a Sparklehorse) with a host of other vocalists including Iggy Pop and Suzanne Vega. Visitors will get a simultaneous aural and visual experience that can continually change their perceptions of these photographs. A shot of a surge protector at the base a night stand takes on many meanings; it could be a fire hazard, a future murder weapon or just a source of electricity. A bobby-soxer grilling on the beach becomes sinister when you consider they way she holds that two-pronged fork. As with much of Lynch's work, you will think about it for a long time.

An article in The Arts on May 25 about the return of the refurbished “Music” stained-glass window to St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue, at 53rd Street, in Manhattan noted that the church is renowned for, among other things, “recitals on its Ernest M. Skinner organ.” While that organ was originally installed by Skinner, in 1913, it has been extensively altered since then, and last year the church announced that it planned to replace it. The article also stated that the church was built in 1914, the date given in a standard reference work, the AIA Guide to New York City. Construction began with the laying of the cornerstone in 1911, and the church was consecrated in 1916.

A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about a study of the black salt marsh mosquito in the Galapágos misspelled the species name of the mosquito. It is Aedes taeniorhynchus, not taerniorhynchus.

An article on May 24 about a recollection of a first night as a copy boy at The New York Times in 1959 misstated the output of Linotype machines he observed in the composing room. They punched out about six metal lines — not words — a minute.

It is Procter & Gamble, not Proctor & Gamble. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Monday, and also correctly noted that The Times has misspelled the name more than 100 times. (This is the second correction.).

An article on Sunday about the Texas Legislature’s voting to scale back a program under which Texans who graduated in the top 10 percent of their high schools were given automatic admission to the state university of their choice misidentified the political affiliation of State Representative Jim McReynolds, who opposed the move. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

An article on Monday about a hearing before the Minnesota Supreme Court on the state’s disputed Senate race misidentified the news organization to which Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, replied, “No, hell no,” when asked if Norm Coleman, a Republican, should concede to the Democratic candidate, Al Franken, if the court rules against Mr. Coleman. Mr. Steele was being interviewed by the National Journal’s Hotline On Call blog, not by The Star Tribune in Minneapolis.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a new government plan to fight cyberattacks gave an incorrect attribution for a statement about the differences between the strategy of the United States and that of other countries, including Russia and China. It was Mark Gerencser, a cybersecurity executive, who noted that the United States had separated defense and offense in the cybersecurity arena, while other countries had a more fluid strategy. The statement was not by “Mr. Hamilton.” (Mr. Gerencser is an executive with Booz Allen Hamilton, a consulting firm that deals extensively in the government’s cybersecurity strategy.).

An article on Tuesday about a task force that is to recommend ways to reveal more information about decision-making at the Food and Drug Administration referred incorrectly to a 2000 paper on the painkiller Celebrex in The Journal of the American Medical Association. After learning that the paper omitted data suggesting that the drug did not protect against ulcers, the journal published a clarification from the authors. The paper was not retracted.

In an unusual but welcome development for theatergoers hoping to see “God of Carnage,” the Tony Award-nominated comedy by Yasmina Reza, its producers announced on Tuesday that the play would extend its run through Nov. 15 with its cast intact — after shutting down for part of the summer. The play, which stars James Gandolfini, Marcia Gay Harden, Hope Davis and Jeff Daniels as two Brooklyn married couples who gather to settle a playground fight between their sons and share an afternoon of philosophy and violence, opened at the Bernard Jacobs Theater on Broadway in March. All four actors have been nominated for Tony Awards; Matthew Warchus has been nominated for best director of a play; and the production is up for best play. The cast members were under contract through late July, and it had been unclear if any would stay on if “God of Carnage” extended its run. In a statement, the lead producers Stuart Thompson and Robert Fox said the show would shut down after the July 26 performance so that its stars could fulfill other commitments, and resume on Sept. 8. Tickets for the new set of performances will go on sale Wednesday.

Given how tightly scripted gala events tend to be, what happened on the High Line on Monday night was one for the books. At an event to honor big donors to the High Line park, which is to run from Gansevoort Street to West 20th Street in Manhattan, the group Friends of the High Line announced a $10 million challenge grant from Diane von Furstenberg, the fashion designer, and her husband, the media mogul Barry Diller, who were hosts of the event. As Joshua David, a founder of the group, thanked the couple and spoke of a $50 million capital-campaign goal, Lisa Maria Falcone said she and her husband, Philip Falcone, had decided to match the $10 million themselves. Mr. Falcone is the senior managing director and co-founder of Harbinger Capital Partners Funds, a hedge fund. Mr. David said, “I guess I can skip through the part about matching the pledge.”.

New York City Opera lost $11.3 million for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2008, as the company was still hoping that Gerard Mortier, its newly appointed and quick to depart general director, would inject new vitality, according to tax returns obtained by Bloomberg News. The numbers are in sharp contrast to the fiscal year that ended in June 2007, when City Opera was running a surplus of $2.8 million. During that year, Bloomberg reported, the company’s revenue, including ticket sales and income from donations and investments, fell 23 percent to $32.9 million, while expenses increased 11 percent to $44.2 million. At his resignation from City Opera in November, Mr. Mortier said that he had been promised a budget of $60 million, but that the board of City Opera would approve only $36 million. He was succeeded at City Opera by George R. Steel.

FELBER--Edith, died peacefully at home in Jericho, NY on June 2 at age 71. Loving wife of the late Dr. Norbert Felber, devoted mother of Michael, Adam and Susie, adoring grandmother of Hugo and Sebastian, dear sister of Freda Rosen, and smitten owner of Daisy. As Edith Layton, she was the award-winning author of more than 30 historical novels and numerous novellas. A warm-hearted, generous, high-spirited and brave woman, she will be missed by all who knew her. Services Thursday, 12 noon at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, Long Island.

(HBO) SMILE PINKI (2008) About 35,000 children are born with cleft lips and palates in India each year; around a million live with the condition, one of the most common and curable birth defects. This Academy Award-winning documentary short, directed by Megan Mylan, follows Pinki, 5, above, and Ghutaru, 11, as they travel from their villages to the G. S. Memorial Plastic Surgery Hospital in the holy city of Benares. There free corrective surgery is performed by Dr. Sudbodh Kumar Singh and his team as part of the Smile Train, a nonprofit organization dedicated to repairing clefts in children from developing countries. 9 A.M. KERN--Ralph. Our sympathy to Lee and the Kern family on the passing of Ralph, our longtime associate. Harriet and Ashley and the Hoffman Family

KERN--Ralph. London Terrace Gardens and Clarendon Management Corp. mourns the death of their partner and good friend. His presence will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Leona, and his wonderful family. The Partners of London Terrace Gardens

KERN--Ralph. Our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. From the start, you were a large presence in a small family. Your love for Leona made you an immediate success and that love never waivered. As in any tight family, there were sometimes quarrels, but you could always be counted on for the full measure of that open heart with which you truly loved us all. In the midst of so many crowded dinner tables, you greeted us joyfully, relished our conversation and delighted in our homemade food. Your enthusiasm for new ideas and your position as the ultimate devil's advocate will never be denied. As a lover of opera, sailing, swimming and art, we admired your enthusiasm for life and the pleasure with which you shared those passions. For more than two years we watched you struggle to overcome great physical infirmity and persevere in loving your family. No less did they struggle and love. For the love you gave and the love you have inspired, we will always admire you and cherish your memory. Shirley, Diane and Bari, Beth and Jim, Elaine and Jerry.

HANDWERKER--Dorothy. We mourn the passing of our beloved Dorothy. She was the devoted wife of Murray for 67 years. She will be deeply missed by Murray and her children Steven, Michelle, Kenneth, Judy, William and Amy, and her grandchildren Adam, Francine, Michael, Diana, and Lucas. We will miss her warm, understanding and generous spirit. Private graveside services.

JACKMAN--Barbara Solomon Died May 31, 2009, after a long and productive life. Survived by her beloved daughter, Patricia Gutman and son-in-law Edward. Adored grandmother of Heidi and Jason Rosenfarb and Robert and Valarie Gutman; loving great-grandmother of Haley, Benjamin and Cassidy. Barbara pursued active and successful careers as the first female radio disc jockey (known as Barbara Day) in the 1950s and later as a life insurance agent. Barbara's keen intelligence and feisty spirit made her a force to be reckoned with. Always elegant and with boundless energy, Barbara spoke with honesty and directness, softened by her deep caressing voice. Funeral services will be private. The family will receive visitors at her daughter's home, Wednesday, June 3, 6-8pm and Thursday, June 4, 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

Andy joined the firm in 1950 and was a valued partner and legal advisor for nearly 60 years. We will miss his keen intellect and sage counsel. A demolition worker used a bolt cutter on Tuesday to open a gate blocked by residents of government housing in Makati City, the financial district of Manila. The residents fought with the workers before they were evicted. Their building was scheduled to be torn down in order to make way for new development in the Philippine capital.

President Obama signed the Ronald Reagan Centennial Commission Act on Tuesday, setting up a committee to prepare for the 100th anniversary of Reagan's birth on Feb. 6, 1911. Reagan's wife, Nancy, accompanied Mr. Obama to the White House signing.

BELL--Marion V. June 18, 1929 - May 4, 2009, a native of Pittsburgh, graduated from The Madeira School and Barnard College. She was librarian at the San Francisco Chronicle before returning to NYC to work at Scribners and later at The Corner Book Store, where she was known for holding parties for dogs and their owners. She is survived by her siblings, Betsy Martin of Pittsburgh, PA and Bill Bell of Brooklline, MA, seven grandnieces and nephews, and their 14 children. Memorials suggested for Animal Haven or Amnesty International.

BEEM--Gordon Ritter, Maj.,USAF, MSC, Retired, 82, of Asheville, NC, died on Sunday, May 31, 2009, at the VA Medical Center. A native of Niles, OH, Maj. Beem was a son of the late Edgar Allen and Marie Ritter Beem. He was a graduate of Bowdoin College, in Maine, and received his M.P.H. degree from Yale, in 1961. He had a 20-year career as a hospital executive in White Plains, NY, and Asheville, NC, and served as CEO of Waveny Care Center, Hall-Brooke and Elmcrest Psychiatric Hospitals, in Connecticut. He was a veteran of the U.S. Air Force, serving for 25 years. Maj. Beem is survived by his wife, Jeanne Franklin Newton Beem; his first wife, Margaret Richard, of Saco, ME; daughter Andrea Beem, of St. Croix, Virgin Islands; daughter, Mimi Herald and husband Geoffrey, of Danbury, CT; son, Mark Gordon Beem and wife Stephanie, of Centennial, CO; sister, Janet Frost and husband Brant, of Macon, GA; brother, Edgar Allen Beem, Jr., and wife Betty, of Westbrook, ME; and grandchildren, Josh, Kade, Connor, Ashley, and Lauren. The family also wishes to acknowledge the love and devotion of Jerry, Tarrants, and Gloria Rinker. Interment will take place at a later date at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. His family asks that memorials be made to Habitat for Humanity, 30 Meadow Rd., Asheville, NC 28803. Groce Funeral Home on Patton Avenue, Asheville, is assisting his family.

BECKHARD--Robert L.,age 91, died May 28, 2009, in New York, New York. Beloved husband to Patricia Knight Beckhard, brother-in-law to Susan Knight Cecil and Sally Knight Rabilloud, and uncle to Elizabeth Waller, Daniel Beckhard, and Ruth Werner. Born and raised in Brookline, Massachusetts, he was a passionate musician and student of English music from the early 20th century. He studied at the Boston University College of Music, the New England Conservatory of Music, and Harvard University. During the late 1940s he was an editor of music and text material at G. Schirmer Inc., working with such composers as Kurt Weill, Percy Grainger, and William Schuman. Bob composed over 200 original published choral and piano works, and his compositions have been performed by numerous professional and school choruses. He was a recognized expert on the music of Peter Warlock, and served as a musicologist for the fictionalized film account of Warlock's life, "Voices From a Locked Room." He contributed an essay to the book "Peter Warlock, A Centenary Celebration," published in 1994. In later years he devoted himself to research for a book about the life of the singer John Goss. Bob was also an accomplished professional photographer, whose images have been publicly exhibited in New York City and Putnam County, New York, and published in books and magazines. His evocative black and white photography illustrated two books by Frances F. Dunwell: "The Hudson River Highlands" and "The Hudson: America's River." He taught photography at the Garrison, NY Art Center. He and Pat loved their cottage near the Hudson in Garrison, where Bob spent countless happy hours tending his vegetable garden. He will be greatly missed by his family and his wide circle of friends.

KERN--Ralph W. of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully at his home, in the arms of his devoted wife of 53 years, Leona. He was a faithful son to Morris and Anna Kern, caring brother to Morton Kern, loving father of Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, and the proud grandfather of Seth, Allison, Melanie and Adam. Born in The Bronx in 1934, son of a furniture manufacturer, he worked full time to put himself through NYU. Early in his career, he established himself as a builder, entrepreneur, and visionary New York City developer. He was also adventurous, traveling and sailing extensively throughout the world. His passions were his family, opera, ballet, tennis, and sailing. We all looked to him for courage, direction, and understanding. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, June 3, 2009, 11:15am, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made in his name to Trustees of Columbia University, Division of Cardiology, Att: Dr. Allan Schwartz or Julie Fisher, 622 West 168th St, NY, NY 10032.

GERRITY--Edward "Ned," June 2nd, at his home in Rye, NY after a long illness. He was 85. A nationally-known corporate executive, he helped the legendary Harold Geneen build ITT into America's first global conglomerate. Ned was in charge of government and public affairs, worldwide advertising and ITT's Washington office. Decorated three times for gallantry during the siege of Bastongne with Patton's Third Army. Born in Scranton, PA, he was the son of Edward J. and Helen Walton Gerrity. Member of Winged Foot Golf Club, the Metropolitan Club. Class president, Columbia School of Journalism, 1948. Survived by his wife, Nadia Bardwil Gerrity, a daughter Katharine of Philadelphia; a son Edward III, Rye and a brother, Thomas of Scranton. His first wife, Katharine Casey of Scranton, died in 1993. Also survived by his grandson Edward IV and six stepdaughters and a stepson and 16 step-grandchildren. Wake at Graham Funeral Home, Rye, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, Friday, June 5 at 12pm. In lieu of flowers, the family hopes you will bestow your favor on Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, Fourth Floor, White Plains, NY 10601.

ORENSTEIN--Clara, 1914-2009, died peacefully at home May 28. Wife of the late Albert. Survived by sister, Mildred Saltzer; nieces, Sandra Saltzer Duzak (James) and Susan Saltzer Drucker (Daniel); grandnephew, Joshua Drucker (Kirstin Martin); grandniece Matana Drucker (Michael Bloor); great-grandnephews, Matthew Bloor and Benjamin Drucker. Family graveside service held Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Queens, NY May 31.

Memorial service will be held Saturday, June 6 at noon at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

We send our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. May his memory be for a blessing. Lewis Krinsky National Chairman Daniel R. Allen CEO

Messinger, President Jim Meier, Chair

BERNARDO--Loretta Jean (nee Stapor), 69, born in Woodside Queens, NY died June 1, 2009 in Philadelphia from cancer. She is survived by her beloved husband of 47 years, Dr. Peter Bernardo, and was a loving mother of J John (deceased), Carol Sue Bernardo, John Peter Bernardo, Alice Ann LoCascio, daughter-in-law, Susan Bernardo and son-in-law James LoCascio. She is also survived by her sister Marcella Stapor and five grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to her high school, St. Michael's Academy for Girls in New York City.

MEYER--Donald B. Left us on June 1st after a long and arduous struggle. He embodied the best qualities one could possess - intelligence, kindness, a largeness of spirit and a wonderful sense of humor. He was a problem solver who had a sense of adventure and who forgave others easily. He will be sorely missed by family and friends. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Mt. Sinai Neuro-Surgical unit. Private funeral. Memorial will be announced.

SULAM--Sondra "Sandi" (nee Cohen), 70 years young, passed away at her home in the Somerset section of Franklin, NJ on Tuesday, June 2, 2009. She was born in Brooklyn, NY and has lived in Somerset for many years. Sandi was an administrator for the Middlesex County College Foundation. She was a very special person with an "electric" personality, who experienced many exciting challenges in life and lived every day with "gusto". Sandi enjoyed multiple interests, including golf, tennis and music and we will all miss her bubbly personality and sharp sense of humor. She was the beloved wife of 49 years to Donald Sulam, proud mother of Marc and Glen, mother-in-law of Debra and cherished grandmother of Luke, Jack and William. Funeral service will be held at Anshe Emeth Temple, 222 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ, today, Wednesday, June 3, 2009 at 11am. Entombment will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Services are under the direction of the Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, 239 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ. Contributions, in her honor, can be made to The Jewish Communal Fund for The Edna Center, 575 Madison Avenue, Suite #

A judge in Los Angeles ruled Tuesday that a jury should decide a suit filed by the heirs of J. R. R. Tolkien, who say they are owed profits from New Line Cinema’s film adaptations of the “Lord of the Rings” novels, Variety reported. Judge Ann I. Jones of Los Angeles County Superior Court denied a motion by lawyers for New Line asking her to decide on the suit’s claims, clearing the way for a trial to begin in October. Last year, trustees of the Tolkien Trust, a British charity, joined trustees of a private family trust of Tolkien heirs and the British arm of HarperCollins Publishers in suing New Line for breach of contract, saying they are owed at least $150 million from the movies’ gross receipts. In their complaint, the plaintiffs said the three movies generated about $6 billion in box office receipts and revenues from DVD sales.

When Whitney Houston released her last studio album of original material, “Just Whitney,” in 2002, she was still the happily married spouse of Bobby Brown who had never starred in a reality television series and had never been impersonated by Maya Rudolph on “Saturday Night Live.” Needless to say, much has changed since then. Now Ms. Houston, the best-selling R&B and pop star, is planning to put out a new studio album. In a news release, Arista Records said it would release the album, whose title was not given. The label has handled all of Ms. Houston’s releases dating to her self-titled 1985 debut, and it said she had sold more than 170 million albums, singles and videos since then. In 2007, Ms. Houston was said to have started work on a new album that would include material from R. Kelly, Diane Warren and other producers. It is not known if any of this material will appear on her new record.

The director Brad Silberling knows a thing or two about merging real worlds with fictional ones. After animating the friendly ghost in “Casper” and working with a quite animated Jim Carrey in “Lemony Snicket’s A Series of Unfortunate Events,” Mr. Silberling was up for the challenge of bringing Sid and Marty Krofft’s cult TV show “Land of the Lost” to the big screen.

Venice – The center ring of the circus here at the 53rd Biennale is the former Italian pavilion, which is now grandly titled the Palazzo delle Esposizioni, with works from around the world chosen by the event’s chief curator, Daniel Birnbaum. One of the rooms in particular is drawing a consistent and often lingering crowd, though the work inside it is far from contemporary.

In principle, Jack Black probably likes the idea of being fought over, but not like this: the video game publisher Activision has filed suit to halt the coming release of Brutal Legend, a long-in-the-works video game in which Mr. Black plays a central role, The Associated Press reported. Since at least 2007, the game developer Double Fine Productions has been at work on Brutal Legend, a game that features Mr. Black (“School of Rock”) as a heavy-metal roadie in a fantasy land. It was originally to be released by Vivendi Games, now part of Activision Blizzard, which apparently dropped the title. In December, Electronic Arts announced that it had acquired the game. In its suit, Activision said that it still has a contract to release the game and had invested about $15 million in its development, according to The A.P. Brutal Legend was among the video games that Electronic Arts demonstrated this week at the gaming industry’s E3 Expo in Los Angeles.

VENICE – The Biennale is typically an over-serious, very adult affair, but today the main pavilion inside the Giardini, the public gardens here, was packed with howling, rambunctious, sticky-fingered Venetian schoolchildren. Many of them wore bright Batman-like masks, courtesy of the Italian artist Massimo Bartolini.

Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the newly installed archbishop of New York, plans to see the Broadway play “Irena’s Vow” on Saturday night, according to a publicist for the show. Written by Dan Gordon, “Irena’s Vow” centers on the story of a real life Polish Catholic housekeeper (played by Tovah Feldshuh) who protected Jews during World War II. “He chose ‘Irena’ because of all the clergy who have glowed to him about it, and he is particularly interested in Judeo-Catholic relations,” said the publicist, Rick Miramontez. The attendance of the archbishop, who took up his post in New York in April, is a well-timed boost for the show’s supporters: The Tony Awards ceremony is on Sunday night, and “Irena’s Vow,” which received mixed reviews from critics, did not draw any Tony nominations.

The rhythms of life have changed so much that the idea of shelling peas for a weeknight meal is pretty much out of the question. Combine them with crab to make a fast and quite tasty salad in less time than it would have taken me to shell the peas.

While three of the photographs in a series showed the storefront at 2038 Fifth Avenue in 1992, 1996 and 2007, the fourth photograph, showing a laundry, was of an adjacent building. It did not show 2038 Fifth Avenue in 1999.

An article on Tuesday, and a correction in this space on Wednesday, about a task force that is to recommend ways to reveal more information about decision-making at the Food and Drug Administration referred incorrectly to a 2000 paper on the painkiller Celebrex in The Journal of the American Medical Association. The paper was not retracted, and the journal did not publish an apology from the editors.

The American premiere of a dance collaboration between the actress Juliette Binoche and the choreographer Akram Khan will open the 2009 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which runs from Sept. 15 through Dec. 19, the organization said. The dance collaboration, “In-I,” will run Sept. 15 through 26 at the Harvey Theater in Brooklyn. Other festival highlights include the premiere of “Lipsynch,” a new theater production created by Ex Machina and Théâtre Sans Frontières, and directed by Robert Lepage; and a concert staging of “Kepler,” a new opera with music by Philip Glass, libretto by Martina Winkel and conducted by Dennis Russell Davies. More details can be found at bam.org.

Start practicing your teenage shrieks and squeals of delight: Paul McCartney will be the first musical artist to hold concerts at Citi Field in Flushing, Queens, the concert promoter AEG Live announced on Wednesday. The company said that Mr. McCartney would perform at the stadium on July 17 and 18, and that tickets for the shows would go on sale on June 15. Mr. McCartney, you may recall, was among the first musicians to play at Shea Stadium, the previous home of the New York Mets, when he performed there with the Beatles in 1965. He also made a guest appearance during a 2008 performance by Billy Joel, who was the last musician to hold a concert there.

Cher has filed suit against Universal Music Group on behalf of herself and the heirs of her ex-husband Sonny Bono, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the suit, filed on Tuesday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Cher said executives at the label had “engaged in wrongful tactics” that prevented her and Mr. Bono’s heirs from receiving the revenues that they are owed from compilation albums. Under the terms of her recording contracts with two labels that were absorbed by Universal, Cher said she was supposed to receive up to 50 percent of net royalties from the label; Mr. Bono was also entitled to a share of royalties under one of the deals. The suit says Universal funneled profits on a 1999 album, “Cher the Greatest Hits,” through its international division to avoid paying these royalties. A Universal spokesman told The Hollywood Reporter that the claims were “meritless.”.

Eminem’s comeback record, “Relapse” (Interscope), lost 65 percent of its sales in its second week out but remains No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. It sold 211,000 copies last week, bringing its total to 820,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (Eminem, left, sold almost twice as many copies of his 2004 studio album, “Encore,” in its first two weeks.) Also this week, Green Day’s “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise) holds at No. 2 with 76,000 in its third week at stores, and the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) is in third place with 52,000. New arrivals to the Top 10 include Marilyn Manson’s “High End of Low” (Interscope), which opened at No. 4 with 49,000 sales; “La Revolución” (Machete) by Wisin & Yandel, at No. 7 with 36,000 sales; and “Veckatimest” (Warp) by the Brooklyn band Grizzly Bear, at No. 8 with 33,000.

SHAINMARK--Mildred, 98 years old, devoted wife of the late Albert, cherished by her daughter Ronda Gelb and her husband, Alvin, her grandsons, Daniel and Michael, their wives, Jillian and Gretchen, her great-grandchildren, Samara, Aiden and Lily, her sister Beverly List and many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by her loving granddaughter, Janet. In our hearts forever. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetery in Rochelle Park, NJ on June 4 at 1pm.

KERN--Ralph. Our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. From the start, you were a large presence in a small family. Your love for Leona made you an immediate success and that love never waivered. As in any tight family, there were sometimes quarrels, but you could always be counted on for the full measure of that open heart with which you truly loved us all. In the midst of so many crowded dinner tables, you greeted us joyfully, relished our conversation and delighted in our homemade food. Your enthusiasm for new ideas and your position as the ultimate devil's advocate will never be denied. As a lover of opera, sailing, swimming and art, we admired your enthusiasm for life and the pleasure with which you shared those passions. For more than two years we watched you struggle to overcome great physical infirmity and persevere in loving your family. No less did they struggle and love. For the love you gave and the love you have inspired, we will always admire you and cherish your memory. Shirley, Diane and Bari, Beth and Jim, Elaine and Jerry.

SHAFFER--Doris Freed, 80, of Manhattan and Goose Pond, MA, formerly of Brooklyn and Great Neck. Died from cancer peacefully at home June 2nd. Her life was characterized by devotion to family and commitment to social justice. Graduate of Midwood H.S., Brooklyn College, and NYU. Professor of history at Nassau Community College, 1960-1988, president of NCC Federation of Teachers, 1973-1987. Board member and chapter advocate of New York Civil Liberties Union, 1970-2006, former chair ACLU Academic Freedom Committee, board member Fund for Modern Courts. Active supporter of The Nation, Center for Constitutional Rights, SANE/Peace Action, Peace Now, New Israel Fund. Loving wife for 60 years of Donald, mother of Nathan, Robert, David, sister of Jack, grandmother of Alan, Ross, Ben, Rachel, Robyn, Lee, Jeremy, mother-in-law of Lauri, Katharine, Susan. Memorial service Sunday, June 14, 3:00 pm, New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. Contributions may be sent to any of the above organizations.

GLOVES are as integral to boxing as sneakers are to running. Just as shoes protect the feet and absorb shock while running, so too do gloves cushion and shield the hands while punching. And as sneakers have become complex highly engineered human-propelling devices, the technology that goes into a pair of boxing gloves has improved beyond a couple of inches of foam padding. Features like interior contouring to help position the thumb, moisture-wicking liners, supportive wrist cuffs and gel padding maximize hand and wrist protection and comfort. Technology's improvements have grown alongside an increase in the sport's popularity. The number of amateur boxers registered as members of USA Boxing, the national governing body for the sport, was 29,986 in 2008, up 28 percent from the 23,436 registered in 1999.

The one-page letter that churned through the White House fax machine came from Jasmine Williams, a 19-year-old black student from a crime-ridden neighborhood in the nation's capital, inviting Michelle Obama to speak at her high school graduation. ''Where we come from, being a young minority means that we have little chance to succeed,'' Ms. Williams wrote. ''The world already has a predetermined thought that our generation is full of criminals and concubines. Although this may be true about some of the people of our generation, there are still a lot of us that live above the influence and strive to be our best.''
