8 P.M. (TCM) GREAT DIRECTORS: INGMAR BERGMAN Turner Classic Movies devotes the evening to this Swedish director, starting with a 1971 interview from ''The Dick Cavett Show.'' ''The Seventh Seal,'' Bergman's 1957 masterpiece about a medieval knight (Max von Sydow) who plays a game of chess with Death (Bengt Ekerot, above left, with Mr. von Sydow) in exchange for his life, will be shown at 9. The tribute continues with ''Wild Strawberries'' (1957), in which a distinguished professor (Victor Sjostrom) on his way to an awards ceremony reflects on his loveless life, at 10:45; ''Persona'' (1966), starring Liv Ullmann as an actress recovering from a breakdown and Bibi Andersson as a nurse, at 12:30 a.m.; ''Hour of the Wolf'' (1968), with Mr. von Sydow as a painter who shares his most painful memories with his pregnant wife (Ms. Ullmann) during a long night on a secluded island, at 2; and ''The Passion of Anna'' (1969), in which a depressed man (Mr. von Sydow again) who has recently ended his marriage moves to an island and begins an affair with an increasingly delusional woman (Ms. Ullmann) who has lost her husband and son, at 3:45. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY A look at an auction of items belonging to Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley; garage sales; and summer camp for children. Thirty-four members of the Organization of American States gathered here Tuesday to argue over whether to readmit Cuba. By the end of the day, the United States had failed in an attempt to broker a deal that would have lifted the ban on Havana. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton emerged from talks with the foreign ministers of nine North and South American countries after an unsuccessful struggle to hash out a compromise that would have granted Cuba membership, provided its regime accepted democratic principles.

Below are examples of some recent postings to Fanfou.com, a social networking site like Twitter. The site was shut down Wednesday. (June 4, or 6/4, is the day generally commemorated as the anniversary of the military crackdown on the Tiananmen Square movement.)

SIMRING--Ruth Friedman. Brilliant and devoted companion, mentor, and dentist. Her courageous belief in life allowed her to nurture others even after the devastating loss of her son, Noah. She fought against ovarian cancer since 2001 and spearheaded a fundraiser for future cancer research this past April. She is survived by her husband Jim, daughter Mia, and countless others whose lives she inspired. Services will be Friday, June 5th at the "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam at 11:45am. Donations can be made to the Noah's Room Foundation, 200 E. 24th St., Apt. 906, NYC, NY 10010.

Congressional leaders unveiled a statue of Ronald Reagan in the Capitol Rotunda on Wednesday, at a ceremony where his admirers repeatedly invoked his insistence that America's brightest days lay ahead. But even as they renewed their embrace of Reagan's belief in a better future, members of the diminished Republican minorities seemed to relish the chance to relive the glory days of the 1980s.

COUDRAI--John C.,80, of Smithville, NJ on June 1, 2009 of lung cancer. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Marcelle, his son Philippe, his daughter-in-law Leila, his grandsons John-Michael and Eric Coudrai; his sister Nicole Ouvre, his niece Anne Polloni, his grand-niece Agnes, his cousins Lucien Vergne and Serge Masse. John and Marcelle emigrated from France to the U.S. in 1954. Being third generation in a family of Hoteliers, his career in the hotel industry as Banquet Manager and Catering Director spanned over 30 years, having worked for Marriott, Resorts, and Hilton's Waldorf Astoria, among others. John loved to read and was an avid student of world history. Relatives and friends of the family are kindly invited to attend his visitation on Friday, June 5, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm, and Saturday, June 6, from 9-9:30am at Lowenstein Funeral Home, 58 South New York Road, Galloway, NJ (609-652-8330). A Catholic mass will be held Saturday, 10am at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church, 603 New Jersey Avenue, Absecon, NJ (609-641-1480). Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the South Jersey Cancer Fund, P.O. Box 1084, Brigantine, NJ 08203.

IT was one of the most strenuously stylish events of the season -- and one of the most schizophrenic. The Veuve Clicquot Manhattan Polo Classic, held on May 30 at Governors Island, drew a tradition-minded straw-hat-and-seersucker crowd and with it more than its share of self-styled eccentrics. Intent on upending convention, guests like Chloë Sevigny (far right) softened the patrician cast of her ivory Chloé blazer with playfully scalloped shorts, while the racily turned out young women below subbed little black dresses for the customary lawn-party whites. In homage perhaps to Prince Harry (atop his pony, bottom left), others at the match, a benefit for the orphans of Lesotho, affected a sportingly upper-crust look. Among them was LL Cool J (bottom center), in a tailor-made fawn-colored suit, and Michael Arenella, (in seersucker, below), who showed off white braces and ascot, which he imagined might capture the mood. After all, as Mr. Arenella noted, smiling broadly, ''I'm here rubbing elbows with the beautiful people.''

JACKMAN--Barbara Solomon Died May 31, 2009, after a long and productive life. Survived by her beloved daughter, Patricia Gutman and son-in-law Edward. Adored grandmother of Heidi and Jason Rosenfarb and Robert and Valarie Gutman; loving great-grandmother of Haley, Benjamin and Cassidy. Barbara pursued active and successful careers as the first female radio disc jockey (known as Barbara Day) in the 1950s and later as a life insurance agent. Barbara's keen intelligence and feisty spirit made her a force to be reckoned with. Always elegant and with boundless energy, Barbara spoke with honesty and directness, softened by her deep caressing voice. Funeral services will be private. The family will receive visitors at her daughter's home, Wednesday, June 3, 6-8pm and Thursday, June 4, 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

Although the iPhone has many features to offer, it lacks one particularly handy tool, a zoom lens for its camera. That's what makes Camera Zoom worth checking out. The 99-cent app adds a 4X digital zoom to the iPhone.

Mark this day in your calendar. On June 1, 2009, Blu-ray officially jumped the shark -- and you can thank Panasonic for that. On Monday, the consumer electronics company announced it was bringing to market the DMP-B15, the world's first portable Blu-ray player. You read that right. Stunning high-def video and 5.1-surround sound on an 8.9-inch screen, with mini stereo speakers.

A congressman has written a letter to the National Basketball Association and its players union asking them to repeal its minimum-age guidelines. Steve Cohen, Democrat of Tennessee, wrote that the four-year-old rule, which requires players to be 19 years old and a year removed from their high school graduation, is of ''deep concern.'' He added that essentially forcing teenagers to go to college had led to recent college sports scandals.

Rain Douses Johnson's Chance at No. 300 For more than three hours, fans at Nationals (Water) Park stayed underneath the cover, hoping the same hopes as Randy Johnson and the San Francisco Giants. Once again, the Pittsburgh Pirates have traded their best and most recognizable player. This time, it was the All-Star center fielder Nate McLouth, who was shipped to the Atlanta Braves on Wednesday for a package of three prospects. McLouth joins Jason Bay, Xavier Nady and Damaso Marte as popular Pirates who have been dealt over the last year, as a new regime tries to infuse young talent into an organization that has not had a winning season since 1992.

ECKHARDT--Robert G.,87, of Levittown and Tampa, Florida passed May 21, 2009. WWII US Army veteran. Longtime New York Times employee. Predeceased by wives Elizabeth Buckhorn and Jean Day. Survived by daughter, Carol Lee Daniel; grandchildren, Jamie, David and Eric Schloss; step-children Tom, Rob and Janet Day; and Companion Ann Cook. Funeral: 11am Monday, June 8th at Florida National Cemetery. Send online condolences to www.macdonaldfuneral.com

I attended my nephew's high school baseball game last week, and it made me wonder how pro photographers go about shooting a game. I found a tutorial by Jim Bryant at Digital Photography School that had some useful tips for just about every level of snap-shooter. Here are a few: Before the game, look for interesting events like tailgate parties and team merchandise vendors. At the game I attended, one family arrived in a truly huge recreational vehicle replete with school colors and a host of decked-out guests.

SULAM--Sondra. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Sondra Sulam, wife of Donald and mother of Marc and Glen (Debra). Marc's generosity strengthens our ability to serve those in need in New York, in Israel, and abroad. We extend our condolences to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KERN--Ralph. Our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. From the start, you were a large presence in a small family. Your love for Leona made you an immediate success and that love never waivered. As in any tight family, there were sometimes quarrels, but you could always be counted on for the full measure of that open heart with which you truly loved us all. In the midst of so many crowded dinner tables, you greeted us joyfully, relished our conversation and delighted in our homemade food. Your enthusiasm for new ideas and your position as the ultimate devil's advocate will never be denied. As a lover of opera, sailing, swimming and art, we admired your enthusiasm for life and the pleasure with which you shared those passions. For more than two years we watched you struggle to overcome great physical infirmity and persevere in loving your family. No less did they struggle and love. For the love you gave and the love you have inspired, we will always admire you and cherish your memory. Shirley, Diane and Bari, Beth and Jim, Elaine and Jerry.
If I can rob a bank, I'll be back for the others. JAMES S. CRAWFORD, who has had three heart attacks, on the prescriptions he can't afford to fill. [A3]

SHAFFER--Doris Freed, 80, of Manhattan and Goose Pond, MA, formerly of Brooklyn and Great Neck. Died from cancer peacefully at home June 2nd. Her life was characterized by devotion to family and commitment to social justice. Graduate of Midwood H.S., Brooklyn College, and NYU. Professor of history at Nassau Community College, 1960-1988, president of NCC Federation of Teachers, 1973-1987. Board member and chapter advocate of New York Civil Liberties Union, 1970-2006, former chair ACLU Academic Freedom Committee, board member Fund for Modern Courts. Active supporter of The Nation, Center for Constitutional Rights, SANE/Peace Action, Peace Now, New Israel Fund. Loving wife for 60 years of Donald, mother of Nathan, Robert, David, sister of Jack, grandmother of Alan, Ross, Ben, Rachel, Robyn, Lee, Jeremy, mother-in-law of Lauri, Katharine, Susan. Memorial service Sunday, June 14, 3:00 pm, New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. Contributions may be sent to any of the above organizations.

JACKMAN--Barbara Solomon Died May 31, 2009, after a long and productive life. Survived by her beloved daughter, Patricia Gutman and son-in-law Edward. Adored grandmother of Heidi and Jason Rosenfarb and Robert and Valarie Gutman; loving great-grandmother of Haley, Benjamin and Cassidy. Barbara pursued active and successful careers as the first female radio disc jockey (known as Barbara Day) in the 1950s and later as a life insurance agent. Barbara's keen intelligence and feisty spirit made her a force to be reckoned with. Always elegant and with boundless energy, Barbara spoke with honesty and directness, softened by her deep caressing voice. Funeral services will be private. The family will receive visitors at her daughter's home, Wednesday, June 3, 6-8pm and Thursday, June 4, 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

The color key in an Op-Ed chart on Sunday, on retail sales at malls, mislabeled some sales figures. In addition, some changes in sales figures were misstated. Sales revenue at Denny's declined 15.4 percent in the first quarter of 2009 from the year-ago period, not 5.1 percent, while sales revenue at Kohl's increased 0.4 percent, not decreased. A corrected version can be found online at nytimes.com.

What's this Wii MotionPlus I've been hearing about? Wii MotionPlus is a small add-on that snaps onto the bottom of a Nintendo Wii Remote, increasing its ability to sense motion. It will be particularly useful for sports games, where hand and arm motion count. It contains a sensor that instantaneously measures the angular velocity (the rate at which an object turns) of a hand or arm. So, throwing a Frisbee is tricky, just like the real thing. According to Nintendo, you'll be able to buy one on Monday for $20. Games in the works include Virtua Tennis 2009, Tiger Woods P.G.A. Tour 10, and EA Sports Grand Slam Tennis.

Manchester United will replace the three-letter logo of one American insurer, now emblazoned on players' shirts, with the three-letter logo of another American insurer. The club said Wednesday it had signed Aon, based in Chicago, as its principal sponsor, starting in the 2010-11 season. Aon will replace American International Group, or A.I.G., which chose not to renew its sponsorship after the company fell victim to the credit crunch and was bailed out by the United States government. Neither Aon nor Manchester United would say how much the four-year deal was worth, but it was believed to be the most lucrative in soccer -- about £20 million ($32.5 million) a year. This is a more complete version of the story than appeared in print.

Lately, Stephen Colbert has had to crow a little quieter than usual when discussing his show’s coming visit to the Persian Gulf. (The comedian could not say exactly where he would be broadcasting “The Colbert Report,” due to military restrictions.) But The Associated Press reports that Mr. Colbert arrived on Friday at the former Al Faw Palace at Camp Victory in Baghdad. There he’ll tape four shows in front of about 450 US troops. The series, which is being called “Operation Iraqi Stephen: Going Commando,” will be shown on Comedy Central starting Monday. Watch for more coverage of Mr. Colbert’s trip to Iraq in The Times in the days ahead.

The members of the British rock band Oasis could have to dig deep into their own pockets if its fans take the group up on an offer to refund their tickets for a recent show. BBC News reported that a show performed by Oasis on Thursday night at Heaton Park in Manchester drew about 70,000 paying fans, but was beset by technical problems. After power to the stage was cut twice and the performance was paused for about a half hour, Noel Gallagher, the band’s lead guitarist, told the audience: “Thank you very, very much, this is a free gig, let’s have it. Anybody who has kept their ticket will get a full refund,” according to the BBC. If everyone in attendance were to ask for a refund, it would cost the band about $4.8 million. The show was the first that Oasis had played in its hometown of Manchester in four years, and had been planned for six months.

A former payroll manager for the Brooklyn Museum stole more than $620,000 from the institution by issuing fake paychecks that were directly deposited into his bank account, according to court papers made public on Thursday.

VENICE – One of the simpler and more striking works at the Biennale, now fully underway here with crowds and long lines and (even these days) flotillas of big shiny yachts, is a small, darkened room created by the Chinese artist Chu Yun inside the Arsenale. Within the room are dozens of household appliances, small and large, arranged on shelves and tables. Even after your eyes adjust, you can’t make them out because it’s pitch black. All you can see are their power or status lights—twinkling, blinking reds, blues, yellows and silvers—staring back at you. They’re like some little Star Wars creatures hibernating in their space cave, or the reflection of the tapetum at the back a dog’s or cat’s eyes. (Mr. Chu also has a piece up, or maybe down, at the New Museum’s inaugural triennial in New York right now: he has hired women to sleep, one at a time and with the aid of medication, on a bed in the center of a gallery for the run of the show.)

NBC Universal said in a statement Friday that a lawsuit filed by a woman over injuries she said she sustained during filming of the coming Sacha Baron Cohen comedy “Bruno” was “completely baseless,” The Associated Press reported. In her lawsuit, the woman, Richelle Olson, said that she was injured in May 2007 at a charity bingo game in Palmdale, Calif., when Mr. Cohen arrived in the guise of his gay character Bruno and the two struggled after she tried to take a microphone from him. Later, Ms. Olson said she fell and hit her head on a concrete slab and sustained bleeding in her brain. In its statement, NBC Universal said that footage of the event “clearly shows that Ms. Olson was never touched or in any way assaulted by Sacha Baron Cohen or any member of the production and suffered no injury,” according to The A.P.

The fantasy subgenre of “vampires vs. werewolves vs. zombies vs. wereleopards,” popularized by series like “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” “Twilight” and “Underworld,” continues to thrive: the first volume of Marvel’s comic book adaptation of the Laurell K. Hamilton novel “Anita Blake: The Laughing Corpse” debuts at No. 4 on our hardcover list. Ms. Hamilton weaves together almost every fantasy element imaginable in her Anita Blake books, focusing on the title character’s investigations into the paranormal (enhanced by her ability to reanimate and control the dead). The author has taken some criticism for the sexually explicit situations depicted in her work, but that hasn’t hurt sales of her books, with more than six million copies in circulation. A 17th “Anita Blake: Vampire Hunter” novel will be released on Tuesday, and a movie based on the earlier books is slated to be shown on the Independent Film Channel next year.

A ray of hope has shined on the people of India, who will now have more to choose from at their multiplexes than repeated viewings of “Fast & Furious”: industry officials say that Bollywood film producers had agreed to end a standoff with Indian movie-theater owners over how they will share revenue from movie ticket sales. The producers had demanded a 50 percent share of ticket grosses, and since April 4 had shut down production of new Bollywood films. The multiplex owners had wanted revenue-sharing to be based on factors like a film’s budget and the stars in its cast. After about eight hours of talks on Thursday, the two sides struck a deal.

In this Sunday's Travel section, Frank Bruni, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, writes about the coastal towns of Tuscany, among them Viareggio and Forte dei Marmi. These are not the glamorous, jet-set getaways of Capri and Positano, both overly familiar to American tourists looking for seaside retreats on an Italian vacation. These are the beach towns that the Italians themselves head to for a weekend getaway. As Mr. Bruni writes, "It's less Riviera than Robert Moses State Park." But this shoreline offers the opportunity to feast on bracingly fresh seafood served in unpretentious trattorias, and to sample the unhurried summer lifestyle of Italian beach.

The women's final between Dinara Safina and Svetlana Kuznetsova on Saturday should be quite a battle. They have split their eight matches on clay, with Safina winning last month in Rome and Kuznetsova winning their match in Stuttgart, Germany. Both are from accomplished athletic families, with Safina attempting to join her brother Marat as a Grand Slam champion. And Kuznetsova's brother, Nikolai, earned a silver medal in cycling in the 1996 Atlanta Olympics.

In the annals of manly pursuits, herb gardening must occupy a spot between gin rummy and the mysteries of Agatha Christie. I happen to like both of those things, which is only to say that the main reason I haven't yet mentioned my herb garden is that it resides in a different plot from my vegetables. It's a small trapezoidal patch at the top of the driveway, outside the kitchen window, and it doubles as an active cruising ground for gray squirrels, mourning doves, grackles, and the odd hairy woodpecker or nuthatch.

Updated | 4:28 p.m. There are few 9-year-olds whose lives would merit an entire book, but Rubina Ali Qureshi, a young star of the movie "Slumdog Millionaire," may be the exception. On Friday, Transworld Publishers and Random House Children's Books in Britain and Delacorte Press Books for Young Readers in the US said that they would publish the life story of Rubina Ali, who was recruited from a Mumbai slum for the Academy Award-winning film, in a book called "Slumgirl Dreaming: My Journey to the Stars." Since the release of the movie, Rubina Ali has accumulated enough material for a second book: a British tabloid said her father had tried to offer her for adoption in exchange for money (the police in Mumbai said they could not found evidence of this); and her family's shanty home was demolished by authorities in preparation for India's monsoon season (state officials said the family would be given a new home in suburban Mumbai). Delacorte said that it would release the book in the US in September; the British release is scheduled for July 16. Proceeds from its sales will go to Rubina Ali and the French medical organization Medecins du Monde.

Are governments pushing for a liberal ideal of Islam that's just as unrepresentative of moderate Muslims as Islamic fundamentalism is? Can progressives embrace God? London's Institute of Contemporary Arts (The Mall, London SW1Y 5AH, 02-07-930-3647), which began at the beginning of the month and continues through June 22, deconstructs these and other religious and political quagmires with a series of talks seemingly aimed at -- and meant to challenge -- contemporary liberal viewpoints.

No one, it seems, is safe from food contamination, not even fans of D'Artagnan's elite duck products, which include many chefs and well-heeled consumers. The packages were sent to distributors and restaurants from Maryland to Massachusetts.

On June 9, 1909, Alice Huyler Ramsey left New York City in a Maxwell Model DA, bound for the West Coast. Two months and 3,800 rugged miles later, she and her three passengers arrived in San Francisco, making Ramsey the first woman to drive an automobile cross-country.

A few nights ago the Times played host to the 6th annual Citi Women & Co. event, and I was asked to speak about fashion and the economy, with a look back at previous recession and a look forward to some of the challenges facing the industry. About 200 people attended the cocktail-hour event, and the questions afterward were diverse and interesting. A number of guests, including Francoise Olivas, a young designer here in the city, mentioned the growing difficulty of getting clothes produced in New York. Although some designers are finding that many factories are more eager than in the past to do small runs-in order to keep their workers busy-the economic pressure on factories and suppliers in New York is obviously a concern to small companies that can't afford to produce in China and other countries. John Martin picked up game-by-game coverage in the third set of the men's semifinal match between Roger Federer and Juan Martin del Potro. Del Potro, hitting powerful ground strokes that keep Roger Federer off balance, won the first and third sets, mounting a lead, 6-3, 6-7, 6-2. The crowd roared with approval for both players, but at that point there seemed to be an apprehension setting in among Federer fans that he was headed for defeat. Del Potro had broken Federer's serve four of the 11 chances he has had. It started as a tough day for Federer, who is seeking his first French Open title. The distance seemed to be growing at that point in the match.

VENICE -- A blimp is not an easy thing to avoid. For art viewers here walking around the Arsenale, the former shipbuilding area that's now one of the main sites at the Venice Biennale, a big grayish blimp - it appears to be a wayward or wounded one wedged into an alleyway between two high walls - has become a outlandishly familiar part of the daily experience. If you're scooting around to the back of exhibition or leaving it, you end up walking right under the downed craft and staring up at its spectral cockpit.

There's a strange summer tradition in New York City of waxing conceptual about photography. In the summer of 2007, Luhring Augustine gallery's "Strange Magic" show celebrated artists intent on dragging traditional photography into the far realms of abstraction. Last summer, the Metropolitan Museum of Art played host to "Photography On Photography: Reflections of the Medium Since 1960," a large-scale survey that helped group together what is now considered the conceptual photography rat pack: Liz Deschenes, Roe Etheridge, Sherrie Levine and Christopher Williams.

The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra announced that its music director, Marin Alsop, had signed a new contract that would keep her in that position to August 2015. In a news release, the orchestra said that Ms. Alsop, who became its 12th musical director in September of 2007, had signed a five-year contract extension. Her current contract was not due to expire until September of next year. The orchestra said that following the arrival of Ms. Alsop, it attracted 23 percent more new subscribers for its 2007-2008 season than in the previous year, and that annual fund giving grew 31 percent to $12.1 million by the end of the 2008 fiscal year. Earlier this year, the orchestra said that its musicians would give back $1 million through wage freezes and other concessions to help it weather the recession, and that Ms. Alsop had personally given $50,000 towards an additional $2 million in matching funds that the orchestra was seeking.

Glancing across the towering stacks of books that crowd our office, it's sometimes easy to imagine that everything gets published these days, and that frustrated writers are a relic of the past along with milkmen and hansom cab drivers and - nervous chuckle here - ink-stained newspaper editors. So contests like the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award offer a helpful corrective: 2,000 manuscripts are winnowed to 500 and then 100 and then just three, before a single winner emerges with a book deal courtesy of the Penguin Group. That's 1,999 frustrated writers to one published author. See? Publishing is still selective after all.

JONES--Robert Wagenseil, 76, of Westbrook, CT, died in Middlesex Hospital on May 15, 2009, after a brief illness. Robert was born on March 22, 1933, in Providence, RI. He was descended from Governor William Bradford of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, and preceded in death by his parents, Robert Bradford Jones and Hazel Wagenseil Jones, and by his beloved son, Adam Simmons Jones, in 1984. A graduate of Moses Brown School in Providence, Robert received his Bachelor of Architecture degree from Cornell University in 1956, where he was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity. He was elected to membership in Tau Beta Pi and Phi Kappa Phi, scientific and engineering honor societies, and was awarded the Alpha Rho Chi architecture medal and an AIA second grant. He was an associate of Charles Luckman Associates, and director of architecture for Donald Deskey Associates in New York. In 1965, he and Serge Petroff founded a partnership and, in 1970, merged with Shreve, Lamb, and Harmon Associates, builders of the Empire State Building. Their plan to add ten stories to the building in order to maintain its status as the tallest building in the world created much controversy. The firm won a Progressive Architecture award for its proposed addition to the United States Embassy in Paris. Robert was later director of architecture for Rockefeller Center. His own firm, Robert Wagenseil Jones and Associates subsequently won a Progressive Architecture award for its design for the Goebel Collectors Club. Robert continued his practice when he moved to Connecticut in 1980 to concentrate on residential and commercial development. A past member of the New York chapter of the AIA and the New York Society of Architects, Robert served for many years on the board of Moses Brown, and was deeply involved with its master plan and the design of new buildings. A passionate yachtsman all his life, with a particular love of wooden boats, Robert was a member of the Grand Banks Owners Association and a past member of the New York Yacht Club. The sight of another boat however distant anywhere on the Sound was Robert's signal to start racing in earnest, whether the other boat was aware of it or not. Robert is survived by his long-time companion, Elinor T. Fine of Connecticut and New York, his daughter, Sarah Winifred Wagenseil Jones, and three grandchildren Alyona Grace Jones, Pavel Henry Jones, and Anderson Pavel Jones, all of Mebane, North Carolina. Truly larger-than-life in every way, Robert was a uniquely talented and creative visionary with fearless opinions and an irreverent wit. He will be forever missed by those who loved and cherished him. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Mystic Seaport, 75 Greenmanville Avenue, Mystic, CT, 06355. A memorial ceremony will be held on July 19, 2009, at 2pm, at Brewer Pilots Point Marina, 63 Pilots Point Drive, Westbrook, CT.

SPENCER--Susan S.,M.D. 60 years old, died on Thursday, May 21, 2009, in Salt Lake City, Utah. She is predeceased by her beloved father, Bernard Schneider, of Yonkers, NY, and survived by her loving family: her mother Magda Schneider of Yonkers, NY; her husband Dennis Spencer of Woodbridge, CT; her daughters Joanna Spencer of Manhattan and Andrea Spencer of Cambridge, MA; her stepdaughter Kate Spencer of Burbank, CA; her stepson Christopher Spencer of Haverford, PA; her sisters Beth Weingarth of Woodbridge, CT and Karen Kimball of North Haven, CT. Dr. Spencer was Professor of Neurology and Neurosurgery and Director of the Epilepsy Program at the Yale School of Medicine and an internationally recognized expert in epilepsy and epilepsy surgery. She was a pioneering woman in medicine, fighting for and forging a pathway for other brilliant female scientists of the next generation. As a leader in her field, Dr. Spencer served as the president of the American Epilepsy Society (AES) in 2000 and vice-president of the American Neurological Society (ANA) in 2001. She served on the executive boards of both the ANA and the American Academy of Neurology. She also co-founded and co-edited the journal Epilepsy Currents from 2001 to 2009. Her contributions were recognized by the AES Clinical Research Award in 2003, the most prestigious honor paid to a member in the field. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Epilepsy Society for the Susan Spencer Fund for Clinical Research and Education (to the AES at 342 North Main St., West Hartford, CT 06117, or by credit card online at www.aesnet.org). A memorial service, open to the public, will be held on July 11th at 3:00 PM in Battell Chapel, New Haven, CT.

PIER--William Stanwood Sr.,died in Aptos, CA at the age of 92. Born in Long Island, NY to Anne Terry Gardiner and Roy Pier, he graduated from Harvard University in 1938 and Harvard Law School in 1941. A First Lieutenant during World War II, he trained B-17 bomber pilots. After the war he lived in London and worked for the State Dept. on the Marshall Plan. Upon returning to the US he practiced law in SF, CA and later was an attorney for the Nuclear Power Division of GE in San Jose, CA. He leaves his wife of 28 years, Susan (Van der Poel); four children: Phoebe Fairburn, Will Pier, Margaret Barton, Virginia Pier; 15 grandchildren; 11 great-grandchildren; two stepchildren, Jennifer and Richard Welling, and three step-grandchildren. His 1st wife Reinette Phillips died in 2004. His 2nd wife, Jade Pier, survives him.

KERN--Ralph W. of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully last Sunday at his home, in the arms of his devoted wife of 53 years, Leona. He was a faithful son to Morris and Anna Kern, caring brother to Morton Kern, loving father of Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, and the proud grandfather of Seth, Allison, Melanie and Adam. Born in The Bronx in 1934, son of a furniture manufacturer, he worked full time to put himself through NYU. Early in his career, he established himself as a builder, entrepreneur, and visionary New York City developer. He was also adventurous, traveling and sailing extensively throughout the world. His passions were his family, opera, ballet, tennis, and sailing. We all looked to him for courage, direction, and understanding. Donations may be made in his name to Trustees of Columbia University, Division of Cardiology, Att: Dr. Allan Schwartz or Julie Fisher, 622 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

BONNARD--Vicente Juliano, President Emeritus of the Brazilian-American Chamber of Commerce, Inc. in New York, died Tuesday evening at the North Shore Hospital. He was 82. Mr. Bonnard was a founding member of the Brazilian-American Chamber of Commerce in New York in 1969. His contributions to the growth and development of the Chamber, and to the creation of stronger business relations between Brazil and the United States in general, were far reaching and will be deeply missed. In 1970 Mr. Bonnard instituted the "Man of the Year" award, now known as the "Person of the Year" award, to honor two innovative and forward-thinking leaders (one from Brazil and one from the U.S.) who have made extraordinary contributions to the forging of closer ties between the two nations. He served as Chairman of its Organizational Committee until his passing. From 1948 to 1967 Mr. Bonnard was Head of the Brazilian Aeronautical Commission's New York Office. From 1960 to 1967 he was accredited to USIS and to the UN as representative and correspondent for the Rio de Janeiro newspapers "O Dia" and "A Noticia". He was also a founding member of the "Brazilian Institute for Education and Business Programs" at Cornell University, a founding member of the "Business Institute for Brazilian Studies" at Pace University and a founding member of the "Business Institute" at San Diego State University. Throughout his honorable career Mr. Bonnard received numerous medals and decorations from governmental, academic, and private entities. Mr. Bonnard is survived by his children Vicente, Patricia, Debora and Mark.

About five years ago, an American friend teaching English in Japan sent me yearbook pictures of his students. Almost immediately, I started working on multi-portrait drawings from those photographs. I went on to make a series of drawings based on a 1964 yearbook from the Bronx, then I turned to my wife's 1972 yearbook from her high school in Cheyenne, Wyo. When I make these drawings, I can't help but think about the people I'm depicting. I make up stories in my head about them, wondering what they were like (or are like), calculating how old they'd be now and the chances that they're still alive. Before long, I started acquiring yearbooks. I found that the older ones, especially, have wonderful quotations to go with the pictures. The drawings below come from two yearbooks in my collection; the names and quotations are verbatim. -- JEFF ZENICK, an artist

NICHOLLS--Paul. The physicians and staff of the Continuum Cancer Centers of New York (CCCNY) join with the entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and generous benefactor, Paul Nicholls, an inspiration to all who were touched by his extraordinary spirit. Paul did not see cancer as an obstacle, but rather as an opportunity to help others. Despite dealing with life-threatening Stage 3 myeloma, he first began raising money to fight this dreaded disease in 2003 when he first ran the New York City Marathon. This effort led to the establishment of Team Continuum, through which others joined with him to support a wide variety of important programs at the CCCNY sites. He will forever be remembered by all whose lives were touched by his efforts. To his beloved wife Diana Walker Nicholls, his children and grandchildren, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum Frank J. Cracolici President St. Luke's-Roosevelt Louis B. Harrison, MD Director, CCCNY Michael Grossbard, MD Deputy Director, CCCNY

9 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS Capt. Paul Watson and his Sea Shepherd Conservation Society return for a second season of battling Japanese whaling ships. Mr. Watson has charged that this season's campaign resulted in the use of aggressive defenses by the whalers, including high-powered water cannon and long-range acoustical devices that can cause pain and even hearing damage. The crew's troubles continued when the society's vessel, the Steve Irwin, docked in Tasmania in March and was met by Australian police who confiscated hundreds of hours of videotape. The televised action begins as the Irwin heads south to Antarctica and hits a storm on the way. 7 A.M. KISSEL--Samuel, of Canton, CT, and formerly of Wilton, Redding and Avon, CT died June 2, 2009. Mr. Kissel was born in New York City on November 10, 1908. For forty plus years he spent summers on Nantucket Island where he developed his interest in photography. This interest led to his own photography exhibit and his illustrating the book Greater Light On Nantucket. A talented violinist, he was awarded scholarships to Juilliard School of Music then situated at 49 East 52nd Street. His musical education was under the instruction of Leopold Auer and Maia Bang. His musical career included playing nightly on the WOR program "Moonbeams" in the 1930s and playing with the NBC Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini. Later Mr. Kissel became concert master of the NBC Symphony of the Air which included a tour of the Far East in the 1950s. Mr. Kissel also taught advanced violinists for many years. Mr. Kissel was predeceased by his son Lawrence (Larry). He is survived by his loving wife, Margaret, son Robert Kissel, stepchildren, Richard Walton and Cathy Barnard, grandchildren: Scott and Terance Kissel, Kevin, Shannon and Maggie Barnard and many nieces and nephews. KERN--Alfred, novelist and Professor Emeritus English at Allegheny College, died in Wilmington, North Carolina, June 2, 2009. Author of novels Made in USA, The Width of Waters and The Trial of Martin Ross, Mr. Kern's essays have been widely published and cited, most notably Hang the Enola Gay. During his long career at Allegheny, Mr. Kern served as Chairman of the English Department, Dean of the College and held the Frederick F. Seeley Chair. During his year as Distinguished Visiting Professor at the United States Air Force Academy from 1979-1980, Professor Kern was inspired to write several acclaimed essays relating arts to the military, including Waiting for Euripides and Humanities at the Hanoi Hilton. Among the many people he touched are the hundreds of students and young writers he taught and mentored, many of whom remained devoted friends throughout his life. Born in Alliance, Ohio, in 1924, Mr. Kern served in the U.S. Army Air Corps in the Pacific Theatre during World War II, returning to Allegheny to finish his degree. It was there he met and married Carole Franklin, his wife of nearly 62 years. Mr. Kern also leaves three children and five grandchildren: Sheridan Kern (Nick Imirziades, children, Ouriana and Georgia Kern); Pamela Quinn (Robert, children, Sarah and Patrick Quinn); and Stephen Kern (son, Riku Kern). Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Allegheny College, 520 North Main St, Box 44, Meadville, PA 16335, or, Lower Cape Fear Hospice, 1414 Physicians Drive, Wilmington, NC 28401. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.andrewsmortuary.com

An obituary last Saturday about Franklin H. Littell, a father of academic studies of the Holocaust, misstated the given name of his second wife, who survives him. Buckley Jr. A court did decide that Mr. Buckley had been libeled when Dr. Littell described him in a book as a “fellow traveler” of fascism. A Spare Times report on Friday about art studios in Brooklyn that will be open to the public for tours this weekend, and other art-related events, misstated the event and the schedule today at the Lumenhouse exhibition space at 47 Beaver Street. A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about plans to house prints and negatives of the work of the photographer Gordon Parks and a collection of images by early American photographers at Purchase College misstated the terms of the arrangement and the name of the organization that owns the works. The Meserve-Kunhardt Foundation — not Collection — owns them and will retain ownership; while they will be kept at Purchase College, the college has not acquired them. The report also misstated the title of the Parks photograph that accompanied it, and the photograph carried an erroneous credit. The picture, which depicts a charwoman, is titled “American Gothic — Washington, D.C.” not “Charwoman.” It is from the Gordon Parks Foundation (a division of the Meserve-Kunhardt Foundation), not Purchase College.

KERN--Ralph W. of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully last Sunday at his home, in the arms of his devoted wife of 53 years, Leona. He was a faithful son to Morris and Anna Kern, caring brother to Morton Kern, loving father of Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, and the proud grandfather of Seth, Allison, Melanie and Adam. CAREY--Sr. Loretta (formerly Sr. Mary Thomas), Sisters of the Divine Compassion, died June 4, Good Counsel Convent, White Plains. Born in Brooklyn, daughter of Leo F. and Loretta O'Connor Carey, she attended St. Agnes Seminary, Good Counsel College, and St. John's, Georgetown, Boston, and SUNY in educational administration. Sr. Loretta served 11 years as principal of Preston High School, Bronx and later became Peace and Justice Coordinator, National Catholic Educational Association, conducting workshops throughout the US, Canada, the Philippines, and advising the U.S. Catholic Conference. Sister was Chair of the Board of the College of White Plains and member of the Board of Pace University for two decades and was awarded the Doctor of Humane Letters from Pace University and St. Thomas Aquinas College. From 1991 to 2007, Sister Loretta ministered to the elderly in St. Elizabeth's Parish, Washington Heights. Visitation: Good Counsel Convent, 52 North Broadway, White Plains, Sunday, June 7, 2:00 8pm, Mass of Christian Burial: Monday, June 8, 10am, Chapel of the Divine Compassion. Indian filmmakers and theater owners settled a two-month dispute about the sharing of ticket revenue Friday, paving the way for new Hindi movie releases beginning next week, industry officials said. Producers and distributors had held back new movies from multiscreen theater companies since April, demanding an equal share of revenue from ticket sales. The theater owners said a 50-50 revenue split was unacceptable, given that many Hindi-language films do poorly at the box office.

JONES--Robert Wagenseil, 76, of Westbrook, CT, died in Middlesex Hospital on May 15, 2009, after a brief illness. Robert was born on March 22, 1933, in Providence, RI. He was descended from Governor William Bradford of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, and preceded in death by his parents, Robert Bradford Jones and Hazel Wagenseil Jones, and by his beloved son, Adam Simmons Jones, in 1984. A graduate of Moses Brown School in Providence, Robert received his Bachelor of Architecture degree from Cornell University in 1956, where he was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity. He was elected to membership in Tau Beta Pi and Phi Kappa Phi, scientific and engineering honor societies, and was awarded the Alpha Rho Chi architecture medal and an AIA second grant. He was an associate of Charles Luckman Associates, and director of architecture for Donald Deskey Associates in New York. In 1965, he and Serge Petroff founded a partnership and, in 1970, merged with Shreve, Lamb, and Harmon Associates, builders of the Empire State Building. Their plan to add ten stories to the building in order to maintain its status as the tallest building in the world created much controversy. The firm won a Progressive Architecture award for its proposed addition to the United States Embassy in Paris. Robert was later director of architecture for Rockefeller Center. His own firm, Robert Wagenseil Jones and Associates subsequently won a Progressive Architecture award for its design for the Goebel Collectors Club. Robert continued his practice when he moved to Connecticut in 1980 to concentrate on residential and commercial development. A past member of the New York chapter of the AIA and the New York Society of Architects, Robert served for many years on the board of Moses Brown, and was deeply involved with its master plan and the design of new buildings. A passionate yachtsman all his life, with a particular love of wooden boats, Robert was a member of the Grand Banks Owners Association and a past member of the New York Yacht Club. The sight of another boat however distant anywhere on the Sound was Robert's signal to start racing in earnest, whether the other boat was aware of it or not. Robert is survived by his long-time companion, Elinor T. Fine of Connecticut and New York, his daughter, Sarah Winifred Wagenseil Jones, and three grandchildren Alyona Grace Jones, Pavel Henry Jones, and Anderson Pavel Jones, all of Mebane, North Carolina. Truly larger-than-life in every way, Robert was a uniquely talented and creative visionary with fearless opinions and an irreverent wit. He will be forever missed by those who loved and cherished him. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Mystic Seaport, 75 Greenmanville Avenue, Mystic, CT, 06355. A memorial ceremony will be held on July 19, 2009, at 2pm, at Brewer Pilots Point Marina, 63 Pilots Point Drive, Westbrook, CT.

LANDMAN--Harold David died on May 29, 2009 at the age of 65 after a four-year struggle against brain cancer. Born in Wales, UK, the second child of the late Simon and Dora Landman, he was the beloved brother of Felice and Alan and the loving uncle of Debra, Melissa and Benjamin. He graduated from Queens College with honors in English and edited its literary magazines, "Scrambled Eggs" and "Non Sequitur." All his life he loved words and wordplay and wrote his own brand of whimsical poetry. For the past twelve years he was employed as a library page at the Briarwood branch, where he enjoyed helping patrons find books and training younger pages. This inspired him to write his own manual for proper library procedure, which he worked on until aphasia set in. His death has torn a gaping hole in the fabric of our lives.

The Rangers are bucking a trend and have decided to raise ticket prices in a recession. The team said that the increase for the 2009-10 season would vary depending on the seating levels, but that it would fall in the range of 7 percent to 10 percent. A few examples: seats that were $52 are being raised to $56; $34 seats will jump to $37; and $200 seats are being raised to $210.

DOOLAN--Dwight Morris, of New York City and Bristol, Rhode Island passed away peacefully at his home in Rhode Island on Thursday, June 4th after a year long battle with lung cancer. He was 76 years old. He is survived by his wife Beverly Voss Doolan. Mr. Doolan was born April 29, 1933 in New Haven, Connecticut and is a graduate of The Wardlaw School of Plainfield, New Jersey and Brown University. He was a Captain in the United States Marine Corps having served from 1956 to 1960. He spent 36 years in the financial services industry starting as a stockbroker with G. H. Walker & Co. in Providence, RI and Hartford, CT and retiring as a Senior Vice-President with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York City in 1996. An avid skier and sailor, Mr. Doolan enjoyed spending time aboard the "Hotel Jerome," as well as a French canal boat and skiing with his family in Vail, Colorado. In addition to his loving wife of 31 years, he is survived by his daughter Talbott Doolan Grimm and her husband John of South Salem, NY, his son Todd H. Doolan and his wife Cynthia of South Freeport, ME and six grandchildren. A tribute to Mr. Doolan is being planned at a date to be determined. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Injured Marine Semper Fi Fund (semperfifund.org) 825 College Blvd, Suite 102, PMB 609 Oceanside, CA 92057 Or Brown University (brown.edu) PO Box 1877, Providence, RI 02912.

"The beat of my heart has grown deeper, more active, and yet more peaceful, and it is as if I were all the time storing up inner riches...My [life] is one long sequence of inner miracles." The young Dutchwoman Etty Hillesum wrote that in a Nazi transit camp in 1943, on her way to her death at Auschwitz two months later. Towards the end of his life, Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote, "All I have seen teaches me to trust the creator for all I have not seen," though by then he had already lost his father when he was 7, his first wife when she was 20 and his first son, aged 5. In Japan, the late 18th-century poet Issa is celebrated for his delighted, almost child-like celebrations of the natural world. Issa saw four children die in infancy, his wife die in childbirth, and his own body partially paralyzed.I'm not sure I knew the details of all these lives when I was 29, but I did begin to guess that happiness lies less in our circumstances than in what we make of them, in every sense. "There is nothing either good or bad," I had heard in high school, from Hamlet, "but thinking makes it so." I had been lucky enough at that point to stumble into the life I might have dreamed of as a boy: a great job writing on world affairs for Time magazine, an apartment (officially at least) on Park Avenue, enough time and money to take vacations in Burma, Morocco, El Salvador. But every time I went to one of those places, I noticed that the people I met there, mired in difficulty and often warfare, seemed to have more energy and even optimism than the friends I'd grown up with in privileged, peaceful Santa Barbara, Calif., many of whom were on their fourth marriages and seeing a therapist every day. Though I knew that poverty certainly didn't buy happiness, I wasn't convinced that money did either.

Neither rain nor pressure nor the startling, scary appearance on Court Chatrier of an idiot fan could keep Roger Federer from his appointed round with tennis history Sunday, as he dispatched the up-and-coming Swede Robin Soderling in three straight sets.On Saturday I alluded to the fact that, throughout the spring season, Federer worked on patterns that would be effective against Rafael Nadal. In many ways, this led to Federer's getting into trouble in some earlier rounds, especially against Jose Acasuso and Tommy Haas. He returned to some of his tried-and-true patterns Sunday, working his forehand crosscourt to perfection and opening the court to either play an inside-out forehand, or his preferred shot to the forehand corner, whipping the ball with blinding racket-head speed and wrongfooting his opponent. He did this countless times against Soderling, but he also employed a tactic he's honed to take on Nadal: the drop shot. The shot was first suggested by Jose Higueras before last year's French Open, but it took a while for the stubborn artist in Federer to buy into the tactic.With today's players playing so far back in the court to defend, the drop shot would be wide open, or so thought Higueras, one of the game's top coaches and a great clay-courter in his day. Notice where Fed dropped those shots: down the line on his backhand and crosscourt on his forehand. This, of course, would be on Nadal's backhand, forcing him to play a one-handed slice approach. An effective drop shot would also prevent Nadal from playing so deep on defense.

Seven sets of programs play in identically named towns or cities; five of those pairs share the name but play in different states, including Bowling Green and W.K.U. Can you name the other six? The first to do so wins the opportunity to write a 100-word guest prediction for his or her favorite university to be included in the Countdown's larger preview. The “Living In” article last Sunday, about Greenpoint, Brooklyn, overstated the effect of a 1950 explosion in polluting Newtown Creek, an estuary along the neighborhood’s boundary. The explosion contributed some of the polluting petroleum, not “much” of it. In addition, the process of contamination was described incorrectly. The oil seeped into the land, eventually contaminating the waterway; it did not “spill” into the waterway.

When Jo Katsaras was hired as the costume designer for “No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency” on HBO, one of the first things she noticed during a research trip to Botswana — where the series based on Alexander McCall Smith’s best-selling novels is set — was the importance clothing holds for Africans. “Poor or rich, they dress up,” said Ms. Katsaras, below, who also incorporated how freewheeling people of Botswana tend to be with patterns. “They’ll mix their stripes with florals and spots, and it looks amazing.” But Ms. Katsaras always keeps the series’s central character, the private investigator Precious Ramotswe (Jill Scott, above), the focus of attention with colorful dresses and head scarves made of shweshwe, the traditional South African fabric known for its pulsating motifs.

A picture caption on May 17 with an article about Angela Lansbury misidentified an actor shown with her in “Samson and Delilah” (1949), and a correction in this space last Sunday misstated the given name of the other actor in the photo. The actor shown with Ms. Lansbury is William Farnum, who portrayed Tubal — not Henry Wilcoxon, who played Ahtur in the film. And the third actor is Victor Mature, not Vincent.
An article last Sunday about Theater an der Wien in Vienna misspelled the name of a work commissioned for the 2009-10 season. It is “Die Besessenen,” not “Die Bessenenen.”.
A picture caption with the DVD column last Sunday misspelled the given name of the filmmaker for whom a newly released DVD set is named. He is Philippe Garrel, not Philppe.
A Film entry and a picture caption in the Week Ahead column on May 24 misspelled the given name of the actress who appeared in “Rashomon” with Toshiro Mifune. She is Machiko Kyo, not Michiko.

To the Editor: Any trip to Philadelphia (“36 Hours in Philadelphia,” May 10) should include a visit to the Institute for Contemporary Art on the University of Pennsylvania Campus (www.icaphila.org), where there is a terrific show of ceramic art on view, and the Fabric Workshop and Museum (www.fabricworkshop.org), where artists and artisans collaborate to create unusual and exquisite projects. Presently, a room-size white felt whale is in residence.

To the Editor: “Roman France” (May 17) brought back vivid memories of a similar quest in 2002 by my wife and me. However, we based ourselves at a charming auberge in Beaucaire, Les Doctrinaires, central to places like Nîmes, Arles, the Pont du Gard, Glanum and Orange. From there daily car trips were close and easy. And the dinners at the auberge were superb.

The Taking the Kids column on May 17, about exploring Israel with children, misstated the history of the Haganah. It was initially the main Jewish paramilitary organization in the final years of the British mandate in Palestine; it was not the country’s “pre-independence armed forces.” (The Haganah eventually became the core of Israel’s military.).

The 36 Hours column on May 24, about Prague, included an outdated address for the Futurista boutique. After the article went to press, the shop announced that it was moving. It is now at Betlemske Nanesti 51.

DOCUMENT READER E-mail messages between Justice Department officials from April and May 2005 about the legality of brutal interrogation techniques. nytimes.com/politics
Theater Ben Brantley
DAVID LETTERMAN Beautiful day here in New York City, am I right? So nice today that General Motors sold a convertible.

As Justice Department lawyers debated brutal interrogation techniques in April and May 2005, James B. Comey, the deputy attorney general, wrote a series of e-mail messages to Chuck Rosenberg, his chief of staff, about his views on the legal memorandums as they were being written and his conversations with other department officials. Here is an excerpt: ''Anyhow, that's where we are. It leaves me feeling sad for the Department and the A.G. [attorney general]. I don't know what more is to be done, given that I have already submitted my resignation. I just hope that when all of this comes out, this institution doesn't take the hit, but rather the hit is taken by those individuals who occupied positions at O.L.C. [the Office of Legal Counsel] and O.A.G. [the office of the attorney general] and were too weak to stand up for the principles that undergird the rest of this great institution.''

THE NEWS Bing, the new search service by Microsoft, made its debut last week as the company unleashed an advertising campaign estimated to cost $80 million to $100 million to establish the service as an alternative to Google. BEHIND THE NEWS Taking on Google, which holds about 64 percent of the search market in the United States, is a tall order. Even after spending billions on search services over the years, Microsoft has a scant 8 percent of the market, according to comScore, a research company. But Microsoft is hoping Bing will evoke the ''aha'' moment that punctuates a successful search and become part of the popular lexicon, as in, ''Why don't you Bing it?''
Pop Jon Pareles

Opponents of Chrysler's sale to Fiat have asked the Supreme Court to block the deal. Three Indiana state pension and construction funds filed emergency papers with the court early Sunday seeking to have the sale halted so they could pursue an appeal.

BERRY--Thomas (1914-2009), Passionist priest and internationally recognized historian of cultures, died on June 1st, 2009 at Well-Spring Retirement Community, Greensboro, North Carolina. His writings and lectures on the relation of humans with the cosmos and the earth have notably influenced the intellectual and spiritual history of the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Originally named after his father, William Nathan Berry, founder of Berico Fuels Company (1924), this second of eight sons in a family of thirteen children adopted the name Thomas (after philosopher-theologian Thomas Aquinas 1225-1274) following 1933 entry into the Passionist Religious Order. Thomas began doctoral studies in history at the Catholic University of America, writing on the historical theory of Italian philosopher- historian Gianbattista Vico 1668-1744, published by the Catholic University of America Press in 1951. Thomas's awards include seven honorary doctorates; the United States Catholic Mission Association Award (1989); the 1992 James Herriot Award of the Humane Society of the United States; Honorary Canonship of the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine (1992); the 1993 Bishop Carroll T. Dozier Medal for Peace and Justice; the Catholic University of America Alumni Award for Research and Scholarship (1993); the 1992 Prescott College Environmental Award; annual Thomas Berry Lecture Awards established, respectively, by the College of Mt. St. Vincent on the Hudson and, in Washington, DC, by the Center for Respect of Life and Environment and the Humane Society of the United States; a Thomas Berry Hall and Thomas Berry Seminars at Whidbey Institute on Whidbey Island near Seattle, WA. Funeral services will be held in Greensboro, NC and Jamaica, New York with internment at Green Monastery in Greensboro, Vermont. .

Devoted sister-in-law of Caroline Miller, Emily Somlyo, June Somlyo and Sarah Somlyo; mother-in-law of Anne Muecke Somlyo and Michael McGowan. MEADES--Gertrude Webb, the wife of the late Harry Meades, military hero who served as a Royal Air Force Officer and was decorated four times and held five Combat Medals. She was the granddaughter of former Mayor William J. Gaynor of New York City, NY. Gertrude passed away peacefully Saturday, May 9, 2009 at her home in Naples, Florida. She was raised in Manhasset, New York and known to her family and friends as "Punchie." Gertrude Webb Meades was born February 28, 1925 the fourth child of five children whose parents were William Seward Webb, Jr. and Gertrude Gaynor Webb. Her father was the founder of Webb and Knapp, real estate agent, and son of the late William Seward Webb, railroad builder and his mother was the late Mrs. Eliza Osgood Webb, a daughter of William H. Vanderbilt. Mrs. Meades mother was the late Gertrude Gaynor Webb, daughter of William J. Gaynor and Elizabeth Handwright. Her parents fortunes enabled the Webb's and Vanderbilt's to be among the earliest to enjoy summers in Shelburne, Vermont and go on to create the world renowned "Shelburne Museum". (The Shelburne Museum was founded by Electra Havemayer Webb and her husband J. Watson Webb whose parents were Dr. William Seward Webb and Lila Vanderbilt Webb. Their 19th century lakeside estate would become Shelburne Farms.) Gertrude (Punchie) Webb Meades, longtime character of life, regaled in living life to the fullest with long freighter trips to exotic ports of call, the love of animal husbandry, she had a passion for reading and enjoyed the solitude of needlepoint. She spent many productive years as a volunteer with the Naples Community Hospital Blood Bank. There was no one else like this woman, lovingly known as Punchie. She will be remembered for her love of family, her dear friends, her zest for life, and her elegantly gentle kind outlook on life, graceful manners, wit and warmth. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by Emma II, her "Pug", her two sons, Michael Harry Meades of Apopka, Florida and Jamie Seward Meades of Sarasota, Florida, three granddaughters, Heather Portanova, Meredith Magennis and Mindy Meades and great-grandchildren, Caitlin Magennis, Caleb Portanova and Kayli Portanova. In addition, she is survived by her sister Frederica Webb Gamble of Westwood, MA, her nieces, Frederique Gamble, Susan Webb Porter and nephew W. Seward Webb. Memorial service was conducted Saturday, May 16, 2009 at the St. John's Episcopal Church, Naples, Florida. In lieu of flowers, family and friends may make contributions in Punchie's name to Vitas Innovative Hospice Care: Naples, Florida, Animal Refuge Center of Fort Myers: North Fort Myers, Florida or the Naples Community Hospital Blood Center: Naples, Florida.

FOR a magazine whose gestation period rivaled that of several elephants, Tiwimuta (This Is What It Made Us Think About) feels strangely of the moment. Odder still, given that its founder, the fashion designer and creative director Andre Walker, created the 212-page ''open playground for experimentation'' as a pie in the face to a publishing industry that, he says, too often reacts to time-sensitive market forces like movie releases and the fashion calendar. ''The only real direction I gave anyone was to do whatever they wanted,'' says Mr. Walker, who no longer designs under his own name but collaborates with his friends Marc Jacobs and Kim Jones.

It used to be that people would question whether a player could handle the big stage in cities like New York and Boston. Now, though, there appears to be plenty of pressure off Broadway as well. This season, Dontrelle Willis of Detroit and Khalil Greene of St. Louis have been on the disabled list with social anxiety disorder. Cincinnati's Joey Votto went on the D.L. last week for a ''stress-related issue.'' And of course, Zack Greinke of Kansas City, currently having a breakthrough season, battled social anxiety disorder and depression early in his career.

The ''Law & Order'' franchise needed some freshening: episodes were becoming musty with the whiff of repetition, and in the case of ''Law & Order: Criminal Intent,'' on the USA Network, thick with the fog of Vincent D'Onofrio's earnestly affected performances. This spring producers added Jeff Goldblum to the cast as Detective Zach Nichols, a child of psychologists and a cop who is considerably less inclined than Mr. D'Onofrio's Detective Robert Goren to put his brilliance up for show and tell. Or perhaps that's just what Mr. Goldblum's ostensibly effortless approach tricks us into believing. It now seems impossible to watch the show and not mourn every scene from which he is absent.

The N.B.A. All-Star Game will return to Los Angeles in 2011, the second time in seven years that the city will host the game. It will be played at Staples Center, the home arena of the Lakers and the Clippers. Los Angeles was the host in 2004. The 2010 All-Star Game will be held in Dallas. The N.B.A. has scheduled a news conference for Sunday afternoon, before Game 2 of the finals between the Lakers and the Orlando Magic. The league did not disclose the reason for the news conference, but a person briefed on the matter confirmed it was about the All-Star Game.

MORRISON--Jane Hayes, 88, of Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Locust Valley, NY and Wayzata, MN, died on June 4, 2009 of ovarian cancer, after, in her words, "a wonderful and most fortunate life". She leaves her beloved husband of 21 years, John Washburn Morrison, as well as three mutually devoted daughters, Carole Williams (Richard), Marilyn Hayes and Sharon Morgan, her grandchildren: Hayes Batten, Jen Hatfield (David) and Cyia Batten, and four great-grandchildren: Quinn Batten, Jane, Mac and Kate Hatfield. She was also devoted to John's children, Helen Morrison and Jack Morrison (Chris) and his grandchildren, Kelly (John Willoughby) and Jeb (Kitsy). She also leaves her brother, James McMillen, Jr. and his children, Bryan (Caroline) and Shelley. Her first husband, William C. Hayes, died in 1985. She was the daughter of Alberta Weber McMillen and James H. McMillen, growing up in Great Neck, Long Island. She graduated from Buckley Country Day School, Westover School, and Katherine Gibbs. She became a respected business leader in Locust Valley, Long Island, owning Jane Hayes Real Estate. She lived her life with grace and will be greatly missed by her loving family and vast collection of friends and admirers. Donations may be made to Westover School, PO Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762 or VNA & Hospice, 1110 35th Ln., Vero Beach, FL 32960. A memorial service will be held Saturday, June 13 at 11am at Oak Harbor, Vero Beach, FL.

WHEN it comes to accessories, this summer's best and brightest are poised to make a splash -- literally. Toywatch recently introduced a line of jelly watches ($175 each) with interchangeable faces and straps in a variety of colors, which pair nicely, by the way, with the stylist Lisa Fernandez's new neoprene swim line. To get your feet wet, there is a wide range of cheerful and relatively cheap designer jelly sandals from the likes of Chloé and Givenchy. Meanwhile, Chanel's new quilted tote bag has a layer of pool-friendly PVC. Just add water. KARLA M. MARTINEZ

ECKSTEIN--Adele L. (nee Birnbaum). We mourn the sudden, untimely passing of our beloved Adele. Devoted wife of 52 years to Rabbi Abraham B. Eckstein. Loving mother of Sharon and Miriam and their husbands, Larry and Ron. Beloved sister of Mamie and her husband Paul Haberfield. Devoted grandmother to Daniel, Yair, Claire, Sarah, Talia. We will miss a kind, loving, caring true lady. A lover of books and former director of the West Hempstead Public Library. Her grace and kindness touched each and every person she met. Contributions to Meir Panim.

MONDSCHEIN--Murray, would have celebrated his 90th birthday on May 30, 2009. He passed away on May 9th and was one of the last World War II veterans who served with distinction in the European Theatre in General Patton's 3rd Army in the 13th Armored Division. He was decorated for his meritorious service with a Bronze Star. He was a man of many talents; a golfer, a teacher, a musician, a pianist known in NY hotels and clubs for his special style of jazz, grace and sense of humor. He was an accountant for the city of New York and graduated from NY University. But most of all he was a loving and dedicated father to his two daughters, Paula and Joan Mondschein whose love will follow him throughout eternity. He will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery on June 11, 2009 at 3pm with full military honors.

EPIDEMIOLOGISTS didn't expect a swine flu outbreak, but did fashion designers see it coming? Judging from all the masks, veils, balaclavas and assorted headgear that came down the runway recently, it's hard not to wonder. The World Health Organization gives fairly loose mask guidelines (you can even fashion one yourself out of ''readily available materials''), but we still wouldn't chance it with a Comme des Garçons shroud or even a Margiela face stocking (above). JONATHAN S. PAUL

FEUERSTEIN--Michael J.,of New York City passed away May 29, 2009 at Hospice of Western Reserve in Cleveland, Ohio. Preceded in death by parents Charles and Bella. Michael was an Administrative Law Judge for 22 years, He worked at New York State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance. He is survived by his fiancee, Bernice Reed, cousins, god-children and many friends. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Western Reserve, 300 E. 185th Street, Cleveland, Ohio 44119.

For its Belmont Stakes coverage on Saturday, ABC Sports (or is it ABC, the ESPN platform?) borrowed heavily from its ESPN ownership. It might seem synergistic for ABC to replay taped features that ran earlier on ESPN's hours of pre-Belmont coverage. It might seem like a reasonable redeployment of resources to show the ABC audience what it might not have seen on ESPN. But it was lazy. A friend alerted me that he had seen all these elements, which made up the guts of ABC's nonlive coverage: features on the influence of horse-racing lexicon; on long shots; on Calvin Borel, Mine That Bird's jockey; and Kenny Mayne's wearisome attempt at wringing humor out of singing and playing 20 questions in a pickup truck with Mine That Bird's trainer, Chip Woolley, who sounded as if he had barely memorized a poorly written script.

BALL--Sally A.,age 88, died peacefully at home June 5, 2009. She was predeceased by her husband Dr. Eugene R. Ball and is survived by her children Martha Ball Heppenheimer and Perry A. Ball, her grandchildren Geoffrey and Elizabeth Heppenheimer, and Katie and Torie Ball. In lieu of flowers, contibutions may be made to The N.Y. Junior League Community Trust Fund 130 E. 80 St., New York, NY 10075. Funeral services are pending.

PLESSER--James J. (JJ), died Tuesday, June 2, at age 91. He was one of a kind, a self made, self educated man who was an inspiration to all who knew him. He founded Hamos and Company, which took him all over the world. He had a talent for making close friends of his clients, over the years, his family became accustomed to these far flung friends-Iceland, India, Japan, etc. We never knew what to expect. He was a great cutter, clipper and sender of articles from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, the Jerusalem Post, etc., which he hoped would implement action, plant seeds and inform his grandchildren of directions they might take. He was never heavy handed; sometimes it worked. He was invited to join the "Young Presidents Organization" and soon became its president. He brought vitality and innovation to that organization. He was passionate about everything Jewish. He became a benefactor of the National Committee on Furtherance of Jewish Education and Chairman of the Chassidic Art Institute. He sponsored chantorial recitals and supported the making of chantorial long playing records. Israel was his pride. He leaves behind a loving family. No one will ever fill the void he left. He will always be in all our hearts. A special program is being established in his name at the Chassidic Art Institute.

In celebration of the quadricentennial of the Hudson River (www.hudson400.com) and the opening of the first section of the much-anticipated High Line park (www.thehighline.org) on the West Side of Manhattan, Classic Harbor Line Cruises (www.sail-nyc.com) is introducing a combination cruise and walking tour called ''High Line and Skyline.'' Starting June 19, the three-hour, Friday afternoon tour will begin with a cruise along the Hudson, during which participants can take in the West Side skyline, which includes Richard Meier's Perry Street towers and Frank Geary's IAC Building. The second half of the tour will be led by the local historian Matt Postal, who will guide participants on a 90-minute walk through Chelsea, including the High Line. Mr. Postal will focus on the history of West Chelsea from about 1820 to the 1930s, when the former elevated railway line -- now the park -- was built.

CONTI--Santo "Sandy" Joseph, Linguist, D-Day Veteran, Painter, Photographer, and New York City high school teacher died on January 29, 2008 in New York City. He was 89. His death was announced on his WWII unit's memorial website: ixengineercommand.com. Sandy Conti was born on December 17, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY. From an early age, Sandy's classmates and teachers recognized his talent for learning foreign languages. Despite the Great Depression, he graduated from New York University with a degree in French Literature. Sandy served with the U.S. Army Air Corps, 834th Engineer Aviation Battalion, Company C from April 1942 to October 1945. On the morning of D-Day +1, Sandy and his unit landed in Normandy on Omaha Beach. Before D-Day, the Office of Strategic Services tried to recruit Sandy, but the officers of the 834th--knowing that his linguistic skills would be needed after the invasion-- would not relinquish him. During his service as a translator, he regularly worked with members of the French Resistance. As a reward for his services, the U.S. Army assigned him to the University of Grenoble for additional language training. Among his fondest memories of the war were talking with Ernest Hemingway at Mont Saint Michel, and flying in an airplane for the first time over the French countryside. After the war, Sandy resumed his education at Columbia University and received a Masters in French Literature; Dwight Eisenhower signed his diploma. He was an instructor and a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Pennsylvania. Because of his close friendship with William Dean Fausett, the painter, Sandy split his time between New York City and Dorset, Vermont. During his time in Dorset, Sandy worked as a set designer and photographer for numerous opera productions. After spending 17 years teaching Foreign Languages for the New York City Board of Education, Sandy spent his retirement learning about emerging digital technologies, trading investments online, attending productions at the Metropolitan Opera, and contributing information to World War II historians and journals.
