Over the past decade, the publishing industry has undergone wave after wave of consolidation. But within the giant media conglomerates there is still a fair amount of biodiversity -- at least judging from the logos that bird- and beast-watchers can spot on the spines of their books.

FATAL ATTRACTIONGlenn Close returns to her bunny-boiling ways in a Blu-ray reissue of Adrian Lyne's 1987 much-talked about adultery drama. With Michael Douglas and Anne Archer. '' 'Fatal Attraction,' without Mr. Lyne, would have been a violence-edged soap opera and nothing more,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times in 1987. (Paramount, $29.99, R) FIRED UP! Nicholas D'Agosto and Eric Christian Olsen as high school boys with a cunning plan to meet cute girls: they'll join a summer cheerleading camp. Will Gluck directed. ''At once funnier than it should be and more witless than it should have been, 'Fired Up!' is the latest addition to the wave of cheerleader movies that first hit way back in 2000 with 'Bring It On,' '' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times in February. (Sony, Blu-ray $39.95, standard definition $28.96, not rated)

WOLFSON--Saul. Survived by wife Martha; sons Howard and Robert (Marcy); granddaughters Sarah, Hannah, Rachel and Stacy. Funeral Services at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road in Rockville Centre on Friday at 9:30am. With love in our hearts you will be missed.

FOR NINO CONIGLIO, pizza is performance. He tosses circles of dough like a Harlem Globetrotter juggles basketballs. He can spin two at once, juggle them, sling them around his back and behind his head and flip them between his legs while leaping. He can roll them sideways across his arm span, or lie on his back and keep them orbiting above and around him like a cowboy's lariat. ''When I was a kid, it seemed like any pizza place in Brooklyn, there'd always be an Italian guy who would throw the pizza for me,'' said Mr. Coniglio, 24. ''One guy would spin it on his finger, the other guy would toss it around a little bit.''

JONES--Robert Wagenseil, 76, of Westbrook, CT, died in Middlesex Hospital on May 15, 2009, after a brief illness. Robert was born on March 22, 1933, in Providence, RI. He was descended from Governor William Bradford of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, and preceded in death by his parents, Robert Bradford Jones and Hazel Wagenseil Jones, and by his beloved son, Adam Simmons Jones, in 1984. A graduate of Moses Brown School in Providence, Robert received his Bachelor of Architecture degree from Cornell University in 1956, where he was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity. He was elected to membership in Tau Beta Pi and Phi Kappa Phi, scientific and engineering honor societies, and was awarded the Alpha Rho Chi architecture medal and an AIA second grant. He was an associate of Charles Luckman Associates, and director of architecture for Donald Deskey Associates in New York. In 1965, he and Serge Petroff founded a partnership and, in 1970, merged with Shreve, Lamb, and Harmon Associates, builders of the Empire State Building. Their plan to add ten stories to the building in order to maintain its status as the tallest building in the world created much controversy. The firm won a Progressive Architecture award for its proposed addition to the United States Embassy in Paris. Robert was later director of architecture for Rockefeller Center. His own firm, Robert Wagenseil Jones and Associates subsequently won a Progressive Architecture award for its design for the Goebel Collectors Club. Robert continued his practice when he moved to Connecticut in 1980 to concentrate on residential and commercial development. A past member of the New York chapter of the AIA and the New York Society of Architects, Robert served for many years on the board of Moses Brown, and was deeply involved with its master plan and the design of new buildings. A passionate yachtsman all his life, with a particular love of wooden boats, Robert was a member of the Grand Banks Owners Association and a past member of the New York Yacht Club. The sight of another boat however distant anywhere on the Sound was Robert's signal to start racing in earnest, whether the other boat was aware of it or not. Robert is survived by his long-time companion, Elinor T. Fine of Connecticut and New York, his daughter, Sarah Winifred Wagenseil Jones, and three grandchildren Alyona Grace Jones, Pavel Henry Jones, and Anderson Pavel Jones, all of Mebane, North Carolina. Truly larger-than-life in every way, Robert was a uniquely talented and creative visionary with fearless opinions and an irreverent wit. He will be forever missed by those who loved and cherished him. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Mystic Seaport, 75 Greenmanville Avenue, Mystic, CT, 06355. A memorial ceremony will be held on July 19, 2009, at 2pm, at Brewer Pilots Point Marina, 63 Pilots Point Drive, Westbrook, CT.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

LYNN--Judith (nee Judith Roslyn Edelman), 68, died peacefully May 28, 2009, after a brief illness. She was the adored and beloved wife of Norman, devoted and loving mother of daughters Amy and Elizabeth, fond mother-in-law of Dennis Heon and David Block, active grandmother of Gregory, Jennifer and Emma, and caring sister-in-law of Helen and Richard Lynn. She will be deeply missed by family and friends and always remembered for her wisdom, humor, and generosity of time and spirit. Donations in her memory may be made to Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York.

SULAM--Sondra "Sandi" (nee Cohen), 70 years young, passed away at her home in the Somerset section of Franklin, NJ on Tuesday, June 2, 2009. She was born in Brooklyn, NY and has lived in Somerset for many years. Sandi was an administrator for the Middlesex County College Foundation. She was a very special person with an "electric" personality, who experienced many exciting challenges in life and lived every day with "gusto". Sandi enjoyed multiple interests, including golf, tennis and music and we will all miss her bubbly personality and sharp sense of humor. She was the beloved wife of 49 years to Donald Sulam, proud mother of Marc and Glen, mother-in-law of Debra and cherished grandmother of Luke, Jack and William. Services are under the direction of the Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, 239 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ. Contributions, in her honor, can be made to The Jewish Communal Fund for The Edna Center, 575 Madison Avenue, Suite #

Upstaging Denis Leary on ''Rescue Me'' is like outpacing Jeff Gordon on a Nascar track: It is a challenge with a limited shot at victory. And yet Michael J. Fox's multi-episode arc on this FX series about a New York City firehouse colonized the show's antic, anarchic spirit, showcasing his maturity as an actor and his ample abilities in the face of Parkinson's disease. As the paraplegic lover of the estranged wife of Tommy Gavin (Mr. Leary), Mr. Fox was all mind games and unchecked id, a deranged, bizarrely appealing emotional terror monger who makes Tommy seem almost grateful for his messed up keg party of a life.

KERN--Ralph W. of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully last Sunday at his home, in the arms of his devoted wife of 53 years, Leona. He was a faithful son to Morris and Anna Kern, caring brother to Morton Kern, loving father of Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, and the proud grandfather of Seth, Allison, Melanie and Adam. Born in The Bronx in 1934, son of a furniture manufacturer, he worked full time to put himself through NYU. Early in his career, he established himself as a builder, entrepreneur, and visionary New York City developer. He was also adventurous, traveling and sailing extensively throughout the world. His passions were his family, opera, ballet, tennis, and sailing. We all looked to him for courage, direction, and understanding. Donations may be made in his name to Trustees of Columbia University, Division of Cardiology, Att: Dr. Allan Schwartz or Julie Fisher, 622 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

As a plaintiff's lawyer with a populist vengeance, Glenn Close's Patty Hewes seemed built purely of the most insidious instincts in the first season of ''Damages,'' the FX legal thriller in which corporations exist only as manufacturers of their own malevolence. But as Patty's reliable systems -- bribery, entrapment and other forms of coercion -- began to fail her during Season 2, Ms. Close shepherded her character's vulnerabilities to the surface, giving Patty an aching self-reckoning that leaves her the finest actress on television and makes us forget almost all other roles she has ever played.

HAIM--Sara. Matriarch of our family. Remarkable woman full of wisdom, love and compassion. Fearless and courageous she saved the entire family along with her late husband, Savas Haim from the Holocaust. We will miss our adoring mother, our tower of strength, our hero. Sara is survived by her five children Allegra Despotidis, Susie Stone, Anna Haim Burak, Elias Haim and she is predeceased by her son Dr. Philip Pinhas Haim. She is lovingly survived by her 10 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Services are private.

Families looking for summer vacation deals might be interested in the new Kids Free Package, offered by Universal Orlando Resort in Florida, for certain trips booked by July 31 for travel through Oct. 8. The package includes four nights of lodging at a property near the resort, like Doubletree Hotel or Hyatt Place, free transportation to the theme parks and free unlimited admission for ages 3 to 9 to all theme parks, starting at about $34 per person per night, or $533 for a family of four.
I tell her, 'All your life you were afraid to talk.' I don't want to live that way. SERGEI KANEV, an investigative reporter in Russia, on his mother's warning that his job is too dangerous. [10]

WUNSCH--Elsie, nee Rubin, 97, of Glen Cove, NY died peacefully at Glen Cove Hospital on June 5, 2009. Elsie was born on August 23, 1911 in Manhattan and is an aluma of Columbia University. She married her beloved Samuel, a mechanical engineer, in 1934. The couple built a home (which they named Elsam) overlooking Long Island Sound on East Island in Glen Cove, moving in on V-J Day in 1945, and spent their lives there. Elsie's and Sam's passion for travel took them to more than 125 countries, an interest that Elsie continued to pursue after Sam's death in 1980. During her travels, Elsie amassed a collection of 350 dolls, favoring examples of local craftsmanship over what she called "tourist dolls." The couple contributed actively to their community as volunteers, lovers of the arts and philanthropists. A long history of support of Glen Cove Hospital most recently included funding for the Wunsch Center for Rehabilitative Therapies, an 8,200-square-foot inpatient rehabilitation and spa center. Elsie volunteered with the Glen Cove Hospital Auxiliary for more than 30 years, following Sam's treatment there in the 1970s. Even as she entered her 90s, Elsie's pink-smocked presence continued to lend assistance and comfort to countless patients and visitors. She was recognized as an exemplar of citizen volunteerism in a 2006 profile by The Daily News. Elsie was also active in teaching English as a Second Language in the Glen Cove School District, and contributed to the Glen Cove Council of the Arts, the Glen Cove Community Scholarship Fund, the Girl Scouts and local animal welfare causes. She attended, with enthusiasm, the Metropolitan Opera and the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on Long Island. Elsie is survived by members of the Wunsch and Durando families. A tiny woman who possessed an encyclopaedic memory and told a good joke, she will be lovingly remembered and missed by all whose lives she touched. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 20, from noon-2:30 pm. Beginning on Monday, June 8, please call 212-889-8790 for information. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Glen Cove Community Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 453, Glen Cove, NY 11542.

Film PEEKSKILL Paramount Center for the Arts ''Tulpan,'' directed by Sergei Dvortsevoy Kazakh. Through Wednesday. ''Sugar,'' directed by Anna Boden. Friday through June 18. Both are $7 to $9. Paramount Center for the Arts, 1008 Brown Street. (914) 739-2333 paramountcenter.org.

THE French photographer Guy Bourdin is among that lot of macabre but gloriously talented artists (think Stanley Kubrick) whose work equally disturbs and intrigues. An influential contributor to French Vogue, Bourdin was known to be whiney and imperious and fraught with abandonment issues. His demons, in fact, were always right there in the photographs: typically a mix of misogyny and eroticism, the leggy, mostly nude models often have their heads cropped off. Yet, despite their twisted subject matter, his images inspired a legion of contemporary photographers, including Mert and Marcus, Nick Knight and David LaChapelle. ''Unseen Guy Bourdin'' opened recently at the Wapping Project in London, with 32 new photographs that, according to Bourdin's wishes, were supposed to be destroyed. His heirs thought better of it. Through July 4 at the Wapping Project, London. MARINA CASHDAN

ROSTEN--Martha, on June 1 survived by her brother Bernard Rosten and sister-in-law Linda Rosten, niece Genna Margolis (Kenneth), Dr. Sloan Rosten (Melissa), grandnieces Jessica, Samantha, Amanda and Julia.

BECAUSE of the Chrysler and General Motors bankruptcies, people looking for car bargains might find a few treasures. But they have to be prepared to act quickly and forgo considerations such as resale value and vehicle reliability, and also ignore the uncertainties around warranty repairs and the availability of spare parts. Feeling lucky?

Search crews scouring the Atlantic Ocean found the bodies of two men from an Air France jet that disappeared with 228 people on board, the Brazilian Air Force said Saturday, just hours after French investigators announced that the plane had been scheduled to have a part of its air-speed sensor system replaced. The plane's manufacturer, Airbus, had advised operators of some of its A330 aircraft to replace the part, the head of French air investigations said Saturday. It was unclear, however, if the part played any role in the disaster, and Airbus said it issued its advisory two years ago because a better part was available, not because the existing one was ''a safety issue.''

''House,'' the popular ''I am God'' medical series on Fox, concluded its fifth season a few weeks ago with its star, Hugh Laurie, still showing no traces of his patrician British lineage. And yet the unwavering A-game that he brings to his adenoidal American inflections every week, still supplies only the most meager reason to keep praising this former sketch comic. Portraying mental breakdowns rarely inspire economy in actors, but Mr. Laurie made real a whole universe of misery and disconnection in a simple series of dreamy, delusional expressions and gestures during House's drug-aggravated unraveling, proving that he is far more than a gifted satirist. Mr. Laurie isn't God -- his character's fierce atheism precludes any such deification -- but every Monday night he makes it unfathomable to imagine that he is anyone other than the broken, defended rationalist he so ingeniously plays.

LANDMAN--Harold David died on May 29, 2009 at the age of 65 after a four-year struggle against brain cancer. Born in Wales, UK, the second child of the late Simon and Dora Landman, he was the beloved brother of Felice and Alan and the loving uncle of Debra, Melissa and Benjamin. He graduated from Queens College with honors in English and edited its literary magazines, "Scrambled Eggs" and "Non Sequitur." All his life he loved words and wordplay and wrote his own brand of whimsical poetry. For the past twelve years he was employed as a library page at the Briarwood branch, where he enjoyed helping patrons find books and training younger pages. This inspired him to write his own manual for proper library procedure, which he worked on until aphasia set in. His death has torn a gaping hole in the fabric of our lives.

CARRINGTON--James H. On June 1, 2009 CDR James H. "Jim" Carrington, 84, passed away peacefully at home in Atlantic Beach, FL surrounded by his beloved family. He was an accomplished athlete, educator and a successful businessman. Commander Carrington, a graduate of Phillips Academy, Andover and the U.S. Naval Academy class of 1948, was a six-time, three-sport All-American in football, swimming, and lacrosse, earning thirteen varsity letters at Fordham, Cornell, and Navy. He was a recipient of the Naval Academy Athletic Association Sword for Athletic Excellence and was inducted into the Naval Academy's Athletic Hall of Fame. During his 19 years of commissioned service, he served on the carrier USS Leyte CV-32, the USS Plymouth Rock LSD-29 and the USS Hanson DDR-832 which saw action in the Korean War. After his Navy career he earned a Ph.D. in Business Administration at The American University and joined its faculty as an Associate Professor. Two years later he became Director of Budget and Management at Georgetown University. His final academic assignment was at George Washington University where he taught small business administration, and wrote the business management text: Command, Control, and Compromise. For fifteen years, CDR Carrington was a nationally-ranked squash player, winning both the national hardball and softball championships and a World Masters doubles title. His passion for sports led him to coach teams from the grammar school to the NCAA level. Jim Carrington was a devoted husband, father and friend, as well as a learned counselor and a tenacious competitor. Above all, he was a good and just man who will remain a source of inspiration to his family and friends. Jim is survived by his loving wife, Kathleen Connell Carrington of Sea Girt, NJ, his five children: James H. H. Carrington, Jr. of Rome, Italy, Wendy Carrington of Southbury, CT, Timothy Carrington of Marietta, GA, Nancy Crown of Winnetka, IL, Kathleen Anderson of Greer, SC and ten grandchildren. He will be sorely missed. The Memorial Mass was held at St. John's Catholic Church in Atlantic Beach, FL on Saturday, June 6, 2009 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Southbury Training School, c/o Director's Office, P.O. Box 872, Southbury, CT 06488-0901, would be gratefully appreciated. Please visit our online Tribute at www.quinn-shalz.com. Services under the care and direction of Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL.

Rafael Nadal could miss Wimbledon because of a knee injury, the Spanish sports newspaper Marca reported on Saturday. Toni Nadal, the reigning Wimbledon champion's uncle and coach, said the 23-year-old Nadal had a damaged right knee and was doubtful for Wimbledon, which starts June 22, the paper said.

THE OOH LA LA KIDZ SPA has a décor described by its owner, Elizabeth Santiago, as ''Beverly Hills meets Whitestone.'' It's a cutesy-pink Magic Kingdom decadence she developed with the help of her daughter, D'Angelique, 9, who also helps out at this pedicure palace, on Clintonville Street near 14th Avenue. Defying the recession, Ms. Santiago took a let-them-eat-chocolate-covered-strawberries approach: the snack and a stiff Shirley Temple come with the spa's deluxe packages (for example, $185 for a day of mother-daughter services like a ''sleeping beauty massage'' and ''fruitylishious facial''). A basic mini-manicure costs $12. For boys, a King of the Castle manicure and massage package is $20. COREY KILGANNON

DESIGNER collaborations are nothing new, but combining two labels in one seems to have become a definite trend in men's shoes. Raf Simons has updated classic Dr. Martens, while Junya Watanabe has put his own spin on Trickers kicks. Now, Duckie Brown has revisited Florsheim's archives to make the all-American brand relevant for a new generation. The new styles (from $395) include boots, color-coded wingtips and even a studded shoe. But our favorites are the more traditional brogues in unexpected colors (above). ARMAND LIMNANDER
KROOG--Lawrence E.,on June 4th. Devoted and loved husband of Doris, beloved father of Glenn and Hope, adoring grandfather of Ariana and Genevieve.

ON June 9, 1909, Alice Huyler Ramsey left New York City in a Maxwell Model DA, bound for the West Coast. Two months and 3,800 rugged miles later, she and her three passengers arrived in San Francisco, making Ramsey the first woman to drive an automobile cross-country. Ramsey's pioneering journey will be honored Tuesday in Manhattan, 100 years to the day after her trip began, when Emily Anderson of Seattle sets off for California in a rebuilt 1909 Maxwell.

WAITZMAN--Hilda (Liener), 86, of West Hartford, CT died June 5, 2009. Widow of Samuel Waitzman. Hilda taught English at Morristown High School, Morristown, NJ. She leaves her children, David M. Waitzman (Marcia) of West Hartford, CT, Norman J. Waitzman of Salt Lake City, UT, Mimi S. Waitzman (Don MacKinnon) of London, England, and Debby R. Waitzman of Hoboken, NJ; her grandchildren, Joshua, Rachel, Sarah, Emma, and Samuel; and her sisters, Jane Stein of Highland Park, NJ, Doris Kukin (Ira) of Orange, NJ, and Carol Deutsch (Sid) of Pittsburgh, PA; and her sister-in-law, Natalie Liener of New York. Funeral Monday, June 8, 2009 at 9 am in the Chapel of the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT. Interment in Beth Israel Cemetery, Cedar Knolls, NJ.

Making the (Fewer) Plays On Tuesday, the Yankees made an error for the first time since May 13, snapping their major league-record streak of 18 errorless games. The Boston Red Sox set the previous record of 17 in 2006.

FRIEDMAN--Theodore R.,94, died peacefully, June 3, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Selma. Devoted father of daughter Patricia, and son Andrew Edward. Adoring grandfather of Roberta (Dudley). Cherished brother of the late Sallie, late Florence, late Shirley and late Irving (survived by Helen). Born in New York, he was a motivated student. He graduated Brooklyn College in three years to attend New York University Law School. He graduated from NYU Law School with honors in the Theta Sigma Lambda Fraternity. He was a member of the "Greatest Generation", as he proudly served in the United States Army during World War II and completed his Judge Advocate General's exam in France at the end of the War. After the War, he became president of his own real estate company. In recent years, he took an active role on the Board of the Five Towns Senior Center. He was a long time member of Temple Israel of Lawrence, as well as the Fresh Meadow Country Club. He was a courageous man who showed determination and passion for life. His trademark jokes and sense of humor, outstanding smile, perseverance, unbridled optimism, generosity and warmth of spirit will always be forever in our hearts. He chose to live life to the fullest and personified the power of positive thinking.

ARNOLD HATTERS, a family business near Times Square that had dressed heads since 1926, has boxed up the last of its fedoras, homburgs, straw boaters and porkpies. It was a father and son and son shop, run by Arnold Rubin and his boys, Mark and Peter. Their motto: ''Much is said by what you wear on your head.'' In 2003, the Rubins had to move from their longtime spot opposite the Port Authority Bus Terminal after the city seized the block to allow construction of The New York Times headquarters. Their new shop was a few blocks down Eighth Avenue near 37th Street. On the company Web site, the owners cited ''the worsening condition of the economy,'' for the closing. CARA BUCKLEY

NICHOLLS--Paul. The physicians and staff of the Continuum Cancer Centers of New York (CCCNY) join with the entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and generous benefactor, Paul Nicholls, an inspiration to all who were touched by his extraordinary spirit. Paul did not see cancer as an obstacle, but rather as an opportunity to help others. Despite dealing with life-threatening Stage 3 myeloma, he first began raising money to fight this dreaded disease in 2003 when he first ran the New York City Marathon. This effort led to the establishment of Team Continuum, through which others joined with him to support a wide variety of important programs at the CCCNY sites. He will forever be remembered by all whose lives were touched by his efforts. To his beloved wife Diana Walker Nicholls, his children and grandchildren, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum Frank J. Cracolici President St. Luke's-Roosevelt Louis B. Harrison, MD Director, CCCNY Michael Grossbard, MD Deputy Director, CCCNY

ZOOM Imagine these two explanatory models. One model tells you: Hitler, Göring -- pick any highly placed Nazi -- liked these paintings because they saw themselves in them. The other model tells you that they wanted to enhance their stature by owning a work of one of the greatest Dutch masters, by owning a Vermeer. Of course, it could be both. When Göring says, ''I want that,'' what exactly is it that he wants? Does he want ''Christ and the Adulteress,'' the Vermeer? Or ''Christ and the Adulteress,'' the Nazi Vermeer? The Vermeer that is designed to appeal to him. If Jonathan Lopez's theory is right, then the van Meegeren Vermeers are possibly more attractive to Göring than a real Vermeer because he sees himself in them. Christ pardoning the adulteress. A German volks-romance. The dark-skinned, sinister-looking Jews hovering in the background.

Hope Davis's performance in HBO's psychotherapy drama ''In Treatment'' superbly conveyed the pain of middle-aged solitude for those who have not been blessed with a ''Sex and the City'' ending. As Mia, a single 43-year-old corporate litigator with sweeping views from her plush office but a narrow range of romantic possibilities (and plummeting fertility levels), Ms. Davis combined fragility, denial and a deeply felt intelligence to transcend the cliché that her character might have otherwise become. She harbored Mia's need -- for love, for attachment, for boundary crossing, for conformity -- in her bones, as her own.

PARIS In the City of Lights, it seems impossible to be jaded with its romantic watering holes. That said, sometimes the tones of red, white and champagne start to lose their luster. And for those not blessed (or cursed) with a wine obsession, hope springs eternal for something new. Le Crocodile, a ramshackle green bar east of the Luxembourg Gardens in the Fifth Arrondissement (6, rue Royer Collard; 33-1-43-54-32-37; www.lecrocodile.fr) is just the ticket for something alternative. It has a reputation for pouring hefty portions from its cocktail list of over 300 options, and there is not a ''verre de vin'' in sight.

Stephanie is survived by sisters Constance McConnell Rush of Maine, Shelagh Kip Nicholas of North Carolina, Geraldine Helene McConnell of New York, Ann Garrett McConnell of New York, Julie Anderson McConnell of New York, Leila Jones Richards of Pennsylvania, brother William Larimer Richards of Texas and nieces Shawn Helene McConnell and Heather McConnell Rush both of New York. Family and friends will hold a private gathering in Stephanie's memory. Her family extends their sincere appreciation to the staff of Massachusetts General Hospital. Memorial donations may be made to MGH Palliative Care Service, 55 Fruit Street, Boston, MA 02114.

Enthusiastic traveler, reader, Broadway show attendee and pianist. Survived by his wife Teresa, his children, Katherine Grimm of London, U.K., Dr. Cordelia Grimm, of Baltimore, MD and Jay V. Grimm Jr., of New York City, their spouses and four grandchildren.

Jesse Villanueva, 32, is a principal of Alife Rivington Club, a store on the Lower East Side that has served a sneaker-obsessed clientele since 2001. Among the ''sneaker heads'' who frequent the store are the rappers Nas and Q-Tip, the singer John Mayer, the actor Robin Williams and the professional golfer Hunter Mahan. But Mr. Villanueva's most devoted followers are ''a lot of regular 15-to-25-year-old dudes,'' he said. He lives with his wife, Jennifer, a business analyst at Scholastic Books, in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and performs hip-hop music under the name Holy Smokes. Mr. Villanueva bought his first pair of sneakers, laser blue Nike All Courts, at the age of 5, but said his longtime habit began in earnest in high school, where footwear was the only article of clothing not dictated by a strict uniform code. His passion has mellowed over the past year: he sold about 200 pairs from his personal collection of 350. And he said he no longer worried about wearing his most treasured models to parties where someone might step on them.

BERKOWITZ--Seymour, passed away on June 5, 2009. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Loving father of Alane (Lew), Lennie (Jeanne) and Carolyn (Michael). Devoted and adored grandfather. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, June 7 at 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. He will be greatly missed.

The party season has moved out of the chandeliered ballroom and into the sumptuous garden. A week ago, hills of huge 100-year-old rhododendrons were in spectacular bloom for the 50th anniversary of the opening to the public of Old Westbury Gardens, the former Phipps estate. Guests were asked to dress in '60s style. During the gilded age, more than 1,000 country houses with elaborate grounds were built on the North Shore of Long Island, 30 minutes from Manhattan. Completed in 1906, the 200-acre Phipps estate is a reminder of that halcyon era and is one of the few that remains intact -- including the furnishings in the mansion, today a house museum.
Art Robin Pogrebin

If you were searching for proof that the Emmy-selection process is suspect, look no further: Sally Field has won an award for her cloying, skittish, performance as Nora Walker on the atrocious ABC drama ''Brothers & Sisters,'' while Connie Britton has yet to even be nominated for portraying the wife of Coach Eric Taylor, matriarch of a whole subculture on ''Friday Night Lights,'' NBC's exquisite exegesis on Texan adolescence. She has consistently brought compassion and complexity to the role but as her Tami Taylor ascended to the job of Dillon High School principal this past season, Ms. Britton rose to new challenges, embodying the tensions -- economic, bureaucratic, emotional -- at the center of an ailing education system. If she doesn't make the list of contenders this year, her agent should boycott the Emmys in protest.

Rick McKay, producer of "Broadway: The Golden Age" is working on a film celebrating her life and work. Memorial gifts may be made to the Actor's Fund.

Family and friends may visit to celebrate her life at her residence on Monday and Tuesday, 6-9pm. Permanently embedded in our hearts; we will miss her love and humor.

Excerpts from recent posts on the Globespotters blog, a travelers' guide to cities around the world. LONDON Tucked away behind an unimposing shop front in London's Bloomsbury quarter is the headquarters of an institution with ambitious ideals. The School of Life (70 Marchmont Street WC1; 44-207-833-1010; www.theschooloflife.com), the brainchild of various writers and intellectuals, including the philosopher Alain de Botton, was established last year to offer people innovative ways of approaching life. Through a variety of short breaks, courses, meals in some of London's interesting restaurants and more, the school claims it is the place ''to step back and think intelligently'' about the concerns and stresses of modern-day life.

Address: 2 Quarry Rock Road The Property: This colonial is one of six homes on a cul-de-sac in Redding's southwest corner, which is convenient to Route 7 and the Branchville train station. Built in 2001, the 4,000-square-foot house has four bedrooms, each with a bath. The master bedroom has a fireplace, a walk-in closet and a bathroom with limestone tile, a soaking tub and a glass-front shower. The kitchen has a spacious breakfast nook and is open to the family room, which has a fireplace and access to the back deck and patio. The finished basement is carpeted and has a powder room. A covered walkway connects the house to the detached two-car garage.

Patrick Fischler has been all over television during the past year or so -- as a Dharma Initiative apparatchik on ''Lost,'' as a cop on ''Southland,'' as a guy in trouble on ''Burn Notice''-- but he was at his most memorable playing the embittered insult comic Jimmy Barrett on AMC's ''Mad Men,'' on which he blasted through the show's calculated reserve. Mr. Fischler forged the character, a combination of Don Rickles and Lenny Bruce, out of a look of squirrely neurosis and a creepy sense of compulsion, which cast Don Draper's falsehoods in even greater relief.

According to Jerusalem law, all new construction in the city must involve the use of Jerusalem stone, a light-colored local limestone, various forms of which have provided the principal building blocks of older buildings, walls and alleys since ancient times. Mamilla Hotel, a new luxury property set to open this month, is no exception to the law. The architect, Moshe Safdie, who also designed Columbus Center in New York, used Jerusalem stone to honor the local aesthetic and yet create a modern hotel with a sleek, minimalist look (Piero Lissoni, who designed the Hotel Monaco and Grand Canal in Venice, provided the interior architecture).

When ''Big Love'' first appeared on HBO three years ago, it seemed as if Chloë Sevigny had been cast as Nicki Grant, the crankily moralizing second-fiddle wife in a family of Utah polygamists, to perform her own abjection. A former It Girl, muse and mediocre actress, she had become best known for performing fellatio on Vincent Gallo in his lambasted directorial effort, ''The Brown Bunny.'' During the show's third season, though, Ms. Sevigny humanized Nicki to the point that she became its heartbreaking epicenter, a mother who sought and failed to find her voice and independence, a woman who had managed to spend her whole life neither loved nor desired. The layers of witchy armor seemed to evaporate, and in an ensemble cast in which talent reigns, Ms. Sevigny emerged as the real thing, the one to watch.

RELAXING ON ANJUNA BEACH IN GOA, INDIA. Louise Alldis, 25, a massage therapist from Newcastle Emlyn, Wales, pictured with Dean Rodda, 27, Jan. 28, 2009. ''I was at the start of a year's traveling around India and Thailand. Goa was my first stop, and I was spending five weeks there with my friend Dean, just relaxing and unwinding after a long year working and saving hard. We were outside my favorite beach bar, Café Lilliput. It is was my second time to Anjuna; I spent a lot of time there on my first trip to India, and got to know the family that runs Lilliput quite well. I feel very at home there. This was just part of our day-to-day life while in Goa, making the most of the wonderful sunshine and being entertained by the antics of the cheeky cows on the beach.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

LYNE--Helena of Kristiansand, Norway died of Polycystic Kidney Disease on April 19, 2009. She was born on September 29, 1945 in New York City to John and Sheila (McGovern) Lyne. She graduated from the Academy of Mt. St. Ursula in 1963 and later from American University with a degree in anthropology. A natural born adventurer, Helena lived in Washington, DC and Seattle, Washington before finally settling in Norway and marrying Leif Iverson. While teaching English in Evje-Hornnes High School, she earned another degree in Norwegian history. She is survived by her husband, Leif Iverson, a sister Diane Gasparrini (Joseph), a niece Suzanne Glynn (Richard), a nephew Peter Gasparrini and many aunts, uncles, cousins and friends who mourn her loss. There will be a Memorial Mass for Helena on June 13, 2009 at 11am at The Church of St. Paul in Congers, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Helena Lyne Scholarshp Fund; c/o Maryellen Collins, North Rockland High School, 106 Hammond Road, Thiells, New York 10984.

We are a couple with a 14-month-old toddler and will be staying with my wife's parents in San Diego in July. We have seen most of San Diego and would like to explore some more of Southern California on day trips or short outings. We are reasonably adventurous, but will probably draw the line at bungee jumping. Hikes in national parks sound like a good option -- or is it too hot? -- Christian Barkei, Shanghai With a toddler in tow, I agree that you should draw the line at bungee jumping, and I'd also skip nearby Tijuana. Southern California in July can get quite hot, so you should take extra precautions to protect your 14-month-old against heat, dehydration and too much sun.

For only the second time in its 47-year history, the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition has ended in a tie. On Sunday, the Van Cliburn Foundation announced in Fort Worth, Tex., that it had awarded the top prizes in its 13th competition to Nobuyuki Tsujii, 20, of Japan and Haochen Zhang, 19, of China. Both performers will receive the Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass gold medal and cash awards of $20,000, as well as concert tours for the three seasons, recording contracts and performance attire. Mr. Tsujii and Mr. Zhang were the youngest pianists in the competition, as well as its first winners from any Asian nation. The 2001 competition also ended in a tie between Stanislav Ioudenitch of Uzbekistan and Olga Kern of Russia. This year’s silver medal was awarded to Yeol Eum Son of South Korea.

Setting aside Bret Michaels’s unforeseen encounter with a piece of scenery, perhaps the most memorable moment of Sunday night’s Tony Awards show was the bawdy closing number performed by Neil Patrick Harris, set to the tunes of “Tonight” (from “West Side Story”) and “Luck Be a Lady Tonight” (from “Guys and Dolls”).

Updated | 4:13 p.m. Though the first round of the Bret Michaels–Tony Awards scenery battle may have gone to the scenery, the singer emerged from the awards show with only minor injuries, a publicist for Mr. Michaels said on Monday morning.
A week after a notorious incident at the MTV Movie Awards, during which the comedian Sacha Baron Cohen ended up in the lap of Eminem, the event continues to grip the national consciousness.

The first post-Tony Awards casualty: Neil LaBute’s play “reasons to be pretty,” which was nominated in three major Tonys categories but won no awards, will close this Sunday, the show’s publicist said this morning.

The police in Thailand said that they would allow the F.B.I. to assist in the investigation of the actor David Carradine‘s death, but only as observers, The Associated Press reported. The family of the actor had met with the F.B.I. on Friday, after Mr. Carradine’s body was found in his Bangkok hotel room on Thursday. According to Mark Geragos, a lawyer for Mr. Carradine’s half brother Keith, the family had been upset by conflicting information coming from Thailand. Initial reports had said that Mr. Carradine, who was found naked and hanged in a closet, had committed suicide, but the police there later said his death may have been an accident. Maj. Gen. Amnuay Nimmano of the Thai police told The A.P., “If the F.B.I. wants to get involved, we will do our best to cooperate.” The director-general for International Affairs of Thailand’s Attorney General’s Office told The A.P. that the agency had not yet received a request from the F.B.I. to assist in the case.

In case television viewers have forgotten, the victor of “American Idol” isn’t merely obligated to spend three weeks appearing on every talk show under the sun and be asked how he somehow managed to defeat the other finalist — there’s usually a recording contract that follows. On Monday, it was announced that Kris Allen, the young singer from Conway, Ark., who stunned roughly half the nation when he defeated Adam Lambert to win “American Idol” in May, had been signed to 19 Recordings, a division of 19 Entertainment, which produces the reality show. In a news release, the company said that Mr. Allen’s recording have been licensed to Jive Records, which plans to release his debut album in the fall. In a statement, Mr. Allen said the new album would feature pop and rock songs similar to his “American Idol” performances, which included covers of “How Sweet It Is” and “Ain’t No Sunshine.”

VENICE – One of the parlor games you can play at the Biennale here is to try to find echoes of old art, the medieval and Renaissance kind, in the brand-new art that suddenly colonizes the city. On my final day, I found myself in a version of the game that would have been macabre if it hadn’t been so funny.

I read in The Times this morning, to my surprise, that Peter L. Bernstein had died. True, he was 90 years old, but he had been active, engaged -- and working -- until a few days ago, when he broke his hip and then died of pneumonia in the hospital. Mr. Bernstein was perhaps best known for two books he wrote at a stage in life when most people are retired: "Against The Gods: The Remarkable Story of Risk," and "Capital Ideas: The Improbable Origins of Modern Wall Street." As my colleague Louis Uchitelle noted in his affectionate obituary, Mr. Bernstein was a firm believer in the efficient market theory -- the subject of my column last Saturday -- and especially the power of diversification, which he touted constantly. He founded The Journal of Portfolio Theory. Harry Markowitz, who was awarded a Nobel Prize, for, essentially, creating portfolio theory, was one of his heroes. Mr. Bernstein's last book, "Capital Ideas Evolving," published two years ago, was an attempt (more successful than not) at incorporating some of the ideas of behavioral finance into the broader efficient market theory championed by the likes of Mr. Markowitz and Eugene Fama of the University of Chicago.

So the Belmont Stakes is in the books. Summer Bird won in a mild upset. Many will be puzzled by the riding tactics adopted by Calvin Borel on Mine That Bird and John Velazquez on Dunkirk. No matter, the lightly raced Summer Bird has now emerged as one of the leading 3-year-olds of this year's crop, joining Mine That Bird and Rachel Alexandra as a winner of a Triple Crown race. Dunkirk also emerged as a horse with a bright future with a hard-fought effort to finish second in The Belmont. Having never been on the lead before, he led nearly the whole way. When he was headed he fought back. A gutsy performance from a talented colt. And what can you say about the diminutive gelding Mine That Bird. He ran three terrific races in the Triple Crown series.

VICTORIA, British Columbia -- The European rabbit, the source species for every pet rabbit variety, was introduced long ago to places as far afield as Australia and North America. While cute and cuddly, the little lagomorphs breed, well, like rabbits. There's no doubt of the species' proliferative potential around the campus of the University of Victoria, which has become overrun with bunnies. Hundreds of visitors convening there over the weekend to discuss literature and nature were bemused by the flocks of cottontails nibbling grass as students and campus workers passed without a second glance.

Nascar: Tony Stewart won his first "official" race as team owner on Sunday at the Pocono 500 in Long Pond, Pa. Stewart, who is in his first year as owner of Stewart-Haas Racing, won the All-Star race last month, but the Pocono 500 was his first points-paying victory. Stewart conserved fuel by easing up on the throttle, and he didn't have to pit for the final 41 laps. "It's 180 degrees from what you're trained to do, what you strive to do," he told The Philadelphia Inquirer afterward. Nevertheless, it was an impressive comeback after starting from the back of the pack in his reserve car, because of a crash in practice on Saturday.

Like so many who have loved the high life, Doris Lilly, a society writer and author of "How to Marry a Millionaire," died broke. Lilly, it seems, never did marry a millionaire, but she had tons of sugar daddies, who kept her in sable and bijoux. Too much bijoux, in fact. If she had only gone for the good stuff, diamonds and rubies, she might have been able to pay her bills. Instead, the executor of her estate had to sell off her costume jewelry in one giant fire sale that looked like something straight out of Bollywood.

The streetscape of downtown Jamaica, the commercial and transit hub of southeastern Queens, is a riot of color: zebra-print handbags, pink Betty Boop suitcases and rainbows of T-shirts for 99 cents seem to burst from small shops onto the sidewalk. Vendors slice bright orange mangoes and serve them in Ziploc bags with salt and hot sauce. Mom-and-pop clothing stores like Vim -- its aging marquee letters decorated with the Stars and Stripes -- outnumber the few national retailers like Old Navy and Marshalls. Outside one hole-in-the-wall shop, a recorded voice squawks: "Air Maxes, Uptowns, Jordans, $40 in the back! Leather jackets, buy one get one free! Closing out!"

Lost in the recent discussion of the Polaroid SX-70 - its artistic legacy and the attempts to revive it - is the fact that Polaroid once made two large-format, positive-negative films. Type 55 was single sheet, Polaroid 665 was a 10-sheet pack. After developing, the film needed to be rinsed in sodium sulfite, washed in water and hung up to dry. You could tell Polaroid shooters because they always toted their trusty white buckets.

For a magazine whose gestation period rivaled that of several elephants, TIWIMUTA (This Is What It Made Us Think About) feels strangely of the moment. Odder still, given that its founder, the fashion designer and creative director Andre Walker, has created the 212-page "open playground for experimentation" as a pie in the face to a publishing industry that too often reacts to time-sensitive market forces like movie releases and the fashion calendar. "The only real direction I gave anyone was to do whatever they wanted," says Walker, who no longer designs under his own name but collaborates with his friends Marc Jacobs and Kim Jones. The unorthodox editorial mission goes a long way to explaining the tantalizingly disparate submissions, including a photo-shoot collaboration between Marc Jacobs and Jean-Paul Goude, a screenplay by the writer Hilton Als, recipes for white food by Tucker Shaw and even a blessing from Walker's mother, an ordained minister. For creative types, TIWIMUTA will come as a godsend, but at $375 a copy, it may need all the celestial benediction it can get.

Roberts and Sandra Day O'Connor before her) relatively unknown outside judicial circles. People flocked to the Internet to learn more about the judge from the Bronx. According to Hitwise, ''Sonia Sotomayor'' was the fourth fastest-growing search term for the week ending May 30. ARESTY--Jerome Joseph, died at the age of 79 after four miraculous years surviving lung cancer, and after quite a few bonus golf games, in Boca Raton, Florida on June 5, 2009. Jerome was born August 23, 1929 in Rochester, New York. The youngest of nine children, he was nicknamed "The Babe." Jerome married his high school sweetheart, Lorraine Kabakoff, in 1952. They recently celebrated their 57th wedding anniversary. Over a thirty year career, Jerome with his brothers and partners, Joseph and Gerald, grew their business into a major sportswear firm, Alfred Dunner, Inc. Jerome will be remembered for his major support of Jewish charities, Morristown Memorial Hospital, Rutgers University and many others. Jerome will be missed by all. He is survived by Lorraine, daughter Karen Kustel of Mill Valley, CA, son James of Aspen, CO, and four grandsons. He is also survived by two brothers, Maurice and Joseph, and a sister, Ann, many nieces and ne-phews, and countless friends. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 9 at 1:00pm at Temple B'nai Or, 60 Overlook Road, Morristown, NJ.

BALL--Sally A.,age 88, died peacefully at home June 5, 2009. She was predeceased by her husband Dr. Eugene R. Ball and is survived by her children Martha Ball Heppenheimer and Perry A. Ball, her grandchildren Geoffrey and Elizabeth Heppenheimer, and Katie and Torie Ball. In lieu of flowers, contibutions may be made to The N.Y. Junior League Community Trust Fund 130 E. 80 St., New York, NY 10075. Funeral services are pending.

NOLAN--Annette M. passed on June 6, 2009. A graduate of St. Joseph's College of Brooklyn, Class of 1944, Miss Nolan was survived by her sister, Ellen, brother Richard and sister-in-law Barbara Nolan; seven nieces and nephews; and 11 grandnieces and grandnephews. Miss Nolan served on active duty with the Coast Guard during World War II and then was commissioned in the U.S. Army Reserve from which she retired as a Lieutenant Colonel. Retired in 1988 from the New York Telephone Company where she serve in many managerial posts, she was President of the Pioneers Manhattan Empire Chapter in 1975-76, she was actively involved in establishing the Burn Center in New York Hospital where she spearheaded efforts to create a laboratory in honor of the deceased New York Telephone President John Mulhearn. A philanthropist to many, she was inducted as a Lady of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre by Terence Cardinal Cooke; served on the Board of Directors at Mercy Home for Children in Brooklyn; was a member of the Bishop's Support Team of the Diocese of Brooklyn; was recognized for "Outstanding Volunteer Service to the City of New York" by Mayor Bloomberg: and "Outstanding Accomplishment" by the Academy of Women Achievers of the YWCA. Viewing will be Tuesday, June 9, 2009, 2-4 and 7-9pm. The Mass of the Resurrection on Wednesday at St. Charles Borromeo Church, Sydney Place, Brooklyn at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Mercy Home for Children, 243 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, New York 11215 would be appreciated. Services are supervised by Heights and Hill, Funeral Directors, 115 Atlantic Avenue (corner of Henry Street), Brooklyn, New York, 718-797-3248

RYAN--Christine, age 63, of Highlands, NJ passed away peacefully at her home on Wednesday, June 3rd. Throughout her illness she never lost the dignity, courage and determination that so marked her life. She was born and raised in New Jersey and loved the Jersey Shore where she lived most of her life. During her career in Communications, she spent 30 years working in New York, most recently for the past 16 years at Emerging Health IT, Montefiore Medical Center as an Assistant Director. She loved her work and the people who surrounded her. She found it rewarding to be a part of an organization so committed to excellence in patient care. One of her most satisfying achievements was her contribution to Children's Hospital at Montefiore. She will be greatly missed by her daughter Sharon Britton, son-in-law Jeff Britton, close friend Lawrence Pumelia and beloved cats Daisy and Jasmine. There will be a memorial service Thursday, June 11th. Please contact sharonbritton@gmail.com for details. Instead of flowers, please make a gift in Memory of Christine to Susan G. Komen for the Cure. Many thanks for the love and support of so many who cared so deeply.

NICHOLLS--Paul. New York Road Runners mourns the death of president and CEO of Team Continuum Paul Nicholls, who died June 4 from cancer at the age of 61. After running the ING New York City Marathon 2003 with stage 3 Multiple Myeloma, Nicholls founded Team Continuum, which has provided over $3.5 million for cancer treatment. The 2005 recipient of the Avis "We Try Harder" Award and Olympic torch bearer completed the ING New York City Marathon five times.

JAYSON--Bob. Bob, loving husband of 30 years, enjoyed life-books, theatre, ballet, travel. Forming a community of friends at Central Synagogue, studying Judaism, singing with the congregational choir, becoming B'Nei Mitzvah, he also served as Brotherhood president and as a member of Central's Board of Trustees. All this without missing a golf game, at which he excelled, or a challenge on the squash court. Services to be held at Central Synagogue, 55th and Lexington, Monday at 11am. Donations may be made to Central Synagogue's Caring Committee. Shalom, Barbara

U.S. Tech Chief Talks Priorities The first question for Aneesh Chopra, below, the chief technology officer of the United States, not surprisingly, was ''What does the nation's C.T.O. do?'' Mr. Chopra said that his top goal was economic development using government policy to create jobs and business around technology. ''My job is to serve as the innovation platform champion in addressing private market opportunities in support of public priorities,'' he said.

KERN--Ralph W.,of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully May 31st at his home, in the arms of his devoted wife of 53 years, Leona. He was a faithful son to Morris and Anna Kern, caring brother to Morton Kern, loving father of Mariane and Bennett Borko, Franklin and Julie Kern, Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye, and the proud grandfather of Seth, Allison, Melanie and Adam. Born in The Bronx in 1934, son of a furniture manufacturer, he worked full time to put himself through NYU. Early in his career, he established himself as a builder, entrepreneur, and visionary New York City developer. He was also adventurous, traveling and sailing extensively throughout the world. His passions were his family, opera, ballet, tennis, and sailing. We all looked to him for courage, direction, and understanding. Donations may be made in his name to Trustees of Columbia University, Division of Cardiology, Att: Dr. Allan Schwartz or Julie Fisher, 622 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

The introduction of full-color versions of electronic ink displays, the technology used by Amazon's Kindle, Sony's Reader and many other electronic book-reading devices, came closer to reality last week with the acquisition of E Ink by Prime View International, based in Taiwan, for about $215 million. ''The No. 1 need in the market is to get color, but we did not have sufficient resources to develop it,'' Sriram K. Peruvemba, E Ink vice president for marketing, said in an interview. ''This acquisition gives us the manpower and cash we need.''

BIANCO--Alfred Jude, on June 5, 2009. Loving and adored husband of Judy. Beloved brother of Jane Kelly and Donald Bianco. Cherished uncle of Carol, Don, Chris, John, Bob and Judy. Caring son of the late Alfred and the late Margaret. Devoted dad to Tappy. His brilliant mind, sensitivity and incredible sense of humor will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, June 10th at 10:30am at St. Patrick's Cathedral-Fifth Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, Donor Services, P.O. Box 4072, Pittsfield, MA 01202.

Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the former head of AT&T who built the company into a telephone giant through a series of mergers, has been chosen to be chairman of the new, slimmed-down version of General Motors when it emerges from bankruptcy protection.

Update | 7:25 p.m. The Supreme Court late Tuesday declined to extend a stay of the sale of Chrysler assets to Fiat, clearing the way for the deal to close as soon as Wednesday morning over the objections of three Indiana state pension funds and several consumer groups.
Update | 5:23 p.m. The federal bankruptcy judge has approved Chrysler’s plan to close the 789 dealerships.

When I return from vacation, it is always nice to do a quick catch-up piece on what I missed. Here are some of the more interesting events in the past 10 days. It was a rather quiet time — if you ignore the bankruptcy of what was once America’s most prominent industrial corporation, General Motors. Nonetheless, signs of early life in the deal market are still appearing.

Indiana’s treasurer isn’t the only one raising sharp legal questions about where Chrysler‘s bankruptcy is headed. Some professionals and academics suggest that the rushed sale of Chrysler, as well as the fast-tracked Chapter 11 of General Motors, could have major repercussions for other deals.
One might expect Richard Mourdock, Indiana’s treasurer and the best-known objector to Chrysler‘s deal with Fiat, to be happy with the Supreme Court’s decision to delay the sale.
In a situation as highly charged and carefully scrutinized as the Chrysler bankruptcy, any and every word uttered by a principal will probably be seized upon for possible use by either side.
Daniel Alpert, managing director at Westwood Capital, an investment bank in New York, offers his take on the core issues raised by the Supreme Court’s stay of Fiat’s Chrysler deal.

If this doesn’t finally settle the question of whether or not Anvil is a real band, nothing will: that hard-rocking Canadian group whose career is chronicled in the documentary “Anvil! The Story of Anvil,” will open for the heavy metal band AC/DC when it performs at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Mass. on July 28 and at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on July 31, the bands’ publicists said in a release.

If you ever wanted to see a company spend a lot of money in an attempt to make it look like it didn’t spend a lot of money to promote its important new product, you could have done worse than watch Microsoft’s Bing-A-Thon, which was broadcast on Hulu.com on Monday night.
Almost from the moment Adam Lambert made his debut on “American Idol,” the singer has been dogged by a persistent question that he can finally answer: Yes, he has a record deal.

The rock band Depeche Mode resumed its world tour on Monday night after coming off the road so that its lead singer, Dave Gahan, could recuperate from cancer surgery, BBC News reported. In May, the band canceled a scheduled performance in Athens, Greece, just before show time, when Mr. Gahan, 47, fell ill in his dressing room. Initially the singer was given a diagnosis of severe gastroenteritis, but later learned that he had a malignant tumor in his bladder. The band subsequently postponed or canceled 12 dates in Europe to accommodate Mr. Gahan’s surgery and recovery. On Monday night, Depeche Mode played its first show since Mr. Gahan’s operation in Leipzig, Germany, where the singer thanked his fans and “all of the doctors who looked after me so well,” according to the BBC.

A two-year investigation of religious artifacts and relics found in the home of an Illinois collector in 2007 has determined that 1,600 of them were stolen, the Web site ChicagoBreakingNews.com reported.

How do you feel about the switch, or what it says about development in New York?

Luck has run out for the Broadway revival of “Guys and Dolls”: the musical is scheduled to play its last performance on Sunday, its publicists said. The show, with music and lyrics by Frank Loesser and book by Jo Swerling and Abe Burrows, featured a cast that included Oliver Platt as Nathan Detroit, Lauren Graham as Miss Adelaide and Craig Bierko as Sky Masterson, and was directed by Des McAnuff. But reviews were mixed, and it fared poorly at the Tony Awards, receiving nominations for best musical revival and best scenic design (for Robert Brill) but winning neither. The revival will have played 113 performances and 28 previews at the Nederlander Theater. A national tour for the 2010-2011 season is planned.

Chang W. Lee, 40, a senior staff photographer at The Times, was ambivalent about working in video. He often said that he didn't want to do it unless there were a camera with which he could make moving images that were like his still photos. When a camera was finally produced that allowed him to use the same lenses he used as a still photographer and also allowed him to shoot in extremely low light, he decided it was time to dive in.

As a colleague here at The Times points out, the Pearl Continental hotel in Peshawar, Pakistan, which was partly destroyed on Tuesday by a massive car bomb, is well known locally as a meeting point for not just wealthy Pakistanis, foreign aid workers and journalists but also intelligence agents. In other words, it is the sort of place a modern-day Graham Greene novel might be set, with security so tight that even the lifeguards at the hotel pool are armed with AK-47s.

Tonight, all of France will be tuned into M6 for the final round of "Nouvelle Star," the Gallic version of "American Idol" that's captured the hearts not only of the French public but also of the fashion press. French television is already infamous for high-concept game shows and indefatigable talking heads, and fittingly les françaises have taken to "Nouvelle Star" like flies to blue cheese. But Soan, one of the two finalists tonight, is nothing short of a phenomenon: his piercings and tattoos, pretty face, smoky eye makeup (l'oeil de biche, i.e., doe-eye) and deep baritone tow a perfect line between gamine and libertine, like the love child Jean Seberg and Jean-Paul Belmondo never had.In his endearingly sincere rendition of Depeche Mode's "Personal Jesus," Soan appears to be wearing a kind of flannel ball-gown, the train slung dramatically over his forearm. (Jean Paul Gaultier has even designed several of Soan's costumes.) And unlike his American counterparts (say, Adam Lambert) Soan is convincingly mal aimé: his facial hair is scrawny and unkempt, and he's pale and unhealthily skinny, like he's been living on baguettes alone. It's part of his whole lost little bird, male Edith Piaf thing, which despite the incorporation of New Yorkais references remains undeniably French.

Amid Afghanistan's struggles to stem violence and political instability, the country is slowly moving forward to protect its biological and environmental patrimony. The country recently established its first national park and now has created a list of 33 protected species, ranging from the snow leopard to the obscure goitered gazelle and paghman salamander. The Wildlife Conservation Society on Tuesday released photographs of snow leopards taken last month in the Wakhan Corridor region using automatically-triggered camera traps, a technology I've written about in the past. Here's more on Afghanistan's new wildlife laws.

Some kind of flu is hitting our towns. The superintendents of the South Orange-Maplewood and Millburn school districts again sent letters urging parents to keep children with high fever (over 100 degrees), cough and other flu-like symptoms at home for seven days, even if a doctor's note says they might return earlier. There has been no outbreak of swine flu, but Dr. Richard Brodow, the Millburn superintendent, said a number of children have been diagnosed with (unspecified) flu and that the schools continue to have more children absent than usual. The letter from South Orange-Maplewood gave standard suggestions for combating the virus: wash your hands, sneeze into something other than your hand (your elbow or a tissue, it suggests) and keep a six-foot radius from sick people. Both letters were reassuring, telling parents there is no need to panic, and that the districts have not been advised to close schools. -- ALEX LOWTHER

For Jackie and me, the big event of spring isn't asparagus or even strawberries -- much less the sight of a politician lobbing the opening pitch of the baseball season. It's peas. And our favorite pea dish, the first one we have each year, is not, as you might think, plain with butter and salt. It is what's often called petits pois à la française, which in my version involves bacon, young onions, a little chicken stock, the peas, a couple of handfuls of soft-leafed lettuce, then finally butter and tarragon. All that stuff, yet the flavor is peas all the way. The best, especially eaten with a big spoon so you can really fill your mouth.

I spent last weekend taking care of my 5-month-old niece. While exhausting, it was incredible to watch a baby discover things. She was giddy as she ate her third-ever serving of solid food. I wasn't sure if it was because her Aunt Jill's fresh pea puree was so good or because she learned that her tongue could do more than get drops from a bottle. For me, it was elating: It made me realize that so rarely do I have a first these days.

Calling itself "a daily online magazine of Jewish news, ideas, and culture," Tablet magazine began publishing Tuesday. The Gordon Parks Awards Dinner and Auction in New York City last week drew an eclectic mix of people - Andre Leon Talley played host while guests like Lyia Kebede, Russell Simmons, Isabel Toledo and Bruce Weber were all honored. There were some blue chip works on the auction block as well, including an image of Andy Warhol shot by Richard Avedon and recent portraits of the Obamas courtesy of Annie Leibowitz. But the photograph that earned the highest bid was one from the late Parks himself, who was equally comfortable taking photos of celebrities as he was of gangs in Harlem. His 1955 photo titled "Drugstore Cowboys, Blind River Ontario" went for $20,000.

Now “The Hangover” has given Pixar a headache. Warner Brothers executives are doing cartwheels over final box office figures that show their R-rated comedy was the No. 1 movie over the weekend after all, beating Pixar’s “Up” by a whisker. Warner said Monday morning that “The Hangover,” co-financed and co-produced by Legendary Pictures, about a bachelor party gone wrong, sold $44.979 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend — as opposed to the projected $43.275 million. “Up,” meanwhile, posted a final number of about $44.138 million, according to Walt Disney Pictures, which distributed the movie for its corporate cousin. Disney had projected that “Up” would finish with $44.244 million in sales.
CBS’s broadcast of the 63rd Annual Tony Awards showed signs of life.
Bret Michaels emerged from the Tony Awards show with only minor injuries, his publicist said.

The Brooklyn Ballet will officially open its new headquarters on June 16 on the ground floor of the Schermerhorn House, the company announced on Monday. The 11-story building in downtown Brooklyn, which also houses low income artists and the formerly homeless, is a collaboration between a real estate development company and a nonprofit affordable housing project. It will include a performance space, a school, and offices. Lynn Parkerson, who founded the company in 2002, said, “To be a ballet company integrated into this mixed use community is what excites us.” She added, “We feel it’s important for the children of Brooklyn to have a conservatory so they can get the kind of dance training that young people need.” The company plans to open its school in September.

For only the second time in its 47-year history, the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition has ended in a tie. On Sunday, the Van Cliburn Foundation announced in Fort Worth that it had awarded the top prizes to Nobuyuki Tsujii, 20, of Japan (right, with Mr. Cliburn) and Haochen Zhang, 19, of China. Both performers will receive the Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass gold medal and cash awards of $20,000, as well as concert tours for the three seasons, recording contracts and performance attire. Mr. Tsujii and Mr. Zhang were the youngest pianists in the competition, as well as its first winners from Asia. This year’s silver medal was awarded to Yeol Eum Son of South Korea.

The police in Thailand said that they would allow the F.B.I. to assist in the investigation of the actor David Carradine’s death, but only as observers, The Associated Press reported. The family of the actor had met with the F.B.I. on Friday, the day after Mr. Carradine’s body was found in his Bangkok hotel room. According to Mark Geragos, a lawyer for Mr. Carradine’s half brother Keith Carradine, the family had been upset over conflicting information. Initial reports had said that Mr. Carradine, who was found naked and hanged in a closet, had committed suicide, but the police in Thailand later said his death may have been an accident. Maj. Gen. Amnuay Nimmano of the Thai police told the agency, “If the F.B.I. wants to get involved, we will do our best to cooperate.” An official of the Thai attorney general’s office told The A.P. that it had not yet received an F.B.I. request.

In case television viewers have forgotten, the victor of “American Idol” isn’t merely obligated to spend three weeks appearing on every talk show under the sun; there’s usually a recording contract that follows. On Monday, it was announced that Kris Allen, the young singer from Conway, Ark., who won “American Idol” in May in a stunning upset, had been signed to 19 Recordings, a division of 19 Entertainment, which produces the show. In a news release, the company said that Mr. Allen’s recordings had been licensed to Jive Records, which plans to release his debut album in the fall. In a statement, Mr. Allen said the new album would feature pop and rock songs similar to his “American Idol” performances.

The Nets' net pretax losses continue to rise, increasing to $25.6 million in the three months ended April 30, up from $24.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue in the three-month period fell sharply to $38.4 million from $48.2 million. The team has posted nearly $380 million in pretax net losses since its acquisition for $300 million in 2004 by a group led by Bruce C. Ratner, chairman of Forest City Ratner, a Forest City Enterprises subsidiary. Forest City Enterprises, which owns 23 percent of the team, said in a government filing that its share of team losses fell to $10.9 million from $12.8 million a year ago because its liability for the loss fell to 43 percent from 53 percent. More than half the losses are for amortization of the team's purchase.

Tiger Woods's come-from-behind victory Sunday on CBS to win the Memorial Tournament generated a 3.6 overnight rating, doubling the performance for last year's final round when Kenny Perry won the event. The rating on Sunday matched that of the Memorial's final round four years ago, when Bart Bryant was the winner. It was the best since 2004, when Ernie Els finished first and Woods third. Still reeling from a sudden revolt a day earlier that shifted control of the New York State Senate to Republicans, Democrats huddled behind closed doors in the Capitol on Tuesday morning, seeking a legal path to help them block the power grab. But it was far from clear whether they would be able to keep Republicans from assuming control of the Senate, or whether they would even be able to keep more members from defecting and cementing the new Republican majority.

On May 19, Dennis C. Blair, the director of national intelligence, sent a classified memorandum announcing that his office would use its authority to select the top American spy in each country overseas. One day later, Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, sent a dispatch of his own. Ignore Mr. Blair's message, Mr. Panetta wrote to agency employees; the C.I.A. was still in charge overseas, a role that C.I.A. station chiefs had jealously guarded for decades.

With little notice, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska and her husband, Todd, dropped in as guests at Monday night's big annual Republican fund-raising dinner, after another flap with its organizers. Ms. Palin had caused some unhappiness in recent days after associates suggested to Republican officials that she wanted to attend and be given a last-minute speaking role at the event, above, sponsored by the National Republican Senatorial Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee.

BIANCO--Alfred J. It is with deep sorrow that Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague, Alfred J. Bianco. Al was recognized as one of the leading finance, restructuring and financial derivatives lawyers in the country. Al received his LL.M. from Columbia University School of Law, his LL.B. from Fordham University Law School, where he served as Comments Editor of the Fordham University Law Review, and his B.S. from Georgetown University. We extend our deepest condolences to Al's wife, Judy, and the rest of their wonderful family. Visitation will be held on Tuesday, June 9, from 2:00pm to 5:00pm and 7:00pm to 9:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel (Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Manhattan). A funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, June 10, at 10:30 am at St. Patrick's Cathedral (Fifth Avenue at 50th Street, Manhattan). In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Donor Services, P.O. Box 4072, Pittsfield, MA 01202.

Rajeev Motwani, a Stanford computer science professor and an investor in technology start-ups who mentored many young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, including the founders of Google, died on Friday at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 47. The cause of death was being investigated, said Robert Foucrault, the San Mateo County coroner. Mr. Motwani was found dead at the bottom of his backyard swimming pool Friday morning, said Lt. Mike Guerra of the Atherton Police Department. There was no evidence of a crime at the scene, he said.

Funeral services will be held on Thursday morning, June 11, at 10 am at the Church of St. Francis de Sales in Manhattan.

Residents around Cleburne, Tex., experienced three earthquakes in the last week, a jarring occurrence in a state better known for hurricanes and tornadoes. ''For the first 150 years of recorded history in Cleburne, we've had no earthquakes,'' said Chester Nolen, the city manager of Cleburne, which is in north-central Texas and has about 30,000 people. ''Then in the last six days, we have two.''

HARING--Eugene M.,of Princeton, NJ died on June 4, 2009 at the University Medical Center at Princeton after a brief illness. He was the beloved husband of Janet Marshall Haring and loving uncle to Amy Newell, London, England and James and Christopher Nichols of Rhode Island. He was born May 16, 1927 to Edith and Horace Haring. A graduate of the Pingry School, Elizabeth, NJ, he received his Bachelor of Arts degree, summa cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa, from Princeton University and a Masters Degree in Philosophy as a Woodrow Wilson Fellow, also from Princeton. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1955. He served in the US Navy and in the Naval Reserve. After Harvard Law School, Mr. Haring joined McCarter and English, where he spent his entire legal career. He became Senior Partner and Chairman of the Executive Committee in 1982 and remained in those positions until 1997. Mr. Haring's extensive practice concentrated on general litigation with trial and appellate experience. His clients ranged from individuals to large, national corporations. Long a proponent of dispute resolution, upon retirement, he served as a Mediator for the US District Court of NJ, a part of the New Jersey Supreme Court Civil Mediation Program and a member of the NJ Panel of Distinguished Neutrals. He served as a member of the vestry and Warden at Princeton's Trinity Church and was a trustee of General Theological Seminary in New York. He was Chancellor of the Episcopal Diocese of NJ, serving four bishops, spanning a period of 18 years. He was recognized for his long service to the Diocese of New Jersey by being named Honorary Canon. Mr. Haring mentored many young lawyers throughout his career, sharing his love of the law and his expectations for the highest ethical and intellectual standards. He will be remembered for his kindness and generosity, his love of animals and of Princeton University. A memorial service celebrating Gene's life will be held Saturday, June 13, 2009 at 3pm at Trinity Episcopal Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to either SAVE Animal Shelter, 900 Herrontown Road, Princeton, NJ 08540 or University Medical Center at Princeton, 253 Witherspoon Street, Princeton, NJ 08540.

The Senate confirmation process can be rough, but that is not why Judge Sonia Sotomayor was hobbling around Capitol Hill on crutches on Monday. President Obama's Supreme Court nominee tripped at La Guardia Airport in New York on Monday morning and broke her ankle, according to the White House. She got on the shuttle anyway and headed to Washington, where she proceeded to Medical Faculty Associates at George Washington University for an X-ray that confirmed a small fracture.

COWEN--George Nathan, 92, died peacefully on June 4 at North Hill Skilled Nursing Facility in Needham, MA. He was born in New York City and attended Rumsey Hall School, Riverdale Country School and The Hotchkiss School. George graduated from Princeton University, an English major and member of the Class of 1940. During World War II he served as an Army Major, and after the war, he joined the family investment banking firm, Cowen & Co., where he became a partner. The firm had been founded in 1918 by his father, Arthur, and two uncles, Edwin and Harry. George was predeceased by his wife, Nan Fingarson Cowen, who passed away in 1998 at their home in Scarsdale, where they lived for 51 years. He is survived by his sons, Peter Donnelly Cowen of West Newton, MA, and George Nathan Cowen Jr. of Denver, and by his granddaughter, Elizabeth Tarleton Sutherland of Los Angeles. George enjoyed tennis, golf, bridge and beach going, but his true passion was attending any occasions that brought together family and friends. A memorial service will be held at the Greenville Community Reformed Church, 270 Ardsley Rd., Scarsdale, NY 10583 at 11am on Saturday, June 20. In lieu of flowers, donations to Princeton University in his memory would be appreciated.

BERKMAN--Dr. Alan. "We are doctors, we treat sick people." His brilliant work gave life to millions when others would let them die. He spoke the language of comfort and sorrow. He lived with integrity and compassion. He died with courage and dignity at 63 on June 5, 2009, surrounded by family and friends. The indifferent universe knows not; we weep for its loss and for ours. He is survived by his wife and comrade, Dr. Barbara Zeller, his daughters, Sarah and Harriet, his grandson, Gabriel, his brothers, Jerry, Larry and Steven and his mother, Mona.

Perhaps the city's unlikeliest renovation project (keep dreamin', Second Avenue subway), the High Line -- or at least its first portion -- opens to the public today. The elevated park, with a highly designed but wild-looking landscape and an installation by the artist Spencer Finch, will be open from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily; enter at Gansevoort Street or 16th Street. For more walking where you were once prohibited, head to the Museum Mile festival, where portions of Fifth Avenue will be closed to car traffic, and all the institutions are free.

The United States men's national team has come out of the frying pan and into the fire. After a breathless 2-1 victory over Honduras in a World Cup qualifier on Saturday in Chicago, the Americans are preparing to leave for South Africa and the Confederations Cup. They open first-round play Monday with a game against Italy (ESPN, 2:25 p.m. Eastern), followed by matches against Brazil on June 18 (ESPN2, 9:55 a.m.) and Egypt on June 21 (ESPN2, 2:25 p.m.).
