SILBER--Austin, M.D.,Psychoanalyst, Teacher, Administrator, died peacefully, surrounded by his family, on June 4, 2009, at age 86. Son of Al and Sophie Glover, and Sam and Sophie Silber, he was born on January 3, 1923. He served in World War II, as a Medic, in the Pacific, from 1943-1945. His undergraduate studies at New York University were completed in 1946, and he received his M.D., from The State University of New York Downstate Medical Center in 1951. On completing his Psychiatric and Psychoanalytic training, in 1959, he began his private practice in Psychoanalysis, which continued until his retirement in September 2005. During his professional career, he published frequently, on the themes of analysis, re-analysis, and self-analysis; the myth of Medusa; the dream within the dream; and alcoholism. From 1984-1988, he was the Director of the Psychoanalytic Institute at New York University Medical Center, New York, and simultaneously Secretary of the National American Psychoanalytic Association. A Training and Supervising Analyst, he was also an elected member of the Center for Advanced Psychoanalytic Studies (CAPS), at Princeton, NJ, for many years, beginning in 1982. Austin is survived by his wife of almost 60 years, Diana, his son, Michael Silber (Lisa), his daughters, Elizabeth Amiel, M.D. (Rick Levy), and Madeline Silber (Paul French), his sister, Joy Stevens (Corrine Netzer), his brother-in-law, Lloyd Heyman, and his grandchildren, David, Lauren, Eitan, Maytal, Ruby, Emilia, Stacie, Kerrie, Elise. A man with a heart open to many, he was loved and revered by family, colleagues, students, and patients. Memorial donations may be made to Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 8th Avenue, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001.

The Obama administration appointed a compensation czar on Wednesday who will have broad discretion to set the pay for 175 top executives at seven of the nation’s largest companies, which received hundreds of billions of dollars in federal assistance to survive, The New York Times’s Stephen Labaton reports from Washington.

Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the architect of AT&T’s rebirth as the largest American telecommunications company, will now try to restore the glory of another institution, General Motors, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic writes.

A number of conservative Republicans remain in high dudgeon over the Obama administration’s handling of the economy — and, in particular, the way it has dealt with the bailouts of General Motors and Chrysler.
With the touch of pen to paper and a simple wire transfer, Chrysler completed its deal with Fiat on Wednesday morning, largely ending its quick trip through bankruptcy.

Chrysler appeared poised to emerge from bankruptcy by early Wednesday after the United States Supreme Court declined Tuesday to hear a challenge by three Indiana state funds and several consumer groups to the sale of most of its assets to Fiat, The New York Times’s Michael J. de la Merced reported.

E*Trade Financial is in talks with Citadel Investment Group, the hedge fund that is its largest shareholder, about a deal to shore up the struggling brokerage firm’s balance sheet, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

Without excessive promotion or unnecessary postponement, Fox broadcast the scheduled episode of its medical drama “Mental” on Tuesday that featured one of the last screen performances of David Carradine. In an eerie twist of fate, Mr. Carradine played a patient who is nearly catatonic; he spends large portions of the episode confined to a wheelchair, rarely verbalizes and never speaks. While we didn’t completely understand the motif of the lightning-filled fantasy land that his character occasionally drifts off to, and we wish some of his fellow actors had exercised similar restraint, the episode was a reminder of what a strangely transfixing performer Mr. Carradine could be without having to utter a single word. (The following scene may contain spoilers if you haven’t watched the entire episode.)

Despite its economic struggles, New York City Opera has signed a new contract with its musicians, the Web site of Musical America reported. In a statement, City Opera said that it had come to terms on a two-year contract with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the members of the New York City Opera Orchestra; terms of the contract were not disclosed. The company has not yet agreed on a new contract with the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents its singers; the current agreement is set to expire next year.

Last week the Dave Matthews Band released its new album, “Big Whiskey and the GrooGrux King” (RCA), with an extensive marketing push that included a live concert broadcast on Hulu.com and the Fuse cable channel. It paid off: “Big Whiskey” opened at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart by a wide margin, selling 424,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Eminem’s “Relapse” (Interscope) fell to No. 2 after two weeks on top, with sales of 141,000. The rock band 311 is No. 3 with 60,000 sales of its new “Uplifter” (Volcano). Chickenfoot, a new rock supergroup featuring former members of Van Halen, is No. 4 with 52,000 sales of its self-titled debut, barely more than Green Day’s “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise). The soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) is No. 6 with 50,000, and the Long Island band Taking Back Sunday opens at No. 7 with 48,000 sales of its fourth album, “New Again” (Warner Brothers).

The House Appropriations Subcommittee on the Interior has approved a bill that sets the annual budgets for the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities at $170 million each for fiscal year 2010. The current appropriation for these agencies is $155 million each and President Obama had requested an increase to $161 million. The new figure is still short of the N.E.A.’s high of $176 million in 1992.

BOSTON — If you’re interested in early music, this is the place to be this week, as it is every second June, when the Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition takes over the city. The festival opened last Saturday, with the production of Monteverdi’s “Incoronazione di Poppea” that is this year’s centerpiece (but not the only opera on the schedule) and runs through Sunday afternoon. But the show really kicked into gear on Wednesday, when the exhibition opened in parts of three floors at the Radisson Hotel.

Arcade Publishing, a venerable independent literary house that has published authors including Octavio Paz, Raymond Chandler, Ingmar Bergman and Shimon Peres, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The company, which was founded by the husband and wife team Richard and Jeannette Seaver, stumbled after Mr. Seaver died in January. The bankruptcy filing in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York listed more than 200 creditors and liabilities of just over $6 million.

Thanks, everyone, for the comments and discussion on the previous post. If you didn't see the Wall Street Journal's recent section on its D: All Things Digital conference, with interviews with Carol Bartz of Yahoo and John Malone of Liberty Media, among others, I suggest you have a look. I found particularly illuminating the Q & A with Malone on how to build revenue online. I came away with the not-too-surprising idea that somehow, eventually, people will be pay for quality content online. They will want to pay if the quality of the information, reporting and opinion is genuinely high, and they will want to because they can't abide the thought of the alternative: more of the same.

"The Pictures Generation," a new show at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, features the work of artists reared in the burgeoning, media environment of post-WWII America. Drawing inspiration from sources such as films, television, magazines and advertising, these artists used representational forms to illustrate the media's influence on individuals and society as a whole. The exhibition covers a decade of artwork from 1974 to 1984 when movements like feminism and gay rights were challenging social constructs.

Sometimes what you do after work can lead to a new career. Take Avery and Janet Glasser. They were just hearty drinkers at a San Francisco bar when a strange sequence of events landed them at Distillery 209, the makers of 209 Gin. There they learned how to mix bitters - liquids made from a distillation of aromatic herbs, barks, flowers, seeds, roots and plants in high-proof alcohol that are used to flavor food, aperitifs and cocktails. Today, roughly two years later, their Bittermens xocolatl mole and grapefruit bitters are available to the cocktail world.

Just a quick note: is it just me, or has the economic news started to darken again? Up through about March, every report was worse than you expected, often worse than you could have imagined. Since then, most reports -- although continuing to be bad in an absolute sense -- have "surprised on the upside." But my sense is that in the last few days we've been getting reports -- Korean trade, Japanese orders, German exports -- that are once again surprising on the downside.

Unless the Indian government makes serious changes to the way it prices and manages water, increased consumption by the nation's farms, factories and growing population will push drinking water supplies to critical limits by 2050, according to a new report from Grail Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., that specializes in developing countries.

The Oakland, Calif., "renaissance" has been touted for so long that one might become incredulous. (Then again, didn't the Italian version last 200 years?) But after a trip to Cafe Van Kleef, the dirty-but-dapper cafe-bar at the epicenter of the downtown scene, you'll need no more convincing that San Francisco finally has a Brooklyn to call its own. The orange sign and rainbow umbrellas that hover above the sidewalk tables emerge from the gray office buildings like a tequila sunrise. And if it's a bit hard to tell whether the people milling outside are cafe patrons or aggressive panhandlers, who cares? Everyone's welcome at Peter Van Kleef's carnivalesque utopia.

Ari Emanuel, who was the chief engineer behind the April merger of two of Hollywood's top talent agencies into the mega-agency William Morris Endeavor Entertainment, has emerged as Hollywood's top power-broker -- a position that has been open for many years, probably since the days that colorful moguls like Michael Ovitz and David Geffen towered over the town. It doesn't hurt, of course, that his brother happens to be Rahm Emanuel, President Obama's chief of staff. But this has left everyone else in Hollywood wondering just what Mr. Emanuel wants and how he will use his power to shape the entertainment industry of the 21st century.

While American retailers struggle to survive the recession, their Chinese rivals, it seems, are enjoying the largesse of the private equity industry's interest. The Deal notes that buyout shops have been busy in the last few months gobbling up minority stakes in some of China's largest retailers.

If you weren't nuts enough after last night's commute home, when a flooded notice board ate all the track numbers in Penn Station, leaving train workers making announcements with bull horns for the people who weren't getting them from Clever Commute, well, the 6:50 a.m. Midtown Direct train from Summit had to drop off its passengers in Secaucus because of mechanical problems. Let's hope that doesn't cascade through the system all morning long.

Tim Floyd suddenly resigned as basketball coach at Southern California on Tuesday following allegations that he gave $1,000 in cash to a man who helped steer the former star player O. J. Mayo to the Trojans.

Minnesota Vikings stars Kevin Williams and Pat Williams are being improperly singled out for extra testing for steroids, their lawyer says. Peter Ginsberg, the lawyer, said he filed papers in Hennepin (Minn.) County District Court asking Judge Gary Larson to say the N.F.L. cannot treat the Williamses differently from other players while the court battle over their suspensions continues. Ginsberg said the players are being tested at least three times a month, in excess of what the testing policies allow.

A 17-year-old California resident who reached the summit of Mount Everest has become the youngest person to scale the tallest peaks on each of the world’s seven continents. Johnny Strange, a senior in high school who resides in Malibu, Calif., reached the top of Everest, 29,035 feet, on May 20. He reached his seventh summit on June 8 when he scaled Australia’s 7,310-foot Mount Kosciuszko.

The Army-Navy football game will be held in Philadelphia for five of the next eight years, including in 2010. The Naval Academy announced that the annual game between the service academies would be played at Philadelphia’s Lincoln Financial Field in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2015 and 2017.

Mike Tyson is married for a third time, two weeks after the death of his 4-year-old daughter. The owner of the La Bella Wedding Chapel at the Las Vegas Hilton hotel-casino said Tyson, the 42-year-old former heavyweight champion, and Lakiha Spicer, 32, exchanged vows Saturday in a private ceremony. Records in Las Vegas show that Tyson and Spicer got a marriage license about 30 minutes before their ceremony.

The Obama administration marked with little fanfare a major milestone in its bank rescue effort - its decision on Tuesday to let 10 big banks repay federal aid that had sustained them through the worst of the crisis - as policy makers and industry executives focused on the challenges still before them, The New York Times's Eric Dash reports.

They have elegant knives, porcelain dishes that start at $1.50 and simple slicers for around $35. There’s hand-crafted plastic sushi ($8.30 to $38.90 a piece), as well as real edibles, like organic tamari, $26.50 for two quarts, and earthy purple sweet potato vinegar ($33.20 for 16.6 ounces), which also comes honey-sweetened ($39.70 or $9.40 for four ounces) and is good in iced tea.

A sketchbook containing 33 drawings by Pablo Picasso, estimated to be worth between $8.4 million and $14 million, has been stolen from a Paris museum, officials said Tuesday. Thieves seized the crayon drawings, dated 1917 to 1924, from a first-floor exhibition room of the Picasso National Museum in central Paris sometime between Monday and Tuesday. Two paintings by Picasso estimated to be worth a total of about $66 million were stolen from the Left Bank home of his granddaughter Diana Widmaier-Picasso in February 2007.

If this doesn’t finally settle the question of whether Anvil is a real band, nothing will: that hard-rocking Canadian group, whose career is chronicled in the documentary “Anvil! The Story of Anvil,” will open for the heavy-metal band AC/DC at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass., on July 28, and at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on July 31, the bands’ publicists said in a statement. Anvil, founded in Toronto in the 1970s, enjoyed a short-lived American success in the 1980s with albums like “Hard ’N’ Heavy” and “Strength of Steel.” The group recently re-entered the cultural consciousness with the “Anvil!” documentary, directed by the screenwriter Sacha Gervasi, though the movie has also prompted the occasional (mistaken) conclusion from viewers that the band is an elaborate, Spinal Tap-style hoax. “Anvil! The Story of Anvil” is scheduled for a DVD release this fall.

A two-year investigation of religious artifacts and relics found in the home of an Illinois collector in 2007 has determined that 1,600 of them were stolen, the Web site ChicagoBreakingNews.com reported. On Monday federal officials announced the result of its investigation into the collection of John Sisto, who after his death in 2007 was discovered to have kept more than 3,500 works in his bungalow in Berwyn, Ill., including documents written by kings and popes and the preface to a book handwritten by Mussolini. An F.B.I. spokesman told the Web site that the stolen items, one shown above, were believed to be worth between $5 million and $10 million and were to be returned to Italy later this week. The F.B.I. said there would be no American criminal prosecutions stemming from the theft, transportation or possession of the items.
On Tuesday, 19 Recordings, the music division of 19 Entertainment, which produces “American Idol,” announced in a news release that it had signed Adam Lambert.

The rock band Depeche Mode resumed its world tour on Monday night after coming off the road so that its lead singer, Dave Gahan, right, could recuperate from cancer surgery, BBC News reported. In May the band canceled a performance in Athens, Greece, just before showtime, when Mr. Gahan, 47, fell ill in his dressing room. Initially he was given a diagnosis of severe gastroenteritis, but later learned that he had a malignant tumor in his bladder. The band subsequently postponed or canceled 12 dates in Europe to accommodate Mr. Gahan’s surgery and recovery. On Monday Depeche Mode played its first show since Mr. Gahan’s operation in Leipzig, Germany, where he thanked his fans and “all of the doctors who looked after me so well,” according to the BBC.
The night’s most-watched show was a rerun of the CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men.”

If you could bring anything from Amsterdam with you to New York, what would it be? Of course you’d choose the New Island Festival, an Americanized version of two annual Dutch arts celebrations that will be coming to Governors Island in September. In a statement, the festival’s organizers said that it would run from Sept. 10 to 13 and Sept. 17 to 20, and would include more than 100 concerts and performances. Participants will include the Dutch director Ivo van Hove (“Opening Night”) and his Toneelgroep Amsterdam theater company; the festival will also feature the American debut of Silent Disco, a dance party in which everyone wears headphones. A full listing of free and paid events is expected in the coming weeks.

With kinetic-like fusion, Dwight Howard and Hedo Turkoglu timed the play to perfection. It could not have been scripted. Its result could not have been more urgent. As Turkoglu deftly flicked his wrist, Howard twisted his body. Suddenly, Andrew Bynum was defending nothing but air. With power and conviction, Howard sent the basketball down through the net, a chain result that started with a steal and ended in an alley-oop, an Orlando favorite that had gone largely amiss in the N.B.A. finals.

A grenade killed 2 people and wounded 56 in a crowded market in Kunar Province on Tuesday morning, but there were conflicting reports as to who threw it. The head of the provincial council said that he had spoken to dozens of the wounded, who said that an American soldier had thrown the grenade into a crowd gathered around a stalled American military vehicle in Asadabad. But the American military and the Afghan Interior Ministry said remnants of the grenade showed it was a Russian-made model typically used by insurgents.

At various stages in life, a person faces a challenge that can be turned into an opportunity: an abrupt career change, a devastating health problem, an ideological shift that shakes one's very identity. Such a challenge can be desperate and overwhelming, but those who have the courage to face it, those who motivate themselves endlessly to fight through it, can ultimately move from struggling self to truthful self. These transformations are what I will explore over the next six weeks in still photographs and videos that I call ''Second Chance.'' The videos are online at nytimes.com/cityroom.

A day after its members narrowly rejected a package of wage and benefit cuts, the Boston Globe's largest union filed a complaint on Tuesday with federal regulators, challenging the 23 percent pay cut the newspaper had set in motion. The union, the Boston Newspaper Guild, also called on The Globe and its owner, The New York Times Company, to resume negotiations rather than carry out the unilateral wage reduction.

RABBAN--Meyer, age 90, died at home in NYC on June 8th. He is survived by Elana, his beloved wife of sixty years, and his loving children, David, Miriam and Jessica, Jessica's husband, Matthew Schofield, and their two children, Rebecca and Benjamin. He was a member of the Psychology Faculty at Sarah Lawrence College from 1949 to 1988. During his career at Sarah Lawrence, he was also the Director of the Windward School from 1955 to 1961 and a teacher in the evening program of the Bank Street College of Education from 1950 to 1960. He directed summer programs at Bronx House Emmanuel Community House from 1952 to 1959 and at Camp Rainbow from 1960 to 1978. He was the National Administrative Secretary of the American Student Zionist Federation from 1939 to 1942. He served with the United States Army in Europe from 1942 to 1946. After the war, he was on special duty at Bad Ischl, Austria to assist the resettlement of survivors of the Matthausen and Ebensee concentration camps. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Scholarship Fund of Sarah Lawrence College, the New Israel Fund, or the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

BOE--Roy, 79, of Fairfield, CT, loving husband of Betty, father of Susan, Roy L.M., Jr., Mandy, Jeremy, Todd and Kate, grandfather of six, brother of Gigi, passed away June 7. The memorial service will be at 1pm, Saturday, June 13 at St. Paul's Church, 661 Old Post Rd., Fairfield, CT.

VEGA--Julia. The family of Leonard Bernstein mourns the passing and celebrates the extraordinary life of Julia Vega, who died at age 91 on June 7 after stomach surgery. Born in the foothills of the Chilean Andes, Julia eventually became a U.S. citizen and a true cosmopolitan. As the Maestro's housekeeper who helped raise the three Bernstein children, Julia was fiercely beloved by all who experienced her gracious housekeeping, her lively conversation, her legendary cooking and prodigious horticultural prowess. Funeral services will be held on Thursday morning, June 11, at 10 am at the Church of St. Francis de Sales in Manhattan.

O'BRIEN--Robert O.,musician, beloved son of the late Joseph and Margaret, died April 21, 2009 in Columbia, South Carolina. His early love of music led to a distinguished career as arranger and band leader in the U.S. military. He is mourned by Geoffrey, Carly, Heather, LaVerne, Yasoko and Harriet.

ROSEMONT--Franklin. Memorial for Franklin Rosemont 1943-2009 at The Newberry Library in Chicago on July 11 at 12-3pm. Founder of Black Swan Press; publisher of Arsenal: Surrealist Subversion; editor at Charles H. Kerr; series director University of Texas Press. Inspired by Andre Breton who he met in Paris and surrealism, he published books on Joe Hill, Jacques Vache, surrealism and the African Diaspora and Wrong Numbers.

The defendants in Germany's largest terrorism case in a generation announced in a Düsseldorf courtroom on Tuesday that they were ready to confess to plotting a series of deadly bombings. The trial was expected to last two years and had been billed as the biggest terrorism case since leaders of the far-left Red Army Faction were prosecuted in the 1970s. But on just the 15th day of the proceedings, the accused abruptly shifted tactics.

SHELTON--Blossom A.,after a brief illness, passed away Tuesday, June 9th in her sleep. On the day before her death, when asked her age by a doctor, she replied "Privileged." We respect her wishes. She leaves behind a daughter, Elizabeth K. Shelton, a son, B. A. Shelton, sister, Sandra Zanger, brothers, Seymour and Howard Leichman, loving nieces, nephews, in-laws and friends. Air France, facing pressure from some of its pilots after the crash of one of its airliners last week, has decided to immediately replace airspeed sensors on all of its Airbus A330 and A340 jets, union representatives said Tuesday. After an airline union urged its members to refuse to fly planes in which the sensors had not been replaced, the company decided to replace at least two of the three sensors, known as Pitot tubes, on all A330 and A340 flights starting Tuesday, a union spokesman said. The Brazilian Air Force said it had recovered a total of 41 bodies from the crash; the flight was carrying 228 people.

She is survived by her siblings, Betsy Martin of Pittsburgh, PA and Bill Bell of Brooklline, MA, seven grandnieces and nephews, and their 14 children. Memorials suggested for Animal Haven or Amnesty International.

A familiar face appeared in the Dodgers' clubhouse in Los Angeles on Tuesday afternoon. Manny Ramirez, who is about halfway through a 50-game suspension for violating baseball's performance-enhancing drug policy, spoke with members of the news media for the first time since his suspension began May 7. ''I'm ready to move on,'' Ramirez said, sitting in front of his locker. ''I didn't kill nobody, I didn't rape nobody. That's it. I'm going to play the game.''

He has guided the Foundation in its mission of supporting education, social service, the arts and medical research.

South Korea imposed its first financial sanctions on North Korean companies, officials said Tuesday, a largely symbolic action against the North for its recent nuclear test. The Ministry of Strategy and Finance said that it had banned trading with the Korea Mining Development Trading Corporation, Tanchon Commercial Bank and the Korea Ryongbong General Corporation, and that it would freeze their assets. But officials said the sanctions would have no practical effect because those firms had no trade with South Korea or assets there.

Recession or not, music festivals of various sizes and persuasions are plentiful now, as they are every spring. The TriBeCa New Music Festival is modest in scope: its four concerts are presented at the Flea Theater, which seats only 75. But from a programming point of view, it has big ambitions, reflected in a handful of young, energetic ensembles and music by nearly all the hottest New York composers under 40.

MILLER--Sylvia. Born Sylvia S. Price in the Bronx on July 22, 1924 into a loving family of three brothers and three sisters, all of whom are deceased. Their names, according to age were Melville, Beatrice, Lenore (called Leslie), Roberta, Morton and Larry. Sylvia's main course of study and practice was opera as a soprano. She was awarded several scholarships to the Aspen Institute in Colorado. She married Harry Miller on August 7, 1960 and always lived in the Westside to allow walks to attend opera performances at Lincoln Center. Sylvia died after an extended illness on June 7, 2009. She is survived by her loving husband Harry, her nephew Eric Price, his wife Ailian, their son Ian F. Price and sister-in-law Lisbeth Price, as well as several great-grandnephews and nieces. A visit to the website of MellvillePrice.com will provide more comprehensive discussion of her and her family.

8 P.M. (HBO2) LETTERS TO THE PRESIDENT (2009) Two days before the Iranian presidential election, which takes place on Friday, HBO2 presents the first of three documentaries focusing on that country. This film by Petr Lom, who has a Ph.D. in political philosophy from Harvard, captures Iranians' impressions of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, above, as he travels the countryside and encourages citizens to write him letters telling of their misfortunes. According to a member of the president's staff, he has received about 10 million letters and has responded to three-quarters of them -- a figure the film claims is propaganda. Mr. Lom visits the Presidential Letter Processing Center in Tehran, where the letters are read by Basiji students, members of a religious paramilitary group. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Topics include getting a job, do-it-yourself weddings and life after cancer. Martha Stewart and M C Hammer are guests. Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere discusses his new book, ''Causing a Scene.''

Rafael Nadal said Tuesday that he would travel to London next week while rehabilitating his injured knees and that he would ''give my 200 percent to be ready'' to defend his title at Wimbledon. The state of Nadal's knees has been the talk of tennis since he lost in the fourth round of the French Open, his only defeat there in 32 career matches. Nadal's Web site said he had undergone 36 hours of ''in-depth medical tests'' to pinpoint the problem, which his doctor said was tendinitis in both knees.

In 1992, Ariel Zev Emanuel, a young operative with the struggling InterTalent agency, had a problem with the rent on a $639-a-month walk-up in the city's modest Fairfax district. The landlord took him to court seeking eviction, and won. Today, Mr. Emanuel has a $10 million home in the Brentwood neighborhood; a pipeline to the White House through his brother Rahm, its chief of staff; and a sprawling new talent agency of his own design, called William Morris Endeavor Entertainment.

BIANCO--Alfred J. It is with deep sorrow that Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague, Alfred J. Bianco. Al was recognized as one of the leading finance, restructuring and financial derivatives lawyers in the country. Al received his LL.M. from Columbia University School of Law, his LL.B. from Fordham University Law School, where he served as Comments Editor of the Fordham University Law Review, and his B.S. from Georgetown University. FEINBERG--Harvey Bertram, M.D.,age 81, of Manhattan and Craryville, NY, passed away on June 9, 2009 after a gallant struggle with end-stage pulmonary disease. A graduate of the University of Bern medical school, he joined the staff of Mt. Sinai Hospital where he served for over forty years as a pediatric and adolescent psychiatrist. He also worked both in private practice and as a psychiatric consultant to the Jewish Child Care Association, the 92nd Street Y, and various courts hearing custody cases, among others. Beloved brother, husband, uncle, father, father-in-law and grandfather, he will be sorely missed. Voracious newspaper reader and occasionally avid golfer, his tenacity, loyalty, kindness, perspective, and humor will live on. Services will be held on June 10 at 12:45 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

WOLFE--Robin Nelson, 65, died peacefully at home. He was a graduate of Lafayette College (where he was a member of their undefeated College Bowl team) and Columbia Law School. He practiced law for almost 40 years before his retirement from the firm of Kantor, Davidoff, Wolfe, Mandelker & Kass. He was a skilled and tenacious litigator. He is survived by his daughter, Thais, his dear friend and companion, Ann Partlow, and his brother Steven. He loved his family and friends, history, travel, the arts, playing poker and a good joke. He could be stoic in the face of adversity and his best years were during his retirement when he traveled to places yet unseen by him and left the cares of the practice of law behind.

Yoshiko Chuma's new 90-minute work, ''Not About Romanian Cinema: Poonarc,'' which opened on Thursday night at Danspace Project, is a feast of beautiful and strange images and sounds. There are spliced black-and-white snippets from films by Rudy Burckhardt, Cristi Puiu, Hiroki Oiishi and others, the ghostly, romantic footage playing out largely on movable white screens attached to the metal cube frames that have become a hallmark of Ms. Chuma's work with her company, the School of Hard Knocks/Root Culture. (The images sometimes expand to fill the larger space of St. Mark's Church, like restless spirits.)

General Motors is close to a deal to sell Saab, the Swedish carmaker, to Koenigsegg, a manufacturer of high-end sports cars that is also from Sweden, a person close to the negotiations said Thursday, The New York Times’s Carter Dougherty reports from Frankfurt.
Fiat will set a new direction at Chrysler, which finished its tour through bankruptcy court Wednesday, completing its deal to join forces with the Italian automaker.

The Italian automaker Fiat took management control of Chrysler on Wednesday, in a sale that occurred 42 days after Chrysler sought bankruptcy protection. Now the company can restart operations. The New York Times’s Micheline Maynard answers some questions about Chrysler’s future.

By investing billions of dollars in General Motors and Chrysler, the government “saved hundreds of thousands of jobs” and gave the carmakers a chance to be “viable, competitive American businesses” again, a leader of president Obama’s auto industry task force testified Wednesday.

President Obama flexed his political muscle back in March when he sought, and received, the resignation of Rick Wagoner, the chairman and chief executive of General Motors. But when it came time to find a permanent replacement for Mr. Wagoner as chairman, being a loyal Democrat didn’t seem to have been much of a priority.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Even in airports, it was easy to spot people bound for Bonnaroo on Thursday morning, as I was. They had the rainboots, the backpacks and the Grateful Dead T-shirts: prepared for changeable weather and ready to party.
Now that First Lady Michelle Obama has returned to the United States, she plans to kick off a new music series next week, according to the White House.

The Greek government on Thursday declined an offer from the British Museum to loan Greece a long disputed collection of stone objects widely known as the Elgin Marbles, Agence France-Presse reported. On Wednesday, Hannah Boulton, a spokeswoman for the British Museum, told Greek Skai Radio that the museum would consider loaning the Elgin Marbles to Greece for three months, in advance of the opening of the new Acropolis Museum in Athens.

St. Ann’s Warehouse, an innovative theater that has been a major cultural player in Brooklyn for nearly 30 years, must find a new home now that its 14,000-square-foot space in Dumbo is scheduled to be turned into an apartment complex and school, artistic director Susan Feldman said this morning.

Lending credence to the theory that it is just as good for one’s career to lose on “American Idol” as it is to win, the contestant Allison Iraheta has signed a recording contract with the entertainment company behind the reality series. On Wednesday, 19 Recordings, a division of 19 Entertainment, which produces “Idol,” said in a news release that it had completed a deal with Ms. Iraheta, 17, a spunky singer from southern California who placed fourth on the most recent “Idol” season. Her debut album will be released on Jive Records, which is also slated to release the first album from “Idol” winner Kris Allen. Adam Lambert, who was the show’s runner-up this season, has also struck a similar deal with 19 Recordings and RCA. So far, no album deal has yet been announced for Danny Gokey, who placed third.

The artist Andrew Kuo breaks down “Crime Pays” by the Harlem rapper Cam’ron, which debuted at No. 3 on the Billboard chart last month, as well as his recent record-release show at the Highline Ballroom in New York. Enlarge here.

The anticipated Broadway revival of Stephen Sondheim’s “A Little Night Music” is expected to go into a Jujamcyn theater this fall, with an announcement forthcoming soon about details of the production, according to two members of the creative team.

Michael Thomas has won the International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award for his debut novel, “Man Gone Down,” his publisher said in a news release. The award, sponsored by IMPAC, a Dublin-based productivity improvement company, comes with a prize of about $140,000. Mr. Thomas’s novel, published in the U.S. in 2007 by the Black Cat imprint of Grove/Atlantic, tells the story of four desperate days in the life of a black writer struggling to support his wife, who is white, and their three children. Other books on the prize’s shortlist included “The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao” by Junot Díaz and “The Indian Clerk” by David Leavitt.

You can cross “My Name Is Earl” off TBS’s to-do list. When that sitcom, which starred Jason Lee as a bad seed attempting to right the wrongs he’s committed in his life, wasn’t renewed by NBC for its coming fall schedule, reports surfaced that TBS was in discussions to produce new episodes of the show. Unfortunately for fans of “Earl,” Twentieth Century Fox Television, the studio that produces the show, said in a statement Thursday that a deal with TBS could not be worked out. The full statement from Fox appears below.

The acclaimed Off Broadway production of “Fela!” will transfer to the Eugene O’Neill Theater, with the first preview scheduled for Oct. 19 and an opening night of Nov. 23, the show’s publicist announced Thursday evening.

Now that the 2009 Tony Awards are over, all eyes are on the new Broadway season that ramps up in the fall. Among other things to chew over is whether the 2009-10 season will see a continuation of strong new plays and play revivals, or if the balance will tip toward musicals.

The investment banker Gary W. Parr has been a player in mopping up some of the biggest financial messes of the last year. Among his assignments, count Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Fannie Mae and Bernard L. Madoff.

BOSTON — The schedule at the Boston Early Music Festival has always been solidly packed, not least because it’s really two festivals in one: the main festival has always presented its opera production as well as high-profile programs by international artists, often three concerts a night, at 5, 8 and 11 p.m. But the daytime, in past years, was given over to the exhibition and master classes, among the official events, and to the Fringe Festival: a huge slate of concerts associated with the main festival (and listed in its book) but presented by individual organizations in churches and galleries. Many are local performers; others come from around the country. Tickets for many of these concerts are free; others are under $20.

BOSTON — I felt a little guilty skipping the harpsichord installment of the Keyboard Mini-Festival, because I had learned earlier Thursday morning that the instrument and its makers are facing tough times. Kathleen Fay, the Boston Early Music Festival’s executive director, mentioned that in past years as many as 23 harpsichord builders had crowded into the festival’s exhibition spaces, but this year there are only three (although one, Harpsichord Clearing House, represents several makers).Why the precipitous drop?

Over on Media Decoder Elizabeth Jensen reports that PBS is facing more economic challenges. It said Thursday that it had reduced its staff by 10 percent, or about 45 positions, and would impose a 3.85 percent pay cut on employees beginning July 1.

This week: Ben Ratliff reviews “The Eternal” by Sonic Youth; Jon Pareles discusses “Hombre Lobo: Twelve Songs of Desire” by Eels; and the Low Anthem performs “Ticket Taker” live in our studio and talks to Ben Sisario about naming its album after Charles Darwin.

On Wednesday’s episode of “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart,” viewers may have noticed a segment (in between Mr. Stewart’s fueling of a feud with MSNBC’s Joe Scarborough and John Oliver’s coverage of the Guantánamo detainee Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani) about this news organization. In the segment (which bore the somewhat pessimistic title “End Times”), correspondent Jason Jones visited the offices of The Times, interviewed Times executive editor Bill Keller and assistant managing editor Richard L. Berke, and marveled at our antiquated landline phones.

Forestalling Michael Jackson‘s ability to sabotage his own shows, a concert promoter in New Jersey has filed suit against the King of Pop, saying that the singer breached an agreement to perform in a reunion concert this summer, The Associated Press reported. In a lawsuit filed Wednesday in Manhattan federal court, the promoter, Allgood Entertainment, said it made a deal with Mr. Jackson’s former manager to produce a reunion concert with the Jackson family this summer. According to the terms of the deal, the promoter said Mr. Jackson was not allowed to perform elsewhere before the event or for three months after.
What we’re reading on Thursday morning.

Bunch of Grapes, the Martha’s Vineyard bookstore that was badly damaged in a fire last summer, has obtained a new owner and will reopen this season. Founded in 1975 by a former nurse in the town of Vineyard Haven, Mass., the independent bookstore was damaged during the Fourth of July weekend in 2008 when a fire broke out at a nearby cafe, and its owners said it would remain closed for the foreseeable future. In a news release, Dawn Braasch, the new owner of Bunch of Grapes, said that the store would hold a ribbon cutting ceremony at its traditional Main Street location on Saturday at 9 a.m. The store will resume its author event series on July 3 with David Kinney, the author of “The Big One: An Island, an Obsession, and the Furious Pursuit of a Great Fish,” and a grand reopening celebration is planned for July 4. Ms. Braasch, the bookstore’s former events coordinator, bought the store from its previous owner, Jon Nelson, about six months ago, according to Steve Fischer, the executive director of the New England Independent Booksellers Association.
Fire and meat join science and technology at the humble backyard barbecue.
Some of the best memories are made during summer and you’ll want to capture those memories with the right camera.
Although you can't improve on nature, you can grab some of the newest tech gear designed to enhance the way you experience it.
Netbook computers, virtually a novelty alternative to notebook PCs only a year ago, are the rising stars of the computer industry.
Some of the stars of the quickly evolving smartphone scene, where the iPhone is the star, but others are catching up.
Alzheimer’s and dementia patients at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale receive much-needed stimulation and a chance to socialize.
Daryl Wein’s documentary about the onetime AIDS activist Richard Berkowitz is a polemic against societal amnesia.
“Food, Inc.” is an activist documentary about the big business of feeding Americans all the junk that multinational corporate money can buy.
Campaigning comes to an end in the hotly contested presidential election in Iran.

Several years ago I walked into a room of Giacometti figures at the Museum of Modern Art and suddenly understood how to see sculpture. Gaunt and insistent, the figures drew everything unessential from what surrounded them. The negative shape of the space between the figures became a positive space.
This Friday by Patrick Berry was easier than usual; it took me just a third of the time that last Friday's by Martin Ashwood-Smith did. Or maybe I'm somehow three times faster than I was last week.
“Moon,” presents a vision of life beyond Earth that emphasizes claustrophobia and loneliness.
An Oregon town may have to go back to marketing itself as a ghost town after a fight with a wealthy history buff over the water supply.

BlackRock said Thursday night that it had agreed to acquire Barclays Global Investors from the British banking giant Barclays for about $13.5 billion in one of the largest deals in the money management industry, creating a juggernaut with nearly $3 trillion in assets, The New York Times's Michael J. de la Merced reports.

Update | 10:07 a.m. | Saturday, June 12 Thanks to all readers in Iran who have been sending us comments on the presidential election and the aftermath in your country. We would like to renew our call for readers of our Web site in Iran to share their experiences of the Iranian presidential election, and the dispute over the results, with us. If you went to the polls on Friday, or attended a rally or protest on Saturday, please send us your comments or photographs or alert us to where you are posting them online.
It is all too familiar.

Carol Bartz, Yahoo's chief executive, has tapped Tim Morse, chief financial officer of the chip maker Altera, to be the Internet company's new chief financial officer. The announcement caps a four-month search to replace Blake Jorgensen, the current finance chief, whose plans to leave were announced in February during a corporate reorganization engineered by Ms. Bartz.

The South Orange Maplewood Board of Education has, by way of silence, officially denied tenure to principal Tom Gibbons. The board had three days after Monday night's hearing to meet and overturn its earlier decision not to renew his contract. But the day ran out without the board taking action, meaning Mr. Gibbons will be replaced next year as head of South Mountain Elementary School and Annex. An e-mail sent to Mr. Gibbons seeking comment was not immediately returned. -- ALEX LOWTHER

The investment banker Gary W. Parr has been a player in mopping up some of the biggest financial messes of the last year. Among his assignments, count Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Fannie Mae and Bernard L. Madoff.
Art and scenes from the 53rd version of the venerable Biennale.
From Tim Arango at Media Decoder:

In May, video game sales fell to $863 million, down 23 percent from the same period a year ago, according to the NPD Group, which tracks domestic sales performance. Sales of hardware (consoles and hand-held devices) dropped 30 percent while sales of software fell 17 percent, to $449 million.

NBC's Kelly O'Donnell reports on a landmark bill that will empower the Food and Drug Administration to regulate cigarettes and other tobacco products. 
(Video: NBC Nightly News)

BOSTON - The struggling Chien-Ming Wang will get another start for the Yankees, but possibly no more after that. Manager Joe Girardi said he told Wang that the Yankees expect positive results from him next Wednesday against the Washington Nationals, with the underlying message that his job will be on the line.
Anyone who has watched a lot of tennis lately has seen the AT&T commercial where a newsman initially implies that he can hit a faster serve than Andy Roddick.
Ford Motor's chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, said Thursday that the automaker would continue to take action to improve its balance sheet so it could become profitable in 2011.

The Times' Media Decoder blog has a post today with Local interest, about America Online's purchase of Patch Media Corp., which was also described on the Millburn Patch site here. Proving that all news is indeed local, one Maplewood blogger, Kirk Petersen, was quickly on the story, as was the All Things Digital blog, which posted internal memos about the sale. AOL's CEO, Tim Armstrong, was described as the principal investor in Patch, a collection of websites covering Maplewood, Millburn and South Orange, among other towns, back when he was an executive for Google.
The World Health Organization raised its alert level to Phase 6 because of the continuing spread of the H1N1 strain of the flu virus and declares it the first global flu pandemic in 41 years.
A comparision of recent residential sales by region and price range.
Now that First Lady Michelle Obama has returned to the United States, she plans to kick off a new music series next week, according to the White House.

Alibay Barkley, the hard-swinging slugger from Manhattan's George Washington High School whom we profiled a few weeks ago, kept tabs on baseball's first-year player draft through most of 49 rounds. Having seen enough and heard too little on Thursday afternoon, he took a shower.
New York is home to several buildings that began life as garages with mansion affiliations.
Seton Hall University's Sean Black was drafted to the New York Yankees yesterday,in the seventh round, during Day 2 of the Major League Baseball draft. He was the 225th overall draft choice.

Based on his teammates' comments, Mark Sanchez should expect to spring for the check for the foreseeable future. He spoke to reporters on the last day of a mandatory minicamp at Florham Park, N.J. It was also the day after he reached contract terms with the Jets.

President Obama defended his idea for a government-sponsored health insurance plan at a town-hall meeting in Green Bay, Wisconsin.
(Video: MSNBC)
In Southport, a lush waterfront enclave in Fairfield County, streets are lined with Greek Revivals that evoke the plantation style of the south.

The New Jersey Nets may not have gotten final approval or the financing for their proposed $800 million arena at the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, but the team has rounded up another lucrative sponsorship deal, with Haier, the giant appliance manufacturer from China.
From the Media Decoder blog. We recently wrote about Patch in an article on local news sites, which are drawing a lot of attention from publishers and advertisers.

We're sure that President Obama and his Jewish advisers will be happy to know that Mr. Obama's former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., has "clarified" his remark to The Daily Press of Newport News this week -- that he had not spoken to the president because "Them Jews aren't going to let him talk to me." This seemed to be a reference to the likes of Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff and David Axelrod, the senior presidential adviser.

Another N.H.L. coach has gone, replaced by one who has had his share of dismissals as well. Today the Stars said goodbye to Dave Tippett, their coach for six seasons, and replaced him with former Nordiques/Avalanche, Canucks and Kings coach Marc Crawford.
Students (and, it should be noted, reporters) with a deadline hanging over their head have a deviously brilliant new delaying tactic.

My wife and I are planning a four-week cross-country trip from Pennsylvania by minivan in July. We would like to visit national parks. Any recommendations? Our plans include either motels or camping, light hiking, taking pictures and driving less than 300 miles a day.

The Hollywood Reporter has an article up online that says that DreamWorks finally has verbal commitments for, and will begin closing formal agreements to receive, $325 million in loans to back pictures to be distributed by Walt Disney.
When a product has become commoditized and its price is regularly dropping and its profit margins are getting ever-thinner, how can a company boost its sales and raise its prices?

Flow of funds data out today. I won't have time to do a careful analysis for a few days, but a quick check shows that the Setser point -- high government borrowing is more than offset by net negative borrowing from the private sector -- remains true.

ALBANY -- In the latest strange turn in state politics, the man Gov. David A. Paterson appointed last month to take over the embattled Commission on Public Integrity asked the governor on Thursday to withdraw his request for the commission's other 12 members to resign. The commission is the state's top ethics and lobbying oversight panel.
A large study found the anti-nausea drug metoclopramide did not harm babies when given to women early in pregnancy.

PBS, facing a $3.4 million budget shortfall in its coming fiscal year, said Thursday that it had reduced its staff by 10 percent, or about 45 positions, and would impose a 3.85 percent pay cut on employees beginning July 1.
Really. Eating moules frites, walking the (partly faux) medieval streets, thinking of Henri Pirenne.
This is a simple little story to illustrate what I hope is a useful point.

What: An outdoor reggae street party to celebrate the opening of Jeanette's, an East London designer store conceived by the gender illusionist James Main. Better known as Jeanette, Main was the door girl for the club Boombox, served as a muse to the designers Giles Deacon and Gareth Pugh, worked as a stylist for Dazed & Confused and i-D magazines and occasionally moonlighted as a hairdresser to Grace Jones. Jeanette's is housed in a minimal, post-industrial space and offers a cool mix of men's and women's items by designers like Louise Grey, Kim Jones, Christopher Kane, James Long and Richard Nicoll. The portrait of a nude transgendered plumber called Pia adds a unique touch to the decor.

A Stuyvesant High School librarian has been arrested and charged with harassment and sexual abuse, after he was accused of inappropriately touching four male students, city investigators said on Thursday.
America Online, the soon-to-be jettisoned unit of Time Warner, bought two small Web sites Thursday - one of which was partly owned by Tim Armstrong, AOL's chief executive.

Thanks to citizen journalist Yury Pronin for sending in these pictures from the Glenwood Elementary School Strawberry Festival yesterday in Short Hills! And thanks, Alex Lowther, for putting it together.
Been waiting until the health-care debate entered the playoffs before you finally started to tune in? O.K., time to tune in.
Have questions about the Millburn Township municipal budget? Now is the time to ask. The budget is scheduled to be discussed and voted on at the June 23 township committee meeting.

The short grass-court season is moving along without the injured Rafael Nadal and the still-elated Roger Federer. At Queen's Club in London, where Nadal had planned to defend his title, the top-seeded Andy Murray easily ousted Guillermo Garcia-Lopez, 6-4, 6-4, and Andy Roddick stopped Lleyton Hewitt by 7-6 (2), 7-6 (4) to reach the quarterfinals (which will be shown live on the Tennis Channel, starting at 7:30 a.m. Eastern).
There are terrible perils abroad. But a photographer who also found himself in harm's way on Thursday was Nathaniel Brooks - at the New York State Capitol in Albany.
As some of you may have heard by now, Jean Hugel, the longtime head of Hugel & Fils, died on Tuesday at the age of 84. (Read his obituary here.)

One of the more bizarre connections uncovered by a Google search for James W. von Brunn, the chief suspect in the fatal shooting at Washington's Holocaust Museum on Wednesday, was an apparent correspondence between Mr. von Brunn, an 88-year-old white supremacist, and Tom Clancy, the mega-best-selling military thriller writer.
In a striking contrast to previous years when a powerful tobacco lobby held considerable influence, the Senate on Thursday approved giving the government vast powers to regulate tobacco products.

In the aftermath of Wednesday's shooting at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, the New York Police Department has mobilized units to protect Jewish-related sites across the city.

Doctors often complain they don't have enough time for conversations with patients in person, let alone through online social networks. But in today's Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen argues that tweeting, friending and blogging may add real value to patient care.
Should doctors give out diagnoses or prescribe treatment on Facebook, in the twitterverse or on blogs?
An interview with Brian Greene and Alan Alda on the connection between art and science at the World Science Festival.
When I saw that the current iPhone would remain in AT&T's lineup at a reduced price of $99, I thought, "Who would want an iPhone that is half the speed of the newest model?"

PARIS | It's not every museum that features a compost heap and encourages children to scribble on the artwork. This museum has neither a ceiling nor doors, and is intruded upon by a slightly scruffy garden. But the Musée des Graffiti (295 rue de Belleville, métro Télégraphe, free entry, material provided) is the brainchild of the utopian designer Yona Friedman, and he's not your average curator.

As someone who writes about deals, I find it oddly satisfying to see members of Congress asking questions about material adverse change clauses. Perhaps these members even understand the questions they are asking about them. But I have no doubt that the person they questioned Thursday about these MAC clauses -- Bank of America's chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis -- is quite conversant in their nuances. For he is using the MAC clause as a keystone in a masterful game of spin.
Twitter is seeing a surge in activity from the scamming and spamming classes.

Updated, 3:52 p.m. | Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a longtime supporter of the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced Thursday that he was endorsing Mr. Morgenthau's rival, Leslie Crocker Snyder, to become the next district attorney.
General Motors has ended production of the 2010 Chevrolet Malibu Hybrid, reports The Associated Press, citing slow sales and a backlog of inventory.
While President Obama was speaking in Wisconsin, senators were struggling to assemble health care legislation they hope to push through two committees this month.

Seatguru.com, which offers detailed charts on the best and worst airplane seats, released a new survey that ranks airlines based on food quality, seat comfort and politeness of flight attendants. Not surprisingly U.S. airlines ranked far behind international carriers in most categories.
Update | 3:22 p.m. A second message, below, was sent out around 3 p.m.
More than 60 years before he burst into the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington and opened fire with a rifle, killing a security guard, James W. von Brunn lived in New York City.

The upcoming Art Basel and just-opened Venice Biennale have some scrappy, sidewinding competition this year, and New Yorkers needn't book a seat in first class to find it. Last weekend heralded the return of Bushwick Open Studios and inaugurated the Bushwick Biennial.
Cavett engages Jonathan Miller again.

GREEN BAY, Wisc. -- President Obama strongly defended his idea for a government-sponsored health insurance plan at a town-hall meeting here today, saying "if the private insurance companies have to compete with a public option, it will keep them honest and it will keep -- help keep their prices down."

Here's one fact about Julius Genachowski, President Obama's nominee to lead the Federal Communications Commission: Pretty much everyone from big phone companies to telecom reform groups likes and respects him. It's hard to find any pocket of opposition to his nomination.
The College Point Yacht Club welcomes blue-collar members, as long as they're willing to work in the boat yard.

For as long as we can recall -- and that's a long time -- very little happened in the N.H.L. during the Stanley Cup finals apart from the final itself. But not this year; an inordinate amount of news from elsewhere has poured in almost daily. So let's get caught up with ownership issues, starting with the legal wranglings in Phoenix.

A 300-year-old waterfront village need not apologize for its quaint quotient, but Bay Shore, on Long Island, evinces a noncutie-pie quaint: It's a place where you can get a customized tattoo and the air smells of garlic, clams, coffee and barbecue. A haute couture spa carved from a 1917 bank building that is reminiscent of the one in "It's a Wonderful Life" coexists with a pottery co-op conjured from a vacant storefront. So dress down, not up. Get in the mood for trout and eggs or wedding cake-size Belgian waffles for brunch. Eat, shop, stroll, indulge: all without leaving Main Street.
Who: TokyoMilk

Update | 4:05 p.m. Riverstone Holdings, a private energy fund and business partner the Carlyle Group, agreed on Thursday to pay $30 million to resolve its role in a widening public pension fund inquiry by Andrew Cuomo, the New York attorney general, The New York Times' Leslie Wayne reported.

On April Fool's Day, the Washington City Paper put up a parody of the Huffington Post that was remarkably executed. Big-link news item at the top? Check. Blog feeds? Same. Navigation tabs? Nailed it. It was a sweet bit of digital cloning that got some bounce for a day of foolery and then receded into archival mist.

Fox's "So You Think You Can Dance," ABC's "Wipeout," and NBC's "I'm a Celebrity Get Me Out of Here!," three reality shows involving three very different kinds of physical competition, faced off in the ratings during the same time period on Wednesday. According to Nielsen's estimates, Fox's dancers fared the best over all, winning the contest of contests with an average of 8.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m.

Less than a day after the Obama administration announced a plan to set executive pay levels at bailed-out companies like Citigroup and Bank of America, a dispute broke out among members of a House panel over the issue of regulating corporate compensation.

Kenneth D. Lewis, the chief executive of Bank of America, testified before a Congressional committee on Thursday that he was pressured by the government late last year to buy Merrill Lynch, Louise Story of The New York Times reported.
One of the subplots of the tumultuous last six months has been a new kind of cold war between Washington and Europe.
In this slow-motion video, vortices form as a maple seed rotates in a smoke-filled wind tunnel.

The national Nielsen numbers for Conan O'Brien's first week as host of NBC's "Tonight Show" are in, and it was a dominant performance, especially in the younger audience categories where NBC hoped he would maintain leadership after the departure of Jay Leno.

Bank of America's chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, testified Thursday before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, which is looking into his bank's acquisition of Merrill Lynch. Mr. Lewis told lawmakers that he was pressured by the government to complete the deal. DealBook's Zachery Kouwe live-blogged the hearing, with the most recent posts at the top:
GREEN BAY, Wisconsin -- There was a rare sight along the motorcade route as President Obama arrived here Thursday to talk about health care: a protest.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

Some economists expressed healthy skepticism about last week's Labor Department report showing that the pace of job losses had eased sharply in May. Some of the slowdown was a result of a statistical adjustment that the department makes, and such adjustments can turn out to be fleeting. The report was also based on a survey that was done before the General Motors bankruptcy plan -- which calls for more than 20,000 job cuts -- was announced.

Apple announced and demonstrated all kinds of things this past Monday at its developers' conference: upgraded laptops, a new iPhone, a new iPhone software suite for all iPhone owners, its new Mac OS X 10.6 "Snow Leopard" operating system, and so on. Lots of goodness, for sure. But to me, one of the most mind-blowing revelations was a single statistic: 29.
Apple intends to charge current Leopard owners $29 for the Snow Leopard version. The company sells millions of copies of Mac OS X. So why on earth would it leave so much money on the table?
A byproduct of wood-pulping, used as a fuel.

In the last two weeks, since Judge Sonia Sotomayor was introduced by President Obama as his choice for the Supreme Court, her voice has seldom been heard. But a trove of video interviews and speeches of hers dating back nearly 25 years shed new light on her views. She provided the videos to the Senate Judiciary Committee last week as part of the materials under review by panel members before her confirmation hearings begin July 13.

Stephen Colbert continued to score strong ratings with his second night of programs from Baghdad. The special edition of his "Colbert Report" on Comedy Central attracted 1.4 million viewers, about 25 percent above his average for 2009. (His first night, Monday, was watched by 1.6 million.)
The question for Dr. Robert S. Siffert was what he thought of Judge Sonia Sotomayor's taste in art - his art.
Updated, June 11, 6:55 p.m. | Rabbi Abraham Cooper of the Simon Wiesenthal Center discusses what Web providers can do about hate sites.

In the South Orange Maplewood School District, the numbers are climbing for students absent from school with flu-like symptoms. Maplewood Health Officer Robert Roe announced that the absences "were well above normal, especially at Seth Boyden Elementary School."

Following is the second set of answers from Michael Jones-Correa, a political scientist at Cornell University. This week he is responding to readers' questions about contemporary Latino immigrants in New York and their politics, both in the city and in relation to their countries of origin.

The Local is raising a pint (of strawberries!) to Jonathan Rosen, a fourth grader at Glenwood Elementary School in Short Hills, our youngest (so far) Citizen Journalist. Here is his review of yesterday's Strawberry Festival:
If Venus Williams was disappointed with her third-round exit at Roland Garros, a glance at tennis history books might cheer her up a little.
From the Pride Fest this weekend, to the Festa Italiana in July to the Wisconsin State Fair in August, the streets of Milwaukee are packed with festivals until Sept. 13.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Edward Whitaker, the former chairman of AT&T, was appointed the new chairman of General Motors. I'm not sure about his business plan. He's giving away free cars on nights and weekends. I think that's a bad idea.

In his Monday post here at Green Inc., James Kanter wondered what it would take to get the developing world to sign a climate change deal. Besides cash, some suggest that any accord must ensure developing countries have access to the proprietary mitigation technologies -- that is, the intellectual property that companies in the developed world are creating to fight global warming -- at bargain basement prices.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Sarah Palin called David Letterman "pathetic." Did you hear? She did. She called David Letterman "pathetic" because of a joke he told. I'm like, David Letterman is my boss. I have got his back, Mrs. Palin, unless you'd won the election. Then Dave would be on his own. But that's show business. That's the way things are.
Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the "Late Show," a division of Fiat.

When fresh basil hits the market, as it has in recent weeks, I want to grab a bunch and start cooking. One of my favorite uses is soupe au pistou, the Provençal creation that combines legumes, vegetables and a strong but pared-down version of pesto (no more than basil, garlic and oil) to produce a gutsy, hearty soup.
The actor is playing “Hamlet” in London.

At the age of 78, Bob Branham, a retired computer software developer in Dallas, Tex., took up quilting. It wasn't his idea, actually. He'd never dreamed of piecing together his own Amish diamond coverlet or rummaging around Jo-Ann Fabrics in search of calico prints. But then he enrolled in a trial sponsored by the National Institute on Aging to assess whether learning a new skill can help preserve cognitive function in old age. By random assignment, he landed in the quilting group.
After writing this week about the link between marriage and better sleep, I heard from several skeptical readers who were the long-suffering bed partners of snorers.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Today, Chrysler was taken over by Fiat and the new C.E.O. said, this is a quote, "Going forward we intend to build on Chrysler's culture of innovation." Yeah. Yeah, then he laughed for three straight hours.

The native tongue of style insiders might sound like gibberish to the casual listener. (Adam Kepler, the assistant to T's editor, Stefano Tonchi, once wrote for The Moment about confusing Miuccia Prada with a cartoon about Mexican wrestlers.) But to industry diehards, the correct pronunciation of the style directory is as important as the right shoe.

A new study of the evolution of the H1N1 strain of influenza virus that moved from pigs to people this spring and has since spread worldwide reveals the need for taking a "one health" approach to humans and the animals around us, experts suggest.
Location: Athens, Ohio.

These days AT&T knows a great deal about its customers: who they call, where they travel, what they watch on TV, what sites they visit on the Web. It has taken a new shot at explaining to them what information it collects and why in a new privacy policy that it posted Thursday morning. The policy is a draft that in 45 days will replace the 17 policies now used by its various subsidiaries.

Jeff Z. Klein answered readers' questions on Thursday about the Stanley Cup finals, which go to a decisive Game 7 on Friday night in Detroit. Klein, who was back in the office for a few hours before heading off to Joe Louis Arena for the big game, has written most recently about Penguins defenseman Rob Scuderi's brilliant defensive play late in Game 6 and about Marian Hossa, who left Pittsburgh for the Red Wings after last year's finals. If the Red Wings win, the championship will be their 12th; the Penguins are seeking their third title.

Can an animal ponder what-might-have-been and learn to change behavior accordingly? Or, as researchers put it, can animals engage in "fictive learning"? Lab readers had plenty to say in response to my post and my Findings column on the topic of animal regret. Now, as promised, one of the experts responds to readers' questions and comments.
Randy Wedin is a chemist, blogger, science writer and single father of four sons, living in Minneapolis. (He has also been a guest here on Motherlode before.)
A spate of daylight robberies has struck pharmacies across the city, and police believe the same two men are to blame.

If you want to advertise your patronage of NPR or your commitment to recycling, you're pretty much stuck with an unbleached canvas tote as your billboard. But fans of the newly opened High Line, the elevated railroad trestle-turned-green space on Manhattan's West Side, have an embarrassment of fashionable options.
Goldman Sachs' profit machine is in high gear, according to a Wall Street analyst who nearly doubled his quarterly earnings estimate for the securities firm.

Everywhere you looked this week, there was the Brammo Enertia electric motorcycle. There it was in The Times's Automobiles section on Sunday. There it was again, on "Good Morning America," and on Fox Business News. And on quite a few other sites as well.

Yesterday on Twitter, a digital kingdom that includes avatars, faux identities and parodies, a tweeter known as @Jack_Welch offered some rather bracing analysis on The New York Times approach to labor negotiations with The Boston Globe.

From time to time, confronted with an odd bit of news, words fail The Lede. When that happens, we turn to you, the readers, to help us make sense of the images that come to us over the news wires. This week we are puzzled by what to say about the image above, which features two recognizable personages but one unusual detail. Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to demonstrate your command of recent, and not-so-recent, events to answer the question Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi may have been tempted to ask Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi when he met him at the airport in Rome on Wednesday: Hey Muammar, what's with the photograph?

The new Green Carts, produce stands that the city has helped set up in neighborhoods with little access to fresh fruits and vegetables, got an enthusiastic reception from residents, Glenn Collins reports.
Bishop Nicholas A. DiMarzio, 64, the leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, is scheduled to undergo heart bypass surgery next week.
Six men and women talk about life with cystic fibrosis.

Paul Poiret was the Yves Saint Laurent of his day. In the early 1900s, he threw extravagant parties and became so famous that he was invited to show his collection at the British Prime Minister's residence. His clothes - innovative, elaborate pieces of draped and billowing fabric - sold for vast sums. In 1911, Poiret launched his perfume collection, named for his oldest daughter, Rosine. The Chanel people chafe when it's mentioned, but I believe Poiret indeed preceded Coco Chanel by a decade as the first fashion designer to launch a fragrance.When Poiret hung up his uniform after World War I, he found the house - then in competition with the clean-lined, sporty new designers like Chanel - almost bankrupt. He was in debt, his business partners abandoned him. The house closed in 1929. Poiret died in poverty.

An 18-year-old who has profound mental disabilities was sentenced to 100 years in prison after pleading guilty to charges in a sexual abuse case involving his 6-year-old neighbor. The teenager, Aaron Hart, was arrested and charged after a neighbor found him fondling her stepson in September. He pleaded guilty to five counts, including aggravated sexual assault and indecency by contact, and a jury decided his punishment. Judge Eric Clifford in Lamar County said neither he nor jurors liked the idea of prison for Mr. Hart but felt there was no other option. “In the state of Texas, there isn’t a whole lot you can do with somebody like him,” Judge Clifford said. Mr. Hart has an IQ of 47 and was diagnosed as mentally disabled as a child. He cannot read or write and speaks unsteadily.

ANKERSON--Robert, died peacefully on June 9th at the age of 75. He is deeply mourned by his beloved companion of 22 years, Herta Z. Frawley, and is survived by two sons Robert Jr. of Cambridge, MA, and Sam and his wife Emily of Burlington, VT, and by two grandchildren, Hannah and Ivy. Born in Mount Vernon, NY, he graduated from Dartmouth College and served in the Navy before beginning a career in publishing and executive recruiting. He had a lifelong love for jazz that gave him great joy and will be remembered for his integrity, his humor, and his warmth and kindness to others. The funeral will be at Good Ground Cemetery in Hampton Bays, NY, on June 13.

Panasonic has taken the wraps off two new camcorders that weigh a feathery eight ounces and shoot video at the full high-definition resolution of 1920 by 1080 pixels. The difference between the $550 HDC-SD10 and the $600 HDC-TM10 is that the SD10 uses an SDHC/SD card for memory while the TM10 has eight gigabytes of built-in memory as well as a slot for SDHC/SD cards. The TM10 can shift from recording to the built-in memory to an SD card when the built-in memory is full, resulting in uninterrupted recording. Both will be available in September.

WOLFE--Robin Nelson, 65, died peacefully at home. He was a graduate of Lafayette College (where he was a member of their undefeated College Bowl team) and Columbia Law School. He practiced law for almost 40 years before his retirement from the firm of Kantor, Davidoff, Wolfe, Mandelker & Kass. He was a skilled and tenacious litigator. He is survived by his daughter, Thais, his dear friend and companion, Ann Partlow, and his brother Steven. He loved his family and friends, history, travel, the arts, playing poker and a good joke. He could be stoic in the face of adversity and his best years were during his retirement when he traveled to places yet unseen by him and left the cares of the practice of law behind.
PICINIC--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Picinic, associated with The New York Times from May 12, 1986 until retiring on April 1, 2008.

Six officers from the Metropolitan Police Service have been suspended or placed on restricted duty after being accused of mistreating suspects during a drug-related raid last November, the police said on Wednesday. The police would not give details about what the officers, from Enfield, in north London, are alleged to have done.
