FRYE--Dorothy Rumsfeld, of New York City and New Canaan, CT, died June 3, 2009, of lung cancer. She was 75. Mrs. Frye, known as Dee, was born in Oak Park, IL, June 26th, 1933, the daughter of Herbert W. Rumsfeld and Dorothy Amos Rumsfeld. She grew up in the small farming community of Naperville, IL, and graduated Monticello College and the University of Illinois. She married ClaytonWesley Frye, Jr., in California in 1957, and they lived in Menlo Park, CA, until 1970, where she was active in the Peninsula Volunteers. They relocated to San Antonio, TX and then to New Canaan, CT and New York City, in 1973. Her husband was the longtime senior associate of the late Laurance S. Rockefeller, the association that brought them to New York. She was on the Board of Directors of the New Canaan YMCA, and the Board of Directors of the Women's Bible Society of New York. She was a long-time member of the Board of the Friends of PS 169 and co-chair of the school's tutoring program, where her dedication and commitment enriched the lives of many emotionally disturbed and learning disabled students, and inspired the volunteers who served with her. She was also active with Bible Study Fellowship in New York City for many years, and served as a Children's Leader. Dee was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, who loved her family with all her heart. Those who knew her were touched by her genuine kindness, warmth and grace. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, a daughter, Diane Frye Tanner of New York City, and three granddaughters, Carolyn M. Tanner, and Charlotte Halloran and Sydney Halloran, both of Weston, MA, as well as many beloved nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her eldest daughter, Carolyn Frye Halloran, who died of brain cancer in 2000. She was also preceded in death by her two brothers, Dr. H. William Rumsfeld of Dallas, TX and Dr. John A. Rumsfeld, of Corona del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Carolyn Frye Halloran Fund, Massachusetts General Hospital, Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Boston, MA, 02114. A memorial service is pending.

An anti-abortion leader says his group may try to buy the now-closed Wichita abortion clinic owned by a doctor who was shot to death last month. The leader, Troy Newman, the president of Operation Rescue, said on Wednesday that his group, which had long fought to close the clinic, was considering trying to buy the squat, beige building to perhaps turn it into a memorial museum, ''a tribute to the babies.''

SIMONS--David Patrick, died on May 29, 2009 after a three and a half year struggle against cancer that can only be described as valiant and courageous. He was 38 years old. He was brilliant but bore his brilliance lightly without ostentation. He had a great wit which he used to entertain and never to wound. A talented writer, his book Love Song for W, his postings on Metsgeek.com and his blog were marvels to all who read them. Even greater than his many talents was his warm and loving nature. Fifteen years ago he married Erika Lewis and, as he remarked recently on their anniversary, "officially became the luckiest man on the planet." He was also a devoted son to his mother, father and stepfather being all that any parent could ever ask or wish for. He is survived by the above as well as his brother Kevin and his three sisters Tracey, Kim and Amy. He and his seven nieces and nephews--Olivia, Luke, Catherine, Tess, James, Ellie and Lucy--together formed a bond of mutual adoration that was wonderful to behold. While he has departed from this earth, he leaves his family and friends with memories that will never die.

BENSON-WILLIAMS--Dr. Belinda, of Miquon, PA, on May 22, 2009. Age 68. Beloved wife of the late Robert Irwin Williams. Survived by her sons Mark Daniel and Craig Tyler, daughters-in-law, Chihirro and Andrea, grandson, Asa Jackson, sisters Muriel Brantley, Beverly Davis and Barbara Johnson, brothers-in-law, Glen Brantley, Ronald Davis, and Dr. Warren Johnson and a host of nieces and nephews. Relatives and friends are invited to her gathering from 1- 2 p.m. on Saturday, June 13th from the Heritage Chapel at George Washington Memorial Park, 80 Stenton Ave. Plymouth Meeting, PA. Services will be held at 2 p.m. Kirk & Nice. www.kirkandnicefuneralhomes.com

AUSTIN--John, M.D.,64, Oakland, California resident. Died in an airplane accident on May 29, 2009. Dr. Austin was a pioneer in bringing high-quality health care services to rural communities. He was the founder, executive chairman and chief medical officer of Arcadian Management Services, an Oakland California-based provider of high-quality, cost-effective administrative infrastructure and management services to health care provider groups, hospitals and health plans. Since 2005, Arcadian Health Plan has continued to live his vision to provide health care needs of traditionally under-served members of rural communities, with 46,000 members in 11 states. As a young doctor, Dr. Austin worked in the Haight-Ashbury Free Clinic in San Francisco and, later, helped develop Rockridge Clinic, one of the early community health plans in the Bay Area. He went on to serve other health care companies in executive roles for more than 20 years. Dr. Austin also was a dedicated conservationist. Most recently, he restored Boulder Creek Canyon Ranch in Utah to have the ranch placed under conservation easement; it now is preserved in perpetuity as an organic working ranch. Dr. Austin received his undergraduate degree and M.D. degree from the University of California in San Francisco, and his Masters in Public Health from Harvard University. Described as a "Renaissance Man" by friends, Dr. Austin excelled not only professionally, but also at most trades mechanic, carpenter, electrician and plumbing. He was well-read, and found the time to continue to read and learn, to accrue knowledge deeply and broadly. Dr. Austin is survived by his loving wife, Jacqui Smalley. A memorial service to honor Dr. Austin will be held on Saturday, June 13, 2009 from 1pm to 4pm at the Claremont Country Club, 5295 Broadway Terrace, Oakland, California. To reach the Claremont Country Club by phone, please dial 510-653-6789. At the family's request, anyone wishing to offer expressions of sympathy may do so by making a donation in the name of Dr. Austin to: Boulder Community Foundation PO Box 1351, Boulder, UT 84716 http://www.bouldercommunityalliance.org/happenings/happenings.html Please make checks payable to: Boulder Community Foundation.

You can laugh at the new Jitterbug J mobile phone as an attempt to make Gramps a bit more hip. Samsung has modernized it just a touch -- sort of like trading Pop-Pop's cardigan for bootcut jeans. New features include Bluetooth, a forthcoming calendar function and unlimited calls to a live registered nurse any time of night or day for $4 a month. A $9-a-month package called ''Jitterbug Complete Care'' offers LiveNurse, roadside assistance and no-questions-asked handset replacement. The company is also planning new pay services, like reminder calls that tell people when to take their medicine.

BERRY--Thomas (1914-2009), Passionist priest and internationally recognized historian of cultures, died on June 1st, 2009 at Well-Spring Retirement Community, Greensboro, North Carolina. His writings and lectures on the relation of humans with the cosmos and the earth have notably influenced the intellectual and spiritual history of the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Originally named after his father, William Nathan Berry, founder of Berico Fuels Company (1924), this second of eight sons in a family of thirteen children adopted the name Thomas (after philosopher-theologian Thomas Aquinas 1225-1274) following 1933 entry into the Passionist Religious Order. Thomas began doctoral studies in history at the Catholic University of America, writing on the historical theory of Italian philosopher- historian Gianbattista Vico 1668-1744, published by the Catholic University of America Press in 1951. Thomas's awards include seven honorary doctorates; the United States Catholic Mission Association Award (1989); the 1992 James Herriot Award of the Humane Society of the United States; Honorary Canonship of the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine (1992); the 1993 Bishop Carroll T. Dozier Medal for Peace and Justice; the Catholic University of America Alumni Award for Research and Scholarship (1993); the 1992 Prescott College Environmental Award; annual Thomas Berry Lecture Awards established, respectively, by the College of Mt. St. Vincent on the Hudson and, in Washington, DC, by the Center for Respect of Life and Environment and the Humane Society of the United States; a Thomas Berry Hall and Thomas Berry Seminars at Whidbey Institute on Whidbey Island near Seattle, WA. Funeral services will be held in Greensboro, NC and Jamaica, New York with internment at Green Monastery in Greensboro, Vermont. .

With so many terrific, bandwidth-hogging applications on smartphones, it is handy to be able to connect through the speedy Wi-Fi network instead of your slower cellular data connection. But where do you find Wi-Fi on the go? That is what WeFi is for. An app that runs on Android, Nokia and Windows Mobile phones, WeFi locates Wi-Fi hot spots and can connect you automatically.

The body count among officials in Russia's volatile North Caucasus region keeps rising. A high-ranking judge was the latest to die, killed Wednesday when a group of men sprayed machine-gun fire on the van she was riding in, a day after President Dmitri A. Medvedev visited the region to condemn the violence. The killing underscored Russia's failure to contain the violence of separatists and Islamic militants. Despite Russian officials' occasional rosy pronouncements of successes, these forces remain a potent source of instability in a region that has known little peace in recent decades.

PAY LIMITS PLAN A federal proposal to restrict executive pay has the potential to humble large institutions that received bailout money, and an official was named to oversee compensation at those companies. Kenneth R. Feinberg, appointed by the Obama administration as the compensation official for companies on federal assistance, has experience in mediating complicated disputes. [B1.]

Hideki Okajima fired a fastball past Johnny Damon to climax the eighth inning, slapped his left hand against his red glove and dashed off the mound. For the usually stoic Okajima, it was a lively display. Okajima struck out three of the five batters he opposed in the seventh and the eighth, twice stranding runners and helping the Red Sox defeat the Yankees, 6-5, on Wednesday night at Fenway Park. The Red Sox have defeated the Yankees in seven straight games, a streak that might have fizzled without Okajima.
More than 10,000 South Koreans rallied Wednesday against President Lee Myung-bak, with many urging him to step down.

For now, the No. 1 draft pick Stephen Strasburg has some modest plans: go on vacation, relax and don't hurl a baseball 100 miles an hour at anyone for a while. Before he thinks about doing so again, his agent will try to wring a record signing bonus out of the Washington Nationals. The agent, Scott Boras, set the stage for that Wednesday, calling Strasburg a premium-level player, the kind who presents ''little to no risk'' to a team if it signs him to a big contract. Boras also said Strasburg's value should not be measured against other No. 1 draft picks but against players who have entered the league in other ways. Pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka, for example, was given a six-year, $52 million contract when he signed with the Boston Red Sox out of Japan before the 2007 season.

Heavy morning fog was blamed for a chain-reaction crash on Wednesday involving some 30 vehicles on Interstate 15 in California near the summit of the Cajon Pass in the San Bernardino Mountains. At least 15 people were injured, and wreckage was scattered for a half-mile.

Computers bulge at the seams with photos, documents, music and videos. The cautious may want to back up all that priceless data. Nero's new BackItUp & Burn software offers plenty of places to park copies of those files: hard drive, discs, network server, flash drive and even an online storage vault. Nero BackItUp & Burn guides first-time users through setting up a backup session, but it offers more advanced controls for experts who want to manually adjust options like compression and encryption settings. The program, which runs on Windows XP and later versions, can also make a disaster recovery disc of your operating system to get the computer up and running again after an unfortunate incident.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Like a long jam-band set, Bonnaroo eases into gear with its Thursday opening, keeping its biggest stages dark and putting on what amounts to a night of warm-up acts. The early arrivals are already primed, though. I’m used to New York audiences, who only respond after carefully gauging peer response and music quality; Bonnaroo crowds are more instinctual; if the music grooves, they join in.

Continuing his tradition of staging surprise installations in unexpected locations, the British artist Banksy has staged another surprise installation in an unexpected location, BBC News reported. His latest stealth project, which officially opens on Saturday, turned up in the City Museum and Art Gallery in Bristol, England, about 120 miles west of London. Though the museum is traditionally home to artwork and artifacts commemorating Bristol’s maritime history, Banksy filled it with animatronic exhibitions, paintings and a rusted ice cream van.

Norm Macdonald hasn’t had a new movie to promote since the turn of the millennium, and has no current television roles to speak of (unless you count his occasional appearances on “Million Dollar Password”). But on “The Tonight Show” on Thursday night, Mr. Macdonald, the acerbic comedian and long-ago “Saturday Night Live” star, demonstrated why the late-night shows still book him in the first guest’s slot — and why hosts like Conan O’Brien keep him around after the commercial break.

If the next James Bond movie ends with 007 defeating a megalomaniacal villain by catching him in a contradiction during a tense television interview, now you know why: Peter Morgan, the playwright and screenwriter of “Frost/Nixon” fame, is one of three writers who have been signed up to write a new James Bond film, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Morgan, the author of political dramas like “The Queen” and “The Deal,” will be joined on the project by Neal Purvis and Robert Wade, who have written the last four James Bond films including “Casino Royale” and “Quantum of Solace.” The film, still untitled, will be James Bond’s 23rd official screen adventure; it is expected to star Daniel Craig as the secret agent and be released in 2011.

Katzenjammer, the group from Oslo that David Byrne picked to open the afternoon he curated for Bonnaroo’s That Tent (there are also This and The Other), was a band of four smiling women, three with big flowers in their hair, one (they took turns) playing a bass balalaika.

This week’s hardcover list is crammed with graphic novel adaptations of literary works. At the very top of the list is “Storm Front,” the first in a series of graphic novels based on Jim Butcher’s Dresden Files books about Harry Dresden, a Chicago detective who’s also a wizard. In his introduction for the book, Mr. Butcher discusses the first comic he bought with his own money. The rest is history: he became a comic book fan and, he writes, he always pictured the Dresden character as a comic book hero. Now he is one.

There have been 58 homicides in the District of Columbia so far this year, down more than 20 percent from this point in 2008. And while every murder is a tragedy among the victim's immediate circle, we all know that few cases -- unless the deceased happens to be a government intern -- even register on the consciousness of society at large. Not so the death of Stephen T. Johns, a 39-year-old "gentle giant" of a man who was shot dead shortly before 1 p.m. on Wednesday. It was not who Johns was that landed his name on front pages around the country, it was what and where he was that mattered: a security guard at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. And while any museum shooting is inherently a big news event, the hot-button nature of this particular institution and the whacked-out beliefs of the alleged killer, James W. von Brunn, not only assured full-press coverage but led to all manner of tangential debate on everything from gun control to British politics to Internet ethics.

Back in the day, my old friend James Surowiecki used to write a blog for Slate every Friday, in which he dashed off snappy little items about the week's business -- to prepare readers for cocktail chatter over the weekend, he used to say. Now that Mr. Surowiecki is an august columnist (and blogger) for The New Yorker, he doesn't stoop to such entertainments anymore. But I'm happy to stoop!
The latest effort from casual game maker PopCap is simple, fun and addictive.
Who knew people were brewing beer in their basements in Maplewood?
Once again, former President George H.W. Bush, known also as "41" (for the forty-first president) or "Poppy" as he was affectionately called, marked his birthday with a skydive.

There is no credible evidence, not even unsourced rumors, that Dell is trying to buy Palm. That hasn't stopped a bit of Web chatter, spurred in part by a report by a Collins Stewart analyst, Ashok Kumar, that that is exactly what Dell should do with the $1 billion it just raised selling bonds. (Palm has a market value of $1.9 billion.)

Mark Teixeira was unaware that John Henry had posted, "The MT curse?" on his Twitter account after the Boston Red Sox halted the Yankees for the eighth straight time on Thursday night. When I asked Teixeira about Henry's posting, I had to explain it to him because he had not read it.
We made it -- just in time.

The Managed Funds Association, a major trade group for the hedge fund industry, has hired the powerhouse K Street lobbying firm Brownstein Hyatt Farber Schreck to press its interests on Capitol Hill, according to a document filed this week with the Senate Office of Public Records.

In this weekend's Travel section, Joe Nocera, who writes the Talking Business column for the Times, bikes along the back roads of Provence, exploring the French countryside and the towns of Avignon, St.-Rémy-de-Provence and Arles. Not all went smoothly - there were a few wrong turns and an unfortunate run-in with the local police at one point - but sublime moments like an impromptu picnic by the side of the road, with cheese bought from a store in the morning and pears picked from a roadside tree just moments before eating, made this leisurely journey a memorable one.
Mark Bittman finds a new use for peanut butter in a hearty, exotic chicken soup.

With the Mets at Yankee Stadium this weekend, it might be a good time for Jerry Manuel and Joe Girardi to compare notes. Girardi, the Yankees' manager, misled reporters about injuries on a number of occasions last season. The tension that caused reached a peak in late September, when Girardi told disbelieving reporters that he never asked Mariano Rivera what was wrong with him when Rivera left the team in Toronto to have a magnetic resonance imaging exam on his right shoulder. Girardi is trying to make amends this year and, by all accounts, has been more forthcoming.

Amanda Knox took the witness stand Friday in the trial in which she is accused of killing her roommate in Perugia, Italy, Meredith Kercher. After nearly a year and half of being painted as a wild party girl, it will be intriguing to see how the European press treats her first appearances in court. Judging by the comments posted in response to my piece on the case, many people have a very harsh view of her, and there's a racial component, which I'm not sure I understand.

Pies 'n' Thighs is still closed. After shuttering in January, 2008, the restaurant hasn't been able to set up in the larger Williamsburg space it rented that March thanks to a familiar litany of real estate problems (paperwork, landlords, permit for the smoker). But right now you can taste some of what you've been missing: Carolyn Bane, one of the co-owners, is working in the kitchen of Roberta's in Bushwick, and her fried chicken is on the menu.

The Celebrate South Orange Festival is looking pretty potentially photogenic. Please send any pictures you take during the day, at the Festival or at the SOMe Book Fest, to southmountainlocal@nytimes.com. Deadline 10 p.m. Sunday.
Though Democrats decided to drop a prohibition on releasing photos of detainee abuse from the final war spending bill, the fight over the photos goes on.

I settled on drop siding for the exterior of the cabin. Milled from white pine, drop siding is a variation on the classic clapboard, but lacks the bevel. The pieces fit together, tongue and groove, one on top of the other, with a cove between each board.
A dispatch from my colleague Dennis Overbye:

LONDON | The garden square has long been a feature of London's urban design, a device for linking green spaces with residential areas. There are about 600 garden squares throughout the city, many of which are accessible only to the residents of the surrounding buildings. But this weekend, June 13 and 14, more than 190 of these leafy precincts will be open to the public in "Open Garden Squares Weekend."

The Los Angeles Lakers' overtime victory over the Orlando Magic in Game 4 of the N.B.A. Finals helped ABC rank No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday. Although final audience figures for the live broadcast were not immediately available on Friday, Nielsen's preliminary overnight estimates show ABC's coverage on track to outpace the series' Game 3 audience of 14.2 million viewers, which would make it easily the night's most-watched program by a significant margin.

As I've mentioned before, I have a somewhat generic Gmail address that people often accidentally type into Web forms. That's how I found myself signed up for an account at MyMudSpace.com, the Web's leading social network for people who like driving trucks through mud, also known as "mudding." And that's how I ended up getting a curious e-mail last week, one that no Web start-up should ever find itself in the position of having to send out. It was from Simon Maziarz of Jupiter, Fla., who runs MyMudSpace, and it is best appreciated in full:
The Hometown Game

Net neutrality is a phrase that means a lot of things to a lot of people. Over the last few months, sites like YouTube, Netflix and Digg.com have tethered themselves to Facebook - letting people sign in to their sites using their Facebook user name and password. The tool, called Facebook Connect, has helped to firmly root Facebook at the center of social activity and information sharing on the Web, despite a strong challenge from Twitter.

The police are on the lookout for a man they believe has been robbing elderly men in Manhattan. There have been three such robberies in the past three weeks, during daylight hours in building lobbies and an elevator.

Christine Muhlke, T Magazine's food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.
Representative Patrick Kennedy, who has long battled both addiction and mental illness, has re-entered some type of treatment, according to a statement from his office.
The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn is rolling the dice again in Atlantic City.

DETROIT -- Despite all his honors over a long career, defenseman and captain Nicklas Lidstrom of the Detroit Red Wings has never played in Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals, and he said on Friday morning that doing so Friday night against Pittsburgh would be special.
DETROIT -- Pittsburgh's Ruslan Fedotenko has 14 points in this spring's playoffs, seven of them goals. But the goals he was asked about Friday morning came five years ago in a similar situation.

The board of my co-op in Queens has decided that to save electricity, the roof-mounted exhaust fans for the bathrooms and kitchens will be operated from 6 to 10 a.m. and 5 to 10 p.m. Is this allowed by law, or must the board provide 24-hour active ventilation for the baths and kitchens?

Cara Buckley and James Estrin describe a unique care program at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, N.Y., to address "sundowning," the tendency of patients with Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia to be struck by sleeplessness, agitation and wandering at night:
Does a co-op proprietary lease ever expire? If so, what happens?

I live in a rent-stabilized apartment. My lease ends on July 31, and I asked my landlord to extend it for one month. He told me that because the apartment is rent-stabilized, there isn't much flexibility with the lease - it has to be for either one year or two years.

The Architecture Foundation, the British non-profit group dedicated to promoting innovative urban design, has teamed up with the Tate Modern for a series of six panel discussions called Art + Architecture: Crossover and Collaboration, taking place now through June 25th at the Tate's Starr auditorium. Encompassing both exhibition and debate, the events will bring together an international group of artists and architects, including Vito Acconci and Steven Holl, who kicked off the first debate yesterday with a discussion of their New York collaboration, the Storefront for Art and Architecture, on Kenmare street.
DETROIT -- The Pittsburgh Penguins, with three defeats in Joe Louis Arena in the Stanley Cup finals, have changed hotels again in preparation for Friday's Game 7 against the Red Wings.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Some controversy today surrounding Miss California, Carrie Prejean. She's the one who said she was against same-sex marriage. Some wanted her to be stripped of her title because of it, but Donald Trump, who owns the pageant, said no, she's entitled to her opinion and she'll remain Miss California. Well, today he fired her, which is what he does, I guess. My money says she's a Fox News anchor by the ... by now. By right now.
Ads have been creeping onto magazine covers lately.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Karl Rove called Maureen Dowd of The New York Times a "bitter, twisted, deranged columnist" and a "dour, downbeat liberal" and - more - a "nasty, snarky person." Hey, get a room.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Iran is bracing itself for their upcoming presidential election. President Ahmadinejad is behind in the polls. I think it's because of his campaign slogan, "Vote for me, and I won't cut off your hand."

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Here's big news from the world of TV. And I don't know if you guys are ready for this or not. If you have an old TV, tomorrow, it won't work unless you digitalize it. You've got to get a converter thing and a lot of people are confused about this. For example, earlier today, John McCain wanted to know after the conversion, will his TV dinner still work.

Shares of the Hartford Financial Services Group fell Friday after the big property and life insurer said it would take as much as $3.4 billion of federal bailout money and sell up to $750 million of common stock to bolster capital after large losses on investments.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Fiat, which took over Chrysler this week, says it plans to build its cars with American, not Italian workers. Fiat says they got the idea from the Olive Garden.
Any hockey fan knows that a Game 7 in the playoffs, and especially the Stanley Cup final, is the best attraction in sports. The players make it that way.

For city residents, this cold, damp spring has been a bit of a drag. Farmers, too, have been inconvenienced, losing crucial planting days to rain, and waiting longer than usual for spring crops to ripen.

Want a megazoom in your pocket? You got it if you get Casio's $300 Exilim Hi-Zoom EX-H10. This slender shooter has an ultrawide angle 24mm lens that zooms to 10X, the 35mm equivalent of 240mm telephoto, with an aperture of F3.2/F7.5.

This week: Kate Walbert, author of the novel "A Short History of Women"; Paul Barrett on the Wall Street implosion; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

Extraordinarily high voter turnout in Iran's presidential election drew notice around the world and yielded the lead photos in Friday's slide show. Shooting for The Associated Press in Qum, Kamran Jebreili used the the Holy Shrine of Hadrat Fatima Masoumeh (also known as the Fatimah al-Ma'sumah Shrine) as a backdrop - and not for the first time, either, as seen in the photo at right, from the parliamentary elections in February 2000. Graphically, the shrine is an irresistible setting, with minarets, domes and arches that seem to be echoed in the silhouettes of the voters in the courtyard in the foreground.

Following is the third and final set of answers from Michael Jones-Correa, a political scientist at Cornell University. This week he has responded to readers' questions about contemporary Latino immigrants in New York and their politics, both in the city and in relation to their countries of origin.
Much has been written about the problem of identity theft, but today's Patient Money column focuses on a new version of the problem: medical identity theft.
Matt Lauer of NBC's "Today" show interviews Alaska Governor Sarah Palin about an oil pipeline development, the future of the Republican Party and jokes David Letterman made about her family.

TPG-Axon Capital Management, the $9.7 billion hedge fund run by the former Goldman Sachs partner Dinakar Singh, followed fellow hedge fund titans in posting solid returns last month, according to the firm's latest letter to investors.

Yesterday, Phoebe Philo showed reporters and retailers a selection of clothes and accessories that will begin arriving in Celine stores in late November. It was the first glimpse here of Ms. Philo's designs for the Paris-based company since she was hired last year. The low-key presentation was similar to one in Paris: a long rail of clothes in a Chelsea loft, with informal modeling, and Ms. Philo, dressed in olive fatigues, a black leather jacket and a putty silk blouse, chatting with small groups of guests. It was a smart way to introduce the collection-the isolated debut rather than the big Paris blowout. She'll have a runway show in the fall.

How do the pros transition from clay to grass? There isn't much time, with two short weeks before Wimbledon. By contrast, the clay-court season allows six weeks of tournaments before Roland Garros. The danger on the dirt can be playing too much, as some observers think Rafael Nadal did, leading to his current injury woes. So what do players do to get ready for Queens and Eastbourne and eventually Wimbledon?

"2,200 Degrees Fahrenheit" (03:18)The Bethlehem Steel Corporation was once the second-largest steel producer in the United States, after U.S. Steel. Forged in the company's fiery cauldrons were the towering beams of the Golden Gate Bridge and steel for skylines and tunnels, as well as for thousands of World War II warships, airplanes and artillery.

Microsoft's headline announcement at this year's E3 gaming conference was a motion-detection system housed in a sensor bar that plugs into your Xbox 360's ports. The pull-out-all-the stops unveiling included an on-stage appearance by Steven Spielberg who raved "I think what Microsoft is doing is not about reinventing the wheel. It's about no wheel at all."

The chairman of New York State's embattled workers' compensation system is resigning, less than two years after he was appointed to bring change to a system long criticized for its ineffectiveness. Gov. David A. Paterson's office said Friday that a search is under way for a replacement.

If you wake up tomorrow morning and all your TV channels are gone, I probably know why. Saturday, June 13, is the first day that analog broadcast television is officially history, except for low-power stations. (Some stations have already converted, a few more are doing it Friday.) From now on, all over-the-air TV broadcasts - the channels you watch using an antenna -- are sent out digitally. If this is all news to you, and you haven't any idea what to do next, read on:
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

Democrats are warning that lawmakers who vote no on the upcoming war spending bill could come down with something bad next year - a case of having to explain to constituents why they were against preparing for the return of the H1N1 flu.

I have read every one of the more than 600 responses to Emmie, the young woman - 22, single, unexpectedly pregnant and about to start a prestigious, difficult graduate program - who wrote asking for readers' advice on what she should do. Emmie tells me she has read every word, too.

It's nice to know that readers of this blog are such thrifty bar hoppers! Using your suggestions, I've updated the map to free bar snacks in New York City with your tips, from the tapas at Spain Restaurant (thanks Theresa) to the fresh tater tots at Trash (with nods to Chris).

For those of you who missed Sunday's South Orange and Maplewood Artists Studio Tour, don't despair! While I did not see the first "Transformers" movie and probably won't get around to seeing the sequel when it opens later this month, I have to admit that I am well old enough to remember the original animated TV series celebrating its 25th anniversary this year. To mark the occasion, Kitson in Los Angeles is featuring a line of limited-edition Transformers Classics T-shirts, tanks and hoodies ($38 to $78). The current wave of 80's nostalgia aside, the model above in particular reminded me less of my lost youth than it did that fleeting Prada robot moment (circa 2004) that somehow slipped me by. Whether I am too old to pull off a Transformers T-shirt, well that's another story.

As we've written before, the pace of jobs cuts has slowed markedly in recent months. This is good news for all those workers who didn't lose their jobs in the last few months. It also seems as if it could be a turning point, signaling that the Great Recession may soon end.

Advertising is built on associations. See a red-and-yellow sign, and food companies hope your hunger will be stimulated enough to head their way. Jeep has always associated its brand with the ability to tackle any terrain, but the way it's projected that image has changed quite a bit over the years. In this recent commercial, Jeep compares a drive in the Wrangler to a roller-coaster ride. In the 1980s, the message was the same, but Jeep projected it a little differently, as you can see in the above commercial. Cue the bison...

Having seen enough and heard too little on Thursday afternoon, he took a shower. When he returned, his cellphone was filled with messages congratulating him for being the last player chosen in the 50th and final round. The Angels made Barkley a trivia answer, baseball's equivalent to the N.F.L.'s ''Mr. Irrelevant,'' a label attached to the last player drafted.

In ''Imagine That,'' a harmless trifle of a family comedy, Eddie Murphy plays Evan Danielson, a buttoned-up Denver financier whose 7-year-old daughter, Olivia (Yara Shahidi), forces him to rediscover his inner child. With Mr. Murphy, of course, the inner and outer child are virtually synonymous. When portraying responsible adults Mr. Murphy always signals that his grown-up alter ego is just a pretentious impersonation to be discarded at the first opportunity. Once the mischievous little genie inside him is let out to make mud pies, he can't be stuffed back into the bottle.

Cristiano Ronaldo, soccer's world player of the year in 2008, is set to join Kaká at Real Madrid, completing a groundbreaking outlay of more than $220 million over four days for two of the world's best players. On Thursday, English champion Manchester United announced that it had accepted $131.5 million to sell Ronaldo to Real Madrid. It is the highest transfer fee ever paid in soccer. The move came three days after Real Madrid completed its $92 million bid to buy the Brazilian star Kaká from A.C. Milan.

Smoking has a long history of addiction, disease and deaths, but government efforts to control it have come relatively recently. Tobacco began spreading around the world after Columbus first encountered Native Americans, who smoked and chewed the leaf. Not until the 20th century, though, did cigarettes became the main form of tobacco consumption -- and the most lethal legal products on the market.

FRYE--Dorothy Rumsfeld, of New York City and New Canaan, CT, died June 3, 2009, of lung cancer. She was 75. Mrs. Frye, known as Dee, was born in Oak Park, IL, June 26th, 1933, the daughter of Herbert W. Rumsfeld and Dorothy Amos Rumsfeld. She grew up in the small farming community of Naperville, IL, and graduated Monticello College and the University of Illinois. She married ClaytonWesley Frye, Jr., in California in 1957, and they lived in Menlo Park, CA, until 1970, where she was active in the Peninsula Volunteers. They relocated to San Antonio, TX and then to New Canaan, CT and New York City, in 1973. Her husband was the longtime senior associate of the late Laurance S. Rockefeller, the association that brought them to New York. She was on the Board of Directors of the New Canaan YMCA, and the Board of Directors of the Women's Bible Society of New York. She was a long-time member of the Board of the Friends of PS 169 and co-chair of the school's tutoring program, where her dedication and commitment enriched the lives of many emotionally disturbed and learning disabled students, and inspired the volunteers who served with her. She was also active with Bible Study Fellowship in New York City for many years, and served as a Children's Leader. Dee was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, who loved her family with all her heart. Those who knew her were touched by her genuine kindness, warmth and grace. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, a daughter, Diane Frye Tanner of New York City, and three granddaughters, Carolyn M. Tanner, and Charlotte Halloran and Sydney Halloran, both of Weston, MA, as well as many beloved nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her eldest daughter, Carolyn Frye Halloran, who died of brain cancer in 2000. She was also preceded in death by her two brothers, Dr. H. William Rumsfeld of Dallas, TX and Dr. John A. Rumsfeld, of Corona del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Carolyn Frye Halloran Fund, Massachusetts General Hospital, Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Boston, MA, 02114. A memorial service is pending.
GERTNER--Eric Benard, 67. Beloved husband, brother, brother-in-law, uncle, great-uncle, cousin, friend and devoted member of Ansche Chesed Synagogue, after a brief illness on June 9th.

CANONICO--John, 90, of New York City and Shrewsbury, NJ, passed away on June 9th. After serving in the Army during WWII, he then attended the School for American Craftsmen at RIT. A furniture designer in Monmouth County, NJ, he joined the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1960 as a wood conservator in the Objects Conservation Dept. and was well respected in the museum world for his breadth of knowledge in his field. A table he designed in 1949 was accessioned by the Met in 1978 for their 20th C. Decorative Arts collection. He remained dedicated to his profession for 45 years until his retirement in 2005 at 86. He is survived by his daughters: Carolyn, Vanieta Jill and Shelley and four grandchildren. Online condolences at: www.thompsonmemorial.net.

WORTHINGTON--Reverend Barbara Jeanne DeVall, of Freeland, Washington, died June 6, 2009 in Seattle of complications from breast cancer. She is survived by her husband of 45 years, the Reverend John V. Worthington; son, Mark F. Worthington (Amy); daughters Elizabeth J. Roehrig (Tom) and Katherine A. Haworth (Michael); and five grandchildren: Haylie, Evan and Matthew Roehrig; Ethan Haworth; and Kyle Worthington. Barbara was born in Los Angeles, CA on August 7, 1936, the daughter of Lester Shields DeVall and Aileen May Mitchell. After graduating from Occidental College, she received M.A. and B.D. degrees from San Francisco Theological Seminary in 1962 and 1964. She was ordained a Minister in the Presbyterian Church (USA) in 1979 and became the Assistant Pastor of the College Park Presbyterian Church, San Diego. Beginning in 1981, she served the Presbytery of San Diego as an Associate for Mission and Acting Executive Presbyter. In 1989 she became the Interim Executive Presbyter for the Presbytery of San Fernando and in 1990 became the Executive Presbyter of the Presbytery of the Palisades in northeastern New Jersey. She retired to Whidbey Island, WA in 2003. In the Presbyterian Church (USA), Barbara had leadership roles in the Synod of Southern California and Hawaii and the Synod of the Northeast. She was a commissioner to the 1982 General Assembly and served on task forces for the Board of Pensions and Southeast Asian Ministries. She was a member and moderator of the national Mission Development and Resources Committee. She also served several terms on the Alumni Council of San Francisco Theological Seminary. Barbara enjoyed time with her children and grandchildren and was proud of their accomplishments. She was a member of the Happy Hookers in Freeland, WA and had become an accomplished primitive rug hooker. She enjoyed a South Whidbey book club and belonged to Chapter GJ of P.E.O. She traveled extensively among the churches of southeast Asia and traveled with John in Europe, Russia and China. God blessed Barbara with extraordinary skills of administration which she used in her ordained ministry. She blessed her family and churches in her care with her love and compassion. Her death comes too early for us all. Gifts in her memory may be made to Susan G. Komen for the Cure or to ministries of the churches of the Presbyterian Church (USA).

de LIAGRE--Mary. The Princess Grace Foundation-USA extends sincere condolences to the family of Mary de Liagre. As a long-time member of the Arts Advisory board, Mary helped to support hundreds of emerging artists nationwide. The Foundation was honored to have her inspirational involvement.

KRAKOWER--Arthur J.,June 10 - It is with deep sorrow we mourn the passing of Arthur J. Krakower, 88 years young. He was a loving and devoted husband to his wife Jean with whom he enjoyed 54 years of marriage; a doting father to Susan, Carole and Tom; a glorious grandfather to Kimberly, Jacqueline and Jenny. Arthur touched the lives of many, many people, young and old. He will be missed, but will be remembered for living life to the very fullest. Funeral services today, 10 am, Congregation Beth Jacob, 1550 Alameda de las Pulgas, Redwood City. Donations to California College of the Arts.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — A festival like Bonnaroo creates a broad carbon footprint since thousands of cars idle in traffic jams getting in. Yet Bonnaroo strives to be ecologically correct, with recycling bins all over theplace, a well-traversed area with booths for groups that, for instance, remind people that their plastic water bottles are an environmental burden, and an entire (solar-powered) stage dedicated to environmental activists.
Update:

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Robyn Hitchcock, the surrealist English songwriter, has allied himself with the Venus 3: R.E.M.’s guitarist, Peter Buck, and two members of R.E.M.’s stage and studio band, Bill Rieflin on drums and Scott McCaughey on bass, who bring California’s folk-rock and psychedelia to Mr. Hitchcock’s warped English pop — a fine transatlantic hybrid. Mr. Hitchcock is never at a loss for snappy patter. On Saturday afternoon, he claimed that the last rock fest he attended was the 1970 Isle of Wight Festival, where Jimi Hendrix played. “Things look almost exactly the same,” he claimed. But Hendrix, he noted, now plays on YouTube.

Can laptop bands jam? Of course, and that’s what it sounded like Animal Collective was doing in a beautifully dizzying set. Most of its equipment was on tabletops, along with microphones and some percussion, and its songs floated up out of an electronic haze: samples and maybe synthesizer parts that looped and burbled, clinked and scraped, arpeggiated and whizzed upward, the makings of songs from its latest album “Merriweather Post Pavilion.” When enough of them are interlocked, band members started singing the handful of lyrics in each song, sometimes overlapping or staggering them for another layer of counterpoint. It seemed open-ended; when they were done, they just let the mix dissolve back into the electronic ooze and teased out a new collection of song parts.

My Sunday column looks at the 40-year "war on drugs" and argue that it has failed and that it is time for a dramatic rethink of drug policy. I haven't written about drugs before because I've been ambivalent -- in particular, I've worried that liberalization would lead to an increase in drug use. I'm not one of those who thinks that drugs are fine -- on the contrary, I've seen how narcotics can devastate families, even countries. My home town of Yamhill, Oregon, has been hit hard by the Meth explosion.

An article on Monday about the investigation of the recent Air France crash in the Atlantic Ocean misstated the given name and the professional title of a safety expert who spoke about the importance of finding the flight data recorder. He is Robert T. Francis, not James, and he is a former — not current — member of the National Transportation Safety Board. The article also misidentified the military affiliation of a Brazilian officer who confirmed that debris collected near the suspected crash site had come from the aircraft. The officer, Lt. Col. In May video game sales fell to $863 million, down by 23 percent from the same period a year ago, according to the NPD Group, which tracks domestic sales. Sales of hardware (consoles and handheld devices) dropped by 30 percent, while sales of software fell by 17 percent, to $449 million. This, the third consecutive month of declining year-over-year sales, leaves scant support for those arguing that the stay-at-home-and-play industry is not susceptible to recessionary pressures. Sales also fell sharply in March and April. But the NPD Group noted that those drops might have causes other than recession. For instance, NPD analysts said at the time that March sales had fallen because Easter was in April this year, after generating holiday sales in March last year. But for May, NPD offered little other rationale for the trend.

SCHAIR--Stanley, of New York City and South Egremont, MA, died Friday morning on June 12 at age 70. He was the beloved husband of Sandra Constantine Schair, brother of Marilyn and Leonard (deceased), stepbrother of Barry, Mark and Hal, loving father of Adam and Alison, father-in-law of Julie, and grandfather of Sam, Abby and Emma. Born in the Bronx on July 8, 1938, he was an accomplished labor and employment attorney, most recently as a partner at Bond, Schoeneck & King. He was an active participant and leader in various New York City business, civic, educational and child welfare organizations, most notably serving on the Board of the Jewish Child Care Association for nearly three decades and on Mayor Bloomberg's New York City Task Force on Career and Technical Education Innovation. Donations in his memory can be made to Jewish Child Care Association, New York City. Services are 11:45am on Sunday, June 14, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY.

GARRY--William J.,on June 11, 2009, beloved Husband of Mary Garry (nee Lochrane). Loving Father to Helen, William, Moira, Patrick and Thomas. Loving Grandfather to William, Francis, Alexander, Thomas, Matthew, Em- ma, Gulianna, Ryan, Patrick and Liam. Devoted Father-in-law to Clifford, Elizabeth, Ronald, Elizabeth and Eileen. Cherished Brother-in-law to Helen Brown, Alice Canizio and Bro. Patrick Lochrane. Loved Uncle to many Nieces and Nephews. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, NY. First generation American - son of Irish immigrants William and Mary Garry (Co. Kildare). Retired Justice of New York State Supreme Court 1986 to 2003. Admitted to practice law for over fifty (50) years. Former Secretary of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, former Director of the New York City Record 1974 - 1975, Honorable Discharge U.S. Army 1950 - 1951. Former President of Our Lady of Angels Parish Council, former Leader of Boy Scouts - Pack 550, former Grand Marshal of the Celts Society, Kings County Chapter, graduate of Seton Hall University, St. John's University School of Law. In lieu of flowers donation to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105, Attn: Tribute Dept. Tribute No: 23886605. Visitation will be Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Mc-Laughlin & Son's Funeral Home, 9620 3rd Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11209. Mass of Christian Burial will be Monday, 9:30am, Our Lady of Angels RC Church, 7320 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11209.

COUDRAI--John C.,80, of Smithville, NJ on June 1, 2009 of lung cancer. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Marcelle, his son Philippe, his daughter-in-law Leila, his grandsons John-Michael and Eric Coudrai; his sister Nicole Ouvre, his niece Anne Polloni, his grand-niece Agnes, his cousins Lucien Vergne and Serge Masse. John and Marcelle emigrated from France to the U.S. in 1954. Being third generation in a family of Hoteliers, his career in the hotel industry as Banquet Manager and Catering Director spanned over 30 years, having worked for Marriott, Resorts, and Hilton's Waldorf Astoria, among others. John loved to read and was an avid student of world history. Relatives and friends of the family are kindly invited to attend his visitation on Friday, June 5, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm, and Saturday, June 6, from 9-9:30am at Lowenstein Funeral Home, 58 South New York Road, Galloway, NJ (609-652-8330). BERGSTEIN--Bernard. Born June 2, 1916, of New York City, NY. Bernard left this life June 8, 2009, six days after his 93rd birthday. Devoted husband of 56 years to Lee Ida (Gluskin) who died November 6, 1996. He owned a CPA practice in lower Manhattan and Augusta, Maine, for 32 years. His clients included artists Isamu Noguchi and Yasuo Kuniyoshi. His love of education, languages, art, and classical and world music excited him and balanced his concern for world affairs and politics. He is predeceased by his siblings Rose Cooper, Lillian Abrams, and Hyman Bergstein. He is survived by his brother Abraham and wife Estelle Bergstein, son Benjamin Bergstein and wife April Werner, daughter Miriam and husband David Smith, grandson Doug Bergstein and wife Alison Duckworth, granddaughter Laura and husband Darin George, grandson Mathew Smith and wife Tenzing Sherpa, grandson Noah Smith, great-granddaughter Michaela George, and great- grandson Cameron Lee George. Donations in Bernard's name may be sent to the VNSNY Hospice care at: www.vnsny.org.

SUCHER--Laurie, died peacefully at home in Chicago on May 26, 2009 surrounded by love and music. She is survived by her husband, Michael Gaster, their sons, Toby, Jonah and Gabriel Gaster, her brother, David Sucher, cousins Diana and Roger Glassman. She touched many lives, leaving close friends who loved her dearly. A native NYer, she graduated from the H.S. of Music and Art, Barnard, and SUNY Stony Brook, where she received a Ph.D in English and published a well received study of Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. (She later taught at Truman College in Chicago, where she lived for 30 years. Also a gifted musician and artist, she was a cantorial soloist leading high holiday services, sang and performed classical, popular, Yiddish, Ladino, and Renaissance music, and exhibited her paintings in many galleries. For her wonderful tireless spirit, her sense of humor and adventure, her relentless spiritual quest, her original and quirky intelligence and her loyalty to us all, she is already more than missed. Her memorial will be Sunday, July 19 at 2pm at Emanuel Congregation, 5959 N. Sheridan Rd., Chicago. Please see and add to her online obituary at www.legacy.com

8 P.M. (HBO) THE DARK KNIGHT (2008) In Christopher Nolan's latest Batman installment, the Joker (Heath Ledger, above, in the role for which he won a posthumous Oscar for best supporting actor) takes control of Gotham, leaving the masked crusader (Christian Bale), Commissioner Gordon (Gary Oldham) and District Attorney Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart) to clean up the chaotic mess. Maggie Gyllenhaal plays Rachel Dawes, Dent's and Bruce Wayne's mutual love interest; Eric Roberts is Salvatore Maroni, a Mafia kingpin. Reviewing the film in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said, ''Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, it goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind.'' She added that Mr. Ledger's Joker is ''a creature of such ghastly life, and the performance is so visceral, creepy and insistently present that the characterization pulls you in almost at once.'' 7 A.M. MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Friday at Bonnaroo was dominated by New York City, from Dirty Projectors to the Beastie Boys. On Saturday, Tennessee took over. The Other Tent was full of Tennessee pickers, musicians with deep bluegrass roots, open ears and flying fingers. The Tony Rice Unit, led by the guitarist who has been a prime mover in new acoustic music, opened its set with “My Favorite Things,” and proceeded to alternate old Appalachian songs and excursions toward jazz. The Del McCoury Band clustered around one microphone, in old-time radio and recording style. Cherryholmes sparkled with rhinestones, but broke into group clog-dancing at the end of one song. These musicians could sound deeply traditional, or not at all, with each item in a setlist.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Someone came to Bonnaroo well prepared. Bruce Springsteen has been taking requests on his current tour from fans who bring handmade posters, and at Bonnaroo he got close enough to the crowd to collect them. Onstage, he unfurled a man-sized poster of Santa Claus, with a request for his version (which is modeled on Phil Spector’s production) of “Santa Claus Is Coming to Town.” Sure, it’s June. But for Mr. Springsteen, it’s not too early to tell the little girls and boys to be good for goodness’ sake.

BOSTON — You would think that an early-music festival run by two of the world’s best lutenists — Paul O’Dette and Stephen Stubbs — might have plenty of lute music in its programming. Or some. But Mr. O’Dette and Mr. Stubbs seem disinclined to push their instrument’s agenda at the Boston Early Music Festival, except in ensemble music.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Sometime around 2 a.m., during a ferocious and meticulous set by his band, Nine Inch Nails, Trent Reznor made an announcement: that it would be “our last show ever in the United States.” The band is headed to Europe on tour. Mr. Reznor went on, “Don’t be sad. I’ll keep going. But I think I’m going to lose my” mind if “I keep doing this, and I have to stop.”

BOSTON — At an early-music festival, you expect to see antique instruments: pegless cellos, gambas with ornate scrolls, wooden recorders and tranverse flutes of every size, and perhaps an occasional shawm, rebec or vielle. And you expect to see re-creations of ensembles that composers no longer write for (although a few composers seem to be gravitating toward the gamba now).

President Barack Obama‘s half brother, George, is writing a memoir to be published by Simon & Schuster in January of next year , The Associated Press reported. Mr. Obama, who is 27 and lives in Huruma, Kenya, has the same father as the president. The two half brothers did not meet until they were adults. The book is tentatively titled “Homeland” and will be written with Damien Lewis, an author and journalist. George Obama fell into crime and poverty as a teenager, before finding a passion for community organizing. “Even had George Obama not been our President’s half brother, his story is moving and inspirational,” David Rosenthal, Simon & Schuster publisher and executive vice president, said in a statement Sunday. “It is an object lesson in survival, selflessness and courage.” The publisher would not reveal how much it paid for the book, but someone with knowledge of the negotiations said it was in the six figures.

But I thought we should start the Wimbledon watch at the real start of the championships. I speak, of course, of the qualies at Roehampton. The good folks over at the Orlando Sentinel have posed that question, and frankly, it's a fascinating one. They've come up with 12 alternatives to the run-of-the-mill outcomes of putting teams on N.C.A.A. probation or forcing them to vacate victories. There are some light-hearted options among the 12, but some would have some serious bite, even if at first glance they seem to be harmless. Forcing assistants off the recruiting trail or barring a team from holding summer football camps could do some serious damage to its recruiting. And could you imagine how quickly teams would fall in line if the N.C.A.A. started away taking home games, and the millions of dollars of revenue they provide for universities and their communities?

To the Editor: Your article “36 Hours: Grand Canyon” (May 31) should have included a short walk down into the canyon. Walking even 20 minutes is well worth it because you can only get a feeling for the grandeur and size of the canyon from down below the rim. A helicopter tour is no substitute; the visitor would completely miss out on the solitude and quiet of the canyon. Walking is free, and can easily be done from the South Rim; a gently graded trail starts just west of the Bright Angel Lodge, beside the Kolb Studio.

Many postindustrial cities have abandoned the notion of the waterfront as a place of commercial and social activity. This project would enable cities to re-establish this connection by emphasizing the intersection of three powerful aspects of urban life: infrastructure, public space and sustainability. Wheels installed at derelict piers or on permanently moored barges along the riverfront harvest energy, effectively converting kinetic energy to zero-carbon electrical energy. They do so by relying on the time-tested technology of undershot water wheels: the river’s current applies a force to the submerged blades of each wheel, and this force spins the wheels, which, in turn, drive electricalgenerators. The electricity produced is then used to illuminate a system of L.E.D. streetlights. Controllers sense when surplus electricity is available and divert it to the city’s electrical grid. At the same time, the wheels enliven the water’s edge and serve as a place for the public to gather, taking infrastructure and sustainability into the realm of celebration.

America’s shopping infrastructure is vast and abundant. That’s the problem.

In our hyperconnected, superfast age, how can the Internet data centers we’ve built keep up?
A plan to reduce traffic congestion by going aboveground.

To the Editor: A few remarks on “The Sweet Life at the Chic Tip of South Beach” (May 31): Of the area restaurants mentioned, Big Pink is by far the most reasonable, and the food is excellent. Monty’s is not just a bar but also a restaurant; it serves the same stone crabs as Joe’s for less money, has a nicer setting, and you won’t miss the long wait and having to “grease” the maître d’.
Michael Connelly’s latest noir thriller, “The Scarecrow,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1.

JAUNTIER than a swinger and more quirky than a fedora, boater hats are having a bit of a moment: Marc Jacobs included a colorful array of charmingly smooshed variations in his spring collection; and, off the runway, they've shown up on stylish downtown folk like Erin Wasson (center right) and Dash Snow (far right). Chloë Sevigny (right) wore a vintage boater she bought years ago in Tampa, Fla., to Prince Harry's recent polo match on Governors Island. She paired it with a cream Chloé suit. ''It was the best choice for the look,'' she said. ''I love hats, but the latest porkpie trend has me gagging.''

Five-Figure Club Last Tuesday, the Dodgers won the 10,000th game in franchise history, joining the Cubs and the Giants as the only teams to reach 10,000 victories. That figure includes victories when the Dodgers were known as the Robins, the Superbas, the Bridegrooms, the Grooms, the Grays and the Atlantics.

During eight years of playing professional soccer in Europe, Oguchi Onyewu of the United States had grown wearily accustomed to monkey noises and racial remarks made by fans toward black players. But Onyewu, a defender whose parents immigrated from Nigeria, said he had never heard such discriminatory remarks uttered at him by another player until a playoff match last month to decide the Belgian league championship.

DEEMS Richard E. A memorial service will be held for Richard E. Deems on Tuesday, June 23 at 5pm at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, 1 W. 53rd St., New York City. Deems, 96, a trustee of The Hearst Family Trust and a member of the Board of Directors of Hearst Corporation and the two Hearst Foundations, as well as a former chairman and president of Hearst Magazines and a longtime force in the publishing industry, passed away Monday, May 4, 2009, at his apartment in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations in Deems's memory can be made for leukemia research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center: MSKCC, Attention: Elise Cooke, 633 3rd Ave., 28th Floor, New York, NY, 10017 or (646)227-2743.

COHEN--Cynthia, of Woodmere, NY, passed away June 12 at age 75 of a brain tumor. She died comfortably at home with her loved ones by her side. Beloved wife of the late Herbert Cohen. Dear mother of Jeffrey and Marsha, Michael and Ilona. Loving grandmother of Frannie, Natalie, Alexander, and Ethan. Devoted sister of Herbert Tanowitz and the late Melvin Tanowitz. Cherished daughter of Joseph and Esther Tanowitz. She was a dedicated teacher in the New York City schools for over 30 years. A sweet, kind, and loving mother and grandmother who had respect for all and exuded dignity. She will be sorely missed. Donations may be made in her memory to the Dysautonomia Foundation, 315 W. 39th St., Suite 701, New York, NY 10018.

SCHWARTZ--Jerome Martin, Ph.D. Jerry passed away on June 10, 2009 after a six year battle with pancreatic cancer. Born October 20, 1940 to Gustave and Marjorie Schwartz (deceased), he received degrees from the City College of New York (BS), New York University (MS), and the University of Chicago (Ph.D., 1969; Virology). He then achieved the rank of Research Associate Professor in the Laboratory of Neurovirology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City, where he published many important original studies concerning the viral etiology of diseases of the nervous system. In 1982, Dr. Schwartz became Research Director at the Schering-Plough Pharmaceutical Corporation at Kenilworth, New Jersey (head of the Departments of Antiviral Chemotherapy and Molecular Pharmacology), making major contributions to the successful discovery and development of the drugs Inton A and Rebetron. These have become the cornerstone treatments for hepatitis C viral infections worldwide. He then went on to become Senior Vice President at United Health Group (Ingenix Division) interfacing with major pharmaceutical companies, facilitating the development and introduction of their novel, important drugs. Jerry is survived by his loving and dedicated lifetime partner, the poet Dennis V. Dever ("The Uses of This World") and their dearest friend Theodore Anthony Lee. He is also survived by his beloved sister Susan (Fred Snowflack) and dearest brother Richard (Doris), loving cousins Gail (Allan) London, Arlene Jacobs, and Glenn (Roz) Lessey and their families. He is also survived by a multitude of cherished friends, including Bernard Weinstein, Ph.D. (Lois), Bill Wiesner (Ph.D.), and a lifetime's worth of many, many valued, talented, and dedicated professional colleagues. A graveside service was held at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ, on Friday, June 12, 2009 at 11:00am. McCorry Brothers, Cliffside Park, NJ handled the services.

ISTANBUL: MUSIC FESTIVAL The 37th International Istanbul Music Festival (www.iksv.org), June 5 to 30, is bringing top international and Turkish classical musicians to the city's stages and providing ticket holders with a rare chance to meet and greet some of the artists before the shows.

FIRST seen in the spring 2005 collections of Balenciaga and Imitation of Christ, the gladiator sandal has earned a place in the pantheon of footwear. In its four-year run, it has been reinterpreted by everyone from Azzedine Alaïa to Aldo, and is still being worn by every second woman walking down the street. It's time for something new. ''I love gladiators,'' said the stylist and swimsuit designer Lisa Marie Fernandez. ''They've become a classic, like ballet slippers. But I've been wearing them less, that's for sure.'' Her current sandal preference is a pair of basic leather T-straps from the St.-Tropez company Rondini. (A similar style by K. Jacques is sold at Scoop.) ''They're the same idea as the gladiator,'' she said, ''but far more simplified.''

FRIDAY THE 13TH From the producer Michael Bay and the director Marcus Nispel, a rejiggering of the 1980s horror series, now with Derek Mears behind the hockey mask. The Blu-ray edition contains both the R-rated theatrical cut and the unrated ''extended killer cut,'' which are available separately in standard definition. ''Granted, most people's notion of entertainment doesn't involve watching sexed-up, beer-guzzling morons impaled, decapitated or burnt alive,'' Nathan Lee wrote in The New York Times in February. ''But there's an itch for this kind of material, and here it is scratched -- to the bone.'' (Warner Home Video, Blu-ray $35.99, standard definition $28.98) LOST: THE COMPLETE FIRST SEASON AND LOST: THE COMPLETE SECOND SEASON A Blu-ray upgrade for the first two seasons of the cult television show (2004-6), in which the survivors of a plane crash fight for their lives on a mysterious tropical island. (Disney, $69.99, not rated)

SCHAIR--Stanley. The Officers, Trustees, and Staff of Jewish Child Care Association (JCCA) express their profound sorrow at the loss of Stanley Schair, a valued and esteemed member of JCCA's Board of Trustees for 29 years. In recent years, he also served as a Vice President/Secretary of the Board. Stanley served and chaired on numerous committees offering his law expertise, unflagging commitment, and wisdom. His dedication to children and families and his significant contribution to New York City business, civic, education, and child welfare organizations will be long remembered. Last year, he was honored on behalf of JCCA and UJA-Federation of New York for "A Lifetime of Community Service." He believed that every child deserves to grow up hopeful. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, his children, and his grandchildren. Barbara Salmanson, President Richard Altman, CEO

Roger Federer wins his 14th grand slam title, and is all but crowned the greatest tennis player in history. Stephen Strasburg is drafted by the Washington Nationals as the greatest pitching prospect baseball scouts have ever seen. Another title for Phil Jackson of the Los Angeles Lakers could make him greatest basketball coach of all time, and Tiger Woods prepares for this week's United States Open hoping to reassert his status as the greatest golfer ever. Along with Michael Phelps' eight gold medals and another Super Bowl ring for the Pittsburgh Steelers, this has been one of sports' greatest stretches for ''greatest'' buffs, whose greatest obsession is to argue about who is, you know, really good. All this ''best'' business is enough to make one forget how futile the arguing truly is.

Pitcher? Think Twice Before the draft, the prevailing wisdom was that the Washington Nationals would be foolish not to take the San Diego State right-hander Stephen Strasburg with the first pick. Believing that Strasburg was a can't-miss prospect, the Nationals did just that last Tuesday.

de LIAGRE--Mary Howard, actress and wife of the Broadway producer, Alfred de Liagre, died peacefully in her sleep, at home, in Manhattan, on June 6th. The funeral service will be held on Tuesday, June 16th, at 3pm, in the Great Choir of The Cathedral of St. John the Divine (Amsterdam at 112th St.), which she served for many years as a trustee. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to The Cathedral.

Marie Antoinette had one. So did Napoleon Bonaparte, Czar Alexander I, King George IV and Louis XVIII. The high-profile items in question were timepieces by Abraham-Louis Breguet (1747-1823), a Swiss who made his name mostly in Paris with innovations like the subscription watch, which had a single hand; the tact watch, whose face simply had to be touched for the wearer to tell the time; and the tourbillon regulator, which neutralized the effects of gravity on a watch's works. Because of inventions like the deck watch and longitude watch, Breguet was appointed Watchmaker to the Royal Navy in 1815. The following year, he was awarded a seat in the Academy of Sciences.

In his 13-year major league career, Astros shortstop Miguel Tejada has had several notable accomplishments. He had the fifth-longest streak of consecutive games played streak (1,152), won an American League Most Valuable Player award, produced four 30-home-run seasons and was selected to five All-Star Games. He also had his name involved in the Rafael Palmeiro steroid scandal and was forced to reveal that he had lied about his age for most of his career. But through it all he has piled up hits.

SCHAIR--Stanley, of New York City and South Egremont, MA, died Friday morning on June 12 at age 70. He was the beloved husband of Sandra Constantine Schair, brother of Marilyn and Leonard (deceased), stepbrother of Barry, Mark and Hal, loving father of Adam and Alison, father-in-law of Julie, and grandfather of Sam, Abby and Emma. Donations in his memory can be made to Jewish Child Care Association, New York City. Services are 11:45am on Sunday, June 14, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Glavine's Protest Yields Apology From the Braves,'' June 6: So Tom Glavine found it ''extremely aggravating'' that the Atlanta Braves mishandled his release notice? How does that compare with his statement in 2007, after his pitiful performance for the Mets in the final game of the season, which cost the team the chance to go to the playoffs, that he was not devastated by his poor showing?

AUDIO Struggling to Play: Thirty-seven years after Title IX, the surge of participation in women's athletics seen around the country is still largely missing in the nation's cities. A coach, a player, a student and an advocate talk about the challenges.

ORNAUER--Richard Lewis, newspaper editor and educator, died June 11, 2009 at Courtland Manor, Dover, Delaware. of a stroke at the age of 86. Mr. Ornauer had been city editor of the Nassau Daily Review-Star in Rockville Centre, NY, and Long Island Press at Jamaica, NY, for 20 years. Previously he had been a reporter, copyreader and night editor at the Review-Star on Long Island, NY. He started his newspaper career as wire editor at the Coastal Georgian in Brunswick, GA. Later, he was an assistant to the commissioner (public information) for the Nassau County (NY) Department of Social Services, and Public Health Information Director for the Nassau County Department of Health from 1971 to 1987. He retired as director of communications for the New York State School Boards Association at Albany, NY, in 1989, and relocated to Dover, DE. On Long Island, Mr. Ornauer was a member of the Merrick Board of Education for 26 years, four years as president; and a founding member of the Board of Cooperative Educational Services (BOCES) of Nassau County for 20 years, 18 as president. He served on the Executive Committee of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association for 26 years, two years as president. Mr. Ornauer was elected to the Board of Directors for the New York State School Board Association in 1979 and served ten years, six as vice president and eight as a member of the Executive Committee. During this period, he was a voting delegate from New York State to the National School Boards Association, served on several of its presidential task forces, and was president of its Northeast Region in 1987. He was a founding member and represented New York's Fourth Congressional District on the National School Boards Association's Federal Relations Network. He also served on the New York State School Board's Legislative Network for the 18th Assembly District. He was the recipient of the Man-of-the-Year awards from the Merrick Chamber of Commerce and Long Island Association of Special Education Administrators. He was named Educator of the Year in 1973 from Phi Delta Kappa, honorary education society. He received Distinguished Service awards from the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association in 1979 and 1987; in 1982 from the Floral Park-Bellerose School District (at which he attended elementary school); and in 1982 from the Public Television Station WLIW-TV (Channel 21) in Garden City. Mr. Ornauer received numerous citations for his work in journalism and public education. He was an honorary life member of both the New York State and National Parent-Teacher Associations. In Delaware, Mr. Ornauer had been an AARP Driver Safety Program (formerly known as 55 Alive/Mature Driving) instructor since 1993, Assistant State Coordinator 1996-2003, and Associate State Coordinator since 2003. He was a member of the AARP's Delaware State Leadership Council, AARP Delaware Executive Council, representing communications since 2004; on the Board of Directors of the Greater Dover Area Chapter 721 of the AARP for six years, serving as its public information officer and chairman of its Bylaws Revision Committee. He was a founding member of the Public Advisory Committee to the Dover/Kent County Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) since 1993 and served as its chairman from 1995 to 2001. He was the Kent County appointee to Delaware Department of Transportation's Prioritization Systems Committee and to its Advisory Committee on Traffic Calming Devices, and the MPO's Project Prioritization Policy Committee. He also was Government Relations chairman of the Mifflin Road Neighborhood Association, member of the City of Dover Transportation Committee, City of Dover Public Safety Issues Implementation Committee and City of Dover Sign Amendment Advisory Committee. He also served as a volunteer communications officer for the Dover (now Mobility) Air Force Base Museum. A graduate of the University of Missouri's School of Journalism, Mr. Ornauer served as an apprentice reporter and copyreader on the Columbia Missourian and a radio news writer for station KFRU in Columbia, MO. He was a life member of the Professional Journalists Society/Sigma Delta Chi, and member of both the Press Club of Long Island, and the Empire State Chapter. He is listed in Who's Who in America since 1977. His hobby was collecting all forms of Puffins, an Arctic sea bird. Mr. Ornauer, an Army sergeant major with both the 5202 and 5221st Engineer Construction Brigades in the Asiatic-Pacific area, served from 1942 to 1945. He participated in invasions at Biak Island in the Netherlands East Indies (now West Papua, Indonesia), Leyte and Luzon Islands in the Philippines. He also served at New Guinea (now Papua), Okinawa and Korea. In the United States, he was assigned to Battery C, 332nd Field Artillery Battalion in the 86th Infantry Division. He is survived by his wife, J. Rexene A. Ornauer, of Dover, DE. They were married on November 24, 1985, at Glen Cove, NY. His parents, Edwin L. and Emma H. Ornauer of Floral Park, NY, and Merrick, NY, died at 95 years of age and 104, respectively. He was the father of three children, David S. of Okinawa, Michael J. of Long Beach, NY, and SaraJo of Merrick, NY; five stepchildren, T. Philip Ashford III of Lake Worth, FL; Mary Collier of Encinitas, CA; Ann Menor of Lake Worth, FL, William R. Ashford of Cherry Valley, NY; and Jean Berrios of West Palm Beach, FL; four grandchildren from Okinawa, and one great-granddaughter on Long Island, NY; 15 step-grandchildren in Florida and upstate New York; and two step great-grandchildren. Born October 19, 1922, in Brooklyn, NY, he was raised on Long Island, NY, residing in Floral Park and Merrick, before moving to Newtonville, NY, and Dover, DE. Interment was in Mt. Ararat at Babylon, NY, following graveside services. A scholarship in his memory has been established at the Long Island High School for the Arts in Syosset, New York. Donations may be sent to Teresa Scaturro at Nassau Boces, 71 Clinton Rd, Garden City, New York, 11530. Also, contributions in his memory may be sent to Compassionate Care Hospice, 702 B Kirkwood Highway, Wilmington, Delaware, 19805.

JAPHA--Etta (nee Veit-Simon). Etta Japha died in Seattle on June 9th at the age of 90. Beloved wife of Erwin, who died in 1971; mother of Irene, Carol, and Anthony; mother-in-law of Ron Louie and Joan Japha; grandmother of Katherine Weiland and Rebekah and Mikaela Louie; sister of Judith Klein and Harro Simon. Steven Marmo, 26, grew up in Bayside, Queens, and spent much of his teens and early 20s in and out of jail for vandalism, drugs and bar fights. He said his anger began at age 5, when his parents divorced. At 15, he spent a year in a juvenile detention center, where, he said, he had to fight to get by. ''One time in the mess hall,'' he recalled, ''this kid came up and took my apple. And I got up and took his bread, and it was all over. If he took my apple, then everyone's going to walk all over me.'' When he was 17, Mr. Marmo dropped out of high school and lived on the street for several months after a fight with his mother and stepfather. He grew a mohawk and hung out on the Lower East Side with other young men who fought every time they went out.

It's been rainy and cool, and the fashion people have reverted to black; even the botanical gardens are sprouting ink-colored irises and pansies. One New Yorker was seen dusting Fifth Avenue in a long charmeuse day dress with a train worthy of the evening. For some stylish women, black leggings are the stem on which they assemble pieces, like the new metal-studded tops. For others, it's bare legs with knee-length skirts or city shorts. Monkey fur showed up on the back of a young dandy; another strolled by in a tall hat with the tiniest dog on a leash -- in a black coat, of course.

Loving grandmother to Daniel and Joshua, Ivy and Michael. Loving great-grandmother to Alec and Eva. Services will be held at Temple Judea in Manhasset, Sunday, June 14 at 12:30pm.
