Larsen Chair in Child Development. Our condolences to his wife Elana, and children David, Miriam, and Jessica, an alumna of the College. His family has graciously asked that contributions in his honor be made to the Scholarship Fund of Sarah Lawrence College in addition to other charities. Karen Lawrence, President John Hill, Chair of the Board of Trustees

THE NEWS Almost 4 out of 10 Republicans and Republican-leaning independents have an unfavorable opinion of the party, a new USA Today/Gallup poll found. BEHIND THE NEWS For Republicans struggling over the future of their party, the results of this poll make for sober reading. Nearly half of Republicans polled could not come up with a single name when asked who speaks for their party -- ''hard evidence,'' said Frank M. Newport, editor in chief of the Gallup Poll, of ''a significant leadership vacuum.'' Overall, 53 percent of those polled said they had a favorable image of the Democratic Party, compared with 34 percent for the Republican Party.

IT'S no secret Tata Motors, India's largest domestic automaker, wants to introduce its low-buck Nano city car in the United States. Speaking at the Cornell Global Forum on Sustainable Enterprise this month, Ratan Tata, chairman of the Tata Group, said he hoped to see the Nano arrive in North America by 2011, according to Reuters. This is despite the need to engineer the Nano to meet United States safety and emissions requirements, not to mention the search to find a suitable location to sell the cars.

Trenitalia, Italy's national railway, which introduced high-speed rail service between Naples and Milan last December (www.italiarail.com), will soon be getting some competition. In 2011, a new privately owned high-speed train company, Nuovo Trasporto Viaggiatori, will introduce a stylish, candy-apple-red fleet of 25 trains collectively known as Italo. The trains' interiors will be designed by the Italian car designer Giorgetto Giugiaro. Called Automotrice Grande Vitesse (A.G.V.; an updated version of the French high-speed T.G.V.), Italo trains will provide service to locations between Naples and Turin. Company officials estimate that a trip from Rome to Milan, about 350 miles by rail, will last three hours and that trains will be able to travel up to speeds of 225 miles an hour. The billion-euro project, spearheaded by the head of Fiat and Ferrari, Luca di Montezemolo, includes investors like the French rail company S.N.C.F., and hopes to produce trains that are mostly constructed from recyclable materials and consume 15 percent less energy than current high-speed trains.

BALTZ--William E.,passed away peacefully the morning of April 18th, 2009. He was 81. Loving husband of Eddie Baltz, proud father of two sons, Kirk and Bruce, and adoring grandfather of Dutch and LouLou. He was a Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute graduate and a partner of the architectural firm Haines Lundberg Waehler. As a member of Larchmont Yacht Club and former president of The Tudor City Greens, his endless contributions will be long remembered. With open arms he gave to whomever was in need. As a husband, father, grandfather, and friend he will be missed and forever loved. For memorial information and charitable donations, as per the family's request, please refer to Tudorcitygreens.org.

SHEEN--Marilyn, died on June 10, 2009 after a brief illness. She was born March 4, 1924 in Brooklyn, New York to Rose and Henry Rubin. She married Lester Sheen in 1948 and was a loving wife and mother, taking care of Lester at the end of his life. She considered her family her greatest achievement. She is survived by her son, Allan and his wife Lisa; grandsons Robert, Liam, Sammy and Max all of Mount Kisco, NY; daughter, Barbara Sheen Busby and husband John of Las Cruces, NM; brother Buddy and wife Sheila of Connecticut; as well as beloved nieces, nephews and friends. She was a caring woman with a good sense of humor. All those whose lives she touched will carry her in their hearts. Services on Sunday, June 14, 11:15am at "The Riverside", Amsterdam Ave and 76th Street. Burial at Mt. Judah Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make a charitable donation.

FRYE--Dorothy (Dee). It is with overwhelming sadness that the Board of the Women's Bible Society of New York mourns the loss of our dear friend and fellow board member Dee. We are grateful for her faith, generosity, and passion for life, as well as her many contributions to our Society, which she served with joy and humility. We will greatly miss her encouragement, her prayers, her can-do attitude, and her sense of humor. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Wes; to her daughter, Diane; and to her grandchildren, Charlotte, Sydney and Carolyn.
JONES--William "Bill", on June 11, 2009 at age 78 after a long battle with illness. Predeceased by partner Pat Iorio. Loved life and lived it to the fullest. Mass date to be announced.

The broad stock market has been in positive territory for 2009 for a while now. Last week, the 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average moved into the black as well. Since the market hit bottom in March, the Dow has climbed nearly 30 percent, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen 40 percent.

New York continues its historic role of taking in immigrants and disgorging residents to the rest of the country. But information from the Internal Revenue Service, which keeps track of the yearly movements of taxpayers and their families, shows how the outward flow has slowed and how destinations are changing. Here is a look at domestic migration into and out of New York City. Metropolitan area The net flow from the city to first-ring suburbs like Nassau and Bergen Counties is down modestly. The flow to second-ring suburban counties like Suffolk and Morris, however, is down more sharply. The exodus to some faraway counties in the region continued to grow through 2007.

It's no wonder she was born on the 4th of July-Teri was a firecracker and will be missed by all. Service: June 15, Riverside Memorial Chapels 11:15.

MITCHELL--Hon. Jerry Warren, born on 30 December 1925 near Sutherland, UT, died at home in Salt Lake City on 9 June 2009. Members of his family were by his side. He is the third son of of Albert Wallace Mitchell, Sr. and Klara Emelie Larsson. A farm boy who graduated High School at the top of his class in Mabton, Washington and later at the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, NY. He served out WWII on Liberty Ships and C-3s sometimes evading Japanese torpedoes and other times 60 foot waves in the North Atlantic. He achieved the rank of Chief Officer and earned his Unlimited Masters License. His seagoing days came to an abrupt end when he met Vivian Beverly Hansen at the Manhattan Ward of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in New York City. She was pursuing her masters degree at Columbia University and later founded the School of Nursing at Brigham Young University in Provo, UT. They were married in the LDS Temple at Logan, UT in 1954. He completed his education with a JD degree from the George Washington University Law School and became an admiralty attorney for the Department of Justice in San Francisco. In 1962 he moved his family, including four children, to the Canal Zone in Panama where he worked in the office of the General Counsel of the Panama Canal Commission. In this position, he set a precedent by commandeering a launch and seizing a Soviet ship that had caused damage to the Panama Canal. This incident did NOT become historic when for the first time the USSR paid the damages. In 1969, he became a federal judge in Portsmouth, VA. He completed his career as an Administrative Law Judge for the USCG in Alameda, California. Throughout his life he volunteered for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints including serving as Scout Master, Elders Quorum President, Branch and District President in Panama, Bishop of the Norfolk, VA and San Bruno, CA Wards, and first counselor in the San Francisco Stake Presidency. At the time of his death he was the High Priest Quorum Secretary in the Arlington Hills Ward in Salt Lake City. Judge Mitchell is survived by his wife of 55 years, Vivian Beverly Hansen and his four children Jeffrey (Gibson Island, Maryland), Eve (Salt Lake City, Utah), Jon (Kannapolis, North Carolina) and Steven (Scottsdale, Arizona), their respective spouses Joanne Bader, Reed Stockdale, Sharmyn Christensen, and Sharyl Edmiston, 15 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at 11am on Saturday, 20 June at the Arlington Hills Ward Chapel at 518 East 18th Ave., Salt Lake City, UT. Friends and family may call at Larkin Mortuary at 260 East South Temple on 19 June. Condolences may be shared at http://www. larkinmortuary.com/cond.php. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the LDS Humanitarian Aid Fund at http://www. providentliving.org/content/ display/0,11666,2911-1-3270-1,00.html.

10 P.M. (A&E) HAMMERTIME Two decades ago M C Hammer, a k a Stanley Burrell, seemed untouchable. But a few years later Hammer, a three-time Grammy-winning rapper who had sold more than 50 million albums, was rapidly sliding from superstardom into middle-class obscurity. In this new reality series, Mr. Burrell; Stephanie, his wife of 24 years; and their six children, ages 3 to 21, try to revive the Hammer empire from their home in Tracy, Calif. This premiere episode introduces the family as it does spring cleaning and unearths Hammer memorabilia buried deep in a closet. Elsewhere, Mr. Burrell, above center, works with his dance crew and his cousin Marv, who desperately wants to kick it but may not have the moves. At 10:30 Mr. Burrell demonstrates his version of Daddy day care. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH JOHN KINGKathleen Sebelius, secretary of health and human services, discusses the fight for a public insurance plan before moving to ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos'' at 10 on ABC.

REVISITING VICTORIA FALLS, ZIMBABWE Kirsten Rockingham, 40, a teacher from London, now living with her family in Cairo, pictured with her husband, Nick, 41, a real estate agent and wine importer, and twin 6-year-old daughters, Freya (standing with Kirsten) and Chloe, Dec. 15, 2008. ''Nick and I took a year out in 1999 to travel around East Africa and wanted to repeat the experience. We fell in love with Zimbabwe all those years ago, and we wanted to take the girls to see Vic Falls. Despite the sulky face of Chloe, they loved it and experienced the 'wow' factor on first sight. We only stayed in Zimbabwe for a night this time, and just that very short visit showed us how it has changed. There was no food in the shops even at Vic Falls, and we spent $50 on eight small bottles of water. We stayed in a National Trust lodge as we did nine years ago, although what cost $1 then is now $99! But it was worth all the money. The whole holiday was an experience of a lifetime for all -- hopefully, however, to be repeated.''

When Petra Kalivodova, a 31-year-old nurse, was considering whether to renew her contract at a private health clinic here, the offer of special perks helped clinch the deal: complimentary German lessons, five weeks of vacation and free liposuction and silicone breast implants. ''I would rather have plastic surgery than a free car,'' said Ms. Kalivodova, who could not have afforded cosmetic surgery on her monthly salary of about $1,400. ''We were always taught that if a nurse is nice, intelligent, loves her work and looks attractive, then patients will recover faster.''

IN a city of pizza snobs, the pies served at the Crocodile Lounge (325 East 14th Street; 212-477-7747), a dark and typically crowded East Village bar, barely rate. The crust may be light and thin, but it's not charred to blistering by a 900-degree wood-fired oven. The sauce, though tomato-sweet, is not made from prized San Marzano fruits. The cheese binds the pizza together well enough, but you'd never mistake it for mozzarella di bufala.

Defusing Santana When Mets Manager Jerry Manuel simply took the ball from Johan Santana after Santana's ''I am a man'' proclamation in the eighth inning against the Phillies last Tuesday night, he took a far different course of action than Frank Robinson did 26 years earlier at Shea Stadium.

DANIELS--Selma, died peacefully at her home in Palm Beach, Florida. Service will be held in Miami, interment in Des Moine, Iowa.

HAMMERSLEY--Frederick, abstract painter, born in 1919, died on May 31 in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Hammersley gained international attention through the 1959 exhibition Four Abstract Classicists which was shown at the Los Angeles County Museum, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, the Institute of Contemporary Art in London, and Queen's University in Belfast, Ireland. The term "hard edge" was coined at the time to describe the geometric, abstract paintings by Hammersley, Karl Benjamin, Lorser Feitelson and John McLaughlin. Hammersley formed the edges of the shapes in his paintings with a palette knife, often adding unique, handmade frames and giving them titles with clever word plays, both of which he considered part of each work. During the 1940's Hammersley attended Chouinard and Jepson Art Schools and served in the U.S. Army in World War II. In 1946, he studied at the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris where he met Picasso, Braque, and Brancusi. He later taught at Jepson, Pomona College, Chouinard, and the University of New Mexico until 1971 when he left teaching to devote himself full-time to painting. His best known works are oils on canvas comprised of "hunch" paintings, "geometrics", and "organics", however, he also took photographs, experimented with computer-generated art, and made prints and drawings throughout his life. Hammersley's paintings were included in the Museum of Modern Art's "Responsive Eye" exhibition in 1965 and in the 35th Corcoran Biennial in 1977. He received a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1973. His works are in the collections of the Albright Knox Museum, Corcoran Gallery of Art, High Museum of Art, Los Angeles County Museum of Art, San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Santa Barbara Museum of Art, The Albuquerque Museum, New Mexico Museum of Art, and the University of New Mexico Art Museum, among others. Over the past decade Hammersley enjoyed a renewed interest in his strictly modernist yet playfully intuitive hard-edge paintings, which were exhibited in Site Santa Fe's "Fourth International Biennial" in 2001, a retrospective at Pomona College Museum of Art in 2007, and Orange County Museum's "Birth of the Cool: California Art, Design, and Culture at Mid-century" in 2008. Hammersley is survived by his sister Susie H. Stone, of Santa Fe.

SPENCER--Susan S.,M.D. 60 years old, died on Thursday, May 21, 2009, in Salt Lake City, Utah. She is predeceased by her beloved father, Bernard Schneider, of Yonkers, NY, and survived by her loving family: her mother Magda Schneider of Yonkers, NY; her husband Dennis Spencer of Woodbridge, CT; her daughters Joanna Spencer of Manhattan and Andrea Spencer of Cambridge, MA; her stepdaughter Kate Spencer of Burbank, CA; her stepson Christopher Spencer of Haverford, PA; her sisters Beth Weingarth of Woodbridge, CT and Karen Kimball of North Haven, CT. Dr. Spencer was Professor of Neurology and Neurosurgery and Director of the Epilepsy Program at the Yale School of Medicine and an internationally recognized expert in epilepsy and epilepsy surgery. She was a pioneering woman in medicine, fighting for and forging a pathway for other brilliant female scientists of the next generation. As a leader in her field, Dr. Spencer served as the president of the American Epilepsy Society (AES) in 2000 and vice-president of the American Neurological Society (ANA) in 2001. She served on the executive boards of both the ANA and the American Academy of Neurology. She also co-founded and co-edited the journal Epilepsy Currents from 2001 to 2009. Her contributions were recognized by the AES Clinical Research Award in 2003, the most prestigious honor paid to a member in the field. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Epilepsy Society for the Susan Spencer Fund for Clinical Research and Education (to the AES at 342 North Main St., West Hartford, CT 06117, or by credit card online at www.aesnet.org). A memorial service, open to the public, will be held on July 11th at 3:00pm in Battell Chapel, New Haven, CT.
Art Karen Rosenberg

BERRY--Thomas (1914-2009), Passionist priest and internationally recognized historian of cultures, died on June 1st, 2009 at Well-Spring Retirement Community, Greensboro, North Carolina. His writings and lectures on the relation of humans with the cosmos and the earth have notably influenced the intellectual and spiritual history of the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Originally named after his father, William Nathan Berry, founder of Berico Fuels Company (1924), this second of eight sons in a family of thirteen children adopted the name Thomas (after philosopher-theologian Thomas Aquinas 1225-1274) following 1933 entry into the Passionist Religious Order. Thomas began doctoral studies in history at the Catholic University of America, writing on the historical theory of Italian philosopher- historian Gianbattista Vico 1668-1744, published by the Catholic University of America Press in 1951. Thomas's awards include seven honorary doctorates; the United States Catholic Mission Association Award (1989); the 1992 James Herriot Award of the Humane Society of the United States; Honorary Canonship of the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine (1992); the 1993 Bishop Carroll T. Dozier Medal for Peace and Justice; the Catholic University of America Alumni Award for Research and Scholarship (1993); the 1992 Prescott College Environmental Award; annual Thomas Berry Lecture Awards established, respectively, by the College of Mt. St. Vincent on the Hudson and, in Washington, DC, by the Center for Respect of Life and Environment and the Humane Society of the United States; a Thomas Berry Hall and Thomas Berry Seminars at Whidbey Institute on Whidbey Island near Seattle, WA. Funeral services will be held in Greensboro, NC and Jamaica, New York with internment at Green Monastery in Greensboro, Vermont. .

AMSTERDAM: ''GRACHT WALK'' Keeping your sense of direction within Amsterdam's ring-shaped center can be a tough task. The individual grachten -- the type of canal that makes up the Grachtengordel in the center's core -- twist in a half moon. Walk long enough, and you'll change cardinal directions entirely, without ever leaving your gracht.

JOHNSTON JOYCE--Helen, died peacefully at home in New York City on May 27, 2009, after a long illness. She was the widow of Timothy Joyce, the renowned pioneer in marketing research and audience measurement, and is survived by her sister, Mary Johnston and her loving nieces and nephews, Edward Kelly (Jenifer), Nora Carey (Michael), James Kelly and Victoria Sullivan, and ten great-nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her sister, Margaret Kelly. Helen was born and educated in New York City and graduated from Hunter College. She was a respected advertising research executive and for many years was Director of Media Research at Grey Advertising. Helen also served as Chair of the Agency Media Research Council for three terms, Chair of the Media Research Committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, President of the Radio TV Research Council and was a frequent contributor to Advertising Research Foundation research conferences. She was a devoted and long time member of the Central Players. At her request, no funeral was held. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

SACHTJEN--Wilbur Manley. Age 81, died Thursday June 11, 2009 at his home in Vero Beach. He was born October 23, 1927 in Madison, Wisconsin. A graduate of Madison East High School, he served in the U.S. Army, after which he received a B.S. degree from the University of Wisconsin. He has an MBA from the Harvard Business School, where he was a Baker Scholar. Wil's early career was in finance, first with the Harris Trust of Chicago and later with Morgan, Stanley & Co., New York investment bankers. He then spent seven years in the New York office of McKinsey & Company, international management consultants. Following that, he later joined Pfizer, Inc., where he was a Vice President in the international headquarters. In 1972, Wil entered executive recruiting, initially as a partner in a New York City firm, after which he established his own firm in 1976. He retired from executive recruiting in 2000. In Bronxville, New York, where he lived before coming to Vero Beach, he was active in community affairs. These included service as Board President of the Lawrence Hospital in 1975 and 1976, and as a Board Member for thirteen years. He was a member of the Bronxville Field Club and Siwanoy Country Club. In Vero Beach, Wil has been an officer and Board member of the Indian River Land Trust and of Mckee Botanical Garden. He is a member of the Vero Beach Country Club, the Moorings Club, and the Harvard Club of New York City. He married the late Nancy O'Neill of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts in 1956. He is survived by four sons (Barry of Arnold, Maryland; Brendan of Bronxville, New York; Jeffrey of Norwalk, Connecticut; and Todd of Atlanta, Georgia) and four grandchildren. His brother, Dr. Kenneth Sachtjen of Madison, Wisconsin, died in 1987. There will be no visitation and the funeral services will be private. Interment will be in Madison, Wisconsin. Memorial contributions may be made to McKee Botanical Garden, 350 U.S. Highway 1, Vero Beach, FL 32962.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Putting the Pressure on a Diagnosis,'' June 7: As a psychiatrist I took great offense at the comments of Dr. Allan Lans. He judges the validity of those baseball players with anxiety disorder diagnoses, and also infers that sufferers are only looking for excuses for their performance difficulties.

Kenny Perry, left, has won 13 times during his 24-year PGA Tour career. He has competed in 42 major championship events, including 10 United States Open championships. His best major championship finishes are a tie for second at The Masters in 2009 and solo second in the P.G.A. Championship, losing in sudden death on both occasions. His best finish in a U.S. Open was a tie for third in the 2003 championship won by Jim Furyk at Olympia Fields Country Club outside Chicago. Perry, who played in the 2002 Open at the Black Course at Bethpage State Park and the 2004 Open at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, described the differences between the two Long Island sites. GALLERIES ''Crowds are definitely more vocal at Bethpage. It's definitely more of a college football atmosphere. That gallery is very vocal. They'll definitely -- if you challenge them, they will be all over you. So you just acknowledge and, 'Yeah, I stink today, or whatever. At Shinnecock it's much more subdued, still loud, but not like Bethpage.''

FRAENKEL--George K.,died on June 10, 2009 at the age of 87 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He is survived by his wife, Eva, six step-children and his sister Nancy Wechsler. Born in Deal, NJ, he graduated from Harvard College with a BA in 1942. He was awarded the Ph.D. in Chemistry from Cornell University in 1949, the same year he joined Columbia University. He served on the Faculty of the Chemistry Department and was Chairman from 1966 to 1968 when he became Dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. He retired in 1991 as the Higgins Professor Emeritus and Dean Emeritus. A memorial service is being planned for September 2009 at Columbia University.

BERGSTEIN--Bernard. Born June 2, 1916, of New York City, NY. Bernard left this life June 8, 2009, six days after his 93rd birthday. Devoted husband of 56 years to Lee Ida (Gluskin) who died November 6, 1996. He owned a CPA practice in lower Manhattan and Augusta, Maine, for 32 years. His clients included artists Isamu Noguchi and Yasuo Kuniyoshi. His love of education, languages, art, and classical and world music excited him and balanced his concern for world affairs and politics. He is predeceased by his siblings Rose Cooper, Lillian Abrams, and Hyman Bergstein. He is survived by his brother Abraham and wife Estelle Bergstein, son Benjamin Bergstein and wife April Werner, daughter Miriam and husband David Smith, grandson Doug Bergstein and wife Alison Duckworth, granddaughter Laura and husband Darin George, grandson Mathew Smith and wife Tenzing Sherpa, grandson Noah Smith, great-granddaughter Michaela George, and great- grandson Cameron Lee George. TABITHA SIMMONS, fashion stylist and shoe designer. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW A vintage top I bought in Nashville. I do a lot of vintage shopping there. Everything's so cheap, you can afford to be a bit more experimental. Trash & Vaudeville jeans. They're inexpensive and fit well, and they come in a ton of colors. I have them in black, gray, stripes. The boots are from my new shoe line, which will be in stores this month. I wanted to do styles that were timeless -- no crazy heels or platforms that tie them to one season. These are English walking boots, crossed with a Scottish Highland influence. I've also done sexy sandals and girly Mary Janes. It's a little schizophrenic, the line.
To the Editor: Re ''What's Your Backup Plan?'' (Sunday Styles, June 7):
To the Sports Editor, Re ''At Last, Some Joy in Detroit,'' June 12:

The other day on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, I was confronted with one of those ubiquitous red warning signs decorated with a snowflake: ''Snow Route / No Standing During Emergency/ Vehicles Towed.'' Underneath it, another red sign said: ''No Standing Anytime.'' So there was no standing when there was a snow emergency and there was no standing when there was not a snow emergency. Like, no standing ever. But sometimes really no standing.

HAPPY DAYS I had been lucky enough in my 20s to stumble into the life I might have dreamed of as a boy: a great job writing on world affairs for Time magazine, an apartment on Park Avenue, enough time and money to take vacations in Burma, Morocco, El Salvador. But every time I went to one of those places, I noticed that the people I met there, mired in difficulty and often warfare, seemed to have more energy and even optimism than the friends I'd grown up with in privileged, peaceful Santa Barbara, Calif., many of whom were on their fourth marriages and seeing a therapist every day. Though I knew that poverty certainly didn't buy happiness, I wasn't convinced that money did either. So, as post-1960s cliché decreed, I left my comfortable job and life to live for a year in a temple on the back streets of Kyoto. My high-minded year lasted all of a week, by which time I'd noticed that the depthless contemplation of the moon and composition of haiku I'd imagined from afar was really more a matter of cleaning, sweeping and then cleaning some more. But today, more than 21 years later, I still live in the vicinity of Kyoto, in a two-room apartment that makes my old monastic cell look almost luxurious. I have no bicycle, no car, no television I can understand, no media -- and the days seem to stretch into eternities, and I can't think of a single thing I lack.

COWEN--George Nathan, 92, died peacefully on June 4 at North Hill Skilled Nursing Facility in Needham, MA. He was born in New York City and attended Rumsey Hall School, Riverdale Country School and The Hotchkiss School. George graduated from Princeton University, an English major and member of the Class of 1940. During World War II he served as an Army Major, and after the war, he joined the family investment banking firm, Cowen & Co., where he became a partner. The firm had been founded in 1918 by his father, Arthur, and two uncles, Edwin and Harry. George was predeceased by his wife, Nan Fingarson Cowen, who passed away in 1998 at their home in Scarsdale, where they lived for 51 years. He is survived by his sons, Peter Donnelly Cowen of West Newton, MA, and George Nathan Cowen Jr. of Denver, and by his granddaughter, Elizabeth Tarleton Sutherland of Los Angeles. George enjoyed tennis, golf, bridge and beach going, but his true passion was attending any occasions that brought together family and friends. A memorial service will be held at the Greenville Community Reformed Church, 270 Ardsley Rd., Scarsdale, NY 10583 at 11am on Saturday, June 20. In lieu of flowers, donations to Princeton University in his memory would be appreciated.

WUNSCH--Elsie, nee Rubin, 97, of Glen Cove, NY died peacefully at Glen Cove Hospital on June 5, 2009. Elsie was born on June 23, 1911 in Manhattan and attended Columbia University. She married her beloved Samuel, a mechanical engineer, in 1934. The couple built a home (which they named Elsam) overlooking Long Island Sound on East Island in Glen Cove, moving in on V-J Day in 1945, and spent their lives there. Elsie's and Sam's passion for travel took them to more than 125 countries, an interest that Elsie continued to pursue after Sam's death in 1980. During her travels, Elsie amassed a collection of 350 dolls, favoring examples of local craftsmanship over what she called "tourist dolls." The couple contributed actively to their community as volunteers, lovers of the arts and philanthropists. A long history of support of Glen Cove Hospital most recently included funding for the Wunsch Center for Rehabilitative Therapies, an 8,200-square-foot inpatient rehabilitation and spa center. Elsie volunteered with the Glen Cove Hospital Auxiliary for more than 30 years, following Sam's treatment there in the 1970s. Even as she entered her 90s, Elsie's pink-smocked presence continued to lend assistance and comfort to countless patients and visitors. She was recognized as an exemplar of citizen volunteerism in a 2006 profile by The Daily News. Elsie was also active in teaching English as a Second Language in the Glen Cove School District, and contributed to the Glen Cove Council of the Arts, the Glen Cove Community Scholarship Fund, the Girl Scouts and local animal welfare causes. She attended, with enthusiasm, the Metropolitan Opera and the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on Long Island. Elsie is survived by members of the Wunsch and Durando families. A tiny woman who possessed an encyclopaedic memory and told a good joke, she will be lovingly remembered and missed by all whose lives she touched. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 20, from noon-2:30pm. Beginning on Monday, June 8, please call 212-889-8790 for information. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Glen Cove Community Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 453, Glen Cove, NY 11542.

ALL the talk of small fuel-efficient cars has raised concerns from many of our readers of passenger safety. And while small cars may be easier to park, their bumpers are awfully vulnerable to a tap from the front or rear, according to a test of seven vehicles conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. None of the bumpers on these cars earned a top rating of Good (actually, none of the 49 cars in the institute's bumper tests have received a Good), and just one, the Smart Fortwo, got an Acceptable rating. One, the Chevrolet Aveo, earned a Marginal rating, and five got the lowest rating of Poor. Those five are the Honda Fit, Hyundai Accent, Kia Rio, Mini Cooper and Toyota Yaris.

MELET MERCANTILE, a vintage clothing and collectibles showroom in SoHo, has operated quietly for six years, opening its doors only by appointment to select designers, stylists and collectors. Now, just as quietly, it has opened up shop in Montauk, N.Y. Housed in an old garage, the store is an ode to beach culture, with rare surfboards and sailing artifacts displayed alongside vintage sundresses, T-shirts, frayed cutoffs and '70s-style board shorts.

DUFFY--Stephen Matthew of West Haverstraw, NY passed away on June 12, 2009. Stephen was predeceased by his wife of 49 years, Jean Patricia Duffy in 1994. He was born in New York City on September 6, 1917 and lived a robust life as an nonagenarian. He was an active member of the Rockland County community and received numerous awards and recognitions for his volunteer service. Mr. Duffy was a veteran of WWII serving in the Army Medic Corps. in the Pacific theater. He married Jean Patricia Cassidy on January 31, 1945 while still on active duty. Duffy worked as a Letter Carrier in Branch 36 at Times Square Station in New York and retired after 35 years of service. Duffy and his family resided on the West side of Manhattan until moving to Rockland County in 1967. Stephen Duffy is survived by his six children, Loraine Duffy Strombeck, Stephen, James John, Peter and Mary Duffy. Six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren, one brother James. Another brother Edward is deceased. Friends may call at T.J. McGowan Sons Funeral Home, Garnerville, NY Sunday June 14 and Monday, June 15 from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10am Tuesday, June 16 from St. Peter's Church, Haverstraw, NY.

WORTHINGTON--Reverend Barbara Jeanne DeVall, of Freeland, Washington, died June 6, 2009 in Seattle of complications from breast cancer. She is survived by her husband of 45 years, the Reverend John V. Worthington; son, Mark F. Worthington (Amy); daughters Elizabeth J. Roehrig (Tom) and Katherine A. Haworth (Michael); and five grandchildren: Haylie, Evan and Matthew Roehrig; Ethan Haworth; and Kyle Worthington. Barbara was born in Los Angeles, CA on August 7, 1936, the daughter of Lester Shields DeVall and Aileen May Mitchell. After graduating from Occidental College, she received M.A. and B.D. degrees from San Francisco Theological Seminary in 1962 and 1964. She was ordained a Minister in the Presbyterian Church (USA) in 1979 and served in various capacities in southern California until 1990, when she became the Executive Presbyter of the Presbytery of the Palisades in northeastern New Jersey. She retired to Whidbey Island, WA in 2003. Barbara enjoyed time with her children and grandchildren and was proud of their accomplishments. She traveled extensively among the churches of southeast Asia and traveled with John in Europe, Russia and China. God blessed Barbara with extraordinary skills of administration which she used in her ordained ministry. She blessed her family and churches in her care with her love and compassion. Her death comes too early for us all. Gifts in her memory may be made to Susan G. Komen for the Cure or to ministries of the churches of the Presbyterian Church (USA).

A.L. PITCHERS ON THE MOVE Who says it's a two-horse race for this season's American League Cy Young Award? While Kansas City's Zack Greinke (8 wins, 1.72 E.R.A.) and Toronto's Roy Halladay (10 wins, 2.53 E.R.A.) deserve front-runner status, indications are the field for the A.L. award will be crowded. Three other starters -- Detroit's Edwin Jackson, Anaheim's Jered Weaver and Seattle's Erik Bedard -- have E.R.A.'s under 2.50, and could make a summer charge. From off the pace, Detroit's Justin Verlander (9.00 E.R.A. after four starts) and Boston's Josh Beckett (7.22 E.R.A. after five starts) are moving into contention. Verlander (7-0, 1.10 E.R.A. since April 27) was so good in Wednesday's 2-1 complete-game win over the White Sox that Chicago's John Danks raved about Verlander's ''almost PlayStation stuff.'' Beckett (4-0, 0.76 E.R.A. in his last five starts) allowed one hit in six innings in a win Wednesday over the Yankees.

RABBAN--Meyer, age 90, died at home in NYC on June 8th. He is survived by Elana, his beloved wife of sixty years, and his loving children, David, Miriam and Jessica, Jessica's husband, Matthew Schofield, and their two children, Rebecca and Benjamin. He was a member of the Psychology Faculty at Sarah Lawrence College from 1949 to 1988. During his career at Sarah Lawrence, he was also the Director of the Windward School from 1955 to 1961 and a teacher in the evening program of the Bank Street College of Education from 1950 to 1960. He directed summer programs at Bronx House Emmanuel Community House from 1952 to 1959 and at Camp Rainbow from 1960 to 1978. He was the National Administrative Secretary of the American Student Zionist Federation from 1939 to 1942. He served with the United States Army in Europe from 1942 to 1946. After the war, he was on special duty at Bad Ischl, Austria to assist the resettlement of survivors of the Matthausen and Ebensee concentration camps. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Scholarship Fund of Sarah Lawrence College, the New Israel Fund, or the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Even Bruce Springsteen jams at Bonnaroo. Phish was Bonnaroo’s finale, playing two sets on Sunday night, and to cap its first one, Phish’s guitarist, Trey Anastasio — who could not have been grinning any wider — described the first rock concert he ever attended, in Princeton, N.J., as a show “exploding with energy for three straight hours.” Then he brought out his “boyhood hero,” the rocker who played that concert: Mr. Springsteen, still in Tennessee after headlining Bonnaroo on Saturday night.

It was that kind of weekend for Susan Boyle. A spokeswoman for the singer told The Associated Press that Ms. Boyle was scheduled to rejoin a live tour of “Britain’s Got Talent” performers at a Monday-night concert in Glasgow, after missing earlier stops on the tour over the weekend. Ms. Boyle, 48, shot to fame as a contestant on the reality competition, but placed second in the show’s finals in May, losing to a dance troupe called Diversity. Since then, Ms. Boyle briefly checked into a London clinic where she was treated for exhaustion. After her release, she played her first shows on the “Britain’s Got Talent” tour in Birmingham and Sheffield in England, but did not appear at a Sunday matinee and evening show at the Manchester Evening News Arena. Her spokeswoman said Ms. Boyle was expected to remain with the tour through its conclusion in July.

Updated | 3:01 p.m. More than two years after his comic book death, the sentinel of liberty known as Captain America is returning to the land of the living. Captain America Reborn, a five-part series published by Marvel Entertainment, will begin in July and is written by Ed Brubaker and illustrated by Bryan Hitch, one of the comic book industry’s most acclaimed artists. Mr. Brubaker is the regular writer of the Captain America series, including issue No. 25, published in 2007, in which the title hero was felled by an assassin’s bullet. It was a shot heard around the world as many news organizations carried word of the death of the captain, and his replacement by his former sidekick Bucky Barnes (a k a the Winter Soldier).

A sculpture intended to celebrate the European Union but that offended several of its member countries is on display uncensored in Prague, Agence France-Presse reported. The sculpture, called Entropa, was commissioned to mark the start of the Czech Republic’s six-month presidency of the European Union. Each of its interlocking segments was supposed to celebrate the union’s 27 member nations but instead offered satirical depictions: Italy was represented with a soccer field; Romania was shown as a Count Dracula theme park; a series of toilets stood in for Bulgaria. (The toilets were covered up after a protest by the Bulgarian permanent representative to the European Union.) Each piece of the sculpture was to be produced by a different artist, but Entropa was later revealed to be the work of the Czech sculptor David Cerny and two friends. At an unveiling at a private gallery on Thursday, Vaclav Havel, the former Czech president, said jokingly that the sculpture had been made by him and Jiri Paroubek, a Czech politician who initiated a no-confidence vote against the government in March.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Erykah Badu came onstage about as incognito as a headliner could, wearing a hoodie (Public Enemy logo) with shades over artfully ripped and paint-spattered blue jeans. At one point, she even had a hat on top of the hoodie. But even before she showed her face, her songs were tell-alls: about her age, her babies, her gap between albums, her body, her first romance, with each revelation drawing approving oohs from women in the audience. Her band played serenely undulating vamps as Ms. Badu sang, rhymed and scat-sang what might have been a stream-of-consciousness autobiography. But it wasn’t; her backup singers, both rehearsed and attentive, underlined selected phrases with neat harmonies, proof that Ms. Badu had her story all planned out.Merle Haggard‘s anti-hippie broadside from 1969, “Okie from Muskogee,” is his signature song; his band plays it for his entrance and exit onstage. By now, he’s played it in all sorts of places. But there was still a little piquancy to see him sing “We don’t smoke marijuana in Muskogee/We don’t take our trips on LSD” to a tie-dyed crowd with, shall we say, a different lifestyle. And while it was drinking songs and Johnny Cash hits that got the crowd whooping loudest, Mr. Haggard also set out his down-to-earth populism, starting his set with a trenchant song about debt: “A Working Man Can’t Get Nowhere Today.”

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Snoop Dogg turned Bonnaroo’s hippie party into a “gangsta party,” all about sex, drugs and cash. Taken as anything but an X-rated cartoon, his songs are virtually nonstop sleaze, detailing a life of arrogant excess and giving explicit instructions to an endless supply of willing women. (It’s impressive that he has come up with enough variations to sustain a career since 1993.) The bounce of the music and his nonchalant delivery combine to come across as amiable, and his set on Bonnaroo’s largest stage drew a crowd ready to sing along and raise a middle finger in the air on cue. The biggest smiles and loudest singalongs came from “the ladies” for whom he usually uses a different word.

Having scared the pants off us with his film adaptation of “The Silence of the Lambs,” the director Jonathan Demme has decided to turn his attention to something truly frightening: directing for the theater. Mr. Demme will make his stage directing debut with MCC Theater’s production of “Family Week” next year, the theater company said Monday.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Phish’s Sunday-night sets, closing out Bonnaroo, were the kind that drive jam-band haters crazy. The setlist was mostly light-hearted, two-chord and three-chord songs, unlike Friday’s set, which had a higher proportion of Phish’s more elaborate compositions. And there’s nothing like a long two-chord vamp to tempt a jam band into noodling territory. But Phish didn’t succumb; the songs were varied ones, like the swaggering “Bathtub Gin” (with Page McConnell pounding free-jazz clusters and glissandos on piano) and the bluesy “Character Zero.” And Trey Anastasio — no doubt aware of Bruce Springsteen in the wings — aimed for ascending, guitar-hero solos that the band could push into crescendo after crescendo. (The crowd did a mass glowstick toss at each crest.) Near the end of the second set, in “Farmhouse,” concentration did give way to noodling, though Phish played on, eventually shaping up for encores. Maybe it was Bonnaroo fatigue setting in.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Is Bonnaroo too retro? It does rely on touring veterans and longtime favorites, threatening to turn it into an oldies extravaganza — though they’re good oldies like “Born to Run” and Public Enemy’s full-length performance of the 1988 album “It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back” (one that I unfortunately missed).

The A&E drama “The Beast,” which starred Patrick Swayze as an undercover F.B.I. agent, will not be renewed for a second season, The Associated Press reported. The show, whose 13-episode run began in January, drew notice when its production was announced last June, about six months after Mr. Swayze was given a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. Mr. Swayze continued to work on the series under the supervision of doctors hired by A&E and his own physicians. Though recent reports had indicated “The Beast” was likely canceled, A&E did not confirm the show’s fate until Monday.

David Letterman directly apologized to Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska and her daughters on his program Monday night, saying he took responsibility for a joke that had offended Ms. Palin, her family, and her supporters.
A lawsuit seeks to reopen documents on 1,150 New York City teachers who were investigated during the anti-Communist fervor of the 1950s. More than 370 were ousted from their jobs.
Much of the talk in the college basketball world on Monday was about who was entering the N.B.A. draft and who was returning to school.

NBC's Game 7 broadcast of the Stanley Cup final between the Penguins and the Red Wings on Friday night drew an average of 8 million viewers, the biggest American television audience for any N.H.L. game since the 9.4 million who watched the Game 6 Cup finale between Montreal and Chicago in 1973.

Now is probably as good a time as any to do the Fifth Down's once-weekly Brett Favre post.
“HawthoRNe,” a hospital drama beginning Tuesday on TNT, stars Jada Pinkett Smith as a nurse who is too predictably valiant.

My mother had always feared domestic animals, but now as a plump neighborhood cat ran up our driveway, she gazed at the feline, and revealed that 70 years ago she had had a pet cat. Her 87-year-old eyes teared up. Her cat was white, she said, and so thin you could see its ribs. Still, she loved to cuddle it. It wasn't a house cat - it couldn't have been, because she was imprisoned at the time, in a forced-labor camp the Nazis set up in Poland, the country where my mother was born and raised. Back then she was as emaciated as the cat, but still she shared her food with it. It gave her comfort she said, and it was a way of fighting back, to help this animal that, like her, the Germans planned to let die.

David Letterman directly apologized to Gov. Sarah Palin and her daughters on his program Monday night, saying he took responsibility for a joke that had offended Ms. Palin, her family, and her supporters.
Women's Designer of the Year: Rodarte.

Oh, hello. Back for the Swarovski young designer awards. For men's: Tim Hamilton, whose first words for "Wow, I didn't really prepare a speech." For accessories: Subversive. And women's: Alexander Wang (in shorts).

For accessories: Proenza Schouler. The first Popular Vote Award: Ralph Lauren (in tuxedo jacket and jeans). Men's wear designer: Scott Sternberg and Italo Zucchelli, a tie. Jacobs is about to receive the international award-given by Antoine Arnault. More to come...

In our discussion about the rising burden of student loans, we received numerous comments from readers who took on a lot of debt to pay for their education. Some found they simply couldn't afford to repay the loans with the jobs they found after college. Others said their debts determined their life choices. Still others wondered if the college experience was worth the financial burden they'll carry for decades afterward. Here are excerpts from their comments.
Whether it's cars or consumer electronics, manufacturers' design concepts almost never make it to production; instead their best features are adopted into more mundane, less controversial versions.
Lehman Brothers, which is liquidating in bankruptcy, paid its restructuring adviser, Alvarez & Marsal, $77.3 million in fees, according a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Marc Jacobs and his business partner Robert Duffy are sitting in the row in front of me, with folks from Vogue in front of them. Tracey Ullman has just come on the stage, saluting Diane Von Furstenberg and Michelle Obama. The theatre is packed. Here we go...

The sociologist Andrew J. Cherlin recently wrote a commentary about how recessions tend to discourage divorces because splitting up becomes unaffordable. Others have written about the relationship (or lack thereof) between divorce rates and the business cycle here at The Times and elsewhere.

New claims for unemployment insurance are one of the highest-frequency economic indicators we have -- that is, the data come in early and often, giving a quicker read than things like employment numbers and unemployment rates. And there's been some celebrating over the fact that new claims seem to have peaked.

The Congressional Budget Office late this afternoon released its estimate of the cost of the health care bill (in draft form) that is known as the Kennedy-Dodd legislation, after Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Christopher Dodd who sit on the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee.

Apple's decision to build an SD (for Secure Digital) card slot into its new 13- and 15-inch MacBook Pro laptops has raised some eyebrows from those who question its utility. Not to mention the fact that there's no longer a functional ExpressCard slot in those Pro models.
Virgin Mobile is offering a prepaid wireless broadband phone modem, an apparent first in the United States.

A lawyer for the American International Group told jurors on Monday that its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, plundered an A.I.G. retirement program of billions of dollars because he was angry at being forced out of the company.
Robert Powers, the Boston Globe spokesman, confirms that negotiators from the company and the union are, once again, talking substantive contract issues - not just how to carry out a pay cut.

David Letterman directly apologized to Gov. Sarah Palin and her daughters on his program Monday night, saying he took responsibility for a joke that had offended Ms. Palin, her family and her supporters.

More than 100 victims of Bernard L. Madoff's $65 billion Ponzi scheme have filed emotional letters with the Federal District Court in Manhattan, and eight of them have asked to speak at his sentencing on June 29.
Like to play jazz? Then imagine having a nine-time Grammy winner teach you a thing or two. In the White House, no less.
If fourth-graders can learn astrophysics on the tees at Rocket Park, what else can be taught on on a miniature golf course?
The new "Frontline" report chronicles the strained union between Bank of America and Merrill Lynch in the wake of the fall financial earthquake.

Officials at The Boston Globe and its parent, The New York Times Company, said that Monday's session with The Globe's largest union, the Newspaper Guild, was merely an information session, to explain to the guild how the company planned to carry out a 23 percent pay cut.

The women's qualifying draw came online on Monday and a host of talented Americans look to do well on the dicey grass at Roehampton. A quirk of Wimbledon qualifying is the 96-player draw, rather than a full 128. And there are only 12 qualifying spots rather than the 16 allotted to the men here. One way to understand the draw is to see it as twelve small tourneys of eight players, single elimination, with the winner advancing to the main draw. So if you like a particular player, zoom in on her part of the draw and see who comes through.
In the future, Amazon.com's Kindle e-book reader will display more book formats beyond its own. And you should also expect to see Kindle books on a lot more devices.

Thanks to the folks who sent in photos, as requested, of festivities at Celebrate South Orange and the SOMe Book Fest in South Orange on Saturday. Here is a slideshow, compiled by Alex Lowther. As you can see, a good time was had by all, despite the rain. Thanks to Matt Glass, Carole Anzalone-Newman of Main Street South Orange, and Marietta B. Zacker of the Book Fest for sending photos.

Moody's Investors Service said Monday that it was considering whether to lower its credit ratings for the big Swiss bank UBS, which has been hit hard by the financial crisis and faces an investigation by Washington into its American clients' offshore accounts.

Parents and doctors often fret about childhood food preferences as kids gravitate toward foods like French fries, chicken nuggets and burgers. But some fascinating new data from market researcher NPD Group suggests kids' eating habits are changing and many kids are now choosing healthier fare.
Jada Pinkett Smith plays the strong but embattled title character of  this hospital drama, which begins Tuesday on TNT.
Betsy Morgan, the chief executive of The Huffington Post, is leaving the news Web site after less than two years on the job.
Now, this is what's called a road trip.

Hand-wringing, breast-beating and finger-pointing appear to have been the order of the day at last week's World Copyright Summit of the International Confederation of Societies of Authors and Composers in Washington. At least that's the impression from this report, from the Intellectual Property Watch Web site.
Could it be that the Yankees have a better bullpen than we think?

Calpers, the nation's biggest public pension fund, decided Monday to allow its investment staff to increase its asset allocation for private equity and venture capital investments and to reduce its stock holdings.

The city is evicting Citarella, the upscale fish and food retailer, from its Harlem market and reclaiming the 125th Street-area properties because Citarella failed to complete renovations that were part of a 2001 sale contract.
A. O. Scott reviews Sidney Lumet's 1975 drama "Dog Day Afternoon."

Update | June 16, 8:11 a.m. Removed reference to Facebook not reserving Web addresses for Times reporters. Facebook says it did reserve custom addresses for a number of reporters covering Facebook, including a Times reporter.

Tuesday night at 7:30 p.m., the Maplewood Township Committee will be meeting at the Municipal Building, at 574 Valley Street. The agenda includes discussion of a proposed law requiring that the township be notified immediately when homes go into foreclosure, and potentially-historic resolutions in support of gay marriage.

PARIS | Some film festivals are dedicated to a director, some to a country. The Forum des Images -- a modish oasis in the otherwise drab Les Halles underground mall -- has chosen a less common theme: revenge.

Members of the union representing food workers in the South Orange Maplewood School District plan to bring their complaints of union intimidation by the district's food service provider to tonight's Board of Education meeting. Jake Lynn, a union representative, explains the union's complaint here. The Local has asked the food company, Pomptonian Food Service, for a statement expressing its viewpoint. In an interview, the company said it is a 50-year-old family-owned business and serves 70 school districts in New Jersey.

It is sadly too easy to find examples of federal technology projects gone awry. To Vivek Kundra, the nation's new chief information officer, one seems to stick in his craw: An effort to build a handheld computer for examiners conducting the 2010 census was abandoned last year, wasting $600 million. Mr. Kundra, who when I met him earlier this month was juggling both a BlackBerry and an iPhone, is shocked that the government could not simply find a way to use an existing smartphone or similar device.

Almost cinematic in its sweep, the photo by Ben Curtis of The Associated Press that leads Monday's slide show conveys the scope of political opposition to the presidential election results in Iran, where Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was declared the winner. At the other end of the spectrum, Olivier Laban-Mattei of Agence France-Presse presents strikingly intimate views of two of the opposition candidates in public appearances: Mir Hussein Moussavi (Slide 2) and Mehdi Karroubi (Slide 3).

Alex Smith, the Millburn High School student who was injured in the Jan. 9 fight at Millburn High School involving Rev. Darryl L. George and his two sons, was cleared of assault and bias intimidation charges last week, according to Paul Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County Prosecutor's Office. The charges were dismissed on June 9, he said.

The Royal Academy of Antwerp end-of-year show last week was so epic and cinematic - not to mention as long as a feature film - that at one point I found myself wishing I had brought popcorn. Held on a round stage in a hangar that brought to mind a film set, the presentation (repeated over three nights) was watched by over 6,000 spectators, including the fashion critic Suzy Menkes, the designer Olivier Theyskens and former graduate Walter van Beirendonck.
BMW is developing a system to bring a car or truck to a complete stop (safely) if the driver loses control because of health-related problems.

Citigroup's chairman, Richard D. Parsons, said Monday that the bank expected to pay back the $45 billion it borrowed from the government's banking bailout program, but that it had no timetable for doing so.
President Obama spoke about his health care proposals at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, a group that has been lukewarm about some of his proposals for reforming health care.

Sun Microsystems may have dropped a bit of weight by the time Oracle officially acquires the company. According to two people briefed on Sun's plans, the company has canceled its Rock chip project, putting an end to one of its biggest revitalization bets.
The discount retailer Syms and Vornado Realty Trust won an auction for the discount chain Filene's Basement, a Filene's executive said Monday.

Porsche may sell a stake for as much as 2.5 billion euros, or about $3.45 billion, to Qatar as the German automaker seeks to cut debt and stay independent of Volkswagen, Bloomberg News reports, citing two unidentified people familiar with the situation.
The Blog of Legal Times (aka BLT) pointed many of us to remarks made by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who said she would welcome Judge Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court.

G. Warren Whitaker, a Manhattan-based trusts and estates lawyer, received a telephone call in December 2003 from a lawyer working for Brooke Astor with an urgent request. Mrs. Astor was not satisfied with a recent amendment she had made to her will, and she wanted to do more, Mr. Whitaker said he was told by the lawyer, Francis X. Morrissey Jr.

There were more absences today at Millburn Middle School -- 176 -- than there were on Thursday, when the decision was made to close it on Friday. The school reopened today after being closed for cleaning. Two students at the school were confirmed as having swine flu last week. There were 170 absences at the school on Thursday, and six more were absent today. The issue will be discussed at tonight's Board of Education meeting, according to district spokeswoman Nancy Dries, who added that it wasn't known how many absences were related to flu-like symptoms. Several different bugs are going around, including strep, and parents may be more likely than usual to keep their students home, because of fear of flu, she said. TINA KELLEY

In a sign that it may become more aggressive on intellectual property rights, NBC Universal is moving its top corporate communication executive, Cory Shields, to a newly created position of executive vice president for global policy strategies.

In today's Science Times, Personal Health columnist Jane E. Brody discusses borderline personality disorder, a surprisingly common mood disorder that has profound ramifications not just for patients but for family and friends as well. One recovered patient describes it as "a serious psychiatric disorder involving a pervasive sense of emptiness, impulsivity, difficulty with emotions, transient stress-induced psychosis and frequent suicidal thoughts or attempts."

By a 37 to 10 vote, the New York City Council on Monday called on the State Legislature to raise the city's share of the sales tax to 4.5 percent from 4 percent, a move that is expected to raise $518 million in the fiscal year that starts next month and help alleviate some of the city's mounting fiscal pressures.

Opening arguments began Monday in Texas in Huntsman's lawsuit against Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank. The suit is one of the few major conflicts from the busted buyout boom that remain unresolved; Steven M. Davidoff (a/k/a The Deal Professor) is live-blogging the arguments, via a video feed from Courtroom View Network. The most recent posts are at the top.

If you're anything like me, you're carrying on more often these days. I'll avoid those pesky fees for checked baggage if I possibly can, and, anyway, lately I seem to be taking shorter trips and therefore packing less. So I was pleased to see that the luggage maker Tumi has just launched a new line called Tumi Light, promising bags that weigh 25 percent to 40 percent less than other models.In the classic Alpha collection, Tumi is introducing a Light version of the carry-on duffel and the carry-on wheelie with zipper expansion; in the more streamlined Voyageur collection, there's a 20-inch and 22-inch wheelie. The Alpha bags come in standard colors like black and brown, while the Voyageurs also have flashier purple and python models.
Though there was a fair amount of personal material in my piece about fish last week, there were some stories left untold.

A little over two years ago, I wrote a piece for The New York Times about Kool-Aid pickles. "Kool-Aid pickles violate tradition, maybe even propriety, " I wrote. "Depending on your palate and perspective, they are either the worst thing to happen to pickles since plastic brining barrels or a brave new taste sensation to be celebrated." I was writing from the Mississippi Delta, which appears to be where Kool-Aid pickles were first created.
Imagine a women's final at Wimbledon without nonstop shrieking. Let's say one of the players repeatedly rushes the net. And neither the players nor the rackets are big.
The Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Orlando Magic in Game 5 of the NBA Finals on Sunday, winning the championship over all and lifting ABC to another No. 1 finish in the night's ratings.

Toyota is in the uneasy position of watching small aftermarket companies make claims about turning its Prius into a car that gets 100 miles a gallon. The popularity of the Toyota hybrid, which has a spare-tire well that's perfect for a second battery pack, could be seen as flattering, but bad conversions could also mar the company's reputation.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gave a much-anticipated speech on Israel and Palestine yesterday. Though overshadowed by events in Iran, Netanyahu's speech was itself history making: he "reversed his longstanding opposition to Palestinian statehood"; "firmly rejected American demands for a complete freeze on Israeli settlements in the West Bank," and demanded that Palestinians recognize Israel as a Jewish state, among other preconditions to negotiation.

If you've been avoiding Twitter, here's a new reason for foodies and travelers to sign up. NYC Restaurant Week, where top restaurants offer three-course lunches for $24.07 and prix-fixe dinners for $35, is tweeting this summer.
Extended Stay, a hotel chain sold for $8 billion near the height of the private equity boom, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday in New York in the hope of restructuring its debt.

The Local posted the Millburn budget online recently, asked for your questions and brought them to Tim Gordon, business administrator of Millburn Township, during an interview Friday. He's been in government for more than 20 years and has ready knowledge of the budget.

More and more, big movie studios avoid "sneaking" their broad-appeal pictures. The practice - opening a movie on a limited basis to ignite buzz in advance of its broad release - can backfire by drawing poor word of mouth. Even if people like the movie, sneak previews can take money off the opening-weekend table and deprive marketers of pushing the "America's No. 1 Comedy!" button.

Slaughterhouse, the new Deste Foundation space on the island of Hydra, opens tomorrow as a satellite addition to the second Athens Biennale, a much anticipated stop on the June 2009 art safari. Among the highlights offered by Deste, the collector Dakis Joannou's foundation, is the mysterious union of the international art stars Matthew Barney and Elizabeth Peyton. Scant details have been divulged about the collaborative site-specific project, aside from this enigmatic submarine-archeology-meets-cryogenics photograph so we're more than a little intrigued. Look for dispatches from Hydra over the next two days.
Only days after his 26th birthday and transporting his goal-scoring shoes from San Jose to Houston, Cam Weaver did what he has done so well during his young professional career -- score goals.

Tom Colicchio's 'wichcraft, will be extending its reach in Bryant Park by creating the menu for a new pop-up lounge, The Southwest Porch, that will open there on June 19. The cafe, at the southwest corner of the park, will serve sandwiches and small plates of cheeses and charcuterie, and drinks.

President Obama took his health care overhaul proposal to one of its more skeptical audiences on Monday, telling doctors at the American Medical Association conference in Chicago that the United States is "not a nation that accepts nearly 46 million uninsured men, women and children."

Well, I'm enough of a conventional economist to think that there's no substitute for a model with dotted i's and crossed t's; it's not THE TRUTH, but it really does help clarify your thinking.
Herbs, not necessarily lettuce, make for delicious salads.
The French for "golden ears" - a nickname for submariners trained to detect acoustic signals.
Protesters massed in the streets of Tehran even as state media reported the Iranian supreme leader’s call for an inquiry into the presidential election’s outcome.
A year ago, Laura Robson won the girls singles title at Wimbledon as a 14-year-old and became the future of women's tennis in Britain. This year, she's a long-shot wild card in the main draw.

There are few New York dreams that do not require money to make them come true. Now the city's dreamers have a new place to turn for funds -- and they are turning.

If you're a regular reader of the Open blog, you're familiar with the Times Developer Network, the TimesOpen event and other Times open-source initiatives. We rely on open-source software to accomplish many critical tasks behind the scenes of NYTimes.com, so we take every opportunity to give back to the open-source community. Today we're releasing a PHP framework called NYT_Transformer: a flexible data processor that can be customized for various input and output types.

The Boston Globe and its largest union today are having a ... well, it's not clear what they're having. All we know for sure is that the people who couldn't reach a contract settlement are, once again, in the same room together.

Update | 4:42 p.m. Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, the influential Pennsylvania Democrat, has demanded that the Securities and Exchange Commission provide Congress with an update on its internal investigation into why the agency failed to detect Bernard L. Madoff's $65 billion Ponzi scheme, despite repeated warnings.

In a surprising move that illustrates how far the financial health of European hockey has deteriorated from its robust state of just a year ago, the International Ice Hockey Federation has called off the Champions Hockey League for the 2009-10 season. In its announcement of the postponement, released Monday, the I.I.H.F. vowed that the league would return in 2010-11.
A brand of premium-priced rum is suggesting that rum drinkers forgo the Coke -- or any mixer, for that matter -- and also say no to garnishes and other embellishments.

A while back, I made a marinade with bay leaves, and when I put the meat on the fire, one of the leaves burned. The smell was enticing, so reminiscent of grilling in the Mediterranean that I got into the habit of throwing a few leaves on the fire before adding meat. It affected the flavor only subtly, but it delighted the cook: this is aromatherapy.

We have received 60 comments thus far on our post last week about a group of researchers at the American Enterprise Institute who released a report on the six-year graduation rates of individual universities.

The Penguins' Stanley Cup parade steps off at noon Monday, and the weather is great for the event. Not sure how many local television stations are streaming it live on their Web sites, but coverage on the Web site of WPXI began at 11 a.m. Eastern.

Low-season deals to the Caribbean abound. CheapCarribbean.com, an online discounter, is offering all-inclusive Caribbean packages starting at $49 a night. The deal, which is good for various 3- to 7-night stays through Dec. 18, covers 13 mid-priced resorts in the Dominican Republic, Jamaica and Mexico.

The Youth Orchestras of Essex County had a bon voyage concert at Seton Hall yesterday, kicking off their overseas performance tour of Austria, including stops in Vienna, Salzburg and Innsbruck.

The Item of Millburn and Short Hills provides an update about Millburn's unsuccessful attempt to join in a lawsuit by Livingston against the builder of proposed affordable housing and a commercial development at the Tutor Time building on South Orange Avenue, the former site of Don's Restaurant.

Lincoln National, the insurance company, said it would take nearly $1 billion in federal bailout funds, issue new stock and debt, and sell its British insurance business in an effort to shore up its deteriorating capital base.

It was the final day of business for the Virgin Megastore chain in North America, which at its peak had 23 locations but by Sunday was down to two: the 57,000-square-foot, two-level New York outlet, and a smaller Hollywood shop that was also set to close.

Bill Pennington, who writes the On Par feature for The Times, answered readers' questions on Monday about the United States Open, which begins Thursday at Bethpage Black golf course in Farmingdale, N.Y.

Summer finally seems to be here, and it's time to celebrate with a new haircut. The most directional one of the season, as far as we can tell, comes courtesy of the superstar stylist Luigi Murenu, who was responsible for the tough, Latino-inspired buzzcuts at Givenchy's fall 2009 runway show. Murenu turned heads with a supersevere two-tier crop - the sides and back were fully shaved halfway up, and the rest was cropped short. If you're willing to try the look, we suggest you print this page and take it to your barber; if you decide to use clippers at home, we are not responsible for the outcome.

Update | 12:33 p.m. Clarifying G.E. comments on initial funding for health-records loan program in post and headline. While it is setting aside $2 billion for financing of health information technology, its initial commitment for loans to accelerate adoption of electronic health records is $100 million.
Obama Foodorama reports that Queen Elizabeth has planted a vegetable garden at Buckingham Palace.

Greenhill & Company said it hired two high-level consumer and retail bankers from UBS in London, Seamus Moorhead and Charles Gournay, as the boutique investment bank continued to expand after the financial crisis.

As debates over national and global climate and energy policy continue to drag out, there's been an intensifying exploration of climate miscommunication among those seeking concrete actions that will make a noticeable difference in the atmosphere someday. If the science pointing to a rising risk of dangerous human interference with climate is settled, the thinking goes, then why aren't people and the world's nations galvanized? Maybe it's a language problem? This reflects an ongoing exploration here.
It's getting awfully crowded in the elevator.
Updated, 1:37 p.m. | The weapons-possession case against the former New York Giants wide receiver Plaxico Burress was adjourned on Monday until Sept. 23.
To start your day, links to some of the best media coverage in today's New York Times:

We were apartment hunting in Fort Greene late last year and thought we'd struck gold on the first try: a two-bedroom in a corner brownstone, sunny, near the park, and the best part: a big -- by Brooklyn standards -- backyard.
The Big Apple Barbecue wasn't the only food party to draw a crowd this weekend. Sounds like the Great American Food and Music Fest in Mountain View, Calif., was a bit too well-attended.

A new study holds potentially unwelcome news for wind power developers: wind speeds in the United States have dropped 15 to 30 percent over the course of about 30 years. And one possible cause, according to the authors, is climate change.

The concept of "ad creep" - advertising coming to sites where it never used to appear - has become pervasive in recent years, thanks to pitches turning up in places like airport baggage carrousels, the lobbies of movie theaters and parks. Now, a company that specializes in installing ads in parking garages is expanding to the United States.
Census data on births among Asian-Americans may reflect not only a preference for male babies, but also a growing embrace of sex selection, demographers say.

As our colleagues in Tehran, Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi, continue to update their news coverage with the latest developments on Monday, The Lede is tracking the aftermath of Iran's disputed presidential election online, as we did over the weekend. Please refresh this page throughout the day to get the latest updates at the top of your screen. Readers inside Iran or in touch with people there are encouraged to use the comments box below to share what you are hearing or seeing with us.

President Obama heads to Chicago on Monday morning, to speak to the American Medical Association, a still-powerful lobby that has already come out against a public health care option, the centerpiece of Mr. Obama's proposal for health care reform.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said it had completed a series of investments in Ma Anshan Modern Farming, a dairy farm company based in the central Chinese province of Anhui, Reuters reported.
Apple's iPhoto software lets me easily organize and edit pictures on my Mac, but the program can sometimes get a little erratic over time, especially with large photo libraries. How do I fix it?

Friday night and Sunday afternoon saw welcome bursts of sunshine, but last week and, alas, this week could set records for dreariness. Celebrate South Orange was a bit soggy, and I'm still recovering from having small children crawl into bed any time there's thunder. And there may be storms five of the next 10 days!
A prototype of the Solar Impulse, an aircraft powered entirely by the sun, is expected to be unveiled on June 26 at an airfield near Zurich in Switzerland.

The Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, one of Japan's three megabanks, said Monday that it planned to raise significantly more cash than expected in a major share sale - as much as 923 billion yen ($9.4 billion), Bettina Wassener of The New York Times reported.
Cypress Sharpridge Investments said late Thursday that it had raked in $100 million in its initial public offering.
The British private equity firm Permira is interested in bidding for the Irish telecommunications group Eircom, The Sunday Times of London reported, without citing its sources.
TomTom, largest maker of car-navigation devices in Europe, announced plans Sunday to raise 430 million euros ($601.4 million) in a private rights offering.

Sprint Nextel plans to sell a swath of its cellular network in the Midwest, as a part of a February ruling that the telecom giant had violated an exclusivity agreement with its affiliate iPCS in certain regions.
Rothschild said Monday that it hired Laurence Grafstein, a former Lazard banker, to be co-head of the investment bank's mergers and acquisitions group in the United States.
Barclays' $13.5 billion deal to sell its Barclays Global Investors to BlackRock, will also translate into a windfall for the British bank's president, Robert E. Diamond Jr.

For most of its history, the Federal Reserve has been a high temple of monetary matters, guiding the economy by setting interest rates but remaining aloof from the messy details of day-to-day business.
BeeTV, a developer of a personalized television programming guide, has landed $8 million in a fresh round of financing led by Italian venture capital firm Innogest.

Health care legislation will dominate the agenda in Congress this week, with the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee scheduled to begin detailed work on its bill at a hearing on Tuesday afternoon.

This week, John Cronin, director and chief executive of the Beacon Institute for Rivers and Estuaries and a senior fellow for environmental affairs at Pace University, answered readers' questions about General Electric's project to remove PCBs from the Hudson River.

Update with press release | 9:18 a.m. Jared Kushner's Observer Media Group has snapped up an 80 percent stake in the Very Short List, the entertainment and media e-mail tip sheet owned by Barry Diller's media conglomerate I.A.C., The New York Post reported.
News Parody | From The Onion:
Commerzbank, the second-largest bank in Germany after Deutsche Bank, has agreed to sell its Dutch private bank, Dresdner VPV, to the unit's own management for an undisclosed sum.

What: Gap Design Edition Vena Cava zip dressHow Much: $88 at gap.com (available Tuesday)Who: Lindsey Gathright, T Magazine's women's fashion assistant From Comme des Garçons for H&M to the upcoming Christopher Kane for Top Shop, designer collaborations with mass-market retailers is a trend that only gets bigger -- and better. Some of my past favorites include a navy leaf print cardigan from Proenza Schouler's Target line and tie-dye shirt dress by Thakoon that I also bought at Target. Wallet-friendly, well-designed and surprisingly good quality, these pieces make for tantalizing impulse buys that are also relatively sensible. Tomorrow, the Gap will unveil its new khaki-theme Design Edition collection designed by 2008 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner Alexander Wang and runners up Lisa Mayock and Sophie Buhai of Vena Cava, and the hat designer Albertus Swanepoel. Vena Cava's chic summer dress will be number one on my buy list. The graphic black print and the toothsome zip front detail give khaki an edge, and like other Vena Cava pieces, it feels handmade. (At $88, you might even have some change left over to add to your summer getaway fund, or a more responsible savings account.) For fashion fans eager to meet the CFDA fashion stars, the Gap will be hosting an event at its New York City store on 54th Street and 5th Avenue at 10:30 a.m. on June 16, the same day the collection will be available nationwide.

OBITUARIES.

An obituary on Wednesday about Norman Brinker, the restaurant innovator who made Chili’s Grill and Bar the core of an international chain, misstated the given name of his second wife and omitted her maiden name. She was Magrit — not Margaret — Fendt. The article also misstated the number of restaurants in the original Chili’s chain that Mr. Brinker acquired. There were 23, not 28.

An obituary on May 15 about Robert R. Pauley, a former president of the ABC Radio network, referred incorrectly to his status while serving in the merchant marine during World War II. He held a position equivalent to that of lieutenant in the United States Naval Reserve; he was not a lieutenant in the merchant marine.
