BURBAGE--Edward A.,a 45 year resident of Pearl River, NY died Friday June 12, 2009 at home with his loving family around him. He was 86. Mr. Burbage was born August 14, 1922 in New Brunswick, NJ to James and Margaret Burbage. Edward served proudly in the United States Navy during WWII aboard the USS Zaniah in the South Pacific. Mr. Burbage worked as a Detective for the New York City Police Dept. He worked for the NYPD for 28 years, retiring 1971. Edward continue his career with the New York State attorney general's office assigned to the Attica prison investigation, Organized Crime Task Force, Medicare Fraud Task Force and the Dept of Correctional Services retiring in 1992 at the age of 70. On June 20, 1959 he married Patricia Winn at St. Clements's in Somerville, MA. He is survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Patricia. He was a beloved and dedicated father and father-in-law of Stephen and Susan Burbage of Wayland, MA and Ted and Jeanne Burbage of Bronxville, NY; and adored gradfather to Catie, Cole, Liam, Brendan and Kyle Burbage. Admired brother of Kevin, Roseleen, Sr. Joan SC, James and wife Maureen and Betty Burbage, predeceased by his sister Catherine and husband Vincent Kazel, Margaret and Denis O'Malley and sister-in-law Josephine. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held 10am Tuesday, June 16, 2009 at St. Aedan's R.C. Church, Pearl River, NY. Burial will follow at Ascension Cemetery, Airmont, NY. Visiting is Monday from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9pm at Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home Inc, 100 Franklin Ave, Pearl River, NY. In Lieu of flowers, friends may send memorial donations to United Hospice of Rockland, 11 Stokum Lane, New City, NY 10956.

The United States Open was also played at Bethpage in 2002, marking the first time the tournament was played on a truly public course. This year the U.S.G.A. has made some modifications to the Black Course. Many of the fairways are wider, many tee locations are new, the greens are likely to be faster and a graduated rough will be used. The course will also play 212 yards longer than in 2002. The U.S.G.A. has made these changes to introduce more risk-reward options for players, rewarding them for well-played strokes and penalizing them for bad shots. The following holes highlight some of the changes from 2002. 10 - In 2002, some players had difficulty reaching the fairway. To ensure this doesn't happen again, it has been brought closer to the tee by about 35 yards. Another change is a closely mowed area created behind the green to allow balls to roll out and give players more short-game options on their recovery shots.

SAUER Frank Xavier, passed away suddenly on June 12, 2009. He is survived by his devoted wife of 49 years, Donna, his loving children Kristen, Ingrid and Ivan, and his cherished grandchildren Mariah, Cole, Edie, Eliza and Lulu. He was a lifelong friend and brother-in-law to Roger and Peggy, and to Jan and Barbara, and a kind father-in-law to Robert, Amy and Harry. He is predeceased by his brother Joseph and his sisters Ann and Lorraine. He taught English at Rockland Community College for some 40 years, influencing generations of young minds. His life was exemplified by charm and wit, a love of both laughter and the world of ideas, and an immense affection for his family, who will miss him dearly. Wake will be on June 15 at 6-9pm at Carter Funeral Home, Croton-on-Hudson, and funeral will be on June 16 at 11am at St. Augustine's, Croton-on-Hudson. Donations may be made in his memory to Phelps Memorial Hospital, Cardiac Rehab and Wellness Center, in Sleepy Hollow.

Devoted father of doctors Andrew, Douglas, and Thomas; beloved father-in-law of Marjie, Leslie, and Teresa; loving grandfather of Jillian, Kathryn, Mark, Jason, Theodore, and Daphne. Served as a Vice President of Merrill Lynch. Harvard University Class of 1940. First Lieutenant in US Army during WWII. Services at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, at 11am on Monday, June 15.
International MAD AT RUSSIAN BAN ON MILK,

Asus Is Aiming Beyond the Netbook Two years ago, Asustek, a Taiwanese company, wowed the world with the hottest-selling computing product to arrive in recent memory: the Eee PC netbook. But even that blockbuster device has failed to do much to raise the profile of the company's brand in the United States, a situation the computer maker intends to correct.

SAUER Frank Xavier, passed away suddenly on June 12, 2009. He is survived by his devoted wife of 49 years, Donna, his loving children Kristen, Ingrid and Ivan, and his cherished grandchildren Mariah, Cole, Edie, Eliza and Lulu. He was a lifelong friend and brother-in-law to Roger and Peggy, and to Jan and Barbara, and a kind father-in-law to Robert, Amy and Harry. He is predeceased by his brother Joseph and his sisters Ann and Lorraine. He taught English at Rockland Community College for some 40 years, influencing generations of young minds. His life was exemplified by charm and wit, a love of both laughter and the world of ideas, and an immense affection for his family, who will miss him dearly. Wake will be on June 15 at 6-9pm at Carter Funeral Home, Croton-on-Hudson, and funeral will be on June 16 at 11am at St. Augustine's, Croton-on-Hudson. Donations may be made in his memory to Phelps Memorial Hospital, Cardiac Rehab and Wellness Center, in Sleepy Hollow.
HANK WILLIAMS JR. ''127 Rose Avenue'' (Curb)

HAUPTMAN--Jack, on June 12, 2009. Beloved husband of Janice. Devoted father of Lisa and her husband Sam. He was a noted Accountant in the New York Metropolitan area for many years. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services Tuesday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

TURNER--Louis B.,MD, FACP, died at age 88, on Thursday, June 11, 2009, in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife, Tanya K. Turner; his loving children: Jon, Kathi and Bob Turner; Ellen Bornstein, Roger Dubin and Barbara Dubin; his loving grandchildren: Jake Turner, Erin Dubin Ward and Jaid Dubin, Gregory and Jessica Goldner and Tannis Vallely. A graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, he was a devoted internist for 48 years in Roslyn, NY, who practiced at North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Hospital. A specialist in hypertension, he performed some of the initial research on multiple myeloma and peritoneal lavage. He was a Captain in the US Army during WWII and the Korean conflict. Lou leaves behind many loving friends and grateful patients. We are all better for having known him; he was a man filled with heart, who never lost his sense of humor. A memorial service will be held in Palm Beach Gardens, FL at a later date, to be announced.
WISIN & YANDEL ''La Revolución''

ESKIN--Diane, 72, died June 13, 2009, of cancer. Beloved daughter of the late Louis and Raye Eskin. Survived by her brother Robert and his wife Eden, nephew Blake, and niece Devra. Graduate of Cornell, class of 1958. Funeral service will be Monday 11am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

ARONIN--Anne M. (Mrs. Stanley Aronin), passed away on June 13, 2009. Visiting hours at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, on Monday 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at 11am on Wednesday at St. Catharine's R.C. Church, 25 Second Ave, Pelham, NY.

UNTERRICHT--Alayne Sharon of Hewlett, NY died peacefully June 13, 2009 after a mighty struggle with glioblastoma. Alayne is survived by husband Dr. Sam Unterricht; loving daughters Rachel, Allison and Stephanie; adoring father Isidore Finkelstein; and devoted brother Dr. David Finkelstein. She joins her darling mother, Kate, in heaven. Memorial services will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, 516-295-3100. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Brain Tumor Association (www.abta.org) or the Multiple Sclerosis Society (www.nationalmssociety.org). Alayne's vitality, superb taste, wise counsel and overflowing love will be cherished.

ABRAMS--Ethel, died peacefully in her apartment on June 9, 2009. She was 94. Born Ethel Kunis in 1915 in Fallsburg, NY, she worked at a family-run hotel as a teenager. She married Leonard Abrams in 1941, and lived for a time in Afghanistan and Liberia. After they returned to New York City, Ethel spent many years working at Associated Merchandising. Always concerned with social justice, she was active in her community and was a key figure in the Lincoln House Outreach program. She is fondly remembered by her numerous nieces, nephews, friends and neighbors. Memorial services will be June 18th at 3:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. (212)362-6600.

A few items worth examining today….The editors of The Times’s “Room for Debate” blog have engaged a handful of experts on the question of “How Much Student Debt is Too Much?”…A Times Metro reporter, Lisa W. Foderaro, examines Columbia University’s newly adopted budget, in a story headlined, “Despite Economy, Columbia Manages Small Increase in Its Spending Plans.” Her opening sentence: “While some other Ivy League schools are lopping budgets and issuing bonds, Columbia University just passed a budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 that is essentially flat and avoids the severe cuts faced by its peers.”…From The Chronicle of Higher Education: an article headlined, “More Than 500 Colleges Commit to Participate in New Veterans’ Program.” The gist? That the federal government will match any financial aid that participating colleges provide to veterans above the cost of the most expensive public college in their state.” (Note: this article, which would ordinarily be accessible only to Chronicle subscribers, is being made available free today to readers of The Choice.)

The General Motors bankruptcy will cause the carmaker’s many stakeholders a lot of pain, Breakingviews says. But, the publication argues, among lenders, it will be allocated more or less appropriately. Sure, some lenders won’t lose a penny, while others will take a drubbing. Updated | 4:59 p.m. Fresh from his visit to The New York Times, Jason Jones, a correspondent for “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” is filing dispatches from a slightly less hospitable setting: Iran. In a news release, Comedy Central said that Mr. Jones would deliver nightly reports from that nation beginning Monday, for a weeklong series called “Jason Jones in Iran: Access of Evil.” A spokesman for Comedy Central said the series would include some coverage of the recent Iranian presidential election. The reports, taped over 10 days in late May and early June, will also include visits to Tehran, Qom and the Imam Mosque in Esfahan, as well as interviews with Mohammad Ali Abtahi, a former vice president of Iran, and Ebrahim Yazdi, a former adviser to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Mr. Jones’s Comedy Central colleague Stephen Colbert recently returned from a trip to Iraq, and in 2007, Rob Riggle, a former “Daily Show” correspondent and reservist in the United States Marines, filed reports from that country.

Los Angeles may seem a world away from Iran and the fallout from the disputed election, but this weekend audiences at the Los Angeles Film Festival will get a first look at a movie particularly relevant to that region. Cyrus Nowrasteh’s fiction feature, “The Stoning of Soraya M.,” about a young woman stoned to death for supposed moral crimes in a remote Iranian village, is to have its debut on Saturday at the film festival. The timing, as Michael Cieply writes, could not be better. Read more on Media Decoder and watch the trailer below.

The play “Irena’s Vow” has become the latest production to announce its closing as Broadway polishes off its 2008-2009 season and prepares for a new year. It will close after its June 28 performance, its publicists said in a news release. The play, which starred Tovah Feldshuh as Irena Gut Opdyke, a real-life Polish Catholic housekeeper who offered protection to Jewish refugees during the Nazi occupation of Poland, was shut out at the Tony Awards. No one in its cast or creative team, including Ms. Feldshuh, a four-time Tony nominee, and its playwright, Dan Gordon, received nominations. Earlier this month, a performance of “Irena’s Vow” was seen by Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the recently installed archbishop of New York. The production will have played 21 previews and 105 regular performances at the Walter Kerr Theater.

The Museum of the Moving Image and the Museum of Arts and Design will hold their first joint film series this summer, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the French New Wave cinema movement. In a news release, the two museums announced that the film series, called “French New Wave Essentials,” would run at the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle in Manhattan from July 11 through Aug. 30. (The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, N.Y., is temporarily without a movie theater while it completes an expansion and renovation project.) The 16 films in the series, which will be shown on Saturdays and Sundays at 2 and 4 p.m., include some of the best known New Wave works, including “Breathless” by Jean-Luc Godard and “The 400 Blows” by François Truffaut, as well as films that anticipated the cinematic movement, including “And God Created Woman” by Roger Vadim and “Bob Le Flambeur” by Jean-Pierre Melville.

The Maltese tenor Joseph Calleja will sing the title role in the Metropolitan Opera’s coming production of Offenbach’s “Contes d’Hoffmann,” replacing Rolando Villazón, the Met said Tuesday in a news release. Mr. Villazón, the Spanish tenor, withdrew from the production following his announcement in April that he needed surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords, and would not resume performances until at least the end of the year. Mr. Calleja, who sang the Duke in “Rigoletto” and Nemorino in “L’Elisir d’Amore” for the Met, will be making his debut as Hoffman in this production. It is to be conducted by James Levine and directed by Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific,” “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone”). The Met also said that the roles of the four villains of “Hoffman” would be sung by Alan Held, who replaces René Pape. The Met said in its release that Mr. Pape “decided not to add the four villains” to his repertory.

Updated | 9:20 a.m. An author who is being sued for a coming novel that J.D. Salinger says is “a rip-off pure and simple” of “The Catcher in the Rye” will argue that his book is a legally protected literary commentary on Mr. Salinger’s original novel.

Whether you believe the animated series “South Park” is crude and obnoxious or a cleverly pointed satire (or possibly both), there is at least one court in Russia that says the show does not provoke religious hatred. The Moscow Times reported Tuesday that on June 2, Moscow’s Basmanny district court canceled a warning it had issued to the Russian television channel 2×2, which broadcasts “South Park,” after complaints by a religious group that said the show was insulting to religiously observant viewers. The group, the Union of Evangelical Christians, was specifically objecting to an episode titled “Mr. Hankey’s Christmas Classics,” a compilation of bawdy parodies of Christmas carols. In September, Russian prosecutors issued an official warning to 2×2, saying that a panel of experts had determined that the episode promoted “hatred between religions,” according to The Moscow Times. Prosecutors had also warned 2×2 in connection with the animated series “Family Guy” and “The Simpsons.” In response, the channel pulled several episodes of both shows but continued to broadcast each series.

The British architect Richard Rogers has accused the Prince of Wales of “an abuse of power” and “unconstitutional behavior,” after the prince complained about Mr. Rogers’s designs for a London housing development, The Guardian reported. Mr. Rogers, who won the Pritzker Prize in 2007, had been working on plans for 552 new homes to be built on the site of a former army barracks in London’s Chelsea district. The project was being managed by a division of Qatari Diar, the property investment arm of the Qatar emirate. But last week, Qatar withdrew its planning application for Mr. Rogers’s design after Prince Charles wrote to Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, the prime minister of Qatar. According to The Guardian, the prince wrote that Mr. Rogers’s designs were “unsuitable” for a site so close to the Royal Hospital designed by Christopher Wren. The Prince’s Foundation for the Built Environment, a charity that Prince Charles oversees as president, has been appointed to help produce a new design for the project.

By 22, the Cologne, Germany-based avant-garde artist Angelika Hoerle had already worked her way through a gamut of styles, from political caricatures to Dadaist paintings to still-life linocuts, had her portrait painted by contemporaries like Jankel Adler, Anton Räderscheidt and Marta Hegemann, and lived through the painful breakup of her marriage. A year later, in 1923, she was dead from tuberculosis. Hoerle's remaining oeuvre - much of it was destroyed by the Nazis who deemed it "degenerate" - is on display for the first time, nearly in its entirety, at the Art Gallery of Ontario where "Angelika Hoerle: the Comet of the Cologne Avant-Garde 1912-23" (through August 30th) recently opened.

Science Times has a fascinating article that questions the conventional wisdom that moderate consumption of alcoholic beverages is good for the health. Nobody in the article disputes the possibility that moderate drinking can be beneficial. Those interviewed simply make the compelling argument that too many variables exist in the research to conclude that moderate wine consumption is the reason for any healthful findings.

If timing were everything, the director Cyrus Nowrasteh's "The Stoning of Soraya M." would have it all. The picture, which tells the story of a young woman stoned to death for supposed moral crimes in a remote Iranian village, is set to screen on Saturday at the Los Angeles Film Festival, and will be released by Roadside Attractions and MPower Pictures on June 26. The debut comes even as the world frets about things Iranian in the wake of a disputed election.

Despite the recent talk about green shoots in Europe, the region's financial system is hardly out of the woods: According to a new report from the European Central Bank, major banks and financial institutions in the euro zone could experience nearly $300 billion in additional write-downs and loan losses in the next year and a half.

Since the launch of the Nintendo Wii, style types (fashion editors, Brooklyn hipsters, Lauren Conrad) have been drawn to Wii Sports tennis like Anna Wintour to Roger Federer. Ironically, the game missed the best parts of tennis: fashion, accessories, logo overkill. Two titles recently released for the Wii finally serve up the good stuff. "Grand Slam Tennis" from EA Sports features 23 pro characters, including 11 retired legends like John McEnroe, rendered in his prime with big hair, short shorts and a wooden racket, and Chris Evert, wearing a blue hair bow, bangs and retro kicks. "Virtua Tennis 2009" from Sega has contemporary pros, photorealistic graphics and the creepy ability to engineer cyborg-like players down to their eyebrows (choose from eight contemporary shapes). But what may be the best new feature for Wii-obsessed fashionistas comes from "Grand Slam Tennis": a calorie counter.

Tattoo magazines are usually about as interesting as last week's issue of TV Guide. Enter Sang Bleu, possibly the most highbrow publication ever devoted to tattooing and body modification. In its pages, there are profiles of ink-laden artists and stylists, photo shoots that highlight body art as much as clothes and an essay on "tattooed skin, film reel and the fetish," among others. We caught up with Maxime Büchi, the editor of the Swiss-based magazine.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: Obviously, ladies and gentlemen, big, big news is from Iran right now. Incredible, three days of riots, street fighting, people setting fire to everything. I'm not sure who won over there, Ahmadinejad or the Lakers.
Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: Welcome to the "Late Show." I'm Dave Letterman, goodwill ambassador. I got a call from Mom earlier today and she told me she was siding with the Governor.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Iran had its presidential election. President Ahma-Dinna-Jacket was way behind in the polls. And then, lo and behold, he won big, everywhere -- in big cities, rural areas, even in Florida.

The University of South Florida Polytechnic is to announce Tuesday that the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava and his firm, Santiago Calatrava/Festina Lente, will design the first building for the university’s new campus in Lakeland, Fla., the university said in a news release. Mr. Calatrava, who designed the glass-and-steel transportation hub planned for the former World Trade Center site, will design the university’s science and technology building. The university said this would be Mr. Calatrava’s first design in the Southeastern United States and his first educational structure in this country. Groundbreaking for the work, which will be done in partnership with Alfonso Architects of Tampa, Fla., is expected to take place later this year. The building is expected to cost $45 million, using a combination of private and public funds, and to be opened in 2012.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Well, the results from Iran's presidential elections are in. And Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has declared victory. But while the homegrown version is campy enough, it took those sophisticated Europeans to make a version so absurdly enjoyable that it belongs in the Kitsch Hall of Fame.

Facing mounting debt payments and lagging demand for office space, Maguire Properties has sold a 19-story office high-rise in Southern California to another real estate investment firm for $160 million -- a discount of roughly 35 percent, The Associated Press said.

FRONT PAGE.
An obituary on June 5 about the actor David Carradine omitted a survivor, his half-brother Christopher Carradine.

An obituary on Friday about Richard Quick, a head coach of Olympic and collegiate swimming teams, attributed a distinction to him erroneously. He won more N.C.A.A. team titles (13) than any other Division I swimming coach, not more titles than any other collegiate coach.

A picture caption on Friday with a film review of “The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3” misidentified the actor shown to the left of John Travolta. He is Gary Basaraba — not Jerry Pollard, the character he plays in the film. Because of an editing error, the review misstated the name of the agency that gave the filmmakers access to New York City subway trains, tunnels and command centers. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, not the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the possible value of The Boston Globe, referred incorrectly to the paper’s circulation. The Globe, owned by The New York Times Company, has a weekday circulation of 300,000 copies — not 300,000 readers.
Judge Sonia Sotomayor defended her membership in an all-female networking club, telling senators that the group did not discriminate in an inappropriate way.

The Wealth Matters column on May 30, about investors who find potential bargains in bonds, real estate and other assets, misstated the level of the major American equity indexes relative to when Barack Obama was inaugurated as president in January. The Dow Jones industrial average, Nasdaq and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index were all higher at close of trading on May 29 than they were on Jan. 16, the last day of trading before Mr. Obama’s inauguration — not lower.
As president, you’ve inherited a health care system that is the insane spawn of a team of evil geniuses from an alien power. How will you fix the mess?

An illustration on May 31 with an article about the many successful people who, like Sonia Sotomayor, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, grew up in New York’s public housing projects erroneously included a jazz musician, using information from the New York City Housing Authority. Thelonious Monk grew up in the Phipps Houses, a private housing complex — not the nearby public Amsterdam Houses.

An article on Wednesday about a two-year freeze on deportations of foreign widows and widowers of American citizens misstated United States law regarding eligibility for permanent residency for foreign spouses of American citizens. There is in fact no requirement that their marriage span two years before the foreign spouse is eligible. (The government has argued, however, that the foreign spouse loses eligibility should the American spouse die within two years of marriage and before immigration authorities have ruled on a petition for residency.).

And the article misidentified the parts of the plane that were likely to be of concern in case of electrical failure during flight. Those are the aileron, rudder and elevators — not the flaps. (The flaps are used in takeoffs and landings.).

Because of an editing error, an article on June 2 about the disappearance of an Air France jet en route from Rio de Janeiro to Paris misattributed a quotation about possible causes and rendered it incorrectly. The comment was by Julien Gourguechon, a long-time Air France pilot, not by Pierre-Henri Gourgeon, the chief executive officer of Air France-KLM, and it should have been rendered as two separate statements — “Lightning alone is not enough to explain the loss of this plane,” and “Turbulence alone isn’t enough” — rather than as one statement.
Jeff Van Gundy had a job as an analyst and he only partly did it. He analyzed plays well and showed his off-kilter sense of humor, but did not analyze Stan Van Gundy the coach at all.
As the White House assumes a more central role in dealing with Iran, the Obama administration plans to move its senior Iran policy maker to the National Security Council from the State Department.
The index compiler MSCI has announced it will upgrade the status of Israel to developed from emerging market, and that it is weighing doing the same for South Korea and Taiwan.
India’s national carrier will defer salary payments for its 31,000 employees by two weeks because of a cash squeeze born of tepid demand and overcapacity, the company says.
Bombardier is reducing its 10-year industry forecast for business jet deliveries by nearly 15 percent from last year because of the global recession.

China and Costa Rica have discussed the exchange of goods and services in a third round of talks for a free-trade treaty they hope to complete this year, officials said. Costa Rica is the third Latin American country, after Chile and Peru, to negotiate a free trade deal with China.
The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said it had completed a series of investments in Ma Anshan Modern Farming Company.
GlaxoSmithKline has taken another significant step in building its business in emerging markets by reaching a deal to form an alliance with the Indian generic drug maker Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories.

The Los Angeles police department has made progress on rooting out corruption, brutality and racially biased arrests, but it must do more, a court-appointed monitor testified.
Social media sites are challenging levers of state media control and allowing Iranians to find novel ways around restrictions.
The purpose of another codicil to Brooke Astor’s will was to give her son more control of a $60 million trust, according to the lawyer who prepared it.
The deal was a relief to many who had feared draconian cuts by the mayor to firehouses, library hours and child care.
A lawsuit seeking access to documents on teachers who were investigated during the Red Scare is raising questions about whether their names can be published, and whether there is still a stigma.
Since taking over as the United States Golf Association’s senior director of rules and competitions in 2006, Mike Davis has found a way to keep courses interesting for golfers and fans.
Congress would like to stop young people from smoking, but opponents say the marketing and advertising restrictions in the measure don’t abide by the First Amendment.
The new effort to intercept North Korean ships, and track them to their next port if they refuse inspection, is part of what officials described as “vigorous enforcement.”
Virginia eliminated second-seeded Cal State Fullerton from the College World Series on Monday, beating another ace by chasing Daniel Renken in a 7-5 victory.
Regimes like Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s Iran may prove far more vulnerable to economic dislocation than their democratic rivals.
Though few suggest that Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s hold on power is at risk, analysts say he has opened a fissure in the face of Islamic rule that may prove impossible to patch.
Victims of the $65 billion Ponzi scheme sent more than 100 letters and e-mail messages to the judge in the case, ahead of Bernard L. Madoff’s sentencing, set for June 29.

Mr. Simon, left, signed a pact with tribal leaders in the jungle city of San Ramón that included a promise to present a bill in Congress by Thursday to rescind the laws, the Andina state news agency reported. Tribal leaders said they would call off the protests if the laws were lifted.

Having scared the pants off audiences with his film adaptation of “The Silence of the Lambs” the director Jonathan Demme, below, has decided to turn his attention to something truly frightening: directing for the theater. Mr. Demme (“Rachel Getting Married,” “Philadelphia”) will make his stage directing debut with MCC Theater’s production of “Family Week” next year, the theater company said Monday. He is to direct a new version of the drama by Beth Henley, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of “Crimes of the Heart,” that will run at the Lucille Lortel Theater in the West Village from April 7 through May 23. The company said its 2009-10 season would also include a new play by Alexander Dinelaris called “Still Life,” to be directed by Will Frears, and a production of “The Pride” by Alexi Kaye Campbell and directed by Joe Mantello. ... Kerry Washington, a star of the films “Ray” and “The Last King of Scotland,” has joined the cast of “Race,” the forthcoming David Mamet play, its publicists said. The production, Mr. Mamet’s Broadway directing debut, also features the previously announced cast members James Spader and Richard Thomas. It is to begin previews at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Nov. 17 with an official opening scheduled for Dec. 6.

The 2009-10 season at Symphony Space will include appearances by the authors Judy Blume, Alice Sebold and Aleksander Hemon, as well as performances by Gavin Creel and Christine Ebersole. Symphony Space announced Monday its new season would begin with the New York debut of the Del Sol Quartet on Oct. 1, followed on Oct. 4 by a book club discussion with Ms. Blume. Ms. Sebold (“The Lovely Bones”) will discuss her selections for “The Best American Short Stories 2009” on Oct. 7, and Mr. Hemon will introduce works from the anthology “Best European Fiction 2010” on Jan. 27. Ms. Ebersole (“Grey Gardens,” “Blithe Spirit”) will perform with Billy Stritch on May 17; a date has not yet been set for a concert by Mr. Creel, a star of the Broadway revival of “Hair,” who is scheduled to perform with the musician Robbie Roth. (Symphony Space’s annual Bloomsday celebration, marking the date on which the events in James Joyce’s “Ulysses” occur, is scheduled for Tuesday.) A full event listing can be found online at symphonyspace.org.

More than two years after his comic book death, the sentinel of liberty known as Captain America is returning to the land of the living. “Captain America Reborn,” a five-part series published by Marvel Entertainment, will begin next month and is written by Ed Brubaker and illustrated by Bryan Hitch, one of the comic book industry’s most acclaimed artists. Mr. Brubaker is the regular writer of the Captain America series, including issue No. 25, published in 2007, in which the title hero was felled by an assassin’s bullet. It was a shot heard around the world as many news organizations carried word of the captain’s death. The story of his return begins in Captain America No. 600 (the series is returning to the original numbering from Volume 1, with a cover date of March 1941), which is in comic book stores now. New comics typically go on sale Wednesdays, but in an unusual move Marvel has allowed the comic to go on sale immediately.

(National Geographic) A DECADE BEHIND BARS: RETURN TO THE FARM In 1998 the filmmakers Jonathan Stack and Liz Garbus, working with the prisoner-turned-author Wilbert Rideau, took their cameras into the Louisiana State Penitentiary in Angola, where they captured a year in the life of six of the maximum-security prison's 5,100 inmates. This new documentary by Mr. Stack picks up a decade later with the four surviving men: George Crawford, who still tends the prison's fields; Ashanti Witherspoon, who was released on parole shortly after the original documentary and works as a motivational speaker; Bishop Eugene Tannehill, who was pardoned in 2007 after 50 years and now preaches and counsels troubled adults in Brooklyn; and Vincent Simmons, who continues to maintain his innocence while fighting for a new trial. Above, inmates at the prison's farm. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYSuze Orman answers financial questions. Other segments look at families affected by immigration, and affordable travel for Father's Day. Hank Williams Jr. performs.

GOLD--Bertram H. AJC is deeply saddened by the death of our longtime colleague and beloved friend Bert Gold. Most recently Executive Vice President Emeritus, Bert served with distinction as AJC's Executive Vice President from 1967 to 1982 and 1987 to 1988. He was also the Founding Director of our pioneering Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations. A man of great wisdom, vision, compassion, humility and dignity, his dedicated contributions to AJC, the Jewish people and American civic well-being will be his lasting legacy. We send our heartfelt condolences to his children, Judy and Larry Rubin, Dan and Ann Gold, Arna Shaw and Ron Chase, his five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Richard J. Sideman, Pres. David A. Harris, Exec. Dir. American Jewish Committee

de Give--David de Barsy, 66, died June 7 at the National Institutes of Health of complications related to a 2008 stem cell transplant for myelodysplastic syndrome. A native of NYC, David lived in Fauquier County VA for 23 years, where he served on various community boards and committees. He was a founding Director and Senior Vice President of Southern Financial Bank in Warrenton, retiring in 2004. Previously, David was co-founder of Newmarket Capital in Fairfax. He also took great pleasure in his pure-bred Angus cow-calf herd at his historic Delaplane farm, Belle Grove. In New York David worked for 16 years at Chemical Bank, the last five as head of funding in the Capital Markets Group. David was born in NYC on January 17, 1943 to Eleanor Hoguet de Give and Paul de Barsy de Give. A graduate of Portsmouth Priory School and Harvard College, he received his MBA from NYU. He served in the Coast Guard Reserve. David is survived by his wife of 33 years, Jose- phine Fisher de Give, known as Jolly; by four siblings: Ghislaine, Paul, Philip and Dominique; and by eight ne- phews and three nieces. A service of Thanksgiving for David's life will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Upperville on Saturday, June 20 at 11:00. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Piedmont Environmental Council, P.O. Box 460, Warrenton, VA 20188 or the NIH Foundation, 9650 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD 20814.

POTESKY-- P. Robert, of Saugerties, NY on June 11, 2009. Led Journal of Commerce Intl Business Group in cross-cultural programs 1954-1969, one of first Americans to forge meaningful trade relationships in post-war Japan, Europe and the Pacific. Helped open trade with Eastern Europe long before Berlin Wall collapse. Ran Journal Advertising 1969-1986, retiring after 35 years. Navy WWII, B.S. Seton Hall, M.A. Economics Columbia. Bob could entertain by simply reading news articles aloud. He was an avid sailor and loved Basset Hounds. Besides his wife Amanda Sherwin, he leaves four sons from previous marriages, Jon Potesky Webb, P. Robert Potesky, Jr., J.M. Potesky and Ronald Potesky and eleven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to UNICEF or Tri-State Basset Hound Rescue.

HORCHOW--Carolyn Pfeifer, a part-time resident of New York, passed away in her home in Dallas on June 15, 2009 after a long illness. Born in Little Rock, Arkansas on May 8, 1934, Carolyn is survived by her husband of 49 years, Roger Horchow; her daughters, Regen Fearon and her husband Jeffrey, Lizzie Routman and her husband Dan, and Sally Horchow McCauley and her husband Christopher; her granddaughters, Samantha Pillsbury, Regen Routman, Emily Routman, Fiona Fearon, and Sabrina Fearon; and her brother, Eugene M. Pfeifer, III, his wife Linda, and his children and grandchildren. Carolyn was a graduate of Connecticut College and a co-founder of The Horchow Collection. She served on the Board of Directors of UT Southwestern Zale Lipshy Hospital and on the Honorary Board of The Modern Museum of Fort Worth. She was a volunteer for Meals on Wheels and a member of several charitable organizations, including The Charter 100 of Dallas, Crystal Charity Ball, Dallas Women's Foundation, Planned Parenthood of North Texas, Sweetheart Ball, and The Visiting Nurse Association of Texas. Carolyn will always be remembered for her dignity, thoughtfulness, impeccable taste, and exceptional sense of style. A private family service has been held. In lieu of gifts, the family requests that Carolyn be remembered with a contribution to the charity of your choice.

SAUER Frank Xavier, passed away suddenly on June 12, 2009. He is survived by his devoted wife of 48 years, Donna, his loving children Kristen, Ingrid and Ivan, and his cherished grandchildren Mariah, Cole, Edie, Eliza and Lulu. He was a lifelong friend and brother-in-law to Roger and Peggy, and to Jan and Barbara, and a kind father-in-law to Robert, Amy and Harry. He is predeceased by his brother Joseph and his sisters Ann and Lorraine. He taught English at Rockland Community College for some 40 years, influencing generations of young minds. His life was exemplified by charm and wit, a love of both laughter and the world of ideas, and an immense affection for his family, who will miss him dearly. Wake will be on June 15 at 6-9pm at Carter Funeral Home, Croton-on-Hudson, and funeral will be on June 16 at 11am at St. Augustine's, Croton-on-Hudson. Donations may be made in his memory to Phelps Memorial Hospital, Cardiac Rehab and Wellness Center, in Sleepy Hollow.

AMEEN--Lane, Psychiatrist dies at 85. Dr. Ameen, a longtime Associate Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at Yale University, fellow of Jonathon Edwards College at Yale, practicing psychiatrist, and Medical Director and CEO of Elmcrest, a private psychiatric hospital, died peacefully at his home in New Haven, Connecticut surrounded by his loving family.

Beginning today, The Times is making its financial tables more concise, and is also eliminating the ''Today in Business'' digest and company names index. The moves reflect the increasing cost of newsprint and the growing use of online listings. Business Day will now include a single page of at-a-glance summary information on the markets and the economy, instead of a page and a half.

Father of Judy and Larry Rubin, Dan and Ann Gold, Arna Shaw and her husband Ron Chase. Proud grandfather of five and great-grandfather of six. Patriarch of a loving extended family. GROSSMAN--Mark Jay Esq. On June 12, 2009. Loving husband to Martha (Klein). Loving father to Paulina and Emily. Loving uncle, great uncle, brother-in-law and cousin. Predeceased by his parents Florence and Benjamin Grossman. A remarkable man who practiced law representing Social Security Disability clients. He was a published author and a respected naval and military historian. Mark was a fine, moral, pious and righteous man. He believed in helping others to be his purpose in life. To be his friend was an honor and a privilege and many were honored and privileged. His sense of humor and radiant smile will be missed by many. Donations in his memory may be made to Chai-Lifeline or to the Young Israel of East Brunswick, NJ.

FRAWLEY--John Joseph, passed away peacefully June 15, at the age of 88. Devoted husband of 60 years to Kathleen. Beloved and dedicated father of Kathleen, John (Mary), Patrick, George (Eileen), James (Vicki), Thomas (Mary), Mary (Andrew), Anne and, Joseph who died in infancy. Proud grandfather of Meaghan (Andrew), James, John, Joshua, Kevin, Matthew, Thomas, Caitlin, Benjamin, Sarah and Daniel. John served proudly in the United States Army during World War II in the North African and European Theatre of War. He was a proud member of the New York City Fire Department and Emerald Society for 35 years. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Tuesday and Wednesday 4-8pm. Mass of Christian burial Thursday 10:30am at Church of the Holy Family, 315 E. 47th St. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. Donations may be made in his memory to: New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation (www.NYFFBurnCenter.com).

ARONIN--Anne M. (Mrs. Stanley Aronin), passed away on June 13, 2009. Visiting hours at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, on Monday 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at 11am on Wednesday at St. Catharine's R.C. Church, 25 Second Ave, Pelham, NY.

WEISER--Selma, died June 12, 2009 at home. Fashion legend, founder of Charivari, Upper West Side pioneer. Brought many illustrious designers to the attention of the world, including Yohji Yamamoto, Dolce and Gabbana, Issey Miyake, Marc Jacobs and many others. Adored mother of Barbara and Jon, beloved by sister Lori Gordon, friend Sonia Nunes, cousins, nieces, nephews and countless friends worldwide. A true visionary, too deeply missed for words. Sweden's Ericsson 4 won the 2008-9 edition of the Volvo around-the-world yacht race, a nine-month competition. The VO70 yacht, skippered by the Brazilian Torben Grael, came in third in the next-to-last stage from the Swedish port of Marstrand to Sandham near Stockholm, and cannot be caught in the overall standings. The 525-mile leg was won by Puma Ocean Racing of the United States, which recorded its first stage victory in the event.

HAIMOVICI--Herman Dr.,of Newton Centre, MA on Saturday, June 13, 2009. For 50 years the devoted husband of Renee (Pitaru). Beloved father of the late Dr. Robert Haimovici and fond father-in-law of Jeanne Rosen. Loving grandfather of Claudia and Andrew. Dear brother of Tirica Stark of West Roxbury, MA and the late Poldi, Rachel and Marcel Haimovici. Services were held in Brookline, MA on Monday, June 15. Remembrances would be appreciated to Trustees of Boston University, The Robert Haimovici Fund, c/o Ms. Lynn Hendricks, Director of Development, BU School of Medicine, 715 Albany St., L219, Boston, MA 02ll8. Levine Chapels, Brookline 617-277-8300.

ROSENBERG--David and Jean. David Rosenberg, DDS, and his beloved wife Jean, both 52, died together in a tragic water accident in the Dominican Republic on June 11, 2009. David was a gifted and respected endodontist who generously shared his knowledge at seminars across the country and abroad. David and his family lived in Vero Beach, FL, where he established his practice 20 years ago following his training at New York University College of Dentistry. Jean was a volunteer with the Food Allergy Network and Habitat for Humanity. She was a graduate of New York University. David and Jean's lives together defined the meaning of love and family. They are survived by their sons, Stephen and Eddie; David's parents, Dr. Paul and Barbara Rosenberg, and Jean's mother Kathleen Lewis and her husband, Bill; David's brothers Robert and Gary; and Jean's brother and sisters Edward Schneider, Bettyann Travers, and Eileen Liles. The funeral will be held on Thursday, June 18 at 11 am at Strunk Funeral Home, 916 17th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960.

Peru lost to Colombia, 1-0, and is in last place, with only 7 points in 14 games, in South America's World Cup qualifying group. CLUB In Argentina, Huracán has made it a three-team race to the finish for the Clausura championship by beating rival San Lorenzo, 1-0, on Sunday. Vélez will have the tougher road to the final; it will play Lanús and Huracán in its final two matches.

Disguising a public-awareness campaign as a play is a tricky business, and ''Night Sky,'' a drama by Susan Yankowitz that focuses on the medical condition aphasia, doesn't quite get it right. Despite a strong lead performance by Jordan Baker, the play is never organic enough to let the audience forget that one of its producers is the National Aphasia Association. That's because Ms. Yankowitz takes a by-the-numbers approach to the story of Anna (Ms. Baker), who has an accident that leaves her with aphasia, which impairs the ability to speak and process language. (It is often a result of a stroke.)

Most people training for a race or sport focus on adding more miles, workouts or weight training to improve their fitness. But new research suggests that simply getting more sleep can improve athletic performance.

The genesis of much of the ab work we do these days probably lies in the work done in an Australian physiotherapy lab during the mid-1990s. Researchers there, hoping to elucidate the underlying cause of back pain, attached electrodes to people’s midsections and directed them to rapidly raise and lower their arms, like the alarmist robot in “Lost in Space.”
For the new owners of Saab Automobile to make money selling small numbers of cars across the globe, they have to return to the Swedish automaker’s roots, industry analysts say.

The Black Eyed Peas’ ubiquitous single “Boom Boom Pow” has been on the top of Billboard’s Hot 100 chart for the last 10 weeks, and now the group has notched another No. 1. Its new album, “The E.N.D.” (Interscope) — it stands for “the energy never dies” — has become the Black Eyed Peas’ first to reach No. 1, with first-week sales of 304,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Last week’s best-seller, the Dave Matthews Band’s “Big Whiskey and the GrooGrux King” (RCA), is No. 2 with 128,000 sales, a 70 percent drop, and Eminem’s “Relapse” (Interscope) is No. 3 with 87,000. Chickenfoot, a band featuring current and former members of Van Halen and the Red Hot Chili Peppers, holds at No. 4 with 79,000 sales of its self-titled album on the Redline label, and Aventura, a group from the Bronx that proudly advertises itself as “kings of bachata,” opens at No. 5 with 47,000 sales of “The Last” (Sony). Down the chart, Mos Def’s latest, “Ecstatic” (Downtown), opens at No. 9 with 39,000, only a few hundred more than Pleasure P’s “Introduction of Marcus Cooper” (Atlantic), which bows at No. 10.

The fictional Weston clan of Tracy Letts’s Broadway play, “August: Osage County,” may have survived three incarnations of its vicious matriarch, Violet, but the play itself could not survive long into the new theater season. It is scheduled to close after the June 28 performance, its press representatives said, having played 648 performances and 18 previews.

A federal district judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that Holden Caulfield, the querulous, precocious protagonist of J. D. Salinger’s most famous work, “Catcher in the Rye,” will exist at least a little longer in a state of permanent adolescence, unburdened by the cares and recriminations of age.
What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

As dedicated readers of The New York Times already know, the newspaper and its Culture report are traditionally produced each day from a 52-story building between 40th and 41st Streets in Manhattan, designed by the Italian architect Renzo Piano. On Wednesday, the Culture department is trying something slightly different: We’re working from an office in New Hyde Park on Long Island, designed by the architect I.M. Functional, and located just next door to the ambulatory surgery ward of a major North Shore hospital.

Here’s hoping that the Nederlander Theater brings better luck to the coming revivals of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound” than it did to “Guys and Dolls“: That West 41st Street theater, recently vacated by the “Guys and Dolls” revival that closed on Sunday, will be home to the two Neil Simon comedies, which will be performed there in repertory in the fall. As part of a double bill called “The Neil Simon Plays,” “Brighton Beach Memoirs” will begin previews on Oct. 2 and open on Oct. 25; “Broadway Bound” will begin previews on Nov. 18 and open on Dec. 10. The casts for both plays include Noah Robbins as Eugene Jerome, Mr. Simon’s alter ego, in “Brighton Beach Memoirs,” and Josh Grisetti as that character in “Broadway Bound,” as well as Laurie Metcalf as Kate Jerome. Both plays are to be directed by David Cromer (who returns to the Barrow Street Theater’s production of “Our Town” on Friday).

Rain, the South Korean pop star and actor, has settled a suit brought by a Hawaiian concert promotion company that won an $8 million judgment against him and his managers, Agence France-Presse reported. In March, a court found in favor of the Hawaiian promoter Click Entertainment, which had sued Rain and his representatives at JYP Entertainment after the singer (whose real name is Jung Ji-hoon) canceled a concert scheduled for June 15, 2007, at Honolulu’s Aloha Stadium, a few days before the show. Lawyers for the promoter argued that Rain never intended to perform, and that his crew never shipped their equipment or applied for visas. Citing a report from Korea’s Yonhap news agency, Agence France-Presse said that the two sides reached an agreement on June 10 to settle the case and avoid an appeal. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

The North Shore Music Theater of Beverly, Mass., announced Tuesday that it was unable to raise enough money to finance its summer season and will close down permanently, The Boston Globe reported. The theater, which opened in 1955, was once the region’s largest nonprofit theater, drawing as many as 350,000 people a year. But in 2005, it sustained $3 million in damages from a fire caused by a defective fog machine that destroyed its auditorium. In 2008, a year-end production of “High School Musical 2″ sold poorly, and the theater laid off 57 employees as it sought $4 million in additional funds. David Fellows, the chairman of the theater’s board of trustees, told The Globe that the theater has about $10 million of debt.

Last night, on the incredibly confrontational finale of Bravo's short, bitter season of "Real Housewives of New Jersey," Dina took a tour of Teresa's newly completed parody of a house. Dripping with faux Roman touches and onyx, it's the anti-Falling Water. Then it was time for a dinner party with the full cast at an appropriately rococo restaurant called Lu Nello (yes, two words). Over the course of the six-episode series, rage coiled deep in the breasts - often augmented - of the five ladies of Franklin Lakes, and it was clear to all that this would be the moment of reckoning. Everyone interested in economics should know about Fred, which has made my life a lot easier.

After last year's moving Wimbledon final, the tennis firmament realigned, with Rafael Nadal emerging as the world's top-ranked men's tennis player. It took a few weeks for the A.T.P. computer to catch up and acknowledge the obvious, that Nadal was the new king. Astronomers were quicker to get with the program as they renamed the asteroid previously known as 128036 the Rafael Nadal Asteroid. It is between Mars and Jupiter, is about two and a half miles in diameter, and clocks in at a speed of 12 miles a second, or 360 times faster than the average Nadal serve.

Criminal charges were dropped in Family Court yesterday against three Millburn High School students charged with assault in connection with the Jan. 9 fight at Millburn High School involving Rev. Darryl L. George and his two sons, according to a law enforcement official. Brenda Barnes-George, Reverend George's wife, had brought a citizen's complaint against the juveniles, which prompted the criminal charges. Assault charges against others cited by Ms. Barnes-George -- three adults, Roger McGlynn and Adam Brender, both 18, and Jerome Miller, the parent of a student at the school -- are still under consideration at the prosecutor's office. Reverend George, his sons, and Alex Smith, the student who was injured in the fight, which witnesses say involved a bat, have all been cleared of criminal charges. Andrea McCoy Johnson, the deputy chief assistant prosecutor, declined to comment on the case. -- TINA KELLEY

On Monday, banks began taking applications for the Small Business Administration's new no-interest, deferred-payment bridge loans, just a week after the agency issued guidelines for the program. Though the early anecdotal evidence suggested that banks were leery of the initiative, it now appears that institutions, at least those that already work with the S.B.A., stand ready to make the loans, if somewhat reluctantly. However, demand for the loans is certain to outstrip supply, partly for reasons that call into question the way the program is going to be operated.

So I've been reading stories about a "surge" in housing starts. And it's true that starts were up 17 percent over the previous month. But here's the thing: new-home construction has come to a virtual standstill, so even large percentage changes mean only a handful of extra homes started. If we're building 6 homes a month nationwide, and that goes to 7, it's a 17 percent rise -- but makes almost no difference in real life.

Ever since music was first introduced in film (live music accompanied the first public screening of a silent film in December 1895, according to Kathryn Kalinak's "Settling the Score: Music and the Classical Hollywood Film"), directors and editors have found it indispensable for stirring emotions, lightening a moment and, of course, hawking soundtracks (think: Cameron Crowe). In response to yesterday's post, many readers championed ticket reselling (the pretty term for scalping) as a laudable manifestation of the free market. Here's the problem: Markets function best when supply can adjust to demand. But despite astonishing advances in biotechnology, science remains unable to increase the supply of Miley Cyruses. (Whether that is good or bad, I leave to music critics.) Miley is just one woman and can do only a limited number of shows (without collapsing). Given her popularity, her shows will necessarily be in short supply. The question of how to allocate that supply is thus inescapable.

The Maltese tenor Joseph Calleja will sing the title role in the Metropolitan Opera’s coming production of Offenbach’s “Contes d’Hoffmann,” replacing Rolando Villazón, the Met said on Tuesday. Mr. Villazón, the Spanish tenor, withdrew from the production after his announcement in April that he needed surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords and would not resume performances until at least the end of the year. Mr. Calleja, who sang the Duke in “Rigoletto” and Nemorino in “L’Elisir d’Amore” for the Met, will be making his debut as Hoffmann in this production, set to run from Dec. 3 to Jan. 2. It is to be conducted by James Levine and directed by Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific,” “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone”). The Met also said that the roles of the four villains of “Hoffmann” would be sung by Alan Held, who replaces René Pape. The Met said that Mr. Pape had “decided not to add the four villains” to his repertory.

The play “Irena’s Vow” has become the latest production to announce its closing as Broadway polishes off its 2008-9 season and prepares for a new year. It will close after its June 28 performance, its publicists said in a release. The play, which stars Tovah Feldshuh as Irena Gut Opdyke, a real-life Roman Catholic Polish housekeeper who offered protection to Jewish refugees during the Nazi occupation of Poland, was shut out at the Tony Awards. No one in its cast or creative team, including Ms. Feldshuh, a four-time Tony nominee, and its playwright, Dan Gordon, received nominations. The production will have played 21 previews and 105 regular performances at the Walter Kerr Theater.

The British architect Richard Rogers, right, has accused the Prince of Wales, far right, of “an abuse of power” and “unconstitutional behavior” after the prince complained about Mr. Rogers’s designs for a London housing development, The Guardian reported. Mr. Rogers, who won the Pritzker Prize in 2007, had been working on plans for 552 homes to be built on the site of a former army barracks in the Chelsea district of London. The project was being managed by a division of Qatari Diar, the property investment arm of the Qatar emirate. But last week Qatar withdrew its planning application for Mr. Rogers’s design after Prince Charles wrote to Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim al-Thani, the prime minister of Qatar. According to The Guardian, the prince wrote that Mr. Rogers’s designs were “unsuitable” for a site so close to the Royal Hospital, designed by Christopher Wren. The Prince’s Foundation for the Built Environment, a charity that Prince Charles oversees as president, has been appointed to help produce a new design for the project.

The Louis Armstrong House Museum is deeply saddened by the death of David Gold, President Emeritus of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation and longtime business associate of Louis Armstrong. For decades, David's vision and leadership has kept Louis Armstrong's legacy alive for millions of people. We will miss him dearly. Our condolences and prayers go out to David's family.

8 P.M. (Cartoon Network) THE OTHERSIDERS Move over, all you grown-up ghostbusters. In the first of two new live-action series geared toward teenagers, five friends (above, from left, Riley, Jackie, KD, Sam and Zack) investigate places rumored to be crawling with paranormal activity, starting with the Lincoln Heights jail in Los Angeles, where since the 1930s people have reported cell doors that open and close on their own, unusual cold spots, clanking chains and moans for help. In ''Survive This,'' at 8:30, eight young players are dropped in the middle of the wilderness, where Les Stroud, formerly of the Discovery Channel's ''Survivorman,'' teaches them how to scavenge for food and water, build a shelter, navigate dangerous terrain and, with luck, make their way out unscathed. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Segments look at education and the bilingual divide; summer reading; and skin cancer awareness. Martha Stewart is a guest.

GOLD--David, 85. It is with profound sorrow that the members of the Board of Directors of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation mark the untimely passing of our Founder, friend, Treasurer and longtime President. Through the genius of his business acumen, the Foundation continues to contribute Louis' legacy of "the service of happiness," funding music education of all kinds. We will continue to strive to meet David's very high standards in Louis' memory.
COXE--Dorothy B.,of East Chatham, NY died June 13, 2009. Born in the Bronx in 1935, she is survived by her husband Charles Woodard and brother Arthur Pearlman.

ROSENBERG--David and Jean. David Rosenberg, DDS, and his beloved wife Jean, both 52, died together in a tragic water accident in the Dominican Republic on June 11, 2009. David was a gifted and respected endodontist who generously shared his knowledge at seminars across the country and abroad. David and his family lived in Vero Beach, FL, where he established his practice 20 years ago following his training at New York University College of Dentistry. Jean was a volunteer with the Food Allergy Network and Habitat for Humanity. She was a graduate of New York University. David and Jean's lives together defined the meaning of love and family. They are survived by their sons, Stephen and Eddie; David's parents, Dr. Paul and Barbara Rosenberg, and Jean's mother Kathleen Lewis and her husband, Bill; David's brothers Robert and Gary; and Jean's brother and sisters Edward Schneider, Bettyann Travers, and Eileen Liles. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 18 at 12 noon at St. Edwards School, 1895 St. Edwards Dr, Vero Beach, FL 32963.

General Motors announced Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its Swedish unit,Saab Automobile, to a consortium led by the sports car maker Koenigsegg Automotive. They did not release further financial details of the deal, which is expected to close in the third quarter.

LEVINSON--Mark A, CPA, PFS The partners and staff of Anchin, Block & Anchin LLP mourn the untimely loss of our beloved partner, confidante, mentor, and friend, Mark Levinson, who joined the Anchin professional family in 2005. Mark had more than 25 years of experience as a certified public accountant with local and regional firms prior to joining Anchin as a tax partner. Mark was a kind, passionate, confident individual who prided himself on his disciplined professionalism and scholarly approach to his work. He possessed an unwavering dedication to his clients, truly becoming their indispensable trusted advisor. Outside of work, he was a devoted New York Giants fan and an avid basketball player. Most important of all, however, was his absolute devotion to his wife, Teri, and his children, Gillian and William. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, his children, and his two brothers.

WASHINGTON--Edith Joan, died peacefully at home on June 14, at age 88. Beloved aunt of Arthur and Pam Washington, great-aunt of Caroline and James, and loving sister of Artie who predeceased her. Edie was born in The Bronx, was a graduate of Hunter College and a finance officer for Chase Bank prior to her retirement. She loved the vitality and history of New York City, and she owned and had read the George Templeton Strong diaries. She also was a fan and advocate of the ballet and theater; literature and women's rights; travel, swimming and the Yankees. We will miss her elan. Visiting at Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, 718-721-9200, Thursday June 18, 5-8pm. Donations may be made in her honor to the Municipal Art Society of New York or Bridges to Community.

de Give--David de Barsy, 66, died June 7 at the National Institutes of Health of complications related to a 2008 stem cell transplant for myelodysplastic syndrome. A native of NYC, David lived in Fauquier County VA for 23 years, where he served on various community boards and committees. He was a founding Director and Senior Vice President of Southern Financial Bank in Warrenton, retiring in 2004. Previously, David was co-founder of Newmarket Capital in Fairfax. He also took great pleasure in his pure-bred Angus cow-calf herd at his historic Delaplane farm, Belle Grove. In New York David worked for 16 years at Chemical Bank, the last five as head of funding in the Capital Markets Group. David was born in NYC on January 17, 1943 to Eleanor Hoguet de Give and Paul de Barsy de Give. A graduate of Portsmouth Priory School and Harvard College, he received his MBA from NYU. He served in the Coast Guard Reserve. David is survived by his wife of 33 years, Jose- phine Fisher de Give, known as Jolly; by four siblings: Ghislaine, Paul, Philip and Dominique; and by eight ne- phews and three nieces. A service of Thanksgiving for David's life will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Upperville on Saturday, June 20 at 11:00. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Piedmont Environmental Council, P.O. Box 460, Warrenton, VA 20188 or the NIH Foundation, 9650 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD 20814.

BIANCO--Antonio. Antonio Bianco, known as "Nino", passed away on June 15th 2009, at the age of 57 after a long battle with cancer. Born in Johannesburg, South Africa, Nino originally came from the city of Foggia, in the Province of Puglia in Italy. He came to the United States in 1976 and established himself as one of the greatest master cutters in the diamond industry. Many of the most historic and important diamonds in the world passed through his hands. Nino was the true master cutter for Safdico and Graff diamonds. Nino met his wife Caterina Cilluffo in New York and soon they were married. He is survived by his wife Caterina and his four children Loredana and her husband Allan Russo, his son Dario, daughter Nadia, and son Sandro, and his three siblings in South Africa, Luigi, Giovanni and Maria. The Wake is on Wednesday, June 17th, 2009 from 2:00 4:00pm and 7:00 9:00pm at: Branchburg Funeral Home, 910 Highway 202, South Branchburg, NJ 08876. Phone Number: 908-526-7638. The Mass is on Thursday, June 18th, 2009 at 10:00am at: Blessed Sacrament Church, 1890 Washington Valley Road, Martinsville, New Jersey 08836. Phone Number: 732-356-4442. Followed by the Burial at: Saint Bernard's Cemetery, 551 Route 28, Bridgewater, New Jersey 08807. Phone Number: 908-725-8305. In Lieu of flowers, friends may make donations by check to: The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th floor, New York, New York 10017 U.S.A. Attention: Elise Cooke. Note: "In Memory of Antonio Bianco" for Pancreatic Cancer Research. Please attach a note if you wish to notify the family of your contribution.

The United States Golf Association sets up its Open courses to be ''the toughest test of golf.'' They use narrow fairways, thick rough and soft bunkers in an effort to force players to be at the top of their game to win the tournament. But perhaps the most diabolical weapon in its arsenal is green speed -- how fast the ball rolls on the green. Nowhere will that be more evident at Bethpage than on No.15, which has more slope than the other greens on the course. It could make for an adventurous week for the players.

First, you called your friends together and ordered a six-foot party hoagie so you could gather to watch the Emmy Awards, which CBS was to broadcast on Sept. 6. Then you dutifully rescheduled your event when the awards ceremony was pushed back to Sept. 13, to avoid a possible overlap with a doubleheader of National Football League games. But don’t mail those invitations out just yet: the Emmys have been rescheduled a second time, and are now planned for Sept. 20. In a news release, CBS said that MTV had already chosen the Sept. 13 date for its Video Music Awards. In a statement, Jack Sussman, a CBS Entertainment executive said, “We had the flexibility to move; they didn’t.” Emmy nominations will be announced on July 16.

Updated | 2:52 p.m. It is no easy feat to follow in the footsteps of Bartlett Sher, but the Intiman Theater in Seattle has found a successor for him there: Kate Whoriskey will become the theater’s artistic director in 2011, after a 2010 season in which she and Mr. Sher will work together on programming, the theater announced Thursday.

Updated | 4:33 p.m. As crews were cleaning up after the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, held over the weekend in Manchester, Tenn., they found the body of a man believed to be in his 20s at the site of the festival, a 700-acre farm about 60 miles southeast of Nashville, The Tennessean reported. The police in Coffee County told The Tennessean that the body was found in a tent on Tuesday, and that the man, whose name was not given, was last seen alive at about 3 p.m. on Monday. The police said he was believed to be from Alabama and they were awaiting the results of an autopsy. The Bonnaroo festival attracted about 75,000 people between Thursday and Sunday.The Chattanooga Times Free Press reported that the man has been identified as 26-year-old Matthew Lands of Fort Payne, Ala.

Updated | 4:17 p.m. In a legal memorandum, a judge who was to hear a case on the ownership of two Picasso paintings in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum has chided the museums for their confidential settlement of the case, Bloomberg News reported. In February, the museums announced that they had reached a settlement with Julius H. Schoeps and his relatives, who said that they were the heirs to the owners of the paintings, “Boy Leading a Horse” and “Le Moulin de la Galette,” and that they were sold under duress in Nazi Germany. At the time, the museums said they would continue to own the works but did not disclose the terms of the settlement.

Updated | 8:06 a.m. Once Liza Minnelli has been given an award, can anyone else truly win it? In the case of the Tony Award for special theatrical event, the answer is an unequivocal no. The Tonys will no longer bestow an award in that category starting with the 2009-2010 season, its press representatives said in a news release. The decision was approved this week by the Tonys’ administration and management committees.

The battle for CBGB is over. Two years ago, shortly after the death of Hilly Kristal, the club’s founder, his former wife, Karen Kristal, filed suit against his estate. She said that she was the rightful owner of the business but had been tricked into signing it over to Mr. Kristal, who then sold the company for $3.5 million and left most of his estate to their daughter, Lisa Kristal Burgman. (The club made little profit, but the CBGB trademark brought in millions from T-shirts and other memorabilia.) A settlement in the suit, which had been filed in Surrogate’s Court in Manhattan, was reached on June 3, lawyers for both sides of the case said on Thursday, but the terms of the settlement were not disclosed. CBGB opened in 1973 and closed in 2006 after a long dispute with its landlord over unpaid rent.

Welcome back to the forum, where the focus is on international sports and where I am parsing this year's Wimbledon with our transatlantic panel. There is, of course, much more to any Grand Slam tournament than Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer, and Nadal isn't even sure he's playing in this one yet. Consider Federer's head-to-head record of 2-6 against Andy Murray, who won at Queen's Club for the first time last week. Yes, Murray won without playing anyone in the top 10, but he still didn't drop a set, and the buildup in Britain has been far from understated. How do you more levelheaded observers like the Scotsman's chances at the Big W?

Purveyors of digital photography step aside, the Lomographic Society International, an organization championing the use of analog film, is celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Lomo LC-A camera with a birthday bash on Friday at The Lomography Gallery Store in New York. Popular in the Soviet Union during the eighties, this compact, fixed-lens point and shoot all but disappeared until its rediscovery by a group of Viennese students in 1991. Since then the camera has been embraced by amateur and professional photographers alike for its quirkiness. To help celebrate, the society published a massive tome featuring thousands of photographs taken with the LC-A.

- A report in the Times of London about Thomas Parkin of Brooklyn, who was arrested Monday for allegedly impersonating his deceased mother to claim more than $117,000 in benefits. He was caught on videotape at the Brooklyn Department of Motor Vehicles while trying to renew his mother's driver's license. Authorities said Parkin's fraud started in 2003, after his mother's death. Maybe he should have invested some of the loot in a lip wax.

Millburn police detective Ed de la Fuente has some advice for parents on Millburn High School's prom night: Speak with your kids directly about drinking and drugs, and know where they are and whom they are with. He said the Millburn Police Department isn't changing any of its behaviors for the night - no checkpoints will be set up. "Especially because the prom is not in our town," he said -- the event is at the Birchwood Manor in Whippany. "Usually traffic is very light late at night anyway, so anybody driving erratically will stick out." He wanted to emphasize that parents be involved in the night and that, contrary to some parents' notions, it is illegal to host parties where underage drinking is happening, no matter what precautions they take. And everyone needs to drive safely tonight, as flash flood warnings are in effect.

The question for moviemakers and television networks is: How loudly will his G.L.A.A.D. complain when it spots problematic treatment?

Is Dave Eggers the busiest man in literature? It's not enough that he oversees the McSweeney's empire and the 826 Valencia literacy project; he also has one movie in theaters ("Away We Go," written with his wife, Vendela Vida), a second on the way ("Where the Wild Things Are," adapted from the Maurice Sendak story and written with the director Spike Jonze), a nonfiction book coming out this summer about a Hurricane Katrina survivor ("Zeitoun") and a 300-page novel coming out this fall ("The Wild Things") that's loosely based on the Sendak but isn't strictly related to the movie. (The "fur edition," pictured here, is available for pre-order at the McSweeney's Web site.) Whew.

Regardless of your profession, the struggle to balance work and personal time is a challenge. In today's Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen explores the often unbalanced life of doctors in training, who cope with long hours, intense medical training and the life or death needs of their patients.

Look in your refrigerator. Got syrup? Not maple, not faux-maple, not Fox's U-Bet, but unflavored sugar syrup, or simple syrup as bartenders and pastry chefs call it. It's pre-dissolved sugar, which means it can sweeten iced tea, iced coffee, lemonade (and other ades) and fancy mixed drinks without the heartbreaking frustration of what can seem like hours of stirring granulated sugar into a glass of chilled liquid - and winding up with undissolved sludge at the bottom anyway (not that lemonade sludge doesn't have charms of its own).

The amendment that Brooke Astor executed to her will in January 2004 did not financially benefit her son as much as prosecutors contend, the lawyer who drafted the change said Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

JPMorgan Chase said Thursday that it had hired a senior Merrill Lynch deal maker as its new vice chairman of mergers and acquisitions, the latest in a reshuffling of the investment banking ranks since the onset of the financial crisis.

Mary Marzano invited me into her Maplewood home to talk about her charitable organization, Green Recoverings, which provides "a good night's sleep for those in need" through collecting and donating gently used linens from hotels. Ms. Marzano's initiative has been immensely successful, showing no indication of slowing down, and I was wondering, with a full-time job as a senior account executive at Vision Creative Group, Inc., an advertising firm,and a baby on the way, how does she do it all? Her comments were slightly condensed.

What constitutes good design? It's a question that has fascinated and vexed us for decades, as demonstrated by two exhibitions currently on view in New York. "What Was Good Design? MoMA's Message 1944-56," which runs until November 30th, examines the museum's role in the mid-20th century defining and promoting its vision of the design of everyday objects like furniture, tools and fishing rods. In exhibitions and competitions, MoMA preached the message that good design was beautiful, useful, well-made and (mostly) affordable. And, of course, modern.

In the Dining section on Wednesday I reviewed the new restaurant Rye, but my visits to it weren't my only recent excursions to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a neighborhood whose easygoing, mischievous ways charm me. I like dining there, though my impulse to do so isn't always rewarded by the quality of what I wind up eating. Williamsburg sometimes works better as a mood than as a meal.

The National Venture Capital Association is seeking to persuade Congress to allow companies financed by venture capital to compete for Small Business Innovation Research (S.B.I.R.) grants. Under the program, federal agencies set aside 2.5 percent of their R.&D. budgets to small, independently financed businesses. Currently, companies backed by venture capitalists cannot get S.B.I.R. grants.

Yumei Wang, who leads Oregon's effort to cut risks from inevitable earthquakes, pointed me to news from Japan that more than 7,300 school buildings in that country face "a high risk of collapse" in a strong earthquake. That might seem a small number as a proportion of the country's nearly 125,000 school buildings, but that's just the schools that are in the worst shape. Japan's education ministry found, all told, that 41,206 school buildings are insufficiently reinforced.

With that transfer and others like it across the country, 10 banks returned their slice of the financial bailout, freeing themselves from the stigma of a government lifeline and the increased oversight that went with it.

Twitter's Internet-messaging service is proving to be more than a tool for gossipy adolescents, Breakingviews says. Media around the world are using so-called tweets - messages sent through the service - from Tehran to supplement their coverage of the post-election upheaval, the publication notes.

If you're heading to Portland, Maine, this summer, it's worth paying a visit to Eli Cayer and the boys at Maine Mead Works (and afterward, check out these other Portland highlights). In a garage in the city's east end, Cayer and his bearded, flanneled colleagues brew their special brand of mead - an alcoholic drink made by fermenting honey and water - using local yeast, berries and other ingredients. You can sample the semi-sweet and dry brews, which taste a bit like a sweet Riesling with a very smooth finish, and if you get there while Maine's famous wild blueberries are still in season, you can try the immensely popular HoneyMaker Blueberry Mead.
A life cast by the sculptor John Ahearn of a Bronx teenager, Justin McWillis, captured his appearance months before he was fatally shot. Now his family has a replica.

An article on Monday about the search for summer jobs along the Jersey Shore misidentified the location of Jenkinson’s Pier, an entertainment complex on the boardwalk. It is in Point Pleasant Beach — not Point Pleasant, as the dateline indicated. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the location of the boardwalk where Laura Rozamus, a former Blue Cross employee, said she had been seeking work after arriving from Albany. It is in Atlantic City; there is no boardwalk in Absecon.

An article on Wednesday about contenders to win the United States Open golf tournament this weekend omitted the name of a player who won the event four times and referred incorrectly to Tiger Woods’s place in history should he win his fourth Open. In addition to Jack Nicklaus, Bob Jones and Willie Anderson, Ben Hogan also won the tournament four times. With a victory, Woods would become the second golfer, not the first, to win four in the same decade — a distinction that belongs to Anderson, who won in 1901, 1903, 1904 and 1905. And Woods would become the seventh golfer — not the third — to defend his title successfully.

An article on Tuesday about a lawsuit that is seeking access to New York City Board of Educationfiles on teachers investigated during the anti-Communist purges of the 1950s misstated, in some editions, the outcome of a legal challenge to the state’s Feinberg Law, which made it illegal for teachers to advocate the overthrow of the government by force.
